b5186a79a84cf4acb2411a374942d770afcb8e39: Nuclear Energy in France Nuclear energy is the of french energy In the France chose to develop nuclear as its base load electricity source as a to the oil crisis and assure its energy independence. Nuclear Electricity Production: France currently counts 58 commercial nuclear reactors operation responsible for producing 80% French domestic electricity. As a comparison, the 104 reactors produces 20% of electricity.Despite scarce natural resources, France has reached an energy independence of 50% thanks its strategic choice nuclear energy. As well as providing safe and reliable energy, nuclear helps to reduce French greenhouse gas emissions by avoiding the of 31 billions tones of carbon dioxide (contrary to coal or gas generation) and making France the less carbon emitting country within the OECD. As a leader in nuclear France has clean technology waste disposal. Reprocessing currently allows France to recover valuable elements from fuels permit a significant reduction of level waste and lead to safer and optimized containment, for radioactive disposition. French nuclear power plants produces only 10 g/year/inhabitant of highly radioactive waste. International Cooperation research: is one of the forerunner in nuclear research and participates in numerous international cooperation programs alongside the United States such as the development of the next generation of nuclear power plants (Gen IV) the International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor (ITER) that will be built in Cadarache, South of France. The French Atomic Energy (CEA) The French Atomic Energy Commission is a public body established in October 1945 by General de It constitutes a power of expertise and proposition for the authorities. A leader in development and innovation, the is involved in three main fields: It develops and acquires the technological building blocks necessary to the development of the nuclear reactors of the future (Contribution to Generation IV and GNEP It contributes to reducing greenhouse gas emission with its research on hydrogen, fuel cells, biomass, energy storage…, It supports the nuclear utilities in by the nuclear plants of the French nuclear fleet and by optimizing the fuel cycle, It offers safe economically viable technical for managing nuclear waste, It conducts fundamental research in climate and environmental sciences, high energy astrophysics, fusion, nanosciences… Information and Health technologies: It tackles micro and nano-technologies telecommunication and nuclear medicine for radiotherapy and medical It programs biotechnology, molecular labelling, biomolecular engineering and structural biology, It shares its knowledge and know-how education and training through the National Institute for Nuclear Sciences and Technologies (INSTN), It manages 300 priority patents and is active in the creation of clusters. and National Security: It conceives, builds, maintains then dismantles the warhead the French deterrence force, It to fight against nuclear, biological and chemical weapons (NRBC program). The missions of the CEA are similar to the Department of Energy in the States. The CEA has a network of counselor or representatives in French Embassies around the world (see joint The French Nuclear Safety (ASN) Created in 2006, from former DSIN (Directorate for the Safety of Nuclear Facilities), the French Nuclear Safety Authority is an administrative authority which is tasked with regulating nuclear safety and protection in order to protect workers, patients, the public and the environment from the risks activities. It also contributes to informing the public. Like the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in the United States, it carries out inspections and may pronounce sanctions, up to and including of operation of an installation. French Institute for Nuclear Safety (IRSN) Created in 2001 by merging the Protection Safety (IPSN) and the Ionizing radiations Protection Office (OPRI), Institute for Radioprotection and Nuclear Safety is a public establishment of an industrial and commercial nature placed under the joint authority of the Ministries of the Environment, Health, Industry, Research and Defense. 2bf3779c08b865f5270a9e0cd73b56be62ad830b: Mexican America Introduction "Mexican America" is a sampling of objects from the collections of the National Museum of American History. The stories behind these objects reflect the history of the Mexican presence in United They a fundamentally American story about the centuries-old between distinct (yet sometimes overlapping) communities that have coexisted but also clashed over culture, and livelihood. Who, where, and what is Mexico? Over the and boundaries Mexico have changed. Aztec and the area where Náhautl was spoken—today the region surrounding Mexico known as Mexico. For 300 years, the colonizers it New Spain. When Mexico was reborn in 1821 as a sovereign nation, its borders stretched from California to Guatemala. It was a huge and ancient land of ethnically, linguistically, economically diverse regions that struggled for national unity. Texas, (then part of the Mexican state of Coahuila y Tejas) was a frontier region far from the cities and fertile valleys of central Mexico, a place where immigrants were recruited from United States. The immigrants in declared the Mexican territory an independent republic in 1836 (later a U.S. state), making the the first cauldron of American culture. By 1853, the government of Mexico, the weaker neighbor of an United States, had lost what are today states of California, Nevada, Utah, Arizona, New Texas, and of Colorado and Wyoming. In spite of the imposition of a new border, the historical and living presence of Spaniards, Mexicans, indigenous and their mixed descendants remained defining force in the creation of the American West. “La América es una muestra por objetos provenientes de las distintas colecciones del Museo Nacional de Historia Americana. objetos reflejan la historia la presencia mexicana en los Estados Unidos e ilustran una crónica fundamentalmente americana acerca del encuentro centenario entre comunidades diferentes que han coexistido, pero que también se han enfrentado, en la pugna por la tierra, la cultura y el sustento. ¿Quién, dónde y qué México? Con el transcurso del tiempo, las definiciones y límites México han ido cambiando. conocía como México al Imperio y toda el donde se hablaba náhuatl región circundante la ciudad México. Durante 300 años los colonizadores españoles se refirieron a ella como Nueva España. Cuando en 1821 México resurgió como una fronteras extendían desde California a Guatemala. En entonces era antiguo e territorio conformado por regiones étnica, lingüística y económicamente diversas que luchaban por adquirir unidad nacional. Texas (en ese entonces de los estados mexicanos de y Tejas) era región fronteriza lejos de las densas urbes y de los valles de México central, donde se reclutaban inmigrantes de los Estados Unidos. En el año 1836 este territorio mexicano se declaró como república (y más tarde, estado de EE.UU.), convirtiéndose en el primer calderón de la cultura Hacia 1853, el gobierno de México, el vecino débil de un Estados Unidos en expansión, había perdido el territorio de los actuales estados de California, Nevada, Utah, Nuevo México, Texas y partes de y Wyoming. 491439fd5b315c77ea0152b44064769cb53dad5d: Details of Glycemic Index (GI) The GI Scale The glycemic index uses a scale from to 100, which the rate at which 50 grams carbohydrate in a particular food is absorbed into the bloodstream as blood-sugar. The main reference food (rated 100) is glucose. GI Rating glycemic index divides carbohydrate foods into three categories: GI Food Testing is Ongoing Not all foods been given a GI value, although most food-types are covered. However, due to the way GI is measured using volunteer subjects, results can vary, so GI values for some specific foods are not yet uniformly established. GI - Diabetes and Weight Control the glycemic index first designed to assist diabetes patients manage their blood-sugar levels, and weight experts now use it as a tool to help treat obesity, food cravings and appetite and improve habits. Both the of carbohydrate in our food influence the rise in blood glucose. But the glycemic only a standard 50 gram serving size of digestible carbohydrate in a particular food, which may not appropriate for all foods. For example, foods whose serving size contains only a small amount of carbohydrate may in be better for blood sugar control than foods whose normal serving size contains amount of carbs. Therefore, to provide a more meaningful GI-rating system, researchers at Harvard University invented the term Glycemic Load, which applies the glycemic index to normal food serving sizes. dad5a4ef19dd6a0bd2f761558b8f5e3ceb658331: the cosmos! Each day a different image or photograph of our fascinating universe is featured, along with a brief explanation by a professional astronomer. 2010 August 12 Explanation: Each August, as planet Earth swings through dust trailing along the orbit of periodic comet Swift-Tuttle, skygazers can enjoy the Perseid Meteor Shower. The shower build to its peak now, best from later tonight after moonset, until dawn tomorrow morning when Earth moves through the denser the dust trail. But shower have been for many days, like this bright Perseid streaking through skies near Lake Balaton, Hungary on August 8. In is the region's Church of St. Andrew ruin, with bright Jupiter dominating the sky to its right. Two galaxies lie in the background of the wide-angle, frame panorama; our own Milky Way's luminous arc, and the faint of the more distant Andromeda Galaxy just above the ruin's leftmost wall. If you watch Perseid meteors be sure and check out early evening sky show too, featuring planets and a young crescent Moon near the western horizon after sunset. Authors & editors: Jerry Bonnell (UMCP) NASA Official: Phillip Newman Specific rights A service of: ASD at NASA / GSFC & Michigan Tech.

The idea of California as a fierce paradise appealed to Europeans, who were reluctant to let the interfere with their vision of the world. So in that spirit, we’re devoting this episode of BackStory to maps — asking what they show us about who we are and and where we want to go. How do maps shape the way we see our and our What do they us about kind information we value? And what do they distort, or ignore? Please help us shape this show! Share your questions, and stories below. Have opinions New York vs. D.C. subway maps? On merits or shortcomings of Google Maps? And do you even still use old-fashioned, ink-and-paper maps? Leave us a comment!
fec4e0750efe1286c68022ffd15f0cf244df68de: Nursing a critically ill state back to health |Indranill Basu Ray highlights the core problems that Bengal's health sector and suggests a few ways to improve the situation| many technological and other achievements that have propelled India from being a developing nation to one of the top economies of the world, one field that India continues to lag behind in is health. This is stories of babies dying in large numbers haunt newspaper headlines. India is behind and Sri Lanka in life expectancy at birth or under-five mortality level. India accounts for about 17 per cent of the world population, but contribute to a fifth of the world's share of diseases. A third of all diarrhoeal diseases in the world occurs in India. The country has the second largest number of HIV/AIDS cases after South Africa. It home to one-fifth of population afflicted with diabetes and cardiovascular diseases. A common that I hear is that we have limited resources to tackle the and burgeoning health problems. But even the country on earth, the United States of America, has to provide appropriate services to a large section of populace. The problem in India is quite different. Apart from poor nation with limited resources, it also has a sizeable population in of basic health Furthermore, the lack of appropriate sanitary measures and education ensures ever increasing presence of communicable disease that have been controlled and even eradicated in the developed nations. India's list woes does stop here. Lack of foresight on the part of successive governments and selective and fragmented strategies to daily problems without a public health goal have the mainstay of health policies. Resource allocation to this sector is influenced by the prevailing fiscal situation as well as by the priorities of the government. Unfortunately, in Bengal — state that faces a dismal fiscal situation — the government's priorities have been skewed as a result of political necessities. Although we have a new government at helm, it is important to realize that gross changes at the level cannot be initiated without having a team with and knowledge define a well-thought-out strategy. It also essential to a government that is to fulfil the financial needs necessary for the strategy to work. It is difficult, if not impossible, to paint a picture of the present state of public health in Bengal to suggest measures to rectify the same in a short article like this. My intention is to highlight core plaguing the system and to suggest solutions based on accepted principles of public health and healthcare The steps that need to be taken are as follows: reducing disease burden, including infectious diseases as well as non-communicable epidemics like diabetes mellitus and coronary heart disease; restructuring the existing primary system to make it more accountable; creating a skilled and professional workforce which is quality driven; financial planning to bring more to the health sector. Reducing disease burden is the cornerstone of any good health policy. The factors that help reduce communicable diseases are clean drinking improved sanitation and an effective vaccination programme. A shift, from the prevalent curative approach to a preventive approach, health promotion by inculcating behavioural to reduce disease burden. West Bengal is one of four states that urgently needs high in water toilet facilities. It estimated that Rs 18,000 crore is required to provide effective drinking water and sanitation facilities the entire country. Kerala, Maharashtra, West Bengal and Odisha would account for more than 60 per cent of total outlay. a huge investment is required to provide nutritional supplements to malnourished and pregnant lactating mothers living below the poverty line. According to a report by the national commission on macroeconomics and health, West Bengal would need to harness an additional resource requirement of (in crore) 1,286, 4,693, and 8,485 in sectors such as health, and sanitation, nutrition, primary schooling roads. It has been projected that in the next five years West Bengal will spend a portion of its revenues on wages and salaries, interest payments and pensions, leaving very little for discretionary expenditure in the health. It is imperative that the present government rethink and strategize in collaboration with the Centre to ensure appropriate funding necessary to make the state healthy. Restructuring the present healthcare delivery system is also equally important. Most healthcare centres are old, dilapidated buildings

75e47d3b3d7a43a43b86bc9390b97112e306cf3c: Yesterday’s House passage of cap-and-trade legislation designed confront climate change is landmark achievement, the first tangible step taken by the country that emits more greenhouse gas per capita than the world. The bill still faces a tough test in the Senate. Passage is far from assured, and similar actions by major emitting countries, won’t much. But it does finally demonstrate to the rest of the world that the United States is to do its part, which puts the pressure on them to follow suit. The bill itself, the product of a thousand political compromises, isn’t perfect. But it also isn’t what its hysterical opponents claim it As Bryan Walsh acknowledges in Time: … have vastly overstated the likely cost. In fact, they’re all lying. During the House debate, Republican whip Eric Cantor, using numbers from an American Petroleum Institute study, said that the bill would eventually cost more than $3,000 family per year — but those numbers assume that billions of tons worth of inexpensive carbon offsets won’t be available under the bill, which would significantly inflate overall cost. going happen. A more reliable study from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office forecast that the bill would cost the average U.S. household $175 in higher costs annually by 2020 — and other studies estimate that the energy-efficiency provisions in the bill might even save Americans money over time. When opponents are forced to lie so blatantly — in this case exaggerating the likely cost 17 times over they don’t have much of an honest argument.
915d816f2ea2881bea6732fcd3dd50d876a54112: Just as there are many variants and forms of electronic malware and Internet-based threats around the globe, so there are many forms protection against these threats. Signature-based detection is of the multifarious forms of defense that have been developed in order to keep us safe from malicious content. Although signature-based detection can be argued to have overshadowed by more sophisticated methods of protection in some environments, it remains as a core ‘technique’ featuring in the anti-virus controls of packages and suites that work to a user’s system today. How does signature-based detection work? Signature-based detection works by scanning the contents of computer files and cross-referencing their contents with the “code signatures” to viruses. A library of known code signatures is updated and refreshed constantly by the anti-virus software vendor. If a viral signature is detected, the acts to protect the user’s system from damage. files are typically quarantined and/or encrypted in order to render them inoperable and useless. Clearly there will always be new and emerging viruses with their own unique code signatures. So once again, the anti-virus vendor works constantly to assess and assimilate new signature-based detection data as it becomes available, often in real time so that can be pushed out to users immediately and zero-day vulnerabilities can be avoided. Next-generation signature-based detection New variants computer are of course developed every day and companies now work users from malware that attempts to disguise itself from traditional signature-based detection. Virus authors have tried to avoid their malicious being detected by writing “oligomorphic“, and more recently “metamorphic” viruses with signatures that are either disguised or changed from those that might be held in a signature directory. Despite these developments, Internet at large does of course still function on basis. Populated as it is users who not only have date security software installed, but also by those who educated themselves as the type of risks discussed here.
5be8b94fc3ae8b4f20b0f5c7c8e47ea3b10fd326: By Jason Kohn, Contributing Columnist Like many of us, scientific researchers tend to be creatures of habit. This includes research teams working for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the U.S. government agency charged with measuring the behavior oceans, atmosphere, and weather. Many of these climate scientists work with massive amounts of data – for example, the National Weather Service collecting up-to-the-minute temperature, humidity, and barometric readings from thousands of sites across the United States to help forecast weather. Research teams then rely on some the largest, most powerful high-performance computing (HPC) systems in the world to run models, forecasts, and other research computations. Given the reliance on HPC resources, NOAA climate researchers have traditionally worked onsite at major supercomputing facilities, such as Oak Ridge Laboratory in Tennessee, where access to supercomputers are just steps away. As researchers crate ever more sophisticated of ocean atmospheric behavior, however, HPC requirements have become truly staggering. Now, NOAA is using a called “n-wave” to connect research sites across the United States with the computing resources they need. The network been operating for several years, and today transports data to fill a network to full all day, day. NOAA is now upgrading this even more data traffic, with the goal of ultimately supporting 100-Gbps data rates. “Our scientists were really used to having a computer in their basement,” says Jerry Janssen, manager, n-wave Network, NOAA, in a video about project. “When that moved couple thousand miles away, we had them a lot of assurances that, one, the data would actually move at the speed they needed it move, but also that they could rely on it to be there. The amount of data that will be generated under this model will exceed 80-100 Terabits per day.” The n-wave project means much more than just a massive new data It a fundamental shift in the way that scientists conduct their research, allowing them to perform hugely supercomputer runs of their data from dozens of remote locations. As a result, gives NOAA climate scientists flexibility where and how they work. “For the first time, NOAA scientists and engineers in completely separate parts of the country, all the way to places like Alaska and Hawaii and Puerto Rico, will have the bandwidth they need, without restriction,” says Janssen. “NOAA will now be able to do things it never thought it could do In to providing fast, stable access to HPC resources, n-wave is also allowing NOAA climate scientists to resources much more easily with scientists in the U.S. Department of Energy and other government agencies. Ideally, of collaboration and access to supercomputing resources will help climate scientists continue to develop more effective climate models, improve weather forecasts, and allow us to better understand our climate. Powering Vital Climate Research The high-speed HPC connectivity capability provided by n-wave is now enabling a broad range of NOAA basic science and research activities. Examples include: - Basic data allowing research teams to collect up-to-the-minute on ocean, atmosphere, and weather from across the country, and make that data available to other research teams and agencies nationwide. - Ensemble forecasting, where researchers run multiple HPC simulations using different initial conditions and modeling techniques, in order to refine their atmospheric forecasts and minimize errors. - Severe weather modeling, where scientists draw on HPC atmospheric data, and archived storm data better understand and predict the behavior of storms. Advancing understanding of the environment to be able to better predict short-term long-term environmental changes, mitigate and provide the most accurate data to inform policy decisions. All of this work is important, and will help advance our of Earth’s climate. And it is all a testament to the networking technologies and infrastructure that scientists now have at their disposal, which puts the most powerful supercomputing resources in the at their fingertips – even when they are thousands of miles away.

Hungry for Pathogens: - M. aeruginosavorus cannot be grown by itself; it must be cultured along with another bacteria to feed upon. A 2006 study found that it only grew upon three bacterial species, all of can cause pneumonia-like disease in humans. A recent study showed that it can prey upon a wider variety of microbes, most of them pathogenic, like E. coli. - These studies also found that M. aeruginosavorus has a knack biofilms, the dense collection of bacteria that cause harmful plaques on teeth and medical implants alike, and can be up to 1,000 resistant to antibiotics than free-swimming bugs. - The bacteria can also swim through viscous fluids like mucous Pseudomonas aeruginosa, the bacterium that can colonize lungs of cystic fibrosis patients and form a glue-like film. - qualities have caught the eye of researchers who think it could be used as a living antibiotic to treat biofilms and various types drug-resistant bacteria, which are a growing problem in medicine. Sequencing the organism’s genome is an important step in understanding its biochemistry and how it preys on other microbes. Clues From the Vampire Code: The new found each phase of involves the use (or expression) of different sets of genes. The migratory/hunting phase involves many segments that code for flagellum formation and genes involved in quorum sensing. The attachment phase involves a wide variety secreted chemicals enzymes that facilitate the flow of materials from the host. - Micavibrio aeruginosavorus no genes for amino acid transporters, a rather rare only seen in few other bacterial species that depend heavily their host to help them shuttle these protein This absence helps explain the bacterium’s dependence on narrow range of prey, from which it directly steals amino acids. Although it remains unclear how the microbe attaches to and infiltrates cells. The Future Holds: - The range of microbes upon which Micavibrio aeruginosavorus can survive is expanding; after being kept in laboratory conditions it has apparently evolved a more diverse diet. If this expansion continues, that could be a real problem for its use as an antibiotic; it could begin to eat beneficial gut example. - Researchers claim it is harmless to gut microbes, been tested on all the varieties of bacteria present in humans. - Several important steps must be taken before testing in people, like learning what traits makes another tasty to Micavibrio aeruginosavorus. Researchers speculate bacterium need be genetically altered order to go after specific or to reduce the risk of it unforeseen complications. Reference: Zhang E Kadouri, Martin Wu. Genomic insights into an epibiotic bacterial predator: Micavibrio aeruginosavorus ARL-13. BMC 12 (1): DOI: 10.1186/1471-2164-12-453 credit: University of Virginia

8f47650a386dbfdf7a662be000f902f9498be130: Common Core Catholic Identity Initiative A national working group has begun the Common Core Catholic Identity (CCCII) to develop and disseminate resources and to assist Catholic elementary and secondary schools in integrating elements of Catholic identity (Catholic values, Scripture, Church social teachings, encyclicals, into curriculum instruction the Common Core State Standards. The initial phase of CCCII focuses on K-8 Arts/ Literacy. Resources for other subjects and 9-12 curriculum will be developed in phases. Forty-six states have to adopt the Common State Standards, a set of quality K-12 learning standards that includes rigorous content and application of higher-order thinking skills, leading students to college and readiness. Catholic schools are assessing what the of the and assessments may be for While Catholic schools have their own local or diocesan standards, their ability to continue to provide high-quality education for their students is compelling them to consider adoption of the common core standards. Catholic schools will be impacted as curriculum resources and professional development opportunities become aligned with Common Core State Standards by producers instructional materials, college teacher preparation programs, or regulations for participation in the federal programs that currently benefit their students and Within this environment, maintaining the uniqueness and integrity of the Catholic school will require the demands of their mission the academic expectations their constituents and the wider education community. To assist Catholic with enhancing identity integrated into the curriculum, the Common Core Catholic Identity (CCCII) has launched as a collaborative project involving Catholic universities, corporations and sponsors in Catholic education, and National Catholic Educational Association (NCEA). The Common Core Catholic Identity Initiative has two goals: - to Catholic schools and dioceses to design and direct the of the Common Core within the and context of a Catholic school curriculum - to infuse the Common standards with the faith/principles/values/social justice themes inherent in the mission and identity of the school. The CCCII project aims to accomplish its goals by creating a process and a product: Phase 1: Gather approximately 35 practitioners and curriculum and catechetics experts to pilot a CCCII ELA Unit development process to be shared larger Catholic educational community. (June 2012) 2: Revise and refine unit development process so that it can be replicated in dioceses country. Phase 3: Invite participation of additional CCCII ELA Units Catholic around the country. Phase 1: Utilize the expertise and strength of experienced and innovative teachers to develop complete units/exemplars that join identify with the Common Core standards. Utilize the expertise of CCCII leaders to develop supporting resources and (June 2012) 2: Post exemplar units, and resources developed in the June 2012 launch for open access by Catholic educators on the Catholic Standards Project Website www.catholicschoolsstandards.org) . (July 2012) Phase 3: Expand exemplar units and Catholic Identity resources available for use by Catholic schools. Tailor the CCCII Unit development process for Catholic secondary schools. Expand CCCII to include additional subject areas. Meet the CCCII Leadership and Planning Teams

dfd94f8cf4151e835a18aa873d99dc452f67063d: Tornadoes are the intense storms on the planet, and they’re never discussed without at least some mention of the term wind shear. Many of us at home, though, have no idea what wind shear is, or if we do, how it affects tornado production. What is Wind Shear shear, although it might sound complex, a simple concept. Wind shear is merely the change in with height, in terms of wind direction and speed. I think that we all understand the wind is generally stronger in the atmosphere over our heads than it is here on the ground, and we think of atmosphere in terms of the three dimensions that has, should be surprising that the wind above us might be blowing from a different direction the wind at the ground. that happens–the wind speed and direction vary with height–wind shear is occurring. Wind Shear and Supercell Thunderstorms This wind shear is an important of the process in the development of a supercell thunderstorm, from which the vast majority of strong tornadoes form. thunderstorms are produced by a powerful updraft–a surge of air that rises from the ground into the upper levels of the atmosphere, and when this updraft forms in an area where wind shear is present, the updraft is influence by and different direction of the wind above, pushing the column of in the updraft a more vertical alignment. Rain’s on Tornado Production Needless to say, thunderstorms produce very heavy rain, and rain-cooled air is much heavier than the warm air of the updraft, the rain-cooled air, produces a compensating downdraft (what comes up, must come down). This downdraft pushes part of the rotating air that was forced in its direction by wind aloft downward, and the result is a horizontal column of air. That’s Not a Tornado! I know what you’re thinking that you’ve seen enough or Channel shows to know that a horizontal column air is NOT a need a vertical column of air. This Can Be Tornado You’re right, but the updraft that is driving the thunderstorm is still working, it’s able to pull the horizontal, column of air into the thunderstorm, resulting in a vertical column of spinning air. (NOAA image showing vertical column of air in a supercell thunderstorm) The result a rotating thunderstorm capable of a tornado, and it would not possible without wind shear. image showing tornado formation in supercell thunderstorm)

e3beac91c52df6ac274eb7169707944d6494919d: Coyotes spend a deal of their day sleeping. Members pack family may sleep within close proximity of each other, or they may sleep much further apart, but probably within the same couple of acres of other. They have amazing built-in time clocks, but they also are influenced by circumstances of the moment. My own dog could tell the time and knew what was to be done at time. example, I always set off, with my dog, at exactly 2:40 to pick up one of my at school. But one day I fell asleep — I would not have it on time except that my dog began poking me with her muzzle at exactly 2:40. to was amazed. The same is true for coyotes — they seem to know is time to meet up, if people or dogs are around, they will Most coyotes I like go trekking alone. After all, their staple diet consists of voles and gophers — animals really can’t be divvied up very as well hunt alone. But some coyotes do enjoy trekking together, usually in pairs. When they in pairs, there is a rendezvous beforehand. Rendezvous locations remain the same for a while, or they can change drastically from day day, but coyotes seem to have various favorite meeting spots which they alternate between for a while, before changing these . This is where congregate then move their foraging. In this case here, the older female had spent her sleeping in the sun quite some distance from where the young male had been also sleeping in the sun. The female was the first to move around — she disappeared some bushes. In the meantime, I male who moved from where he had been to a new location where he curled up then dozed a longer. Finally, he got up, stretched, scratched, and began to forage. I watched catch a and toy with it. He continued for and then looked ahead. He must have the female approaching, because sat down and intently. She trotted over, and arrived on the scene. The ritual began with hugs and kisses. They are hidden in the grass in these photos, but you can see on. It was intense, but lasted only about a minute. That was first phase of the meeting. Then there pause where all activity I think the male was waiting something, but since nothing happened he turned and backed into her looked like a request. He did again and then looked his shoulder: “well?”. The female was obliging. She began grooming the young fellow, pulling off burrs and bugs. He accepted this, repeatedly laying his ears back his head — he seemed to melt with There was care, affection, and intensity here which few animals that have seen show each other. The next phase of meeting involved trotting off together. From what I have seen in the past — though I did follow them this time they will spend their time together trekking, marking their hunting, playing, exploring and maybe even meeting up briefly with a couple of lone who live adjacent to territory, before returning to separate localities to rest.

c24f9531f4a21bb71eb92a9bddc4643923506615: Wood Anemone - Dainty Spring Bloomers for Woodland Garden It's to and vote for favorite article in the 2013 Write-Off Contest! The four finalist's articles are featured in the May 13 newsletter and can be found through this link. Voting ends May 18. If your garden is has dappled shade and you are looking for a lovely spring woodlander to combine spring bulbs, and Hepatica, then try growing wood anemone, Anemone nemorosa. Available in white, pink or blue shades, spring flower is sure to delight you! (Editor's This was originally published on June 5, 2010. comments welcome, but please be aware that authors of previously articles may not be respond new or comments.) One of the harbingers of the European spring is drifts of wood anemone growing under the forests of beech, oak maple.Botanically, wood anemones are called Anemone nemorosa. produce wiry to 10 to 25 cm.Each stem a whorl of three, trisected leaves is topped a single 2 to 3 cm diameter flower.Each bloom normally has 6 to 8 tepals (the ‘petals' are actually modified sepals).In the wild, white is the normal colour but pink and blue forms exist.Plants be grown from seed but the seed needs to be sown as soon as it is ripe (they quickly lose viability if left dry on shelf).They require a stratification period (essentially a winter) before will germinate. Due to the fussy nature of seed germination, plants are more commonly grown by division of narrow rhizomes.If happy, wood will multiply rapidly via rhizomes to produce a large-size colony.If dug after flowering, you can separate the plants numerous plantlets. All need is a growing stem and a couple of inches the rhizome. In garden, wood anemones prefer dappled shade.Their soil should moderately moist and organic-rich.They make admirable groundcovers under deciduous trees in climates, may go dormant by mid summer.In cool climates, they will stay green well into September. Wood anemones have been grown as garden ornamentals for hundreds of years.As a result of their natural variation, many named varieties now exist, most which were selected many years ago.While the wild form has small 2 3 cm diameter some selected forms have flowers approaching 6 cm in diameter. Availability of this woodland anemone variable. Generally you will need seek out a specialty plant has white flowers twice of the wild type.Two of the largest-flowered selections include ‘Allenii' and ‘Robinsoniana'.Both have flowers but the outside of the is lilac-blue on ‘Allenii' while the exterior is more grey-blue on ‘Robinsoniana'.Also quite large-flowered ‘Blue Beauty' and ‘Blue Bonnet', both which are pale blue. The richest blue colour is found on ‘Royal but its flowers are a little smaller the previous selections. Shown is 'Allenii' (top left), 'Robinsoniana' (top right), 'Royal Blue' (bottom left) and 'Blue Eyes' right) ‘Rosea' and ‘Westwell Pink' have very pale pink flowers that age to deep pink.One the prettiest is ‘Vestal'.This selection has small flowers that white a double, pompom-like center.‘Monstrosa' has flowers double flowers that are a of white and green while ‘Blue Eyes' has double white with a center.If unusual flowers are your thing then try ‘Green Fingers' whose white flowers have a small, central leafy tuft.More bizarre still ‘Bracteata' whose tepals are by tiny green leaves! Shown above is 'Vestal' (top left), 'Green Fingers' (top right), 'Monstrosa' (bottom left) and 'Westwell Pink' (bottom right) Closely related to wood anemone and sometimes growing in the same area isA. ranunculoides with small buttercup-yellow flowers.In areas the two species overlap, you many a natural hybrid called A. lipsiensis.From this hybrid comes the selection ‘Pallida' whose flowers are 3 cm and a pretty butter yellow. Shown above is A. ranunculoides (left) and A. X lipsiensis. Outdoors I grow alpines, bulbs and ericaceous shrubs. Indoors, my passion is orchids. When not in the garden, I'm out bird a hobby that has gotten me to some lovely parts world.

b85ee0d19d71788d8d4b7e86dabd996ef85985cd: Xantusiidae is a clade of viviparous (live bearing) lizards that ranges from southwestern North Baja California (Xantusia) into Central America (Lepidophyma) and Cuba (Cricosaura). Xantusia magdalena occurs in Baja California. Xantusiidae a relatively small clade, genera approximately 30 species. Lepidophyma the most speciose species), whereas Cricosaura is monotypic. Xantusiids have a reasonably good fossil extending from the mid-Paleocene onward in western North America. Xantusiids are fascinating lizards for several reasons. First, although they are almost uniformly diminuitive (Xantusia magdalena measures less than 4 cm snout-vent length, and the xantusiid species measure about 10 cm snout-vent xantusiids generally take several years to reach sexual maturity, and several species give birth to just 1 or 2 offspring. It is a more usual reproductive strategy for small lizards mature quickly and produce large numbers of offspring, to increase their chances of survival. Despite this low reproductive potential, xantusiid neonates a life expectancy; this be attributed least in part to their lifestyle, which leads to the second reason why xantusiids are particularly interesting -- microhabitat Microhabitat specialization is an ecological hallmark of Xantusiidae. Many populations are narrowly restricted to specific niches -- crevices (e.g., Xantusia henshawi in granitic cap rocks), interstices in agaves and yuccas in climates (e.g., X. magdalena), decaying logs in wet climates Lepidophyma flavimaculatum) -- and individuals may be found under the same patch of cover throughout their lives! These microhabitat restrictions result in extremely disjunct geographical distributions, and also may be responsible for some morphological convergence within group (e.g., flattened skulls for crevice Xantusiidae also includes two insular endemics: the Cuban Cricosaura typica is the only xantusiid found in the West Indies and is interpreted as one of the Caribbean's few ancient endemic vertebrate lineages; and riversiana (formerly Klauberina is limited to three of the Channel Islands off the coast of California. The phylogenetic relationships of Xantusiidae are problematic. Morphology and molecules produce different topologies within the clade: morphology recovers a + Lepidophyma clade, while mitochondrial genes recover a Lepidophyma Xantusia clade. of resolution of relationships within Xantusiidae has hindered the placement of this clade within the squamate tree. Xantusiidae is a "tree-changing" taxon: it causes homoplasy it is and its placement can tip the balance between the primary competing hypotheses of scleroglossan relationships. Xantusiidae is traditionally placed within Scincomorpha, but some have placed it Gekkota. Thus, Xantusiidae is either a highly derived, or extremely basal, scleroglossan clade. Previous analyses of squamate phylogeny have almost certainly suffered in relying on species of the readily available -- but relatively derived -- genus Xantusia exemplars for Xantusiidae. Cricosaura or a species of Lepidophyma would be more appropriate, but both are exceedingly rare in collections; indeed, species of Lepidophyma are known from only 1 2 specimens. Whatever the placement of Xantusiidae within squamates, there is no doubt that xantusiids monophyletic. The following are some of the hypothesized synapomorphies of the lineage (from Estes et al., 1988), most of which can be seen in skull reconstructions above: supratemporal fenestra closed by postorbital; paired well into postembryonic ontogeny; parietal table extensive posteriorly, largely obscuring dorsal view, supratemporal short; vomers fused; ectopterygoid contacts palatine anterolaterally, excluding from suborbital fenestra; ectopterygoid enlarged medially, restricting suborbital fenestra. d698abffedea05841053da90c120564e097cc047: There are many ways to effectively teach a dog. so long ago, most of the accepted methods for training were forceful or aversive. Unfortunately, some of these methods still are in use among the abusive and uneducated. One of the pioneers of gentle training techniques was Barbara This English dog trainer instrumental in paving the for today’s nonaversive and positive methods of training. She was a genius at molding behaviors with lures and gently “modeling” a dog into without force. But even used some techniques that can be considered rough by today’s standards. If you have researched dog-training methodologies at all, have noticed that a percentage of the available training books advocate the use of a “choke chain” (otherwise called the training collar). When used properly, this training device relies on aversion to get the dog’s attention or to make a correction when your dog doesn’t respond to a command correctly. A sharp snap of the leash tightens the collar around the dog’s neck, the dog with a momentary, low-level pain. chain is not a training device for leash pullers, as is commonly thought, and when used incorrectly can, at the least, of the spine and trachea damage. At worst, it can cause brain and even death. Because there is such a high risk for misuse of this device (you may not that the choke chain should be with free ring up, for instance), the training world probably would be better off without it. Your efforts to train your should focus on building a bond and nurturing trust. This bond becomes the motivator that drives your dog to learn, focus and respond. Why would want to force or violence when positive reinforcement works so well? Why should your dog trust you if he knows you are likely to hit him when he is unfocused or confused? That’s like your supervisor yelling at you when you problems with a difficult task. Stress won’t help you concentrate or focus better. Abusive of dogs the name training, just as abusive handling of employees the name of supervision, doesn’t work. It however, tell us a lot about the trainer. For any method of dog training to be successful, must be: Effective – If it’s not effective, what’s point? Efficient – Both you and your dog will become frustrated if training takes too long. Enjoyable – is an important ingredient motivating both you and dog. The execution of any training program is dependent on these three But, ultimately, the most important ingredient in your training program is you, the owner. The trust you nurture your dog will be in willingness to look to you for leadership his motivation to work with you in any and all situations. Those qualities are in your dog right now but cannot be developed through the use of training methods. Dog training can be whatever you want it to be. If you rely on anger and force, relationship and trust will suffer. If you rely on motivation and reward, while appropriate consequences for misdeeds, training just gets and better. Julie Winkelman is a certified pet dog trainer and a dog trainer. Reach her at www.alphacanineacademy.com.

One solution that many communities have adopted is the establishment collaborative partnership that involves all the relevant partners—home, and community—in the planning and monitoring of for children. Unfortunately, achieving a strong partnership with meaningful participation can often be difficult and time-consuming. This article focuses on set of training materials that has been developed to assist partnerships in their efforts. materials highlight eight elements of continuity and successful partnerships: (1) families as partners, (2) shared leadership, comprehensive/responsive services, (4) culture and language, (5) communication, (6) knowledge and skill development, (7) appropriate care and education, and (8) evaluation of success. Results from a field study included more than 200 reviewers and 8 pilot sites are summarized. Results indicate that a majority of reviewers found the training materials easy to understand, relevant to their work, and up-to-date. In addition, data gathered from the pilot sites indicate that partnerships found the materials practical and useful for addressing a variety of issues, including time constraints, communication gaps, differences in professional training, and funding face a host of problems that threaten the health and well-being of children and families. Poverty, unemployment, inadequate care/education, and poor health care are just a few of difficult issues communities must confront. What these issues particularly challenging is that children and families who experience one problem are often likely to experience other problems as well. Compounding problem is that delivery of services to children and families is fragmented and scattered. Even efforts designed to the quality and supply of services to children and families have, at times, created greater fragmentation and discontinuity. In previous years, those who to improve outcomes for concentrated only on the child. however, many service providers have come to understand that the best way to serve and preserve children is to serve and preserve the supportive networks that benefit children (Family Support America, 1996). An extensive body of research identifies the elements that contribute to children's well-being, beginning with those closest to the child and moving outward encompass the family, early care/education, the neighborhood, the community, and beyond. ecological perspective (Bronfenbrenner, 1979) has motivated a growing number of communities to focus more closely on the need for collaboration--engaging in a process allows the community to many problems at once rather than one at a time. One solution that many communities have adopted is the establishment of a collaborative partnership involving all the relevant partners--home, and service the planning and monitoring of services for children (Kagan, 1992; Hoffman, 1991). The goal of most of these collaboration initiatives to improve child recognizing that many of the child's needs are closely linked to needs of the family and the community. to Collaboration Community collaboratives/partnerships one of the most challenging--yet one of the most effective--efforts for creating a flexible, comprehensive system that meets the of children and families. They involve new relationships among service providers and the and families they serve. They require time, resources, and the willingness of collaborating agencies to learn about and establish trust each other. In they require change (Bruner, & Knuth, 1992). As a result of the new roles and responsibilities that service providers must assume, collaboratives/partnerships encounter many common difficulties, (Melaville, Blank, & Asayesh, 1996): staff or agency representatives who are resistant to power; - policies and regulations within agencies that make it difficult coordinate services, information, and resources; - differences in prior knowledge, or experience that make it difficult for members communicate and work together; and - lack of time to meet plan together. (2012) Using the Moon a High-Fidelity Analogue Environment to Study and Behavioural Effects of Long-Duration Space Exploration. Planetary and Space Science, Epub of print (in press). Elsevier. DOI: 10.1016/j.pss.2012.07.030. Full text not available this Due to its proximity to Earth, the Moon is a promising candidate the location of an extra-terrestrial human colony. In addition to being a high-fidelity platform for research on reduced gravity, risk, and circadian Moon qualifies as an isolated, confined, and extreme (ICE) environment suitable as an analogue for studying the psychosocial effects of long-duration human space exploration missions and understanding processes. In contrast, the various Antarctic research outposts such as Concordia and McMurdo serve as valuable platforms studying biobehavioral adaptations to ICE are Earth-bound, and thus lack the low-gravity and radiation risks of space. The International Space Station (ISS), itself now considered an analogue environment for long-duration missions, better approximates the habitable infrastructure limitations of a lunar colony than most Antarctic settlements in an altered gravity setting. However, the ISS still protected against cosmic radiation by earth magnetic field, prevents high exposures due to solar particle events and reduces exposures to galactic cosmic radiation. Universal Serial Bus (USB) is a of setting up communication between a computer and peripheral devices. USB is intended to replace many varieties serial and parallel ports. USB can connect computer peripherals such as mice, keyboards, gamepads and joysticks, scanners, digital cameras, printers, media players, flash drives, external hard drives. For many of those devices, has become standard connection method. A USB has an asymmetric consisting of a host, a multitude of downstream USB ports, and multiple peripheral devices connected in a tiered-star topology. Additional USB hubs may be included in the tiers, branching into a tree structure with up to five tier levels. A USB may have multiple host controllers and each host controller may provide one or more USB ports. (December |— Department —| |• President of the General Council||Augustin Bonrepaux (PS)| |• Total||4,890 km2 (1,890 sq mi)| |• Density||30/km2 ( 79/sq mi)| |Time zone||CET (UTC+1)| |• Summer (DST)||CEST (UTC+2)| |^1 French Land Register data, which exclude estuaries, lakes, ponds, and glaciers larger than 1 Foix is the administrative capital of the It is an ancient medieval town with a fortress Chateau de Foix perched on a hill overlooking it. The has attacked many times without capture, including an attempt by Simon de Montfort. It has also been used as prison, the names of English prisoners of can still be seen on the cell walls. Another famous chateau in the Ariège Montségur, located on a rocky outcrop at a height of metres (3,900 During the Albigensian Crusade and siege of AD the chateau was largely destroyed, more than two hundred Cathar priests burnt at the stake as heretics. The chateau was gradually rebuilt by Royalists over period of the next three hundred years. The start of seventeenth century saw area ravaged by wars between Protestants and Catholics. In 1621 Huguenot forces ruined the church at La Tour-du-Crieu. In 1629 Pamiers was sacked by Henry of Condé following uprisings several hundred dead in the city. This was also the period during which the Foix, Tarascon-sur-Ariège, Saint-Girons, Saverdun and Le Mas-d'Azil were destroyed. The nineteenth century was a of strong industrial growth, supported in by an abundant water power. The department also benefitted its significant of iron ore. The growth of iron based industries were a feature of the with the establishment in 1817 of a manufacturing plant at Pamiers which has been a principal driver of the local economy ever since. Other representative examples of the iron based industry that developed in Ariège during the nineteenth century include the forges at Montgaillard and the blast furnaces at Tarascon-sur-Ariège. Description of the department's industrial development during the nineteenth century should also include mention of the paper industry at Saint-Girons and the textile in the Pays d'Olmes. Towns of historical interest in the département include host large commercial centre and three churches. is a medieval town, as Saint-Lizier situated on hilltop with winding streets, views and a with cloisters that are noteworthy. Saint-Girons is an agricultural centre with a Saturday market. The geography is dominated by the Pyrenees mountains, which form the border and Spain. There are hundreds of miles of well-marked paths which allow exploration of the magnificent Pyrenees The mountains accessible via good roads, cable cars or by foot. There are a number of lodges providing high level mountain accommodation are comfortable, warm and with good meals. There are a number of fresh water lakes which provide a variety of including, walking, swimming, fishing, canoeing, sailboarding and picnicking. The Ariege has several of its own downhill ski resorts, the three largest being Ax-Bonascre, Les Monts D'Olmes and Guzet-Neige. are many cross country ski-ing one of the best being at Plateau de Beille, near Cabannes. The Pyrenees mountain range forms a fantastic backdrop to the entire Ariège Department, rising some 10,000 feet (3000m) in Montcalm Massif, along the with Andorra and Spain. The highest peaks are clearly visible visible from Toulouse in the Haute It is one of the least populated and unspoiled regions of France. locals enjoy keeping alive, especially old farming techniques. Consequently, as fewer insecticides, for example, have been used, the flora and of the area continue to be in diversity and numbers. Butterflies are common and birds are numerous; particularly noticeable are large of prey, including magnificent Griffon vultures. There are also many unspoiled villages hamlets tucked away in valleys close to the border Spain – Seix, Cominac and Aulus Les are examples – together with picturesque mountain villages, most notably Aleu which comes alive in the holiday season. Ariège stands on the eastern limit of oceanic dominance over rainfall, but other influences are felt: - Mediterranean – particularly visible in vegetation the foothills and of the valley of the Ariège river Tarascon, and in the Pays de Sault; - Continental – in the Pyrenean valleys, with many and big differences of temperature day night. There is no great tendency to summer as the flow of air from the north-west brings rain

729f35c3b2535a6abc66c6917e1fa1d6ba7cc793: A one of the symbols of Halloween |Also called||All Hallows' Eve All Saints' Eve by||Western Christians & many around the world| |Celebrations||Trick-or-treating/guising, costume making jack-o'-lanterns, lighting bonfires, divination, bobbing, visiting haunted attractions, fireworks displays| |Observances||Church services, prayer, fasting, and |Related to||Samhain, Hop-tu-Naa, Calan Gaeaf, Kalan Gwav, Day of the Dead, All Saints' Day (cf. vigils)| Halloween Hallowe'en (a contraction "All Hallows' Evening"), also as All Hallows' Eve, is a yearly celebration observed in a of countries on October 31, the eve of the Western Christian feast of All Hallows (or All Saints) and the day the triduum of Hallowmas. According to many scholars, All Eve is Christianised originally influenced western European harvest festivals, and of with possible pagan roots, particularly the Celtic Samhain. Other scholars maintain that it originated independently Samhain has solely Christian roots. Typical festive Halloween include trick-or-treating (also known as attending costume parties, carving pumpkins into jack-o'-lanterns, lighting bonfires, apple bobbing, visiting attractions, playing pranks, telling stories, and watching horror films. The word was first used in 16th century and represents a Scottish variant of the fuller All Hallows' Eve ('evening'), that the night before All Hallows' Day. Although the phrase All Hallows' in Old (ealra hālgena mæssedæg, mass-day of all saints), Hallows' is itself not seen 1556. Celtic influences Though the origin of the word Halloween is Christian, the holiday is commonly thought to have roots. Historian Nicholas Rogers, exploring the origins of Halloween, notes that while "some folklorists have detected its in the Roman feast of Pomona, the goddess of fruits and seeds, or in the festival of the dead called Parentalia, it is more typically linked to the Celtic festival of Samhain", from the Old Irish for "summer's end". Samhain (pronounced SAH-win SOW-in) was first and most important of the four quarter days in the medieval Gaelic Scottish and calendar. It was held on or October 31 November 1 and kindred were held the same time of year in other Celtic lands; for example the Brythonic Calan Gaeaf (in Wales), Kalan Gwav (in Cornwall) and Goañv (in Samhain is mentioned some of the earliest Irish literature and many events in Irish mythology happen begin on Samhain. It marked the end of the harvest season and the beginning of winter or the 'darker half' of the year. was a time for stock-taking and preparing for the cold winter ahead; cattle were brought back down from the summer pastures and livestock were slaughtered. In much of Gaelic world, were lit and there were rituals involving them. Some of these rituals hint they may once have involved sacrifice. Divination games or rituals were also done at Samhain (like was seen as a time when the to Otherworld enough the souls of the dead, and other beings such as fairies, to come into our world. The souls of the dead were said to revisit their homes on were had, at souls of dead kin were beckoned to attend and a place set at the table for them. Lewis Spence as a "feast of the dead" and of the fairies". However, harmful and fairies were also thought be active at Samhain. took steps to allay or ward-off harmful spirits/fairies, which is thought have influenced today's Halloween customs. Before the 20th century, at Samhain was done in parts of Ireland, Mann, Highlands islands, and Wales. Wearing costumes may have as means of disguising oneself from these harmful although some suggest that the custom comes a or Christianized belief (see below). In Ireland, people went about before nightfall for Samhain feasts and sometimes wore costumes while doing In the 19th century on Ireland's southern coast, a man as a white mare would lead door-to-door collecting food; by giving them the household could expect good fortune the 'Muck Olla'. 84b1141bb7a03d43d0baa0eaf6b14915d2125d58: |Elevation||4,095 m (13,435 ft)| |Prominence||4,095 m (13,435 ft) |Listing||Country high point John Whitehead (highest peak) Mount Kinabalu (Malay: Gunung Kinabalu) is a prominent mountain on island of Borneo in Southeast Asia. is located in the East Malaysian state of Sabah and is protected as Kinabalu National Park, a World Heritage Site. Kinabalu is the highest peak in Borneo's Crocker Range and is the mountain in the Malay Archipelago. Mount Kinabalu is also the 20th most prominent mountain the world by topographic prominence. In 1997, a re-survey using satellite technology established its summit (known as Low's Peak) at metres (13,435 ft) above sea level, which some 6 metres (20 ft) less than the previously thought and hitherto published figure of 4,101 metres (13,455 ft). Mount includes the Kinabalu montane alpine meadows ecoregion in the montane grasslands and shrublands biome. The mountain and surroundings are among the most important biological sites in the world, with between 5000 6000 plants, 326 species of and more than 100 mammalian species Among this rich of wildlife are famous species such as the gigantic plants and the orangutan. Mount Kinabalu has been UNESCO World Heritage Low's be climbed quite easily by a person in good physical condition and there is no need for mountaineering equipment at any point on the main route. Other peaks along the massif, require rock skills. Mount along with other upland areas the Crocker Range is well-known worldwide for its tremendous and biological species biodiversity plants of Himalayan, Australasian, and Indomalayan A recent botanical survey of the mountain estimated a staggering to 6,000 plant species (excluding mosses and liverworts but including ferns), which is more than all of Europe and North America (excluding tropical regions of Mexico) combined. It is therefore one the world's most important biological sites. The flora covers the mountain zones of different types habitat as one climbs up, beginning with a lowland belt of fig trees and insectivorous pitcher plants. Then between 2,600 to m (8,530 to 10,499 ft) is of trees such the conifer Dacrydium gibbsiae and dwarf shrubs, lichens, liverworts, and ferns. Finally many of the world's richest variety of orchids are found on the high rockier slopes. These plants have levels of endemism (i.e. species which are only within Kinabalu Park and are not found anywhere else in the world). The orchids are the best-known example with over species including some the highly-valued Paphiopedilum slipper orchids, but there also over 600 species of ferns (more whole of Africa's 500 species) of 50 found nowhere else, richest collection in world for the Nepenthes pitcher plants (five of thirteen are found nowhere else on which reach spectacular proportions (the largest-pitchered in the world being the endemic Nepenthes rajah). The parasitic Rafflesia plant, which has the largest single flower in the world, is also found in Kinabalu (particularly Rafflesia keithii whose grows to 94 centimetres (37 in diameter), though it should be that blooms the flower are rare and difficult to Meanwhile another Rafflesia species, Rafflesia tengku-adlinii, can be found on the neighbouring Mount Trus Madi and the nearby Basin. Its incredible biodiversity in plant life due to a combination of several unique factors: its setting in one of the richest plant regions of the world (the tropical biogeographical region known as western Malesia which the Sumatra, the Malay Peninsula, and island of fact the mountain covers a wide climatic range from near sea level to freezing ground conditions near the summit, the jagged terrain and of rocks and soils, the high levels of rainfall (averaging about 2,700 millimetres (110 in) a year park HQ), and the climatic instability caused by periods of glaciation and catastrophic droughts which result in evolution and speciation. This diversity in the lowland regions (consisting lowland dipterocarp forests, so called because the tree family are dominant). However, most of Kinabalu's endemic species are found in the forests, on ultramafic soils (i.e. soils which are low in phosphates and high in iron and metals poisonous to many this high toxic content gave rise to the development of distinctive plant species nowhere else). 913a22d404501038b24b26e6b818da11061a902d: Sabermetrics the specialized analysis of baseball through objective evidence, especially baseball statistics that activity. The term is derived from the acronym which stands for the Society for American Baseball Research. It was coined by Bill James, who is of its pioneers and is often considered its most advocate public face. principles The Sabermetric Manifesto by David Grabiner (1994) begins: Bill James defined sabermetrics as "the search for objective knowledge about baseball." Thus, sabermetrics attempts to answer questions about baseball, such as "which player on the Red Sox contributed the most to the team's offense?" or "How many home runs will Griffey hit year?" It cannot deal with the subjective judgments which are also important to the game, such as "Who is your favorite player?" or "That was a great game." It may, however, attempt settle such as "Was Willie Mays faster than Mantle?" by establishing several possible parameters for examining speed objective studies (how many triples each man hit, how many bases each man stole, many times he was caught stealing) and then reaching tentative conclusion on the basis these studies. Sabermetricians frequently question traditional measures of baseball skill. For instance, they doubt that batting average is as as conventional wisdom it is because team batting average provides a relatively poor fit for team Sabermetric reasoning would say that runs ballgames, and a good measure of a worth is his ability to help his score more the opposing team. This may imply that RBI (runs batted in) is an effective metric; however, sabermetricians also reject RBI, for number of reasons. Rather, sabermetric measures are usually phrased in terms of either runs or team wins. For example, player might be described as being worth 54 offensive runs more than a replacement-level player at the same position over the course of a full season, as the sabermetric statistic VORP can indicate. Sabermetrics is both with determining the value of a player or team in current or seasons with attempting to predict the value a player or team in the Many areas of study still in development, specifically in the of performance measurement. Early history Sabermetrics research began in the middle of the 20th century. Earnshaw Cook was one earliest researchers of sabermetrics. Cook gathered the of his research in 1964 book, Percentage Baseball. The book was the first its kind gain national media attention, although it was widely criticized and accepted by most baseball organizations. 9d871729ec5d1c56626091fe6ee83163af260270: The Arch November 14, 2001 The above photo was taken at evening twilight in Calgary, Alberta by Jeff McIntosh. On the lee (eastern) side of the Rocky Mountains in Colorado, Wyoming, Montana, and the province of in Canada, chinook winds occasionally bring respite from cold weather. Chinook is Indian name meaning "snow eater." These warm, westerly winds result from downslope winds - air moving across the Rocky Mountains and down onto the prairies. During those cold, dull gray winter days, Albertans sometimes look toward the mountains for the Chinook Arch, a curved patch of blue sky (as shown above) that indicates that winds are approaching. Over this past weekend, strong chinook was felt in Alberta and Montana. Chinooks typically occur from November late March.

(2004) Effectiveness the area network in diversity. Nature, 428 (6983). ISSN available as: Fifth World Parks Congress in Durban, South Africa, announced in September that the global network of protected areas now covers 11.5% of the planet's land surface. This surpasses the 10% target proposed a decade earlier, at the Caracas Congress, 9 out of 14 terrestrial biomes. Such uniform targets based on area become deeply into national and international conservation planning. Although politically expedient, the scientific basis and conservation value these targets have questioned. In practice, little is known of how to set appropriate targets, or of the extent to which the current protected area network fulfils its goal of protecting biodiversity. Here, we combine global data sets on the distribution of species and protected to provide the first gap analysis assessing the protected areas in species diversity. We show that the global network is far from complete, and demonstrate the inadequacy of uniform—that is, 'one size fits all'—conservation targets. |Copyright, Publisher and Additional Information:||© 2004 Nature Publishing Group| |Academic Units:||The of Sheffield > Faculty Science (Sheffield) > School Biological Sciences (Sheffield) > Department of Animal and Plant Sciences (Sheffield)| |Depositing User:||Repository Officer| |Date Deposited:||12 Jan 2005| |Last Modified:||08 Feb 2013 16:47| Actions (login required)

2283734284a0bcf598779e6625edb3b2b4c4da86: Science -- Asher et al. 307 (5712): We describe fossils referable to Gomphos deposits close to the Paleocene-Eocene boundary at Khushu, Mongolia. Gomphos shares a of cranioskeletal characters with extant rabbits, hares, and pikas but retains primitive dentition and jaw compared to its modern relatives. Phylogenetic the position of Gomphos a stem lagomorph and excludes Cretaceous taxa from the crown radiation of placental mammals. Our results support the hypothesis that rodents and lagomorphs radiated during the Cenozoic and diverged from other mammals close to the Cretaceous-Tertiary boundary. Lagomorphs are rabbits, hares, and pikas. This might be referred to as a "missing link" of the Why do we care? Most mammals are rodents, and this tells us the evolution of the most successful group of mammals. Cool!
ab8adedbc042584f20e064c709ad112bd21eafd3: Photo Courtesy of Steve Dewey, Utah State University, bugwood.org Thermopsis montana Nutt. Scientific Name Synonyms: Span: Perennial Growth Characteristics: Mountain goldenpea is an erect forb, growing up to 2 feet in height and spreading by rhizomes. It blooms between May and August, depending on the elevations. Flowers: Pea-like colored flowers in a raceme. are ½ to ¾ inch long. There are five to fifty flowers which make up the inflorescence. The flower arise from the leaf axils Fruits/Seeds: The seedpods are long, thin, blue/green and covered with downy hairy. They project vertically from stem. The pods grow the late and early summer, and mature in late summer. There are two to seeds per pod. Leaves: Leaves are alternate, palmate, with leaflets, which are oval in shape. Stems: Multiple stems up to 2 feet tall. Mountain goldenpea found in montane subalpine zones. It is common woodlands and meadows. Soils: Sandy, well-drained soils. Associated Species: Aspen, lupine, snowberry. and Management: Mountain goldenpea poisonous to cattle. The toxin has not been isolated, but is thought to similar to quinolizidine alkaloids found in Lupines. The toxin causes acute muscle degeneration – become weak, ataxic, and unable to stand. Animals die from hunger and thirst. Glodenpea will remain toxic in hay, especially if seed pods are present.

c66d9385fddffa4663632ed4bcef0d09b839792e: LANs to WANs(c) The Complete Management Guide Authors: Muller N.J. Published year: 2003 |< Day Day Up >| Depending on the facing network managers, bridges can be used to either extend or segment LANs. At one level, bridges can be used for segmenting LANs into smaller subnets to performance, control access, and facilitate fault isolation and testing without impacting the overall user population. At another level, they to create an extended network that greatly expands the number of devices that can be supported and the services to each user . Bridges may even offer additional features such as data compression, which has the effect of providing greater over low-speed lines. of 2:1 the way to 6:1 may selected by the network manager, depending on what the vendor offers with specific product. As noted, bridging occurs the link (see 5.1), which provides physical addressing, manages to physical medium, controls data flow, and handles transmission Bridges analyze incoming frames, make forwarding decisions based on the source and destination addresses of those frames, and forward the frames to their destinations. Sometimes, as in source-route bridging, the frame contains the entire path to the destination. In other as in transparent bridging, frames are forwarded one hop at a toward the destination. Figure 5.1: Bridge functionality in reference to the OSI model. Bridges can be local or remote. bridges direct connections between many LAN segments in the same area. Remote bridges connect segments in different areas, over telecommunication There are several kinds of bridging and all may be in same device: bridging —used mostly in environments that have same media types, these bridges keep a table of destination addresses and bridging —used mostly in token-ring these bridges only frames based on the routing indicator the frame. End stations are responsible for determining and maintaining table of destination addresses and routing indicators. bridging —used to bridge data between different media types, devices typically go between Ethernet and FDDI token ring to Ethernet. Source-route translation bridging —this is combination of source-route bridging and transparent bridging that communication in mixed Ethernet environments. (Translation bridging without routing indicators between token ring Ethernet is also called source-route transparent bridging.) The engine for transparent bridging is the tree algorithm (STA), which dynamically discovers a loop-free subset of network’s topology. The STA accomplishes this by placing active bridge ports that create loops into a standby or blocked condition. A blocked port can provide redundancy in if the primary port fails, it can be activated to take the traffic load. The spanning tree calculation is triggered when the bridge powered up and whenever a change in topology is detected . A topology change might occur when a forwarding port is going down (blocking) or when a port transitions to forwarding and bridge has designated which indicates that the bridge is not standalone. Configuration messages known as bridge protocol data units (BPDUs) actually trigger the spanning calculation. These are exchanged between bridges at regular set by the network usually 1 to 4 seconds. Once change in topology detected, this information must be shared with all bridges on the network. This is a two-step process that starts a bridge notifies the root of the spanning tree by it a special BPDU known as a topology change notification (TCN). The bridge sends out over its root port. The root bridge acknowledges the message by sending back a normal configuration BPDU with topology change acknowledgment (TCA) bit set. The second step in the topology entails the root bridge sending out configuration BPDUs with the topology change (TC) bit These BPDUs are relayed by every bridge, so they can become aware of the changed topology. are some with spanning tree. The more hosts on the network, higher the probability of topology changes. For example, a directly attached host, such as a client or server, will trigger a topology change when powered off, then go on to clear an operating system problem. In a large, flat network, the point can be reached when it is continually in topology change status. The high level of flooding can lead to an unstable STP environment. To with this vendors have come up with ways to avoid TCN for certain events. For example, the network manager can configure the brid

Broccoli, cabbage, and cauliflower chemical component called indole-3-carbinol that can combat breast cancer by converting a cancer-promoting estrogen into a more protective variety. 64f9aeb108a081118af48affe0817460766ada61: | Welcome to the lava tube portion of the Virtual Cave. Lava tube caves found throughout the world in places where fluid lava has flown over the surface. and most vertically extensive lava tubes known are on the Big Island of Hawai`i. Our idealized lava cross-section is based on the tubes and most of the photos are from there. Lava tubes are found in the western U.S.A. (Washington, Oregon, Nevada, Idaho, New Mexico, Utah, and Arizona), the Canary Islands, Galapagos Islands, Italy, Japan, Kenya, Mexico, and many other volcanic regions. Most tubes form when lava flows down the sides of volcanoes, the upper layer begins to cool, and the lava beneath continues to flow in tubular conduits beneath the surface. Due to the insulating effects of the hardened lava above, molten lava is able to travel a considerable distance with very little cooling. In Hawaii, lava tubes have carried fluid lavas 50 or more miles from their may also form when lava follows trenches or gulleys the surface, which then roof over as lava accumulates along the top edges. Lava tubes contain many features similar to those in limestone caves, such as stalactites and stalagmites, helictites, and a sort of flowstone. Most of the features in the diagram were when the cave was active and during the early cooling stage. minerals may be in the tubes later, such as gypsum or calcite crystals, but these tend to be on much smaller scale than you can in limestone caves. To take a tour of the wondrous world of lava select feature in context on our very cool Virtual Lava Tube Map (drawn by master lava tube Carlene Allred) or choose the above it. Not all of the items in the text list are represented on the image map. Those are shown in all capital letters, so be sure to these newer pages out. here: a LAVA TUBE Check out my book on lava tubes, based on the Virtual Lava Tube, called OF FIRE: INSIDE AMERICA'S LAVA TUBES. It is a guide to lava tube features (with many more examples of each than shown here on website) and and pictures many lava that you can easily find and visit in national, state, and parks and forests. It has 128 pages 345 color images.
