3613172cd75f518d66e6fceb1295f768127db2e2: Question from Amanda: Where and what acids are found in wine. Which have acid (dry sweet) and why due to the climate. Explain why and how titration can be used to determine the relative content of wine. If you could help answer my question i would be very grateful. Answer: Hi, Amanda! Thanks for your question! I’ll do my best…. The main grape acid is tartaric, a relatively strong acid, unlike most fruits. It’s followed by malic (found in lots of fruits and vegetables) and there are trace amounts of lots of different acids. We have an article on wine components, including acid, at goosecross.com. Generally, white wines are higher in acid than reds, for aesthetic reasons. Sweet wines should be the highest of all, offset the sweetness, or the wine will be cloying. Cool climates usually wines of high acid compared to warm climates because heat causes the sugar to go up and acid to go down. A Chardonnay from Burgundy, France almost always higher in acid than a Napa Valley Chardonnay because the difference in climate. Imagine trying to ripen tomatoes in a cold climate–they be quite tart! Titration is a simple color-change test. I’ve paraphrased this from a wine text: Titration is process of determining the concentration of a substance, such as acid, in a solution by adding carefully measured standard reagent (usually sodium hydroxide) until a reaction (change in color) occurs due the presence an indicator (phenolphthalein). Most home winemakers buy inexpensive kits to do this. I hope this you. Are you studying

It the work of that assembly of divines which was called together by Parliament and met in London, at Abbey, during years 1643-1648. e58e6f31b3e87842fce8e757bc8219a1508630f3: Most of us know someone with a food allergy. I certainly do-two of my children have been labeled with life threatening food allergies; one peanuts and tree nuts and the other to soy. Every time I head the grocery store I spend a tremendous amount of time each and every label-including labels I am familiar with to be sure they haven’t changed. This is a necessity to keep family safe and healthy. In January, 2006, the new Food Allergen Labeling and Consumer Protection Act took The law requires food manufacturers to identify all ingredients a food product containing one or more of the eight major allergens. The eight foods identified by the law are: - Fish (e.g., bass, flounder, cod) - shellfish (e.g. crab, lobster, shrimp) - Tree nuts (e.g., almonds, walnuts, pecans) The law states that the name the food source of a major food allergen must - In parentheses following the name of the ingredient. Examples: “lecithin (soy),” “flour (wheat),” and “whey (milk)” – OR – - Immediately after or next the list of ingredients in a “contains” Example: “Contains Wheat, Milk, and Soy.” Most companies are very clear in their labeling and use the “contains” language in bold after their ingredient WHERE IT GETS REALLY CONFUSING I have been scrutinizing food labels for years-I noticing that I have to squint these days to read the fine print. labels contain language about cross-contamination-if the food was processed on shared equipment or shared processing lines with one of the 8 allergens. But not manufacturers are listing cross-contamination information. The reason being- companies are not required to information. There are no particular regulations on whether they need to add statements such as “may contain traces of peanuts,” for example, for foods that aren’t to such allergens. It is a company’s choice whether not to include this and how to word it. How to decide if cross-contamination is an issue So line is YOU will need to what degree of risk you are with when purchasing foods. That is a lot of pressure when you are buying food for someone else. is my internal checklist for whether or not to buy a product: - first check the list for the 8 common allergens. - If there is no cross-contamination or “may contain” information I then look at the other same brand products on shelf. If there are other products that have either nuts or soy I will more often than not there might be cross-contamination. - I might contact the manufacturer on occasion to ask specifically about a cross-contamination issue. Let me know do you decide which products are to purchase? My Go-To Food Allergy Sites:

In this article Henry tackles Two-Phase Commit, the protocol most databases use to arrive at a for database writes. The article very written with lots of pretty and informative pictures. The problem is when a co-ordinator fails availability dramatically reduced. This is why 2PC isn't generally used on highly distributed systems. e47e0f9885a4d6afad9f4780e1c84891f669990c: This is an old lecture by linguist and activist Noam (professor MIT) given at UC Berkeley in 2003. For in the Charles M. and Martha Hitchcock Lecture series, Chomsky examined - the study of relations between physiology and speech. A second video of Chomsky is featured below, which is the second half of this talk. Fair - this is not easy material - Chomsky is speaking to people who are well-versed in this field. Chomsky has been one most influential scholars over last three or four decades - between 1980 and 1992, he was cited as a source more than any other living scholar, ranked eighth overall. As background for this lecture, Wikipedia offers a good summary of his influence in linguistics (below video). Chomskyan LinguisticsChomskyan linguistics, beginning with his Syntactic Structures, distillation of his Logical Structure of Linguistic Theory (1955, 75), challenges structural linguistics and introduces transformational grammar. This approach takes utterances (sequences of words) to have a syntax characterized by a formal grammar; in particular, a context-free with transformational rules. Perhaps his most influential and time-tested contribution to field, is the claim that modeling knowledge of language using a grammar accounts for the "productivity" or "creativity" of language. In other words, a formal grammar a language can explain ability of a hearer-speaker to produce and interpret an infinite number of utterances, including novel ones, with a limited of grammatical rules and a finite set of terms. He has always acknowledged his debt to Pāṇini for his modern notion of an generative grammar although it is also to rationalist ideas of a priori knowledge. It is popular misconception that proved that language innate and discovered "universal grammar" (UG). In fact, Chomsky simply observed that while a baby and a kitten are both capable of inductive reasoning, if they are exposed to exactly the same linguistic data, the human child will always acquire the to understand and produce language, while the kitten will never acquire either ability. Chomsky labeled whatever the relevant capacity the human has which the cat lacks the "language device" (LAD) and suggested that one of the tasks for linguistics should be to figure out what the LAD is and what constraints it puts on the range of possible human The universal features that would result from these constraints are often termed "universal grammar" or UG. df13c0b264fe24a7d61f4d02cd1aa1e369cdedd2: World’s poorest on front line in climate fight 24 July 2008 | News story Climate change is already happening – and it poor people most. The effect of more frequent hurricanes, floods and droughts on developing is devastating, as this year’s cyclone Nagris proved again in southern Myanmar, leaving over 130,000 people dead or missing. To protect the world’s poor against today’s more frequent weather events, some US$ 2 billion is required according to the Internacional relief agency Oxfam. However, commitments so far total US$173. The need for innovative means to climate change impacts and help poor countries adapt is high on the agenda of World Conservation Congress, held by IUCN, the International for Conservation of from 5-14 October in Barcelona. - In 2007, there were 950 natural catastrophes 2007 compared 850 in 2006, according to Munich Re, one of the world’s largest insurance companies. This is highest number recorded since the company annual disaster reports in - The burden of the fall on the poor who are least to blame for climate change. Benin, and Bangladesh, for example, are at particularly high risk from rising sea-levels and storm surges, their per capita contribution to gas output is one eightieth that of the United States, according to the British Institute of Development Studies. - “What worries the is the impact on the poorest which have the least capacity to respond to the challenge,” said Yvo de secretary of the Convention on Climate - A healthy environment help people survive. Healthy mangrove forests and coral reefs, for example, can serve as barriers prevent coastal erosion; a solid forest cover prevents flooding in times of heavy rainfall. - “There are positive of local level adaptation to the impacts of climate change, such as replanting mangrove forests can serve as buffers against more frequent storms. But to implement these solutions on a larger substantial financial support is required,” says Ikkala, Climate Change Officer at IUCN. Upcoming media products: August – International Press Release – Primates Red List update 12 August – International Press Release – Cetacean List update Julia Marton-Lefèvre, IUCN’s Director Ninni Ikkala, IUCN Climate Programme Thomson, IUCN Global Communications, m +417972182326, e email@example.com. Carolin Wahnbaeck, IUCN Global m +41 79 85 87 593, e firstname.lastname@example.org World Conservation Congress, Barcelona (5-14 October) Conservation Congress (WCC) 8,000 leaders from the public government, business and non-governmental organizations for what is the premier summit on sustainable development 2008. Over ten days they debate best ways to tackle environmental and development challenges. They share pragmatic solutions to pressing issues. And they commit to collaborative action.

The third and final stage of labor is when you deliver placenta. If don't go into labor within a week of your due date, your health care provider may recommend you receive a nonstress test, which monitors fetal rate and movement be sure that the baby is receiving adequate oxygen and that the nervous system is responding. 6f87cd0dcc5effb69b43543b72ae81f6d204df63: What Is It? Fertility awareness a way to prevent pregnancy by not having sex around the ovulation (the release an egg during a girl's monthly cycle). Couples who do want to a baby can also use this method to have sex during the that they are most likely to conceive. Fertility awareness include methods such as natural family planning, periodic abstinence, and rhythm method. How Does It Work? If couple doesn't have sex around the time ovulation, the girl less to get pregnant. The is knowing when ovulation Couples use a calendar, a measure body temperature, the thickness of cervical mucus, or a kit that tests for ovulation. ovulation kits are more useful for couples who are trying to get pregnant. The fertile period around ovulation lasts 6 to 9 days during this time the couple using only fertility awareness for birth who does not want to get pregnant should not have sex. How Well It Fertility awareness not a reliable way to prevent pregnancy for most teens. Over the course of 1 year, as many as 25 out of 100 typical couples who rely on fertility awareness to prevent pregnancy will have an accidental Of course, this is an average figure, and the chance getting pregnant depends whether a uses one or more of the fertility awareness methods correctly and consistently and does have unprotected sex during the fertile In general, how well each type birth method works depends on a lot of These include whether a person has any conditions, is taking any medications that might interfere with its use, whether the method chosen is convenient and whether it is used correctly all the time. In the case of fertility awareness, it also depends on how consistent woman's ovulatory is, how accurately a couple keeps of when she could be ovulating, and how reliably unprotected sex avoided the fertile period. Protection Against STDs Abstinence (not having sex) is the only method that prevents pregnancy and STDs. Who It? Fertility awareness is not a reliable way to prevent pregnancy for most teens. It is often very difficult to tell when a girl is fertile. Because teens often have menstrual cycles, it makes predicting ovulation more difficult. Even people who have had regular cycles can have irregular of ovulation when factors such as stress or illness are involved. Fertility awareness also requires a commitment to monitoring body changes, keeping daily records, and not having sex during fertile period. How Do You Get It? For couples interested in this method, it is best to talk to a doctor who is trained in fertility awareness. He or she can then teach the couple the they need to to practice this birth control method accurately. How Much Does It Cost? The tools needed for fertility awareness — such as ovulation detection kits and thermometers, for example — are available in drugstores. But can be expensive. 5269470739a7286426c009d2461d073ed0f7e8a6: Operation: aka Hydroceles, Hydrocele Sac, Swollen Testicle, Hydrocelectomy What is it? operations or hydrocele surgery is release fluid that forms in a sac within the scrotum. Typically hydroceles develop testicle passes into the scrotum but passage through which this occur fails close properly. Fluid accumulate in this passage from the abdomen, and then enters the scrotum causing it to swell. This can cause one or both sides of the scrotum to swell the testicle itself to swell or become damage and inflamed. Fluid can also block the tube where sperm typically flow from. Hydroceles are newborn boys but exclusive to newborn boys. To diagnose a hydrocele typically a doctor will look for swelling in the scrotum caused primarily by build up or will look for something solid like a fluid-filled sac in the scrotum. Typically fluid is removed from the hydrocele sac during a procedure called hydrocelectomy. For the most part this is a straightforward uncomplicated procedure that may a amount of soreness for a few days following the procedure. The benefits far outweigh any short-term soreness. Many times the patient is a under the age of 10 or in many cases a baby that is born with a hydrocele defect. Usually a surgery takes placed under general anesthesia. A surgeon will a small incision in the scrotum will allow fluid to be drained from scrotum and seal the passage from the scrotum to the abdomen. Usually the incision is closed with stitches that will dissolve on their own so they not have to be removed later. Alternatives to Surgery There are no alternatives to this currently. Before the Operation Prior to the operation the doctor will confirm fluid filled sac exists by placing a light to the will light up testicles, veins in the scrotum and the fluid sac which will appear clear to the light. A doctor will also perform a comprehensive medical history and check any medications the patient is currently taking. Patients are not to eat or drink anything up to 12 hours before the because it is performed under general anesthesia. After the Operation- At Home Once the operation is complete the patient will recover usually for a few hours in a day bed. The procedure is usually performed on an outpatient basis meaning the patient can usually go home on the day. Most of the time it is best to wear looser fitting that will prevent irritation and discomfort on leaving. There are risks associated this procedure as are with any procedure including a small risk of infection. Other risks including the risk of bleeding during after the and a risk of a blood clot forming the area of the The doctor may accidentally damage the scrotum or the tissues surrounding this area too. Anytime a undergoes general anesthesia there are risks associated with this too a risk of pneumonia following surgery. The nurse doctor will encourage patient to take deep breaths to clear lungs following surgery. Many people especially younger children undergoing this operation may report feeling nauseous or dizzy following the procedure, a side effect largely associated with the general anesthesia. These complications are usually temporary however and resolve within a couple of days of treatment. A hydrocele procedure is generally to relieve fluid build up around the testicle within the scrotum. This procedure relatively with few complications. primary risks include a of infection and risk rupture or nicks to nearby tissues or structures. If work health professional you reduce your odds of complications. Because these surgeries are often performed on younger it pays to ask someone they have experience working on youths or pediatric patients. You need to pay a small amount extra to work with someone in pediatrics even if you are over 50 or 60 and have a fluid-filled sac in the scrotum that you require surgery for. Regardless of where you go or who you make sure they practice safe practices to ensure your safety and wellness. 58a9b6dc1a66a0f2f0e44aec9b8b919124c35f91: Other Proposed Treatments It one of the cardinal principles of natural medicine that treatment should aim not only to treat illness but also to enhance wellness. According to this ideal, a proper course of should improve your sense of general well-being, enhance your to illness, raise your physical stamina, and increase mental alertness, as as resolve the specific condition you took it for. Unfortunately, while there can be little doubt that this is a laudable goal, it easier to laud than to achieve it. Conventional medicine tends to focus on treating diseases than increasing as a matter of philosophical but because it is easier to accomplish. Probably the strongest force affecting wellness is genetics. Beyond that, common steps endorsed by all physicians include increasing exercise, reducing stress, improving diet, getting enough sleep, living a life of moderation bad such as smoking or overeating. Beyond however, it is difficult to make strong affirmations, and the optimum forms of diet and exercise and other aspects of lifestyle remain unclear. In fact, they may always unclear, as it is impossible to perform double-blind, studies most habits. (For information on why such studies are irreplaceable see "Why Does Database Depend on Double-blind Studies?" ) Principal Proposed Treatments In order to our best, we need good nutrition. However, the modern diet often fails to provide people with sufficient amounts all the necessary nutrients. For this reason, use of a multivitamin/multimineral supplement might be expected to enhance overall health and well-being, and preliminary double-blind trials generally support this view. For more see the article on General Nutritional Support . PLANNING A SCREENING Topics and Issues Relevant THE BELOVED COMMUNITY As you plan your screening, you might consider speakers, panelists, or discussion leaders who have expertise in or more of the following - Children's Health Community Organizing - Corporate Social Responsibility - Endocrine Disruptors - Environmental Justice - Green - Human - Native Culture, History & Land Rights - Precautionary - Reproductive Health - Toxic Exposure Health Impacts - Workplace Health and As You Plan Your Event A screening of THE BELOVED COMMUNITY can be used to spark interest in any of the topics listed above, as well as individual and community action. Using the checklist below help ensure high quality and high impact event. Set realistic goals. Will you host a single screening or use film to spur ongoing efforts? Will you steer a panel or discussion a specific topic or let participants pursue whatever issues they choose? sure to include your event partners the decision making process. Being clear about your goals will make it easier to structure the event, target publicity, and evaluate results. Structure your event to match your goals. Do you need an outside facilitator? If your goal is to share information beyond is in the are there experts the who should present? How many participants do you want? (Large groups appropriate for exchange. Small groups allow for more intensive dialogue and action plans.) Arrange involve all It is especially important that people be allowed to speak for themselves. We encourage you to out 'unlikely alliances' and push your own comfort zone, going out of your way to invite representatives all the constituencies with a potential stake in building a healthy and sustainable community. Once the group is assembled, make sure that all participants have a chance to be heard and are treated with respect. Choose an accessible venue. If you are together different constituencies, is your venue 'neutral territory'? Is it in a part of town that is reachable by various kinds of transportation? Does physical configuration of the room allow for the kind discussion you hope have? Can everyone easily see the screen and hear the film? Is the room comfortable? Leave time for feelings. the lights come up, people may have a strong emotional response to the film. This is where people the empathetic connections that make the following work possible, so it's to encourage that personal response before moving on to questions of strategy. The conversation will naturally flow into "What do we now?" Leave plan for If you want your screening to have lasting impact, it is important to leave time to plan action. People will be looking for something that is concrete, and local. Planning next steps help people leave room feeling energized and optimistic, even when the discussion has difficult. It's also important to be prepared to facilitate Provide a sheet the door so can share contact information like email addresses. Let participants know exactly how that information will (and won't) be shared. Let participants know whether or not press will present. Facilitating a Discussion of THE People who feel safe, encouraged, respected and challenged are likely to share openly thoughtfully. a facilitator you encourage of participation. Here's how: View the film before your This will give time to reflect so you aren't dealing with raw emotions at the same time that you are trying to facilitate a discussion, as well as letting you check the DVD and to make sure there are technical glitches. You may want to refer to the Discussion Guide to get you started. You don't need be an expert on globalization or environmental justice to lead an event, but knowing the basics can help you keep a discussion on and gently correct of fact. Prior your event, take time to check the Background Information Suggested Resources in the film guide handout. Be clear about your role. Being a facilitator is not the same as being a teacher. A teacher's job is to convey specific information. In contrast, a facilitator remains neutral, helping move the imposing her or his views on dialogue. Know who might be present. It isn't always possible to know exactly who might attend a screening, but if you know what kinds of groups are present in your community, you might be able to predict w

d177bb5ed220a0e64ce95b625d01c9bde2cfbf84: Attempts to relay mail by issuing a predefined combination of SMTP commands. The goal of this script is to tell if a SMTP server is vulnerable to mail relaying. An SMTP server that works as an open relay, is a email server that does verify if the user is authorised to send email from the specified email address. Therefore, users would be able to email originating from any third-party email address that they want. The are done based in combinations of FROM RCPT TO commands. The list is hardcoded in the source file. The script will output all the working combinations that the server allows nmap is in verbose mode otherwise script will print the number of successful tests. The script will not if the server requires authentication. If debug is enabled and an error occurrs while testing the target host, the error will be printed with the list of any combinations that were found prior to the error. Use to change the IP address to be used (default is the target address) Define the destination email to be used (without the domain, default is relaytest) or smtp-open-relay.domain Define the domain to be used in the tests and command (default nmap.scanme.org) Define the source email be used (without the domain, default is antispam) smbdomain, smbhash, smbnoguest, smbpassword, smbtype, smbusernameSee the documentation for the smbauth library. smtp-open-relay.nse [--script-args smtp-open-relay.domain=<domain>,smtp-open-relay.ip=<address>,...] -p 25,465,587 <host> Host script results: smtp-open-relay: Server is an open relay (1/16 tests) |_MAIL FROM:<email@example.com> -> RCPT TO:<firstname.lastname@example.org> Arturo 'Buanzo' Busleiman License: Same as Nmap--See http://nmap.org/book/man-legal.html
cec28c6ba2afbd7ef10a70357741f6ec38d70de6: How much is to be a child in your home? Do ever stop to think about how house looks from their point view? My task for this week to conduct a Child’s Eye Audit of our living space, to try and make the rooms more child- and play-friendly. The audit need only take a few minutes and might simple changes to make to improve the play To conduct a child’s eye audit, sit so you’re at your child’s eye-level and consider the following things. 1. Safety first. Most importantly, needs to be safe and it’s t0 review this aspect of your home from time to time as children grow taller, become more mobile or more adventurous. Think what your child can reach, what you don’t them to and make any necessary 2. Child’s eye view. Sit back for minute on the floor and scan the visible to your child at their height, and what’s not? You might display all their lovely paintings on the wall and fridge door – but are they too high for child to actually see? their view just of empty walls? some art work a lower level or set up a low or table with a display of things they can enjoy. 3. Within reach. Consider how accessible your toys are. Do you have an enabling environment where your child can help themselves to toys and resources to use in their play or is everything out of reach? Try to find a balance so you can keep the space tidy whilst still allowing free access. Open shelving and low baskets work well for us with some materials such as paint stored higher up. 4. Ring the changes. Do you always have they same toys out? Sometimes putting away familiar toys and bringing out some forgotten ones can spark new creativity and Don’t have a complete of resources though, as children do like to know favourite toys are. With Christmas the now is a good time to have a toy audit, donating ones your has grown out to the charity shop and getting ideas for their Christmas list. 5. to play. Do you have toys that never get played with, activities that you child takes part in? What can you change to make things more inviting? you’d like to encourage some more reading, perhaps could up a cosy reading corner or – with comfy cushions, a basket of tempting books a favourite teddy to share with? If your toy kitchen has been ignored for a while, add some resources to catch your child’s eye: a muffin tin and paper cases, some jars of real dried pasta, a recipe from your shelf or lay the for a birthday and your child with a new play possibility. Do you sometimes review things from your child’s point of view? What changes have you made to make your more child- and play- Leave a and share an idea with us. I’m writing this one o’clock in afternoon and the sky is grey and rain is tumbling down. making me think about how the affects our play, and particularly I’m thinking about how time we spend outdoors in autumn and winter. I don’t think there’s any question that playing outside is wonderful children: the fresh air, the feeling of space, the sensory benefits of being in I know with own two girls, and all the children I’ve looked after, that if we’re having a grumpy sort of day, getting outside – in the garden, park or just for walk – often is all that’s needed to lighten everyone’s mood. But it’s getting colder now, and windy and rainy dark. If you’re the type who is happy to be outside all the time in all weathers, I really do salute you. I however naturally to prefer a hot cup of coffee and a warm blanket inside! We do play outside everyday, whatever the weather, but there’s denying we play outdoors less in winter – which I’m guessing is the same for lots of So, I’m to put more thought into getting out there and planning on bringing you some posts over next few months that inspire us to venture out. I’d also like to invite you to share your ideas too. The Play Academy carnival on Friday is open to any of your posts and I’d also love to from if you’d like to write a guest post any play in fact, not just playing outside. You can e-mail me cathy (at) (dot) co (dot) uk if you have an idea you’d like to write about). To start us off, my top three tips for getting outside, whatever the weather are… - Keep yourself warm. If wearing the right clothes, you’re much more likely to enjoy your time outside. Pretty much all the children I know care if it’s cold, windy or raining – they active kids and just love being outside. So, to help everyone enjoy outside, and to stop you cutting short the children’s outdoor fun because you’ve had enough, my first tip is to make sure you are wearing the right clothes. Layer don’t for

84e0c7e5f56e10a8f78caeb645deeb8c87672f9a: This collection consists of digital images the correspondence of John Muir from 1856-1914. The vast majority of the letters were sent and received by Muir, although the collection also includes some correspondence of selected family members and colleagues. Muir’s correspondence offers a unique first-hand perspective on thoughts and experiences, as well as those of his correspondents, include many notable figures in scientific, literary, and political of the 19th and early 20th centuries. The correspondence forms part of the John Muir Papers microfilm that filmed letters located at over 35 institutions. Scottish-born journalist and naturalist, John Muir (1838-1914) studied botany and geology at the of Wisconsin (1861-1863). He worked for awhile as a mill at the Trout Broom Factory in Meaford, Canada (1864-1866), then an Indianapolis carriage factory (1866-1867), until an accident temporarily blinded him and directed his thoughts toward full-time nature study. Striking out on foot South America, Muir walked to the Gulf of (September 1868), but a long illness in led him to change his plans and turn his interests westward. Muir arrived by ship Francisco (March 1868), walked to the Sierra Nevada and began a five year wilderness sojourn (1868-1873) during which he made his year-round home in the Yosemite Working a sheepherder and lumberman when he needed money for supplies, investigated the and breadth of the Sierra range, focusing most of his attention on glaciation and its on topography. He began to publish newspaper articles about what he saw the California mountains and these brought him to the attention such intellectuals as Asa Gray and Ralph Waldo Emerson, both of whom sought out during their visits to Encouraged by Jeanne Carr, of one-time botany professor, Ezra S. Carr, took up nature as a profession He set up in Oakland began pattern of and summer mountaineering followed by winter writing based upon his travel journals that he to 1880. His treks took him to Mount 1875 & 1877), the Great Basin (1876, 1877, 1878), southern and the Coast Range (1877), and southern Alaska (1879). Muir found that he could finance his modest bachelor lifestyle with from contributions published in various San Francisco newspapers and magazines. During this period he the first lobbying effort to protect Sierra forests from wasteful lumbering Some of the in the John Muir Correspondence may protected by the Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) and/or by the copyright or neighboring rights laws of other nations. Additionally, reproduction some materials may restricted by privacy or publicity rights. 5ed000885d9c4d693f25131d43a8fcd1d8739a10: Manta Giant Manta Ray Manta birostris often describe the experience of beneath a manta ray as like being overtaken by a huge flying saucer. This ray is the biggest in the world, but like the biggest shark, the whale shark, it a harmless consumer of plankton. When feeding, it swims along with cavernous mouth wide open, beating its triangular wings slowly up and down. On either side of the mouth, which is at the front of the head, there are two long called cephalic lobes. These lobes help funnel into the mouth. A stingerless tail trails behind. Giant manta rays to be found over high points like seamounts where currents bring plankton up to them. Small fish called remoras often travel attached to these giants, feeding on food along the way. mantas are ovoviviparous, so the eggs develop and hatch inside the mother. These rays can leap high out of the water, to escape predators, clean their skin of parasites or communicate.

3b1d326d54294940d2ee95051a64c319d4ab22a9: On Monday the American Library Association will announce the winner of its highest award for a book, named for the great English illustrator Randolph Caldecott (1846–1886). Why was Caldecott so important? Here’s an answer from Maurice who won the Caldecott Medal for Where the Wild Things Are: “Caldecott’s work heralds the beginning the modern picture book. He devised an ingenious juxtaposition picture and a counterpoint that had never happened Words are out – but the picture says Pictures are left out but the word says it. In short, it is the invention of picture book.” * * * “My favorite example of Caldecott’s fearless honesty is the final page of Hey Diddle Diddle. we read, ‘And the Dish ran away with spoon,’ accompanied by a drawing of the happy couple, is the shock of turning the page finding a picture of the broken into ten pieces – obviously dead – and the being hustled away by her angry parents. There are words that suggest such an end to the adventure; it is purely a Caldecottian invention. Apparently, he could not resist enlarging the dimensions of this nursery adding a last sorrowful Sendak in Caldecott & Co.: Notes Books & Pictures (Farrar, Straus and 1988), a collection of Sendak’s reviews and other writing for adults. The first quote comes from his “Randolph Caldecott” and the from his acceptance speech the 1964 Caldecott Medal. Sendak is one the few great picture-book artists who is also a critic. b5d3c302ccb5e5fea3cc9cd24feb4980c4bfa5a3: A character’s name often gives you the first clue to what novel is “about,” especially when it’s also the title of the book. A good example turns in Olive Kitteridge, the collection of linked short stories that won the 2009 Prize for fiction. A just-picked olive is as bitter — and the color is as drab — as the title character of the book appears at first to be. The salt added during curing removes the just as love, the salt in this book, removes some of Olive’s. In Ireland a kitter is a left-handed person. And Olive is at least metaphorically left-handed: She’s out of sync with others in her coastal town in Maine. A surname database of Kitter: “This is an Olde or Anglo-Saxon 10th Century name which derives from the ‘Cyta’ and is a nickname of the medieval period generally given to one of fairly violent attitudes.” Olive’s views of life are “fairly especially in the first story, when they are angry they verge on caricature. 0c84791698db5c1a2a73b5d992842d6c65d072f6: Talk:20.109(F12) Pre-Proposal: Engineering Viral Magnetic Nanoparticles for Magnetic Hyperthermic Cancer Therapy - This is a brainstorming page. You very welcome to write any crazy / non-crazy / conventional / knowledgeable ideas or information you may about our project. Some key words: Magnetic (MNP), Viruses, Magnetic Hyperthermia, What is Magnetic Hyperthermia? How it Under an alternating field, MNP releases heat due relaxation of moments (hysteresis). This can cause an in temperature to the range of 41C 47C. Since tumor cells are more heat sensitive than normal cells, they will be killed by this thermal dissipation. Here is tidbit from paper I was reading: "In addition to expected tumor cell death, hyperthermia treatment has also induced unexpected responses, such as tumor-specific immune responses as a result of heat-shock protein expression. results suggest that hyperthermia is able to kill not only local tumors to but also tumors distant sites, including metastatic cancer cells." (Kobayashi) - Clinical trials in prostate cancer - promising results when coupled with irradiation on breast cancer (mouse) Current Limitations (This information will us shape and define the problem.) (1) achieve the necessary rise in temperature with minimal dose of MNP. - In other words, this means: - High specific loss power / specific absorption rate (SLP) of the MNP. why is higher applied dosage bad? > leads to unnecessary heat dissipation (2) Lack of knowledge about the clearance, and toxicity of MNP. Biomedical potentials of MNP - Could be used as early detection for the following using MRI: - Drug Delivery - Cellular labeling and tissue targeting - Purifying and separating cells and DNAs - Transfection by magnetic nanoparticles - Tissue repair - Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) Types of Relevant Viruses 1. Mosaic Virus (TMV) - 18nmx300nm, helical - Can withstand high temperatures up to 50C for 30mins (conventional hyperthermia involves heating up to from an external source - Safe for consumption - Mann has active research on it - 2130 molecules of coat 2. Bacteriophage helical (Length is too long - an issue in targeting cells) - Lots of research done Belcher group, including attaching MNPs to M13 for imaging purposes - We are familiar with the 3. Cowpea chlorotic mottle virus (CCMV) - 26nm, icosahedral 4. Cowpea mosaic virus (CPMV) icosahedral 5. Brome mosaic virus (BMV) - 28nm, icosahedral 6. Turnip yellow mosaic virus (TYMV) - 30nm, icosahedral Work in Viral MNP Attachment Attachment of MNPs to M13 phage for in vivo imaging of prostate cancer What we propose to do See flowchart sketch. - Identifying / Screening for appropriate virus vehicles and tumor-specific anchoring sequencse - / Engineering viral MNPs - in vivo testing for efficacy of engineered vMNPs in mouse tumor cells. We will start with using ferritin (Fe3O4) as the MNP. Stage 1: Virus Hunt - We to investigate how the selected virus (likely one of the following: TMV, M13, CCMV, CPMV, BMV interacts with cells in vivo. Stage 2: Screening for MNP binding site on virus - We by using Fe3O4 as our MNP of interest. With this, a protein coat screen of the selected virus for a protein coat that can with our MNP is necessary. 3: Screening for tumor-specific sequence binding site on virus - We need do a protein coat or RNA screen of the virus for a that can bind a tumor-specific peptide If necessary, we might need to screen for unique short sequences their cell surfaces. Stage 4: Virus engineering - We can now engineer wild-type viruses using specific or RNA regions isolated in 2 and 3 to produce the viral MNP of interest. Stage in testing - Perform an in vivo experiment by injecting the engineered MNPs into the circulatory system of that have developed tumors. By subjecting these mice to an alternating magnetic field under standard hyperthermia conditions and measuring the change in tumor size, we will be able quantify the efficacy of using viral MNPs in magnetic hyperthermia. - Experimenting double layer MNP to increase response - Target other cancerous cells - with other types of Quantitative Goals (We can quantify IC50 value) Currently, the aid of 10Gy radiation, the hyperthermia treatment successfully accumulated less than 0.3mg Fe/g tissue. The time period for the breathing stops or decreases is usually 10 and 30 seconds. these episodes repeatedly, sleep apnea can seriously the quality of sleep. There are three types of respiratory - Obstructive apnea—caused by a or complete blockage of the airway - Central apnea—caused by a temporary failure to make an effort to breathe Mixed apnea—combination of first two types These factors your chance of sleep apnea. Tell your doctor if you have any of these risk factors: - male - Large neck circumference - middle to age - Family history of apnea Structural abnormalities of the nose, throat, or other part of the respiratory tract. Examples include: Severely enlarged tonsils - Deviated nasal septum - Medicines: sedatives and sleeping aids - Alcohol consumption Fatigue and sleepiness during waking hours - Loud - Breathing that stops during the night (noticed by the partner) - Repeated waking at night - Unrefreshing sleep - Morning headaches - concentration or problems memory - Irritability or short temper with chronic untreated sleep may be risk for: An overnight sleep study is to help sleep Overnight Sleep Study (Polysomnography) test helps detect presence and severity of sleep sleep, it measures your: Eye and muscle movements - Brain activity ( electroencephalogram ) - Heart rate - Breathing (pattern and depth) - Percent saturation of red blood cells with oxygen are a number of treatment options for sleep apnea, including: - Lose weight you are overweight. - Avoid using sedatives, sleeping pills, alcohol, and nicotine, to make the condition worse. - Try on your side instead of your back. - Place pillows strategically so you are as comfortable as possible. - For daytime sleepiness, practice safety measures, such avoiding driving or operating potentially equipment. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) entails wearing a mask your nose and/or mouth sleep. An air blower forces enough constant continuous air through your air passages to prevent the tissues from and blocking the airway. In some cases, dental appliances that help the tongue or in a more forward position may help. In some cases, surgery may be It is most often beneficial in pediatric patients. of surgery that may be done to severe cases of sleep apnea include: - Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty—The doctor removes tissue from nose and/or throat. - Maxillomandibular jawbone repositioned forward. - Tracheotomy —For life-threatening cases of sleep apnea, an opening is made the windpipe to allow for normal breathing. Bariatric surgery may help with loss some people who are obese This surgery may reduce of complications that are related to obesity, sleep apnea. Only used in central apnea, acetazolamide (Diamox) may help improve the ability to regulate breathing. there is not a lot of evidence to support the of medicines to treat sleep apnea. oxygen may be given if blood levels of oxygen fall too low during even after the airway. You may be able to prevent the onset of sleep apnea by maintaining a healthy weight . 76a29a16311d88e2db63ae592c6867cb7ae2c3b1: Kristensen, Hanne L. and Thorup-Kristensen, Kristian (2006) Roots one meters depth are important for nitrate uptake by annual crops. [Rødder under 1 meters er vigtige for afgrøders optagelse af nitrat.] In: CD-rom "The American Society of Agronomy - Crop Science of America - Soil Science Society of America International Annual Meetings, November 12-16, 2006, Indianapolis, USA. No. 205-9., CD-rom "The American Society of Agronomy - Crop Science Society of America - Soil Science of America International Annual Meetings, November 12-16, 2006, USA., no. Abstract No. 205-9.. The root depths of annual crops vary from 0.2 to more than 2 m depending on root growth rate and length of growing season. However, studies of root growth and N uptake are often restricted to a depth of 1 m or less, as root biomass is assumed to be negligible this depth. We studied the importance of root growth and N uptake to a depth of 2.5 m fully grown field vegetables and cover crops by use of minirhizotrons and deep placement of 15N. Deep rooted crucifereous crops were have high root densities to a depth of 1.5-2 m and high uptake to this depth. work shows that knowledge the interactions between root growth soil N below a depth of m are important to understand crop N uptake and nitrate leaching from agro-ecosystems. |EPrint Type:||Conference paper, poster, etc.| |Type of presentation:||Paper| |Subjects:|| Soil > Nutrient turnover| Crop husbandry Crop combinations and interactions Crop husbandry > Production systems > Vegetables |Research affiliation:|| Denmark > DARCOF III (2005-2010) > VEGQURE - Organic Systems for Vegetable production| > AU - Aarhus University > AU, DJF - Faculty of Agricultural Sciences |Deposited By:||Kristensen, Ph.D. Hanne |Deposited On:||28 Nov 2007| |Last Modified:||12 Apr 07:35| |Refereed:||Peer-reviewed and accepted| Repository Staff Only: control page

c5f981cd264dde4f7890ec236e315b7ebf71acf5: |Gallium metal is silver-white and melts at approximately body temperature (Wikipedia image).| |Atomic Radius:||187 pm (Van der Waals)| |Atomic Symbol:||Ga||Melting Point:||29.76 °C| |Atomic Weight:||69.72||Boiling Point:||2204 °C| |Electron Configuration:||[Ar]4s23d104p1||Oxidation States:||3| the Latin word France; also from Latin, gallus, a translation "Lecoq," a cock. Predicted and described Mendeleev as ekaaluminum, and discovered spectroscopically by Lecoq de Boisbaudran in 1875, who in the year the free metal by electrolysis a solution of the hydroxide in KOH. Gallium is often found as a trace element in diaspore, sphalerite, germanite, bauxite, and Some flue dusts burning coal been shown to contain as much 1.5 percent gallium. It is one of four metals -- mercury, cesium, and rubidium -- which can be liquid near room temperature and, thus, can be in high-temperature thermometers. It has one of the longest liquid ranges of any metal and has a low at high temperatures. There is a strong tendency for gallium to supercool below its freezing point. Therefore, seeding may be necessary to initiate solidification. Ultra-pure gallium has a beautiful, silvery appearance, and the solid metal exhibits a conchoidal fracture to glass. The metal expands 3.1 percent on solidifying; therefore, it should not be stored in glass or metal containers, because they may break as the metal solidifies. High-purity gallium is attacked only slowly by mineral acids. Gallium wets glass or porcelain and forms a mirror when it is painted on glass. It is widely in doping semiconductors and producing solid-state devices such as transistors. Magnesium gallate containing divalent impurities, such as Mn+2, is finding use in commercial ultraviolet-activated powder Gallium arsenide is of converting electricity directly into coherent light. Gallium readily alloys with most metals, and has been as a in low-melting alloys. Its toxicity appears to of low order, but should be handled with care until more data is available.
4de40b7661feadf762fd513f33e86b5e632c350e: From University Press: There is a broad consensus among scholars that the idea of human rights was a product of the Enlightenment but that a self-conscious and broad-based human rights movement focused international law began World War II. In this narrative, the nineteenth century's absence is conspicuous--few have considered that era much less written books on it. But as Jenny Martinez shows in this novel interpretation of the roots of human rights law, the foundation of the movement that we know today was a product of of nineteenth century's central moral causes: the movement to ban the international slave trade. Originating in England in the late eighteenth century, abolitionism achieved remarkable success over the course of the nineteenth century. Martinez focuses in particular on the international admiralty courts, which tried the crews of captured ships. The courts, which were based in the Caribbean, West Africa, Cape Town, and Brazil, helped at least 80,000 Africans from captured slavers 1807 and 1871. Here then, buried in the dusty archives of ships' logs, the British foreign office, are the foundations of contemporary law: international courts targeting states and transnational actors while working on the world's most persecuted West Africans bound for the slave plantations the Americas. by a powerful thesis and novel evidence, Martinez's work will reshape the fields of human rights history and human rights law. - Forces us to fundamentally rethink the origins of human rights activism - Filled with stories of captured slave ship crews brought to across the Atlantic world in the nineteenth century - Shows the prosecution of the international slave trade was crucial to the development of modern international law

0db4eebbd86d98c317e5f68b8134c8eb8790ff77: Outside of the environment, a harsh seemingly ever-growing debate has appeared, concerning how mass media the political agenda. Few argue the that the institutions of the mass media important to contemporary politics. In the transition to liberal democratic politics in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe the media was a key battleground. the West, elections increasingly focus around television, with the emphasis on spin and marketing. Democratic places emphasis the mass media as a site for democratic demand and the “public opinion”. The media are seen to empower citizens, and subject government to restraint and redress. Yet the media are just neutral observers but are political themselves. The interaction of mass and political actors — politicians, interest groups, and who play important roles — in the political is apparent. this framework, the American arena can be as a dynamic environment in which communication, particularly journalism in its forms, substantially influences and is influenced it. According the theory of democracy, people rule. The pluralism of different political parties provides people with “alternatives,” and and when one party loses their confidence, can support another. The democratic principle of “government of the people, by the people, and the people” would be nice if it were all so simple. But in medium-to-large modern state things are not quite like that. Today, several elements contribute to the shaping of the public’s political discourse, including the goals and success of public and strategies used by politically engaged individuals and the rising influence of new media technologies such as the Internet. A naive assumption of liberal democracy is that citizens have adequate knowledge of political events. But how do citizens acquire the information and knowledge necessary for them to use their votes other than by blind guesswork? They cannot possibly everything that is happening on the national scene, still less the level of events. The vast majority are not students of politics. They don’t really know what is happening, and even if they did would need guidance as to how interpret what they knew. Since the early twentieth century this has been fulfilled through media. Few today in States can say that they do not have access to at least form of the mass media, yet political knowledge is remarkably low. Although political information is through the of mass media, different critics support that events are shaped and frames are constructed by politicians and news casters, and ownership influences between political actors and the provide important short hand cues to how to interpret understand news. One must not forget another interesting fact about the media. Their political influence extends far beyond newspaper reports and articles of a direct political or television programs connected with current affairs that bear politics. In a much more subtle they can influence people’s patterns by other means, like “goodwill” stories, pages with entertainment and popular culture, movies, TV “soaps”, “educational” these types of information form human values, concepts of good and evil, right and wrong, sense and what is “fashionable” “unfashionable,” and what is “acceptable” and “unacceptable”. These human value systems, in turn, shape people’s attitude to political issues, influence how vote and therefore determine who holds political power.

d48514df0ddf69d05270318322873bb677a89de4: Taking Play Seriously By ROBIN MARANTZ HENIG Published: February 17, 2008 On a Tuesday night late January, 200 people came out to hear a psychiatrist rhapsodically about play just the intense, joyous play of children, but play for all people, at all at (All species the lecture featured touching photos of a polar bear a husky engaging playfully at a snowy outpost in northern Canada.) Stuart Brown, president of the National Institute for Play, was speaking at the New York Library's main branch on 42nd Street. He created in 1996, more than 20 of psychiatric practice and research persuaded him of the dangerous long-term consequences of play deprivation. In a talk the library, he and Krista Tippett, host of the public-radio ''Speaking of Faith,'' discussed the biological spiritual underpinnings of play. Brown part of sequencing of becoming a human primate. If you look at what learning and memory and well-being, play is as fundamental as any other of life, including sleep and dreams.'' The message seemed to resonate with audience members, who asked anxious questions about what seemed to be the loss of in their children's lives. Their concern came, no doubt, from the recent of eulogies play . Educators fret that school are hacking at recess to make room for an increasingly crammed Psychologists complain that overscheduled have no time for the real business of childhood: idle, creative, unstructured free play. Public health officials link insufficient playtime to a rise in childhood obesity. Parents bemoan the fact that kids don't play way they did -- or think they did. And everyone seems to worry that without the chance to play stickball or hopscotch out on the street, to play with on the kitchen or climb trees the woods, today's children missing out on something essential. The ''The Dangerous Book for Boys'' -- which has been on the best-seller list for the last nine months -- and its instructions activities like folding airplanes is testament to the generalized longing for play's good old days. So were the questions after Stuart Brown's talk; one woman asked how her children will learn trust, empathy and social skills when their frequent playing is Brown told her that while video games do have some play value, a true of ''interpersonal nuance'' can be achieved by a child is engaging all five senses by playing the three-dimensional world. This is part of larger conversation Americans are having about Parents bobble between a nostalgia-infused yearning their children to play and that time spent playing is time lost to more practical pursuits. Alarming headlines U.S. students behind other in science and combined with the ever-more-intense competition to get kids into college, make parents rush to sign up their children for piano lessons and test-prep courses of just leaving them to improvise on their own; playtime versus r?m?uilding. Discussions about play force us to reckon our underlying ideas about childhood, sex differences, creativity and success. Do boys play differently than girls? Are children being damaged by staring at computer screens and video games? Are they missing something when fantasy play is populated with characters from imagination and not own? Most of these are vast to be addressed by a single field of study (let alone a magazine article). But the growing science of play does much to add to the conversation. Armed with research grounded in biology and experimental neuroscience, some scientists have shown themselves eager -- at times perhaps little too eager -- to promote scientific argument for They spent past few decades learning how and why play in animals, generating insights that can inform our understanding of its evolution in humans too. They are studying, from an evolutionary perspective, to what extent play is a luxury that can be dispensed with when there are many other competing claims on growing brain, and to what extent it is central to that brain grows in the first place. Scientists who study play, in animals and humans alike, are developing consensus view that is something than a way for kids to work off steam; more than a way for chubby kids to burn off calories; more than a frivolous luxury. Play, their view, is a central part of neurological growth and development -- one important way that children build complex, responsive, socially adept and cognitively flexible brains. Despite 90,000 a year to the capital island, Rarotonga, Cook Islands are largely unspoiled by There are no high-rise hotels, only four beach buggies and very little hype. The Cook Islands a rare opportunity for an authentic island holiday. There are a total of 15 islands in the heart of the South Pacific over 850,000 square miles with a approximately 15,000. Islands most visited are Rarotonga and Aitutaki which only 140 miles apart. Cook Island History Ru, from Tupua’i in French Polynesia, is believed to have landed on Aitutaki, and Tangiia, also from French Polynesia, is believed to have on Rarotonga around 800 AD. Similarly, the northern islands were probably by expeditions from Samoa and Tonga. Island Climate Cooled by the gentle breezes of the Pacific, the climate of these is sunny and pleasant. Roughly speaking, there are two seasons: from November through May the climate is hot and humid, and from June through October the climate is warm and Most of the rain falls during hot season, but there are also many lovely sunny days during these months, with refreshing trade-winds. Cook Geography The Cook consists of two main groups, one in the north and one in the south. The southern group is nine “high” islands mainly of origin although some are virtually The majority of the population lives in the southern group. The northern group comprises six true atolls. Cook Island Southern Group Aitutaki, Atiu, Mangaia, Manuae, Mauke, Mitiaro, Palmerston, (the capital island), Takutea. Cook Island Northern Group Manihiki, Tongareva (Penrhyn) also known as Mangarongaro, Rakahanga, Suwarrow Cook Island Time Zones Rarotonga and Aitutaki are in the same time zone. As David Thompson describes the process, "exam wrappers required students to reflect their performance before and after seeing their graded tests." The first four completed just prior receiving their graded test, asked students to report the time they spent preparing for the test, their methods of preparation, and their predicted test grade. After reviewing their graded test, students completed the three reflection questions, including a of test mistakes and a list of changes to implement in preparation for the next test. Thompson then collected and made copies of the wrappers returned them to students several days later, reminding them to consider what they planned do differently or the same in preparation for the upcoming test. Thompson reports that each reflection exercise required only 8-10 minutes of class time. Clara Hardy and others also describes uses exam wrappers. - Reading Reflections. As Karl Wirth writes, reading reflections, outlined by David Bressoud (2008), are designed to address some of the challenges students face with reading assignments. Students submit online reading reflections using Moodle or Blackboard) after completing each reading assignment and before coming to class. In each reflection, summarize the important concepts the reading and describe what was interesting, surprising, or confusing to them. The reading reflections not only encourage to regularly before class, but they also promote mastery and foster student development of monitoring, self-evaluation, and reflection skills. For the instructor, reading facilitate "just-in-time" teaching and provide invaluable into student thinking and learning. According to Wirth, expert readers are skilled at using a range of strategies during all of reading (e.g., setting goals for learning, monitoring during reading, checking comprehension, and but most college instruction simply assumes the mastery of such metacognitive skills. - Knowledge surveys. members the group were influenced by Karl Wirth's work "knowledge surveys" as central strategy for helping students think about their thinking. surveys involve simple self-reports from students about their knowledge of course concepts and content. 76db65e11464a7e0ae495ced5538c16149c5e6d7: Free the Cans! Working Together to Reduce In a blog about how people share, it’s worth the occasional reference to the bizarre ways that SHARE. Is it safe to say we live in a society that places great value on independence, private personal space, and privacy? Even sometimes extreme value? Is that why people at an 8-unit apartment building in Oakland, CA have separate caged stalls for eight separate cans? I know it’s not nice stare, I walked by these incarcerated cans and could not help myself. I returned my so that share my question with the world: Why can’t people share trash cans or a single dumpster? Or, at very least, why the cans share driveway space? The Zero Waste Movement has come to the Bay Area and it calls for a new use for these eight cages. are my suggestions: - Turn two of those cages into compost bins. Fill one with grass, leaves, and vegetable scraps, let it decompose for six months, then start filling the second bin in the meantime. - Put in a green which is what Oakland uses to milk cartons, pizza boxes, yard trimmings, and all food to send it to the composting facility. If your city do yet, them it’s a great idea and they be as cool and cutting edge as Oakland. - Put in one or two recycling cans for glass, plastic, paper, etc. - Put out a FREE STUFF box for unwanted clothing and household items. The neighbors could sort through it each week, and later put it on the curb for passers-by to explore. VSC HVDC is based transistor technology and was developed in the 1990′s. The switching element is the Insulated Gate Bipolar Thyristor (IGBT), which can be switched on and off by applying a suitable voltage to the gate (steering electrode). Because of the more switching operations, and the nature of the semiconductor devices itself, the converter losses higher than those of classic converters. VSC is commonly used with underground or submarine cables with a transfer capacity in the range of 10 1000 MW, and is suitable to serve as a connection to a wind or supply a remote load. VSC HVDC technology steer and control functionality and is suitable for meshed networks. It characterised by the converter due to the reduced need for AC filters and reactive power compensation. Power flow reversal in VSC systems is achieved by reversal of the current, whereas in HVDC classic systems the voltage polarity has to change. An important consequence of this source is the ability to use cheaper and easier to install XLPE cables, instead of the mass-impregnated cables that are needed HVDC classic. Most projects have submarine cable, some projects include long lengths of underground as Murraylink (220 177 km underground and E.On (400 MW, 75km underground cable). Stanley Williams's device. Because behave functionally like synapses, replacing a few transistors in a circuit with memristors could lead to analog circuits that can think like a human brain. It’s time shrinking. Moore’s Law, the semiconductor industry’s obsession with the shrinking of and commensurate steady doubling on a chip about every two years, has been the source of a 50-year technical and economic revolution. Whether this scaling paradigm lasts for five more years or 15, it will eventually come an end. The emphasis in electronics will have to shift to devices that are just increasingly infinitesimal but increasingly capable. Earlier this year, I and my colleagues at Hewlett-Packard Labs, in Palo Alto, Calif., surprised with a fascinating candidate for such a device: the memristor. It had been theorized nearly 40 years but because no one had to build it had long since become an esoteric curiosity. That all changed 1 May, when my group published the details of the memristor in Nature. Combined with transistors in hybrid chip, memristors could radically improve the performance of digital circuits without shrinking transistors. Using transistors more efficiently could in turn give us another decade, at least, of Moore’s Law performance improvement, requiring the costly and increasingly difficult doublings of transistor density on In the end, memristors might even the cornerstone of new analog circuits that compute using an much that of the brain. For nearly 150 years, the known fundamental passive circuit elements were limited to the capacitor (discovered in 1745), the resistor (1827), and the inductor (1831). Then, in a brilliant but underappreciated 1971 paper, Leon Chua, a of electrical engineering at the University of California, Berkeley, predicted existence of fourth fundamental device, which he called a memristor. proved that memristor behavior could not be by any circuit built using only the other elements, which is the memristor is truly fundamental. Memristor is a contraction of ”memory resistor,” because that is exactly its function: to remember its history. A memristor is a two-terminal device whose resistance depends on the magnitude and polarity of the voltage applied to it and the length of time that voltage has been applied. When turn off the voltage, memristor remembers its most recent resistance until the next you turn it on, that happens a day later or a year later. Think of a resistor as a pipe through which water flows. The water is electric charge. The resistor’s obstruction of the flow of charge is comparable to the diameter of the pipe: the narrower the pipe, the greater the resistance. For the history of circuit design, resistors have had fixed pipe diameter. But a is a that changes diameter with the amount and direction of water that flows through it. If water flows through this pipe in one direction, it expands (becoming less resistive). send the water in the opposite direction and the pipe shrinks (becoming more resistive). Further, the memristor remembers its diameter water last went through. Turn off the flow and diameter of pipe ”freezes” the water is turned back That freezing property memristors brilliantly for computer memory. The to indefinitely store resistance values means that a memristor can be used as a That might not sound like very much, but go ahead and pop the battery out of laptop, right now—no saving, no nothing. You’d lose your work, of course. But if your laptop were built using a memory based on memristors, when you popped the battery in, your screen would return to life with everything exactly as you left it: no reboot, no half-dozen files. But the memristor’s potential goes beyond instant-on computers to one of the grandest technology challenges: mimicking the functions of a brain. Within a decade, memristors could let us emulate, instead of merely simulate, networks of neurons and synapses. Many research groups have been working a brain in silico: IBM’s Blue Brain project, Hughes Institute’s Janelia Farm, and Harvard’s for Brain Science are just three. even a mouse brain simulation in real time involves solving an astronomical number of coupled partial differential equations. 7e6a229d3d349c93a9fe6c761b2bd27823e78554: Mercury in the Morning The planet Mercury -- the planet closest to the Sun -- is just peeking into view in the east at dawn the few days. It looks like a fairly bright star. It's so low the sky, though, that you need a clear horizon to spot it, and binoculars wouldn't hurt. Mercury is a bit of a puzzle. It has a big core that's made mainly of iron, so it's quite dense. Because Mercury so small, the core long ago should've cooled enough to a solid ball. Yet the planet generates a weak magnetic field, hinting that the core is still at least partially molten. The solution to this puzzle may involve an iron "snow" deep within the core. The iron in the core probably mixed with sulfur, which has a lower melting than iron. Recent suggest that the sulfur may have the outer part of the core from solidifying -- still a hot, thick liquid. As this mixture cools, though, the iron before the sulfur does. Small bits of solid iron fall toward the center of the planet. This creates convection currents -- like a pot of boiling water. is enough to create a "dynamo" effect. Like a generator, it produces currents, which turn create a magnetic field around the planet. Observations earlier this year by the Messenger seem to support that idea. But Messenger will provide better readings of what's going on inside when it enters orbit around the planet in 2011. 70c004ce90ce0c7617d8d04913ed5a3b581c1664: Monitor drivers vs. video adapter drivers: are they different and which do need? Monitor drivers are specific to the monitor. are text files that tell operating system what the monitor is what it is of. They are not required for the monitor to function. Video adapter drivers Your video lets your computer communicate a monitor by sending images, text, graphics, and other information. Better video adapters provide higher-quality on your screen, but the quality of your monitor plays large role as well. For example, a monochrome monitor cannot display colors no matter how powerful the video adapter A video driver is a file that allows your operating system to work with your video adapter. Each video requires a specific driver. When you update your video adapter, your operating system will provide a list let you pick the appropriate video driver for it. If you do not see the video driver for your adapter in the list, contact the manufacturer of your video adapter to get the necessary video driver.
a463295a9d922c29358685d7cb411b12efd5a48b: In 1962 President John F. By Sheryl Smith-Rodgers Have you ever watched eastern fox squirrel (Sciurus niger) bury an acorn or pecan? A nuzzle here, another there, then hurriedly pushes the leaves grass over site before scampering up the closest tree. Minutes later, he's back with another Over the course of three months, that industrious squirrel can bury several thousand pecans. winter, when food's scarce, he'll find them again with his excellent sense of smell. Some will escape his appetite, though, and sprout into saplings, which is how native nut trees get planted. Eastern squirrels - the state's most common and wide-ranging squirrel and a popular game too occur in forests and riparian habitats. They also easily adapt to cities and neighborhoods, where they've lost most of their fear of natural predators. the call of red-tailed hawk didn't phase squirrels on campus," reports McCleery, a wildlife lecturer at Texas A&M University, who has studied urban squirrels in College Station. "When we played a coyote call in Navasota river bottom, a squirrel immediately itself in the crotch of a tree a good five minutes." When agitated, fox squirrels - whose fur closely resembles that of a gray - bark and their bushy tails, which they use for balance when scampering utility lines and other high places. Tails warmth and protection, too. "In the summer, I've seen them lying down with their tails their heads to block the sun," McCleery says.

His parents Isaac Bers and Weinberg were his mother being head at an elementary in Riga where teaching was in Yiddish while his father was head at the high school in Riga. Born in 1914, Lipa's early years were affected by political and military events taking place Russia. Latvia had been under Russian imperial rule since the 18th century so World War I meant that there were evacuations from Riga. The Russian Revolution which began in October 1917 between the Red Army and the Army and for the next couple of years various parts of Russia came first under the control of one faction then of the other. Lipa's family went to Petrograd, name that St Petersburg had been given in 1914 when there was strong anti-German feeling Russia, but Lipa was too young to understand the difficulties that his parents went through at this time. At end of World War I 1918, Latvia regained its independence although was to be short-lived. Lipa spent some time back in Riga, but he also spent time in Berlin. His mother took him to Berlin while she was training at the Psychoanalytic During his schooling mathematics became his favourite subject and he decided that it was the subject he wanted to study at university. He studied at University of Zurich, then returned to and studied at university there. At this time Europe was a place of extreme politics and, in Latvia became ruled by a dictator. Lipa was a activist, a democrat who argued strongly for human rights. He was at this time a soap-box orator putting his views across strongly both in and in writing for underground newspaper. Strongly opposed to dictators and strongly advocating democracy it was that his criticism of Latvian dictator could not be ignored by the authorities. A was issued for his arrest and, just in time, he escaped to Prague. His girl friend Mary Kagan followed him to Prague where they married 15 May 1938. There were a number of reasons why Bers chose to to Prague this time. Firstly he had to escape from secondly Prague was in a democratic country, and thirdly aunt lived so he could permission to study at the Charles University without having to find a job to support himself. One should not underestimate fact that by this stage his mathematical preferences were very much in place and Karl Loewner Prague looked the ideal supervisor. Indeed Bers did obtain his doctorate which was awarded in 1938 from the Charles University of Prague where he thesis on potential theory under Karl Loewner's supervision. At the time Bers was rather unhappy with Loewner :- Lipa spoke of feeling neglected, perhaps even not encouraged, by Loewner and said that only retrospect did he understand Loewner's teaching method. He to each of his students the amount support needed ... It is obvious that Lipa did not appear too needy to Loewner. In 1938 became an impossible country someone background. Equally dangerous was the fact that Bers homeland since he was a wanted man in Latvia, and was a left wing academic. With little choice but escape again, Bers fled to Paris where his daughter was born. However, the war followed him and soon the Nazi began France. Bers applied for a visa to the USA and, while waiting to permission, he wrote two papers on Green's functions and integral Just days before Paris surrendered to the advancing armies, and family moved from Paris to a part of France not yet attack advancing German armies. last he received the news that he was waiting for, the issue of American visas for his family. 1940 Bers and his family arrived in the United States and joined his mother who was already in New York. There was of course a flood of well academics arriving in the United States fleeing from Nazis and there was a great scarcity of posts, even for the most brilliant, so he was unemployed until 1942, living with other unemployed refugees in New York. During this time he continued his mathematical researches. After this he was appointed Research Instructor at Brown University where, as part work relevant to the war effort, he studied subsonic fluid This was important at that time since aircraft wings were being designed for with engines capable of high speeds. 1945 1949 at Syracuse University, first at Assistant Professor, later as Associate Professor. This was how the men tried to intense itchiness that comes with blindness, a rare tropical disease. "You can imagine bad the itching must be, that running a red-hot machete up and down your back would be a relief, but it was," said Unnasch, whose laboratory works on diagnostic for the disease. About 18 million people have blindness worldwide, according to World Health Organization, more than 99% of cases of this disease are found in Africa. It goes by the technical name "onchocerciasis," and it spreads through small black flies that in fast-flowing, highly oxygenated waters. When an infected fly bites a person, it drops worm larvae in the skin, can then grow and reproduce in the body. Unlike river blindness is not fatal, but it causes a life," said Moses Katabarwa, senior epidemiologist the Atlanta-based Carter Center's River Blindness Program, been leading an effort to eliminate the disease in Americas and several African countries. Some strains cause blindness, while others come with more severe skin disease. With time, generally all strains of the disease can to "lizard" skin, depigmented "leopard skin" and hanging groins. Another big among patients is itching, which happens when the die inside a person. In Uganda, the locals call the disease "Obukamba," referring to the of distorted skin appearance and itchiness, Katabarwa said. In western Uganda, he said, "the fly is called 'Embwa fly' or dog fly, for bites like a dog!" There is for river blindness, but there is a drug, called ivermectin that and kills of adult worms, according to the Mayo Clinic. It may also slow the reproduction of adult worms, so there are fewer of them in the blood and eyes. The pharmaceutical company Merck has been donating treatment, under the brand since Great strides have been made this disease. In the Americas, it was eliminated in Colombia in 2007 and in Ecuador in 2009.

4773ffaa135f6fc6d0ecc3148a1cce59a5c2a9c1: Weights linked to lower diabetes risk Weight gains Weight training, and not just cardio workouts, is linked to a lower risk of type 2 diabetes, according to a US study. "We all that aerobic exercise is beneficial for diabetes - many studies have at that but no studies have looked at weight training," says study leader Frank Hu, at the Harvard School of Public Health. "This suggests weight training is important for diabetes, and probably as important as aerobic training." Hu and his colleagues, whose report was published in the Archives of Internal Medicine, used data on more than 32,000 male professionals, who answered questionnaires two years from 1990 to 2008. On average, four out of developed type 2 diabetes year, the researchers found. The risk of getting the blood sugar disorder was only as high for men did cardio, aerobic, workouts say brisk walking, jogging or playing tennis - at least 150 minutes a week, as for those who didn't do cardio exercise. Men who did weight training for 150 minutes or more had a risk reduction of a third compared to those who never lifted weights, independently of whether or not they did aerobic exercise. Exercise is beneficial Whereas weight increases muscle mass can reduce abdominal obesity, it tends to cut overall body mass, says Hu. The results don't prove that working out staves off diabetes, because many men who fit may also be healthier in ways, but the researchers did their best to account such potential differences, including age, smoking and diet. "I think the benefits of weight training are real," says Hu. "Any type of exercise is beneficial for diabetes prevention, training can incorporated with aerobic exercise to get the results." with an appropriate diet, exercise is also important for people who have type 2 diabetes and can help control high blood sugar, he adds.
