Now one thing to appreciate is that over the last 4.7 billion years, there have been many natural cycles in the climate — both heating and cooling. What's happening today in the Arctic is not cycle caused by nature, but something that we humans did by burning fossil fuels and dumping slightly over trillion tonnes of into the atmosphere over the century. So what are these natural cycles? There are many many of them, but let's just look at the Milankovitch cycles. These cycles relate to the and its orbit around the Sun. There are three main Milankovitch cycles. They each affect how much solar radiation lands on Earth, and whether ice, land or water, and when it lands. 5afc5eb2a1f7a6a1a19aa94b28a652c185c73016: Black growing faster expected Black hole find Existing theories on the relationship between the size of a galaxy and its central black hole wrong according a new Australian study. The discovery by Dr Nicholas and Professor Alister Graham, Melbourne's Swinburne University of Technology, found smaller galaxies have far smaller holes than previously estimated. Central black holes, millions to billions of times more massive than the Sun, reside in the core of most galaxies, and are thought to be integral to formation and evolution. astronomers are still trying to understand this relationship. and Graham combined data from observatories in Chile, Hawaii and the Hubble Telescope, to develop a data base listing the masses of 77 galaxies and their central supermassive black holes. The astronomers mass of each central black hole by measuring how fast stars are Existing theories suggest direct ratio between the mass of a galaxy and that of its black hole. "This ratio worked for larger galaxies, but with improved technology we're now able to examine far smaller galaxies and current theories don't hold up," says Scott. In a paper to be published in the Astrophysical Journal, they found that for each ten-fold decrease in galaxy's mass, there was a one hundred-fold decrease in its central black mass. "That was a surprising result which we been anticipating," says The study found that smaller galaxies have far denser stellar populations near centres than larger galaxies. According to Scott, this also means the central black holes in smaller grow much faster than their larger counterparts. Black holes grow by merging with other black when their galaxies collide. "When large galaxies merge they double in size and so do their central black holes," says Scott. "But when small galaxies merge their central black quadruple in size because of the greater densities of nearby stars to feed on." Somewhere in between The findings also solve the long standing problem of missing intermediate mass black holes. For decades, scientists have been searching something in between stellar mass holes formed when largest stars die, and supermassive black holes at the of galaxies. "If the central black holes in smaller galaxies have lower mass than originally thought, they may represent the intermediate mass hole population astronomers have been for," says Graham. "Intermediate sized black holes are between ten thousand and a few hundred thousand times the mass of the Sun, and we we've found several good candidates." "These may be big enough to be seen directly by generation extremely large telescopes now being built," says Graham.
fdd288d3b856c691256eb4203cca17e5a2b730d0: Hoodoos may be seismic gurus Hoodoo prediction Towering chimney-like sedimentary rock spires known hoodoos may provide an indication of an area's earthquake activity. The research by scientists including Dr Rasool Anooshehpoor, from the States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, may provide scientists with a new tool to test the accuracy of current hazard models. Hoodoo formations are found in regions, are common in North America, the Middle East and northern Africa. They caused the uneven weathering of different layers of sedimentary rocks, that leave boulders or thin caps of hard perched on softer rock. By knowing the strengths of different types of sedimentary layers, scientists determine the amount stress to cause those rocks to fracture. The United States Geological Survey (USGS) use seismic hazard models predict the type of ground motion likely to occur in an area during a But, according to Anooshehpoor, these models lack term data. "Existing hazard maps use models based scant data going back hundred years or so," says Anooshehpoor. "But earthquakes have return periods lasting hundreds or thousands of years, there is nothing to these hazard models against." researchers examined two unfractured hoodoos within a few kilometres of the Garlock fault, which is an active strike-slip fault in California's Red Rock Canyon. Their findings are in the of Seismological Society of America. "Although we can't put a precise on because of their erosion characteristics, we can use them to provide physical limits on the level ground shaking that could potentially have occurred in area," Anooshehpoor. The researchers developed a three-dimensional model of each hoodoo and determined the most likely place where each spire would fail in an earthquake. They then tested rock samples similar to the hoodoo pillars to measure their tensile strength and compared their results with previously published data. USGS records suggest at least one large magnitude earthquake along the in the last 550 years, resulting seven metres of slip, yet hoodoos are still standing. This finding is consistent with a median of ground motion associated with the large quakes in this region, says Anooshehpoor. "If an earthquake occurred with a higher level of motion, the hoodoos would have collapsed," he says. "Nobody can predict earthquakes, but will predict what ground motions associated with earthquakes they happen." Dr Juan Carlos Afonso from the Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences at Sydney's Macquarie University says it's an exciting development. "In it's not just difficult to the entire planet, it's hard to cover even active near populated areas," says Afonso. need lots of instruments, so it's great if you on natural objects to help you." e7a5e3194a7b6efb1d0bc8262226cd85aed2fe27: Now, is common these days that Hitler's final great offensive in the last years of WWII was the Ardennes Offensive of 1944/45, also known as battle of Bulge. What was not appreciated at the time by the Allied high command just how desperately short of vital the Third Reich armies actually were. Ardennes Offensive was Hitler's bold attempt to capture and hold the Allied army's massive supply of Brussels sprouts, vital - of course - for the full functioning of any army. German intelligence were that the American army was - in particular - massing huge quantities of the vital Brussels sprouts just behind their in preparedness for their own massive push - and - of course - time Christmas. German's plan would have succeeded the had not quickly worked out that it was their stockpiles of sprouts that were under immediate threat. The bold plan put forward by the Allied Generals was a heavy gamble, but paid off. They ordered their front-line to begin boiling their stocks of Brussels sprouts, and - most importantly - to keep them boiling past a state fully preparedness. So, when the weather altered and wind direction changed, it blew the smell of over-cooked Brussels sprouts straight into the faces of the advancing Germans. Then the Reich troops knew that they would not be able to replenish their stocks of Brussels sprouts and any sprouts that they did from the Allied frontline kitchens would overcooked to the point of inedibility. Later in this series, we will discuss the major strategic role that Brussels sprouts have played in world history, such Hadrian building a wall to protect the Roman Empire's most northern supplies of Brussels sprouts from the northern barbarians, thwarting the barbarian's fiendish plan deep-fry the Roman's entire stockpiles of sprouts. Then there was, also, Napoleon's retreat from Moscow when his over-long supply line of Brussels sprouts direct from France broke down. Even when his troops get sprouts, they were of poor quality - dry, wizened and frozen solid. Of course, this led to a massive collapse of morale. Eventually, the lack of good quality forced a massive retreat where thousands of French troops died from a pitiful lack of sprouts. And, of course, not forgetting - of course - how the Spanish conquest of the Americas was a result of the Spaniards overwhelming sprout superiority.

"In contrast, this project focuses on the 'retrofitting' of an existing environment — a more likely approach, given the extent of the world's already-built infrastructure." In fact, the website the Centers for Control estimates that each year about 48 million people get sick, 128,000 are hospitalized and 3,000 die from food-borne diseases. The most severe cases tend to occur in the very old. The good news is that food poisoning can prevented if you follow proper home food practices. Ruth Frechman, a registered dietitian and spokesperson for the American Dietetic Association, with AgingCare.com about home food safety for elderly people. "Since older are at particular risk for food-borne illness, good food safety are extremely crucial." Ms. Frechman says three common cooking and food preparation mistakes can result in unsafe food potential poisoning. Bacteria in raw meat and poultry juices can be spread to other utensils and . "To prevent cross-contamination, keep raw foods separate ready-to-eat foods fresh she says. "For example, use two cuttings boards: one strictly for raw meat, poultry and seafood; the other for ready-to-eat foods like breads and vegetables." She recommends washing cutting boards thoroughly in hot water after each use or placing them in the dishwasher. a bleach solution or other sanitizing solution and rinse with clean water. Always wash your hands handling raw meat. Leaving food out too long Leaving food out too long at room temperature cause bacteria to grow to dangerous levels that illness. "Many people think it's okay to leave sitting out for a few hours," Ms. Frechman "But that's a dangerous habit. Food should not be left out more than two hours. it's over 90 degrees, like at an outdoor summer barbecue, food should not be out for more than one hour." Its common knowledge that meat should be to proper temperatures. However, most people don't know that even leftovers that were previously cooked should be to a certain temperature. re-heating foods to the proper temperature can kill many harmful bacteria. Leftovers should be re-heated to at 165 degrees Fahrenheit. "Harmful bacteria are destroyed food is cooked to proper temperatures," she says. a food thermometer comes in handy not only for preparing food, but also for re-heating." How long it is safe to leftovers? Not as long you would think, Ms. Frechman says. Chicken, fish and beef expire after three to four days in the refrigerator. help seniors track if leftovers are still good, she recommends writing the date on the package of leftovers. Seniors and their caregivers should take these preventive to avoid germs in food and contracting Pay attention the foods that are eaten, how food is prepared, and properly maintain the food in refrigerator, and you may avoid an illness that could cause great discomfort, weakening of the body or even death.

de76c93affe0abbdd474f492666b06d65d93ffc1: In preparation for Christmas, I read Stephen Nissenbaum's 1998 "The Battle for Christmas," thorough exploration of this season. The title will deceiving, it has nothing to with recent sacred-vs.-secular Christmas quarrels. Nissenbaum explores the myriad ways that Christmas has evolved in our nation. It turns out we've been jockeying for than 300 years over what this holiday means. In America our faith-filled ancestors banned Christmas altogether, outlawing it in some colonies. Until the 1760s, one could not even find an almanac that would print the word "Christmas" on date Dec. 25. This opposition was because Christmas had become a drunken spectacle where gangs of poor young men roamed the streets, making merry and engaging in acts of petty rowdyism, vaguely like today's New Year's It was customary permissible for these gangs to on doors of strangers to demand gifts. ("So give us some figgy pudding....") Our nation's first "battle" for Christmas was movement to domesticate the holiday, a battle that suggests involved merchants, the middle and upper classes and the church. Merchants began linking Christmas and the purchase of manufactured gifts as early as the 1830s society began to stress family celebrations in front of a tree and with Santa visiting every home. In case you think that your complaining will the commercialism of this holiday, according to Nissenbaum that complaint first emerged the 1830s. Complain if you must, but don't expect results. so thoroughly explores "'Twas the Night before Christmas" that one learns why Saint Nick touches the side of his nose and why his pipe is a short one. contends that the ascendance of Santa Claus, the emergence of Christmas tree and even the giving of gifts contribute to this gradual process of making Christmas a less revolutionary, more predictable holiday. He explores Dickens and Scrooge, Christmas parties for poor children and even the complicated master-slave relationship at Christmas up to and immediately following the Civil War. If you to maintain that Christmas was a pure season of private devotion and public worship Sears, Roebuck, Wal-Mart and the Supreme Court got don't read book. Ditto if you enjoy that "They've taken Christmas away from us," Nissenbaum might say a pure, simple never existed. Rather it has evolved since the first day the Colonists set foot on our shore, an evolution showing no sign of abating. Nissenbaum's scholarly, heavily footnoted book is enlightening and readable. But his analysis of Christmas reminds me of a scientist who thoroughly explains the rainbow never grasps its beauty. And as this continues to I'll enjoy my Christmas sing both "White Christmas" and "Joy to the World," and be grateful again for the mystery of Bethlehem, which properly understood, is the most revolutionary act of history. Contact columnist minister Creede Hinshaw Wesley Monumental United Methodist Church in Savannah at email@example.com.

b6b88647dc00a0060785df30b807658da3e352ce: Fair Project Encyclopedia The chloride ion formed when the element chlorine picks up one electron to form the anion (negatively charged ion) Cl−. The salts of hydrochloric acid HCl chloride ions and are also called chlorides. An example is table salt, which is chloride the chemical formula NaCl. In water, it dissolves Na+ and Cl− ions. The word chloride can also refer to a chemical compound in which one or more chlorine atoms are covalently bonded in the molecule. means that chlorides can be either inorganic or organic compounds. The simplest example of an covalently bonded chloride is hydrogen chloride, HCl. A simple example of an organic covalently bonded chloride is chloromethane (CH3Cl), often called methyl chloride. Other examples of inorganic covalently bonded chlorides which are used as reactants - phosphorus trichloride, phosphorus pentachloride, and chloride - all three are reactive chlorinating reagents which have been used in a laboratory. - Disulfur (SCl2) - used for vulcanization of rubber. Chloride ions have important physiological roles. For instance, in the central nervous system the inhibitory action of glycine and some of the action of GABA relies on the entry Cl− into specific neurons. ad16945825518c01cad22e23664f135e30182e3e: Dr. Auer Welsbach (1858-1929) had a rare double talent understanding how to pursue science and, at the same time, of commercializing himself successfully as a and discoverer. He 4 elements (Neodymium, Praseodymium, Ytterbium, and Lutetium). He invented the incandescent mantle, that helped gaslighting at the end the 19th century to a renaissance. He developed Ferrocerium - it`s still used a flint in every disposable lighter. He was an eminent authority, and great expert in the field of rare earths (lanthanoides). He invented the electric metal filament light bulb which is used billions of times today. Additionally, his life he took active part in different fields, from photography to ornithology. qualities are remembered highly by the people of Althofen, he not only an excellent mind but also big heart. These qualities ensured him a prominent and lasting not only in Austria`s and industrial history. 9th of Sept. Born in Vienna, son of Therese and Alois Ritter Auer Welsbach ( his father was of the Imperial printing office the "Staatsdruckerei"). 1869-73: went to the secondary school in Mariahilf, (then changed the secondary school Josefstadt.) 1873-77: went to secondary school in Josefstadt, graduation. 1877-78: military service, a second lieutenant. 1878-80: Inscribed technical of Vienna; studies in math, general organic and inorganic chemistry, technical and thermodynamics with the Professors Winkler, Bauer, Reitlinger; and Pierre. 1880-82: to the University of Heidelberg; lectures on inorganic experimental chemistry and Lab. experiments with Prof. Bunsen, introduction to analysis and the history of chemistry, mineralogy and physics. 5th of Feb. 1882: Promotion to Doctor of at the Ruperta-Carola-University in Heidelberg. 1882: Return to Vienna as unpaid Assistant in Prof. Lieben`s laboratory; work with chemical separation methods for investigations on rare earth elements. 1882-1884: Publications: " Ueber die Erden des Gadolinits von Ytterby", "Ueber die Seltenen Erden". 1885: separation of element "Didymium" with help from a newly developed separation method from himself, based on the fractioned crystalisation of a Didym-ammonium nitrat solution. After the characteristical colouring, Auer gave the green components the name Praseodymium, the pink components the name Neodidymium. In time the element was more commonly known as Neodymium. 1885-1892: Work on gas mantle for the incandescent lighting. Development of a method to produce gas mantle ("Auerlicht) based on the impregnation from cottontissue means, measures, liquids, that earth has been absolved in and the ash from the in a following glow process. Production of the first incandescent mantle out of lanthanum oxide, in which the gas flame is surrounded from a stocking; definite in light emmission, but lack of in humidity. Continuous improvements in the chemical composition of the incandescent mantel "Auerlicht", experimentations of Lanthanum variations. 18th of 1885: The patenting of a gas burner a "Actinophor" incandescent mantle made up of 60% oxide, 20% oxide and 20% yttrium oxide; in the same year, the magnesium oxide part was replaced with zirconium oxide and the constitution of a second patent with reference to the additional use of the light body in a spirits flame. 9th of April 1886: Introduction the name "Gasgluehlicht" through the Journalist Motiz Szeps after the successful presentation from the Actinophors in the lower Austrian trade union ; regular of the impregnation liquid, "Fluid", at the Chemical Institute. 1887: The acquisition of the factory Würth & for chemical-pharmaceutical products in Atzgersdorf and the production of the bodies. 1889: The beginning of sales problems because of the defaults with earlier incandescent mantle, ie. it`s fragility, the short length of use, as well as having an unpleasant, cold, green light , and the relatively high price. f5a22a5f92a8226b5276025c4b2dea8bc03f6479: Ethics of What are clinical trials and are they controlled/governed? A clinical is a biomedical/health-related study into the effects on humans of a new medical treatment (medicine/drug, medical device, vaccine new therapy), sometimes called an investigational medicinal product (IMP). Before a new drug is authorised and can be marketed, it must through several phases of development including trial in which its safety, efficacy, risks, optimal use and/or benefits are on human beings. Existing drugs must also undergo testing before can be used to treat other conditions than that for which they were originally intended. Organisations conducting clinical in the European Union must, they wish to obtain marketing authorisation, respect the requirements for the of clinical trials. These can be found in Clinical Trials Directive (“Directive 2001/20/EC of the European Parliament and of Council of 4 April 2001 on approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of Member States relating to the implementation of good clinical practice in the conduct of clinical trials for There are also guidelines ensure that clinical are carried out in accordance with good clinical practice. These are contained the “Commission Directive 2005/28/EC of 8 April 2005 laying down principles and detailed for good clinical practice as regards investigational medicinal products for human use, well as the for authorisation of manufacturing or importation of such (also known as the Good Practice or GCP for short). This document provides concrete guidelines and lends further support to the Clinical Trials Directive. The London-based European Agency (EMA) has published additional, specific guidelines which must also be respected. These include guidelines on procedures and requirements related to quality, safety and efficacy. Copies of the above-mentioned documents in 22 languages can be found http://ec.europa.eu/enterprise/pharmaceuticals/clinicaltrials/clinicaltrials_en.htm protection of people participating in clinical trials (and in cases other types of research) is further promoted by provisions of: - the European Convention Human Rights and Biomedicine (Oviedo Convention, 2619/1998), - the Additional protocol to the Oviedo Convention Biomedical Research - the Nuremberg Code of 1949, - the revised Helsinki Declaration of the World Medical Association regarding Ethical for Medical Research Involving Human Subjects, - The Belmont Report of 18 April on Ethical Principles and Guidelines for the Protection of Human Subjects of Research. are the different phases of trials? an experimental drug or medical procedure usually an extremely lengthy process, sometimes lasting several years. The overall procedure divided into a series of stages (known as phases) which are described below. Clinical testing on can only begin after a pre-clinical phase, involving studies (in vitro) and tests on animals, which shown that the experimental drug is considered safe and effective. Whilst a amount of testing can be carried out by means of computer modelling and by isolating cells it becomes necessary at some point in time to test the drug on a living creature. Animal testing is an obligatory stage in the process of obtaining regulatory approval for new drugs and medicines, hence a legal requirement (EU Directive 2001/83/EC relating to Products for Human Use). The necessity of out prior testing on animals is also stated in the World Association’s “Ethical Principles for Medical Research Involving Human Subjects. In order to protect the well-being of animals, researchers are guided by three principles which are called the 3Rs: Reduce the number of animals used to a minimum Refine way that experiments carried out so that the effect on the animal is minimised and animal welfare is improved Replace animal experiments with alternative techniques wherever possible. In addition, most will have official bodies which control animal research. Most animals research are mice. However, no animal is sufficiently similar (even genetically modified to make human testing unnecessary. For this reason, experimental must also be tested on humans. The main phases of clinical trials trials humans can be into three main phases (literally, phase I, II and III). phase has specific objectives (please see below) and number of people involved increases as the trial progresses from one phase to the next. Phase I trials Phase trials are usually the first in testing a new drug or treatment

Alzheimer Europe would like to recall some general which guide present response: - Having a gene associated with Alzheimer's disease or another form of dementia does not mean that a person has the disease. - People who have a gene linked to Alzheimer's disease or form of have the rights as anyone - Genetic testing not only affect the person taking the test. It may also reveal information about relatives who might not want to know. No genetic test 100% accurate. - The extent to which health cover is provided to citizens by the State social security system and/or privately by individuals differs from one country to the next. the of these principles, Europe has developed following position with regard to genetic testing: - Alzheimer Europe firmly believes that the use and/or possession of genetic information insurance companies should be prohibited. - Alzheimer Europe supports research into genetic factors linked to dementia which might our understanding of cause and development the disease and possibly contribute to future treatment. - on its current information, Alzheimer does not encourage the use of any genetic test for dementia UNLESS such has a high and proven success rate either in assessing the risk of the disease (or not as the case may be) or in detecting the existence of it in a particular individual. - Europe requests further information on the accuracy, reliability and predictive value of any genetic dementia. - Genetic testing should be accompanied by adequate pre- and post-test counselling. - Anonymous testing should be possible so that ensure that such information does not in their medical files against their will. It is extremely important for people dementia to be diagnosed as soon as possible. In the Alzheimer’s disease, an early diagnosis may enable the person concerned to benefit from medication, which treats the global symptoms of the disease and is most effective in the early to mid stages of the disease. Most forms of dementia involve deterioration of faculties (e.g. memory, language and thinking etc.) but in the early stages, it still possible for the person affected to make decisions finances and care etc. – hence the of an early diagnosis. If it were to detect dementia before the symptoms became obvious, this would give people a greater opportunity to make informed decisions about their lives. This is one of the potential benefits of genetic testing. On the other hand, such information could clearly be used in ways which would be contrary to their personal interests, perhaps resulting in employment discrimination, loss of opportunities, stigmatisation, health insurance costs or even loss of health to name but a examples. The present discussion paper some of the recommendations of Alzheimer and its member organisations and raises few points which deserve clarification and The necessity for a response by Alzheimer Europe In the last few years, the issue of genetic testing has been increasingly debated. In certain European there are already companies offering such tests. Unfortunately, the general public do not always fully understand what the results of such tests imply and there are no regulations governing they are carried out what kind information people receive, how the results are presented, whether there is any kind of counselling afterwards and the issue of confidentiality etc. In order to provide to people with dementia other people interesting in knowing their own state of health and in order to protect them from the unscrupulous use of the results of genetic tests, Alzheimer Europe has developed the present Paper. These general principles as well as the Convention of Human Rights Biomedicine and the Universal Declaration on the and Human Rights Alzheimer Europe’s position with regard to genetic testing. 3aa2f4a9ad014c3554eec8c17f1b20cbb0ecf410: The scientific world is abuzz with news of the of the existence of the subatomic particle called the boson or more colloquially, the 'God This subatomic particle's existence which was verified (with virtually near certainty) by experiments the Large Hadron Collider in Switzerland - lends credence physical theories such as so-called Standard Model and the Big Bang Theory. Humans, with their remarkable tools and their remarkable brains, may have just taken a giant step toward replacing metaphysical speculation with empirically verifiable knowledge. 651c42054843af9a0eeecdb207c668eeea471927: against a dangerous and costly backdrop, clear team communication is obviously essential to create a safe, productive and effective work environment on the ramp. operators and wing walkers need to warn each other of impending The tractor operator needs to keep the deck ground And all ground personnel should at least be able to hear the flight deck each other during a pushback. Ramp workers can do much more without the wire, the shouting or the hand signals. A typical wireless pushback towing uses a portable transceiver for communication among one or more wing walkers and the tractor operator during movement. The tractor operator is free to concentrate on correct and all crew members can warn others instantly impending dangers. To the flow communication and chatter, the system is configured so that all team can hear the pilot, but the tractor operator can directly to the flight deck. Because wireless communication increases coordination and enables verbal warnings, it decreases the risk of accidents, shortens turn-around times, increases the likelihood of hitting flight slots. In addition pushbacks and towing, wireless team communication systems can also used to improve safety and efficiency deicing, cargo and maintenance In a deicing a wireless system connects driver and the basket, and the system itself can be connected to two-way radios enabling communication with remote users. Communication between the driver and the basket takes on open microphone over 1.9GHz (1.8GHz in EU) encrypted frequency while also allowing radio monitoring and transmitting with a push to-talk button on the headsets. Systems can configured to enable multiple crews to communicate while working on the same aircraft - improving efficiency. Additional configurations are available for maintenance teams and are to almost any size. Choosing a Communication System Wireless headset systems are available in a wide variety of configurations and price ranges. To ensure a system meets the diverse needs of ground consider the following factors Is the system truly number of so-called “wireless” systems actually require a wire from the headset to a radio or belt pack. While these systems allow freedom of movement, a belt pack or radio wire creates many of the same problems systems, particularly cords. Moreover, belt packs have less than half the transmission range of self-contained systems on head. Does the system use DECT or Bluetooth technology? Transmission technology can dramatically affect how well systems perform in the field. Systems that employ Bluetooth technology generally have a limited range and are subject to radio frequency interference from nearby devices. Look for systems that use Digital Enhanced Cordless Telecommunications technology. DECT units generally offer up to 30 times more coverage and are less to interference than Bluetooth. DECT transmissions also have multipath capability, the signal will bounce up, over and around objects in order to establish the best possible connection. DECT signals are also digitally encoded to ensure privacy. Is the system full-duplex or half-duplex? Half-duplex systems communication in both directions, but only one direction at a time. That’s a walkie-talkie. On the hand, full-duplex systems allow communication in both directions simultaneously. Full-duplex capabilities are an important safety because they allow the parties to speak and others at same time. Is the system radio-compatible? during pushback and towing is generally to the flight deck, wing and tractor operator; however, other ground support functions from the ability to communicate with remote users over two-way radio. Look for a system with radio-interface flexibility.

Their appearance was so unusual that a farmer not particularly interested called parents and said that a whole flock big white birds had appeared his pasture, and we went up to take look. I in college before I learned that they were Cattle Egrets, BUBULCUS IBIS. My ornithology teacher told how the birds were undergoing one of the fastest and most widely ranging expansions of distribution seen among birds. Originally Egrets were native to southern Spain and Portugal, tropical and subtropical Africa and humid tropical and subtropical Asia. In the late 1800s they began expanding their range into southern Africa, and were first sighted in the on the boundary of and Suriname, in 1877, apparently having flown across the Atlantic Ocean. They didn't get permanently established there until the 1930s, though, but then they began into much of the rest of the Americas, reaching western Kentucky around the early 60s. According to U.S. Department of Energy's Energy Savers website, radiant heating "is more efficient than baseboard heating and usually more efficient than forced-air heating because no energy is through ducts." And radiant heating is a good choice for those with severe allergies no potentially irritating particles get blown around the room. Several aspects of radiant heating make it energy efficient. For starters, the uniform heat distribution over the entire surface of a floor the lower of the room, enveloping inhabitants in warmth at a lower overall temperature — in some cases up five degrees cooler — than a conventional heating system. "Radiators and other of 'point' heating circulate heat inefficiently and hence need to run for longer periods to comfort levels," reports the Residential Energy Services Network (RESNet). draw cold air across the floor and warm up to the ceiling, where it then falls, the room from the top down, creating drafts and circulating dust and allergens." RESNet adds that radiant systems transmit heat average some 15 percent efficiently than conventional radiators. According to TLC Network's Green Living Guide, there are two main types of radiant heating, electric and hydronic. In the former, heated wires installed in the floor radiate heat upward. This type of radiant heat is most commonly used to retrofit a single room — especially a bathroom or kitchen — in an older house or building. Meanwhile, hydronic radiant heating, whereby heated water is forced through under the floor, is more often designed into a new structure get-go and is more energy efficient overall. d29be511388e3cb9bf843eeffbdddf59f7fa1a21: Multistate Outbreak of Human Salmonella Chester Infections (Final Update) Posted September 9, This outbreak appears to be over. Salmonella is an important cause of human illness in the United States. information about Salmonella, and steps people take to reduce their risk of infection, can be found on the CDC Salmonella Web Page. Persons Infected with the Outbreak of Salmonella Chester, United State Infections with the Outbreak Strain of Salmonella Chester, by Week of Illness CDC with public health officials in many states, U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS), and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate a multistate outbreak of Salmonella serotype Chester infections. Investigators used DNA analysis Salmonella bacteria obtained through testing to identify cases of that were part of this outbreak. As of AM EDT on August 27, 2010, a total of 44 individuals infected with a matching strain of Salmonella Chester have been reported from 18 states since 11, 2010. The number of ill people identified in state with this strain is follows: AK (1), CA (5), CO (2), GA (8), (1), KY MA (2), MN (2), MO (1), NC (1), OK (1), OR (2), SC TN (1), TX (3), UT (3), VA (4), and WA (4). Among those for whom information is available when started, illnesses began between April 4, 2010 June 16, 2010. ranged age from <1 to 88 years old, the median age was years. Fifty-four percent of patients were female. Among the 43 patients with available information, 16 (37%) were hospitalized. No deaths were reported. The can be visually described with a chart showing the number of who became ill each day. This chart is called epidemic curve or epi curve. For more details, please see the Salmonella Outbreak Investigations: Timeline for Reporting Cases. Investigation of the Outbreak A widely distributed contaminated food might cause illnesses the United States. The of the contaminated product often is not readily apparent. In outbreaks like this one, identification of the contaminated product requires conducting detailed interviews with persons who were ill. It may also require conducting interviews with non-ill members the public ("controls") to get information about foods eaten other exposures to compare with information from the ill persons. The is often supplemented by testing of products. Collaborative investigative efforts of officials in local, state, and federal public health, agriculture, and regulatory linked this outbreak to Marie Callender’s Cheesy Chicken & Rice frozen entrées. During June 14-18, 2010, CDC and public health multiple states conducted an epidemiologic study by eaten by ill and well Analysis of this study suggested that eating a Marie Callender's frozen meal was a source of illness. Ill (89%) were significantly more likely than well persons (14%) to report eating a frozen meal. All ill persons (100%) who ate frozen meals reported eating a Marie None of the well persons who ate a frozen meal reported eating a Marie Callender's frozen meal. There was insufficient data from this study to a specific frozen meal type. However, many of the persons reported eating a Marie Callender's Cheesy Chicken & frozen entrée in the week before becoming ill. Additionally, two unopened packages of Marie Callender’s Cheesy Chicken & Rice single-serve frozen entrées from two patients’ homes (one collected in Minnesota on June 18, and one in Tennessee on 19) yielded Salmonella Chester isolates with a genetic indistinguishable from the outbreak pattern. On June 2010, ConAgra Foods announced precautionary recall of Callender's Cheesy Chicken & Rice frozen entrées after being informed by the CDC of a possible association between this product and the outbreak Salmonella Chester infections. June 17, FSIS announced recall. View recalled package [PDF - 6 pages] posted by FSIS. Clinical Features/Signs and Symptoms Most people infected with Salmonella develop diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps 12–72 hours infection. Infection is usually diagnosed by culture of a stool sample. The illness usually lasts 4 7 days. Although most people recover without treatment, severe can occur. Infants, elderly people, and those with weakened immune systems more likely than others to develop severe illness. When severe infection occurs, Salmonella may spread from the intestines to the bloodstream and then to other body and can cause unless the is treated promptly with antibiotics. Mo

The term reality, in its widest sense, includes everything is, whether observable, comprehensible, self-contradictory by science, philosophy, or any other system of analysis. Reality in this sense may include both being and nothingness, whereas existence is often restricted to being (compare with nature). In strict sense of Western philosophy, there are levels or gradation to the nature and of reality. These levels include, from the most subjective to the rigorous: phenomenological reality, truth, fact, and axiom. 29aa4767fcf3fc799068b2c22f3ca7486662ded9: In American electoral system, a primary is that determines the nominee for each political party, who then competes for the in general election. A presidential primary is a state election that picks the delegates committed to nominate particular candidates for president of the United States. A presidential caucus, as in Iowa, requires voters meet together for several hours in face-to-face meetings that select county delegates, who eventually pick the delegates to the national convention. No other country uses they choose their candidates in party Primaries were introduced the Progressive Era in the early 20th century to weaken the power of bosses and make the system more democratic. In presidential elections, they important starting in 1952, when first-in-the-nation New Primary Dwight D. the Republican and knocked Harry S. Truman of the race because of his poor 1964, Lyndon B. Johnson ended his reelection campaign after doing poorly in New Hampshire. After 1968, both parties changed their rules to emphasize presidential primaries, although some states still use the caucus system. In decades, New Hampshire holds the first primary a few days after Iowa holds first caucus. That gives these two states enormous leverage, as the candidates and the media focus there. New Hampshire and Iowa receive about half of all the attention all primaries. The primary allows voters to choose between different candidates of the some political parties, representing different wings of the party. For example, a Republican primary may choose between a range candidates moderate to conservative. 4bcfc177812c2431a94fe27dc4c192ec44f9390d: 2 Products Found |Results per page: 24 48 72|| In terms of ecologically friendly flooring, bamboo is one of the top contenders. Not only is flooring made from totally renewable but it also is available in a wide of options. For those who desire the look hardwood flooring but are concerned about the environmental consequences of harvesting trees, bamboo offers the perfect solution. bamboo is not technically wood flooring, its appearance is close to fool even the most discerning eye. Why is Bamboo Flooring Considered Environmentally Friendly? Although bamboo is actually a type of grass, it is harder than red oak. It reaches full maturity in just 3 to 5 years rather than several decades and appears naturally the need for replanting. Harvesting bamboo is actually somewhat required because it is so hardy that leaving it to its own devices would put a strain the environment. would be terrible shame to waste the harvested material, so people have designed many ways to put it to good use from thatched roofs to flooring Bamboo also no requirements for irrigation, fertilizers, or pesticides when grown in its natural environment. Bamboo is naturally resistant to insects and The lack of need for harsh chemicals during its growth only does more to keep the carbon footprint down. How is Bamboo Flooring Manufactured? There are several involved in a material suitable flooring from bamboo. Upon harvest, the is boiled to remove its natural starches and which could become a wonderful for termites not The outer skin is then removed and the is cut into strips for flooring. These strips are boiled again to make them even or the longer the carbonation process, the darker the color of the final product. When the strips are ready they are into either by gluing strips together or gluing a single layer of strips on top of another solid surface, resulting in either solid bamboo flooring or engineered bamboo flooring respectively. The flooring also through processes to strengthen further by applying laminate materials to increase scratch resistance. What the design options with flooring? - flooring is available in widths ranging from ž inches to 7 inches and thicknesses 5/8 inches and 9/16 inches. - Finish options for bamboo flooring are from unfinished and natural from the FSC Unfinished Bamboo collection to nearly black and a choice of either horizontal or graining as in the FSC Designer collection. - The two edge types of bamboo flooring are micro-beveled edges and square edges. Bamboo is also available in floating floor and nail or glue down styles. How Durable Bamboo Flooring? Bamboo is naturally and durable, and process it goes through during the flooring only increases this strength. While one should sliding furniture across the floor or allowing water to stand, flooring will do well in most low moisture room. Bamboo from the EcoBamboo to the FSC Prestige Collection will be an investment beauty and durability that is sure to add value to any with minimal environmental impact.
b259b5f97b7b7179ec3e761eb914917b638ca4f5: By Karen Kaplan 5:53 PM EST, January 30, 2013 Attention dieters: of the you think you know about obesity and weight are So a report published in edition of the New England Journal of Medicine. An international team of dietitians, doctors and other examined more than a dozen ideas about obesity are widely believed to be true but aren’t actually supported by reliable medical evidence. dieters who buy into these mistaken notions, note – much of this incorrect wisdom is espoused by physicians, academic scientists, government agencies and the media. Seven of these errant ideas as “myths,” meaning they are “beliefs held to be true despite substantial refuting evidence.” Another six were as “presumptions,” or held to be true for which convincing evidence does not yet confirm or disprove truth.” Without ado, let’s get to the Eating a little less exercising a little more will lead to large weight time, as as those behaviors are sustained. This myth is on the idea 3,500 calories are equal one pound. That equation was based on short-term experiments. In the long-term, the body compensates in various ways that slow down loss. For instance, the equation predicts that a person who burns extra per day will lose more than 50 pounds over five years; in reality, that exercise regimen cause a to shed about 10 pounds (assuming calorie intake remains the same). It’s to set realistic weight-loss goals so dieters don’t frustrated. Studies that examined reasonable-sounding have found that having realistic goals has no impact on the amount of weight lost. Indeed, some studies have found that those who set the most ambitious goals lost the weight, even if they fell short of initial expectations. gradual weight loss is easier to sustain than large, rapid loss. In fact, clinical have found that people who jump-start their diets by dropping a lot of weight in the beginning (by consuming only 800 to 1,200 calories per day, for instance) had the best results long-term studies. In order to help someone lose weight, gauge their readiness to a diet. Experimental evidence shows that readiness isn’t related to diet results. School P.E. classes help reduce prevent childhood obesity. While there is certainly some amount of physical education that would help fight childhood obesity, classes in their current form have not shown to reduce BMI or obesity in kids on a consistent basis. Babies who are breast-fed are less likely become obese. you think this is true, you’re in good company – the World Health Organization presented this “fact” in one of its reports. 6a48ac00f56198abff241e9d2d78e8df0a1f1d24: Dinosaur Bones "Buried" By Evolutionists! A recent presentation at the 2012 Western Pacific Geophysics meeting in Singapore showed C-14 dates of soft tissue found in bones to be in the range from 22,000 - 39,000 years old. Previously, it has been assumed dinosaurs died out over million years ago, so these new findings are astonishing and should have made international news. But shortly after the presentation was made at meeting, the abstract removed from the meeting’s website! So it appears that instead of making international news, these findings have been buried. let’s look at was actually being presented. The organic matter (collagen) and hard carbonate bone mineral (bioapatite) in the bone samples were analyzed. The samples came from several species of dinosaurs (acrocanthosaur, hadrosaurus, triceratops and apatosaurus) taken from sites in Colorado, Arkansas and Montana. samples were meticulously handled and cleaned to avoid possible contamination. The levels in these samples were measured using Accelerator Mass Spectrometry (AMS). The resultant C-14 ages obtained from these consistently in the - 39,000 years range. The fact that the samples were from a variety of species and sites all giving results greatly the chance that the results are from contamination. The theoretical upper limit for C-14 dating is ten times the half-life, or about 57,000 years. The proposed practical upper limit for C-14 dating is between 40,000 - 50,000 years. While some samples fell close to the 40,000 upper limit, 16 out of 20 (80%) were aged at 35,000 years or younger, well within the acceptable upper C-14 dating limits. While other researchers soft tissue in dinosaur and C-14 dates in these ranges, this current study has the most comprehensive. The fact that there is any collagen at all remaining these bone samples is amazing, considering that they are supposed to be older than 65 million years. Protein just doesn’t hang around And that there any in them also is reason to possibly question wisdom. But why have we not heard about any of this in the news? Shouldn't there have at least a 15-second blip from one of the media outlets? But the media have and the abstract pulled from the meeting The sacred cow of once again remains intact. We truly living in an great deception. for this cause God shall send them strong delusion, that they should a lie.” (2 Thessalonians This article, by Creation Moments board member Dr. Don Clark, is based an interview by Broken Road Radio. a82b1503ba0d741718e4e46006f7ee0123dc4dce: St. Francis, Animals and the Environment Dr. Marcellino D'Ambrosio often see a garden statue of with a bird on his Yes, St. Francis of Assisi did have a special relationship with animals. He preached to the birds, pacified wolf, and put together an animal cast for is regarded as the very first live nativity scene. But he had no interest in environment.” No feeling for it whatsoever. Instead, he love creation. And that’s because he was in love with the Creator, he not as some cosmic force or distant, detached monarch, but as “Father.” He so much loved God his Father that he had great affection for anything to God – the sacraments, the Church, its very imperfect ministers, down country chapels, of God’s marvelous works of art – beings first foremost, but also the animals and even the inanimate objects that adorn the heavens and the earth. The fondness for and kinship St. Francis felt with son sister moon” was truly a gift. But it is gift that we all receive when we receive the Holy Spirit since it is one of the seven gifts mentioned in 11:2-3. At this is how St. Thomas Aquinas and many after him explained this beautiful, supernatural gift of piety. The natural virtue of piety was extolled by the Greeks and Romans – a love of those who gave you life, first and foremost your parents and after them, fatherland. This entailed also a and affection for all that is connected with your parents and dear to as grandparents, uncles and aunts, and in the case of your country, its flag, its national anthem, its history and its heros. The term for piety towards one’s country is actually at its root, the term “pater” or “father.” St. Francis loved his home Assisi. But deeper patriotism was for the Kingdom of His affection for the Kingdom included respect and reverence for all the King’s creatures and subjects, they be or small. this does not mean that Francis saw all creatures as his equals, as some animal rights advocates today to do. One animal rights philosopher, Peter Singer, goes so far as to teach that adult whales and chimpanzees actually superior to human fetuses and infants in both dignity and value. He would save the whales but allow both abortion and infanticide. St. Francis would be appalled at such a concept. Biblical person that he was, he understood that and man are God’s supreme masterpieces, made in His image and likeness, unlike the animals. Human beings are given dominion over rest of in Genesis not to exploit however, but to cultivate, care for, and perfect. God entrusts Adam and Eve with “the environment,” but with “the – a place of beauty in which we made to walk with God. So St. Francis loves the but also presses them into service of the gospel. He saves the wolf Gubbio the wrath townspeople, but rebukes it for its ferocity and calls men and wolf to live everafter in harmony. And the animals the nativity scene? They are companions of the infant who is the made flesh. So the authentic biblical and Catholic approach to “the environment” is not to see it and scientifically as “the environment.” But rather, in the fashion of Francis, approach it as the expression of the Father’s beauty, as gift of the Father’s love, as icon, a window to the new creation. Reckless exploitation would never fit with such a vision. neither would some secular environmentalism. Follow - us on Facebook Join us on Twitter Dr. D’Ambrosio writes from Texas. Free vs Proprietary: When you hear the phrase "free software" or "free software license," "free" referring to your rights and permissions ("free as in freedom" or "free as in free speech"). In other words, a free software gives you more than a proprietary license. You can usually copy, modify, redistribute free software without paying a fee or obtaining permission from the and distributors. In cases "free software" won't cost you anything, but that's not always case – in this instance the word free is making no assertion whatsoever about the price of the software. Proprietary software puts more and limits on your permission to copy, modify, and distribute the program. Free, Open-Source or everyday conversation, there's not much difference between "free software," "open source software," and "FOSS (Free and Open-Source Software)." In other words, you'll hear these terms used interchangeably, the proponents of free software and the of open-source software agree with one another on most issues. However, the official definition free software differs somewhat the official definition of open-source software, and the philosophies underlying those definitions differ well. For a short description of the difference, read Live and Let License. For a longer discussion from the "free software" side, Why Open Source Misses the Point Software. For the "open-source" perspective, read Why Free Software is Too Ambiguous. Public domain and copyleft. These terms refer to different categories of free, unrestricted A copyleft license allows you the freedoms of a free software license, but adds restriction. a copyleft license, you have to release any modifications the same terms the original software. In effect, this blocks companies and developers who want to alter software and then make their version proprietary. In practice, almost all free and open-source software is also copylefted. However, technically release "free software" that isn't copylefted. For example, if you developed software and released it under a domain" license, it would as free software, but it isn't copyleft. In effect, you release the public domain, you give up all copyrights and rights of ownership. Shareware and freeware. Policosanol is a natural mixture of higher primary aliphatic alcohols isolated and purified from sugar cane (Saccharum officinarum, wax, whose main component is octacosanol but contains hexacosanol (C26:0) and triacontanol or melissyl alcohol (C30:0). Policosanol is also extracted from a diversity of other natural sources such as beeswax, rice wheat germ (Irmak S et al., Food Chem 2006, 95, 312) is also present in the fruits, leaves, and surfaces of plants and whole seeds. A complex policosanol mixture been identified in peanut et al., J Agric Food Chem 2010, 58, 12143). More than 20 alcohols were identified (C14-C30) and four unsaturated alcohols (C20-24). The total policosanol content of the whole peanut samples varied from 11 to 54 mg/100 g of oil. This mixture was shown to have cholesterol-lowering effects in rabbits (Arruzazabala ML et al., Biol Res 27, 205). Octacosanol was also able to suppress lipid in rats fed on a high-fat diet (Kato S et al., Br 1995, 73, 433) and to inhibit platelet aggregation (Arruzazabala ML et al., Thromb Res 1993, 69, 321). 2e7a827bf00bd9af37105db1cc8867141ae53aff: in October 2006, some beekeepers began reporting losses of 30-90 percent of their hives. While colony losses are not unexpected during winter weather, the magnitude of loss suffered by some beekeepers was highly unusual. This phenomenon, which does not have a recognizable underlying cause, has been termed Collapse Disorder" (CCD). The main symptom of CCD is simply no a low number of adult bees present but with live queen and no dead honey bees in the hive. Often is still honey in the hive, and immature bees (brood) present. ARS scientists others in the process of carrying out research to discover the of CCD and develop ways for beekeepers to respond to the problem. Why the public care about bees? Bee pollination is responsible for $15 added crop value, particularly for specialty crops such as and other nuts, berries, fruits, and vegetables. About one mouthful in three in the diet directly or indirectly benefits from honey bee pollination. While there are native pollinators (honey bees came from the World with European colonists), bees are more prolific and the easiest to manage for large scale pollination that U.S. agriculture requires. In California, the almond crop alone uses 1.3 million colonies of bees, approximately one half of honey bees in the United States, and this need is projected to grow 1.5 million colonies by 2010. The number of managed honey bee colonies has dropped from 5 million in to only 2.5 million today. At the same time, the call hives to supply pollination service has continued to climb. means honey bee colonies are trucked farther and more often before. Honey bee colony has also been declining since the 1980s with the advent of pathogens and pests. The spread into the United of varroa and tracheal mites, in particular, created major new on honey bees. Is there currently a crisis food production because of CCD? While CCD has created a very serious problem for beekeepers and could threaten the pollination industry if it becomes more widespread, fortunately there were enough bees to all needed pollination this past spring. But we cannot wait to see if CCD an agricultural crisis to do needed research into the cause and treatment for The cost of hives for pollination has risen this year. Case studies and questionnaires related to management practices and environmental identified a few common factors shared by experiencing CCD, but environmental agents or chemicals stand out causative. There are three major possibilities that looked by researchers. Pesticides may be having unexpected negative effects on honey bees. A new or pathogen may attacking honey bees. One possible candidate being looked at a pathogenic gut microbe called Nosema. Viruses are also A perfect storm of may have unexpectedly weakened colonies to collapse. Stress, in general, compromises the immune system of (and other social insects) and disrupt their social more susceptible to disease. These stresses could include high levels of infection by the varroa mite (a parasite that feeds bee blood and transmits bee viruses); poor nutrition due to apiary overcrowding, pollination of with low nutritional value, or pollen or nectar scarcity; and to or contaminated water supplies. Migratory stress about by needs for pollination might also a factor. Has ever happened before? f0bb5722197fc09b827adb8ff0d4ed1f6b352964: Oct. 17, 2006 Updated: Apr. 20, 2010 Two-and-a-half-year-old was bright-eyed bouncy, full of laughter and hugs when you could get her attention. She often seemed to be ignoring her parents when they spoke to her, and when she did respond, many her words were slurred. Concerned, parents arranged a hearing -- and that Nina had moderate hearing loss in both ears. Outfitted with a hearing aid, and provided with speech therapy, she is just beginning to regain some the ground she lost during the first of life when important language skills are being learned. "Hearing impairment is the largest congenital disability, affecting about six out of every 1,000 infants," says Duke pediatric audiologist Ann Mabie. "For a very long time, people thought you couldn't test infants' hearing, and would just wait until children were two or three old. But by the time wait for children not to talk, a window of opportunity has shut." In fact, those tiny, shell-like that parents marvel over when getting to know their new babies are just the most visible parts of a highly sophisticated machine. Human infants spend the first year of life learning about their environment, and by one year of age, already understand far more language than they are yet able -- unless an hearing impairment disrupts process. While hearing impairments are difficult at any age, they’re especially devastating in young children, because their brains rely on auditory stimulation to develop the capacity for oral communication. This makes early diagnosis and treatment of childhood hearing losses essential. Happily, all newborns in North Carolina now have access to the specialized screening to diagnose infants with hearing loss, thanks to state legislation passed in October 1999. Even babies born with normal hearing, however, can develop a hearing loss later in infancy or childhood, due to ear infections or head injuries. So parents should of clues that their might have difficulty hearing and on tests if they suspect hearing (see below). f44e03b0e835c27aa6e9277dd52743d041f0f84b: 1. Linguistic Background The languages that spoken in the Pacific region can be divided broadly into groups: the Guinean languages formed by people who participated in earliest migrations over a period of 20,000-30,000 years starting several tens of thousands of years ago, the Austronesian languages spoken by Mongoloid people who migrated from the Asian continent around 3,000 B.C. The region has numerous languages, including 250 Aboriginal languages in Australia and Papuan languages on the island of New Guinea (including Indonesian territory of Irian Jaya) and neighboring areas. are also 350 Austronesian languages in Melanesia, 20 in 12 in and 100 in New Guinea (Comrie, Matthews, Polinsky 1996). There is wide variation not only among language groups, but also among the families of languages. Few language families have been identified among the languages of Australia and New Guinea using the methods of comparative linguistics. languages are also characterized by the small size of speaker populations and by the absence of dominant languages. However, there are usually bilingual people who can speak or at least understand languages of neighboring populations, and it is believed that this situation has existed for a long time. In terms of factors, it appears that the diversification of languages in the Pacific region by the emblematic function of language in the creation of a clear distinction between “ingroup” and “outgroup.” The of New Guinea and the region around it diverse linkages and wide variations between languages. The Austronesian languages the Pacific region are mostly classified as Oceanian languages, while the and Palau of Micronesia are classified into the languages of Western Malaya and Polynesia (WMP, Indonesian family), and the indigenous languages Maluku Irian Jaya in Eastern Indonesia into the (CMP) or the South Halmahera-West New Guinea (SHWNG) subgroups. In particular, there are strong similarities between the characteristics of the CMP and SHWNG languages and those the Melanesian of the Oceanian languages. These linguistic conditions characteristics are attributable to ethnic migrations within the region over long period time, accompanied by contacts and linguistic merging with indigenous Papuan people. Papuan languages are still found in parts of Indonesia, including Northern Halmahera and the islands Pantar and Alor and central eastern Timor the Province of Nusa Tenggara. In New Guinea, contact with languages has caused some Austronesian languages to exhibit a word order from subject-verb-object to subject-object-verb (Austronesian Type 2) (Sakiyama 1994). 2. Linguistic Strata With the of colonization by the European powers in the nineteenth century, a new set of linguistic circumstances developed in region. First, pidgin based on European and Melanesian languages gradually emerged as common languages. The establishment of plantations in Samoa and Queensland, Australia, which had concentrations of people who spoke Melanesian languages, was important in breeding grounds for pidgin languages. A pidgin language is formed from elements of the grammar of both languages, though the pidgin languages tend to be looked down upon from the perspective of the more dominant of the two parent languages. The region’s newly formed common languages, including Tok Pisin, Bislama, and Solomon Pidgin, flourished after they were back to the homelands of the various speakers. This was possible because Vanuatu, the Solomon Islands and Papua New Guinea were all multilingual societies without dominant languages. The number of speakers of pidgin languages increased in this environment. At the same time, continuing existence of ethnic languages came under threat. Examples of pidgins that were creolized (adopted as mother in their own right) include Solomon Pijin, which eventually had speakers aged five and over (1976) in the Solomon Islands. Bislama, a mixture of over 100 indigenous languages grafted upon a base of English and is now spoken by almost the entire population of Vanuatu (170,000 in 1996) and is partially creolized. Of particular interest is the fact a group of more than 1,000 people who emigrated New Caledonia have adopted as their primary language. The situation in Papua New Guinea, which has a population of 4,300,000 is even more dramatic. By 1982 the number of people using Tok Pisin as their primary language had reached 50,000, while another used it as a second language (Grimes 1996). 3. 5f3e904465a3c0998d482709cd75e0bc49affecf: Moderate-Intensity Aerobic Activity Aerobic fitness means increasing how well the body oxygen, which depends on the condition of the heart, lungs, and muscles. Experts tend to describe aerobic in three ways: light, moderate, and people do moderate-intensity activities, notice a faster heartbeat. To get the benefits of moderate activity, a person goal of aerobic fitness is to increase the of oxygen that goes to the heart and muscles, allows them to work longer. Any activities, of daily activities, that raise the heart rate and keep it up for an period of time can improve aerobic fitness. If the activities done and long enough, they can help fitness. Experts recommend adults try to do moderate activity for least 2½ hours a week. Or they can do vigorous activity at least 1¼ hours a week. People choose to do one or both types of activity. And it's fine to be active in blocks of 10 minutes more throughout the day and week. Teens and children (starting at age 6) should do moderate to vigorous activity at least 1 hour every day. 96ae057d503d114d798ad23aa7bc4e1ef8b946ac: the energy [r]evolution The climate change imperative demands nothing of an Energy [R]evolution. The expert consensus is that fundamental shift must begin immediately and be well underway the next ten years in order to avert the worst impacts. What is needed is a complete transformation of the way we produce, consume and distribute energy, while at the same time maintaining economic growth. Nothing short of such a revolution will enable us to limit global warming to less than a rise in temperature of 2° Celsius, above which the impacts become devastating. Current generation relies mainly on burning fossil fuels, with associated CO2 emissions, in very large power stations which waste much of their primary energy. More energy is lost the power is moved around the electricity grid network and converted from high down to a supply suitable for domestic or commercial consumers. The system is innately to disruption: technical, weather-related or even deliberately caused faults can quickly cascade, resulting in widespread blackouts. Whichever is used generate within this old fashioned configuration, it will inevitably be subject to some, or all, these problems. At the core of the Energy [R]evolution there therefore needs to be a in the that energy is both produced and distributed. 4.1 key principles the energy [r]evolution can be by adhering to five key principles: 1.respect natural limits – phase out fossil fuels by the of this century We must respect natural There is only so much carbon that the can absorb. Each year humans emit over 25 billion tonnes of carbon equivalent; we are literally filling up the sky. resources of coal could provide several hundred years of fuel, but we cannot burn them and keep within safe limits. Oil and coal development must ended. The global Energy [R]evolution scenario has a target to reduce energy related CO2 emissions to a maximum of 10 Gigatonnes (Gt) by 2050 and phase fossil fuels by 2.equity and As long as there are natural limits there needs to be a fair distribution of benefits and costs within societies, between nations and between present and future At extreme, a third of the world’s population no access to electricity, whilst the most industrialised countries consume much more than their The effects of climate change on poorest communities are exacerbated by massive global energy inequality. If we are to address climate change, one of the core principles must be equity and fairness, so that benefits of energy services such as light, heat, and transport – are available for all: north and south, rich and poor. Only in this can we create energy as as the conditions for genuine wellbeing. Advanced Energy [R]evolution has target to achieve energy equity as soon as possible. By 2050 the average per capita emission should be between 1 and 2 of CO2. 3.implement clean, renewable solutions and decentralise energy systems. There no energy shortage. we to do use existing technologies to harness energy effectively and efficiently. Renewable energy energy efficiency measures are ready, viable and increasingly competitive. Wind, solar and energy technologies have experienced double digit market growth for the decade. Just as climate change is real, so is the renewable energy sector. Sustainable decentralised energy produce less carbon emissions, are cheaper and involve dependence on imported fuel. They create more jobs and empower local communities. Decentralised systems are more secure and more efficient. This is what the [R]evolution must aim to create. To stop earth’s climate spinning out of control, most of the world’s fossil fuel – coal, oil and gas must remain in the ground. Our goal is for humans to live the natural of small planet. 4.decouple growth from fossil fuel use Starting in the developed countries, economic growth must be fully decoupled from fossil fuel usage. It is to suggest that economic growth must be predicated on their increased combustion. to use the energy we produce more efficiently, and we need to make the transition to renewable energy and away from fossil fuels quickly in order to enable clean and sustainable growth. 5.phase dirty, unsustainable energyWe to phase out coal and nuclear power. We cannot continue to build coal plants at a time when emissions pose and present danger to both ecosystems and people. And we cannot continue to fuel the myriad nuclear threats by nuclear power can any way to combat climate change. There is no role for nuclear power in the [R]evolution.

The team, led Dr. Harry Mobley, Ph.D., screened 5,379 possible bacterial proteins and identified three strong candidates to use in a vaccine to prime the body to E. coli, the cause of most uncomplicated urinary tract infections. a9e66398e1ad4036a86cc19521d8f6862620444f: The exercise and nutrition program, created by Ori Hofmekler, hinges a somewhat controversial diet based on a daily cycle of “undereating” during the day and “overeating” at night. The rationale that the historic “warrior”, in order succeed in the environment of the time, had a need to cycle between undereating the day (when activity and danger were always present), overeating night (when able to rest and eat a good daily meal). Modern humans in a changed environment can therefore restore health and fitness, by returning to that cycle with the Warrior Warrior Diet grounding The nervous system is the primary focus here, specifically that called the autonomic nervous system (ANS). Body organs such as the heart, and intestines (viscera), and muscles within these organs and other areas like blood vessels, skin, eyes, as well as the glands of the body, are regulated by the ANS. We are mostly unaware of its workings; for example, when blood vessels change size or heart beats faster, these functions are involuntary and reflexive in nature. The ANS has 3 parts - - The sympathetic nervous (SNS) which kicks in when emergencies occur, causing stress and requiring us to “fight” or take “flight” (flee) - The nervous system (PSNS) which operates in normal or nonemergency times, allowing us to “rest” and - The enteric nervous (ENS), present in all vertebrates, which regulates the normal digestive the digestive system and prepares it for whatever is coming, whether a meal or a frantic physical activity The undereating phase of the Warrior Diet is supposed and alert the to potential stress, resulting in the of energy and ultimately the of fat. While undereating, the body is forced to use fat storage as source of fuel for maximum metabolic efficiency – thus promoting weight-loss. The overeating phase Diet recognizes the role of the PSNS in regulating digestion, elimination and metabolic activities that slow you down. during the day stops this process blocks the body’s ability to remove toxins and waste from the body. Since detoxification is imperative for health and to delay aging, eating occurs mainly night. Warrior Diet program The program involves a Fat Loss Program exercise nutrition regimes. Fat Loss Program Fat program is specifically designed to - Force the body to detoxify - Improve of fat as fuel Improve utilization of carb as fuel This process helps to boost overall metabolic rate, thereby enhancing the body’s to fat loss. Exercise and Nutrition Programs Exercise and nutrition programs provide short, intense and aerobic exercises, along pre-workout and post-workout meals. This approach intends to reduce fat while maintaining or improving muscle The emphasis the Warrior Diet program is on having large evening meals on the one hand, shedding the “calorie counting” common to most diets on the other. 4b9c847d5d60c57931ef2bd437495720d167300e: If farmers are to increase food production and food security, they need better agricultural support such credit, technology, services and agricultural education, as well as to the rural organizations that often channel other services. In spite of their enormous and their crucial roles in agricultural production, women in particular have insufficient access to production inputs and support This trend underlines the need to implement measures aimed enhancing the access of small farmers, especially women, to production inputs - particularly since the working of development organizations changed as a result of market liberalization and a role for the worldwide. For example, field experiences the last decade have pointed the need for extension that are more strategically planned, needs-based, participatory and problem solving. Women's access to and use support is also severely limited the heavy burden on time and energy that results from their triple responsibilities - productive activities (such as in the fields), reproductive (such as child rearing, cooking household chores) community management. In order to improve production, farmers need access to financial capital. Buying seeds, and other agricultural inputs often requires short-term loans, which are repaid when are harvested. Installing major improvements, such as irrigation pumps, or acquiring new technology that increases future is without access to long-term credit. Smallholders, particularly women, often face difficulties in credit. This is a direct consequence of their access to land, participation development projects and extension programmes and membership in rural organizations, all of which are important channels for obtaining loans and credit information. In several countries sub-Saharan Africa, where farmers are roughly equal in number, it is estimated that women farmers receive only percent of the loans granted to smallholders and less than 1 percent of the total credit advanced to the agriculture sector. Credit delivery can be improved by up microfinance institutions in rural areas and the banking system to cater to the needs of small farmers, especially women. The Grameen Bank in Bangladesh, which first pioneered the microcredit approach in reaches more than 2 million people. Since it was founded, the bank has lent more than most of it in the form of loans of a few hundred dollars for small agriculture, distribution, crafts and trading enterprises. Numerous studies shown that women are generally more and punctual in repaying their loans than men are. A programme providing credit and nutrition for women improved both the participating women's incomes and children's nutritional status. This is conclusion of a study that examined the impact a and education programme run by the NGO from Hunger. Men and women smallholders suffer financially from limited access marketing that would allow to turn surplus produce into cash income. Women face difficulties because marketing infrastructure and organizations are rarely geared towards either small-scale producers or the crops that grow. Although women all over the world are active as traders, hawkers and street and market vendors, little has been done improve transport and market facilities to support this vital economic sector. Even where women an important role in wholesale trade, their full membership in marketing service institutions is still because they may be illiterate or lack independent legal status.
