fcc979386d44171f4b7609ebeb37997b1606b2f1: Catholic reformers the 16th century occasionally spoke scornfully of Anabaptists as "new monks," referring to Anabaptist insistence on holy living and intense spiritual life (e.g., TA Elsaß 1, 110-13). Anabaptists occasionally accepted the comparison (Klassen, William and Walter eds. and trans. The Writings of Marpeck, Classics of the Radical Reformation, vol. 2. Scottdale, PA: Herald Press, 1978: 217) but more frequently rejected it (Klassen Klaassen: 215-16; Menno, Writings, 369, 401), in part because monks often came from socially privileged classes. Several scholars have used monastic history as an aid to interpret Anabaptism (Troeltsch, Ritschl, Davis, Snyder, Martin). Many Anabaptists and Mennonites, beginning with the Hutterite pointed to quasi-monastic sectarian medieval movements, especially Waldenses, as forerunners of Anabaptism (these theories promulgated or discussed by Keller, Gratz, Verduin, One of the most extensive efforts to relate monasticism and Anabaptism drew both and quasi-monastic traditions (Davis). Most scholars have carefully limited their interpretations to pointing out "intellectual parallels" or general similarities; some have argued direct continuity and influence. The crucial interpretive question revolves around the nature of is it a nonconforming sectarian critical of the institutional church (Workman) or an intensified institutional of the ecclesiastical establishment? Or, did monasticism begin as charismatic, lay, "sectarian" in the century but become fully integrated into the sacramental, ecclesial, institutional church by the early Middle Ages (Rousseau, Martin)? How central the critical, separatist aspect of early monasticism is to monastic identity is disputed, even by those within the community (Eoin de Bhaldraithe). Particularly significant in this regard is distinction between contemplative monastic (Benedictine, Carthusian) more lay-oriented, urban mendicant orders and houses regular canons of the Middle Ages (Franciscans, Augustinian Friars, Praemonstratensians, Augustinian Canons). The latter orders were associated with the class and were visibly and pastorally active; the former were often but not associated with the nobility and lived in secluded and rural areas. Most Anabaptist links to to have been with mendicants and canons regular. Michael Sattler is the exception to this generalization. Most agree that Anabaptists rejected the sacramental and institutional "culture-church" of the Middle Ages in favor of a voluntary, non-institutionalized, even anti-clerical church of the faithful few, in effect, reducing the church to a devout "monastic" core. At issue among scholars is whether the label "monastic" should properly be applied to sectarian, pure church vision as that held Anabaptists, since most monks did not believe that church was made up solely of monastics, rather, they believed that monks and nuns were part, perhaps the most important of the church. The qualities and virtues prized by Anabaptists and Mennonites (hospitality, humility, community, Gelassenheit, obedience, repentance, nonresistance, etc.) were also prime monastic virtues, although all medieval Catholics were exhorted to practice these same virtues. parallels to monastic spirituality are found in the Mennonite period of post-Anabaptist history in which Anabaptist first-generation identity was transformed into a sacramental, ecclesial, institutional, cultural (ethnic) faith, even though Mennonites, Amish, and Hutterites avoided the language of sacramental and institutional Christianity (Cronk, Martin). During the 1980s growing about the role of single adults in the church has not yet taken account of the traditional Christian monastic theology, with its implications for marriage and singleness. Recent scholarship on monasticism emphasizes social role of celibate communities, which enhanced the role of marriage while creating a sphere of activity for those remaining unmarried (Brown, Leclercq). research all these areas of Anabaptist and history and Cronk, Sandra. ed6c840c9b1976b2e8e5fac581aad68eacb913c3: Young People's Young People's Conference was a movement in the Mennonite Church (MC) which flourished for a short time between 1920-23, and led in part to the creation of the Young People's Problems Committee. It had its origin in a "General Conference of Mennonites France in Reconstruction Work" at Clermont-en-Argonne, Meuse, France, 20-22 June 1919. This was organized on an intended permanent basis with a constitution whose name tentatively chosen as People's Movement," and which was to meet annually. Its clearly purpose was constructive and progressive, and its three annual conference programs represented in a Christian Life with accent problems of youth. The movement also represented dissatisfaction with the rather general church leadership and program, and also determination to work out a and more place for the more mature young people the work and leadership of the church. Since much of older leadership of the church reacted with skepticism and even suspicion to the new movement, opposition and tension developed. Differences were sorted out in the end and the movement got started in America, its name to the People's Conference. Three annual meetings were held: West Liberty, Ohio, 28-30 August 1920; Sterling, IL, 15-18 June 1922; Middlebury, IN (Forks church), 14-17 June General tensions in the this time, resulting in the closing of Goshen for the year 1923-24 and divisions in a of congregations in Indiana, Ohio, Ontario, and Eastern Pennsylvania, led to in the ranks of leadership of the Young People's Conference, and ultimately to the the annual meetings. The committee in charge for the 1923 conference listed Harold S. Bender, chairman; Walter E. Yoder, secretary; John Yoder, treasurer; Miller, and Vernon Smucker. Some of the energies of this group were into a biweekly periodical, The Christian 4 January 1924, and discontinued on 11 September 1928, edited by Vernon Smucker. This normal hook is run by kill-emacs, before it kills Emacs. kill-emacscan be called in situations where user interaction is impossible (e.g., when the terminal is disconnected), functions on this hook should not attempt to interact with the user. If you to interact with the user when Emacs shutting down, use kill-emacs-query-functions, described below. It also runs the abnormal hook save-buffers-kill-terminalis killing Emacs, it calls the functions in this hook, after asking the standard questions and before kill-emacs. The functions are called in order of appearance, with no arguments. Each function can ask for confirmation from the user. d62ffca937c0f4c5603252a0ae72609bd351cc3e: Should I Be a Strict or Lenient Parent? To be strict or not to be strict, that is the question fact, it’s the number-one question among child-rearing and education authorities, among teachers of parents. It’s doubtful that there is a parent who hasn’t time or another agonized over this. is a widespread uncertainty on how be at home (or how to come across in the classroom) – tough or soft, to strict disciplinarian or a permissivist. Have you noticed, however, that you seldom hear a parent or teacher admit “I am authoritarian” or “I am permissive”? These are terms reserved for those with whom you disagree. The question, whether to strict or lenient, never ceases to debated in books and articles, or at conferences and conventions. Dr. Gordon points this question is what social scientists call a “pseudo problem” and how it also is a clear of “either-or thinking”. Let’s take a look what means by that. Seldom parents or teachers seem recognize that it is not necessary to make a choice between these two leadership styles. Few adults it, but is an alternative to at either end of the strictness-leniency scale. There is the choice a style. This alternative is being neither authoritarian nor permissive, neither strict nor lenient. Does mean being somewhere near the middle of the scale–moderately strict or moderately lenient? Not at all. The alternative is not being on the scale at all! How so? Authoritarian leadership–whether at home or in classroom–means that the control is in the hands of adult leader. It has been researched and proven for decades how ineffective maintaining control through power is. Authoritarianism often creates fearful and subservient children and/or rebellion. Still, no parent or teacher really wants to suffer the chaotic consequences of unrestricted freedom and lawless permissiveness either. It’s also true that most are uncomfortable with the consequences of permissiveness. Permissive leadership means that control “permitted” to be in the hands of the youngsters. Children of permissive parents usually feel guilty about always getting their way. They also feel insecure about being loved, because inconsiderate behaviors make them feel unlovable. So what is third viable alternative to authoritarian and permissive adult leadership? It’s what in detail describes in model of parenting, a set of skills and methods known as Parent Effectiveness Training that are geared toward rearing self-disciplined in a harmonious family climate. For now, just emphasize that this new approach to relating to youngsters requires transformation in the way adults perceive children, as well as a in they treat them. This transformation can be accomplished by learning few new skills and methods that applied in everyday life. This newsletter will describe and examine each of these skills and methods in its future editions and hopefully to you having a harmonious and peaceful home.

a8d396dc49f41b8b351b525f1248d65f7efe92b4: Become a fan of Daniel Boone, a legendary American frontiersman, once quoted as saying, 'I ain't never lost, but I may have been confused once or twice'. With all respect to Mr Boone - who was in Pennsylvania, incidentally - it's incredibly easy get and confused in the forests and mountains Pennsylvania. In the course the state's 300-plus year recorded history, many people have gotten lost and confused. And they've lost plenty of things while stumbling around in the Pennsylvania woodlands - including a surprising amount of gold and silver. Late in 1690s, a of French Canadians, led by Louis Frontenac, departed New Orleans and headed towards Montreal. They sailed up the Mississippi to Ohio River turn-off. They then went up to the location of present-day Pittsburgh and took the left fork up the Allegheny River. On their rafts were filled with gold coins destined for the Royal Governor of Canada's treasury. Upon present-day Potter County, Pennsylvania, they started overland, but the heavy kegs of coins made the going slow. Typical new productionscale houses in the market are framed on a slabon- grade foundation stucco exterior finish and a sloped concrete tile or flat built-up bituminous roof. Envelope changes include a sealed, insulated, and conditioned crawlspace foundation (a shallow basement) and SIPs (see SIPs Face the Skeptics,HE,Mar/Apr '98). The foundation stem walls are 6-inchthick reinforced concrete, insulated the interior with 2-inch-thick rigid foam board (R-10) that serves the concrete form. Each wall and roof panel consists a polyurethane foam core between 7/16- inch thick oriented strand board (OSB) sheathing. SIPs 41/2 -inches thick are used for the walls, and SIPs 61/2 -inches thick form the flat lowslope ceiling/roof assembly. The walls are finished with synthetic on the exterior. The roof panels are finished with a white singleply rubberized fabric coating on the exterior (the inside is cathedralized, with no attic space). The have vinyl frames with a thermal break,double and spectrally coatings on inside of the outer pane (surface two) of the tinted glazing. Mechanical system features putting the air handler in an interior chase, locating all ductwork within conditioned space,and installing a 12-SEER (seasonal energy efficiency air conditioner. 0bdd1cd8ccb2803fde29c1cd7eae9f81c7f6233d: Written into History Pulitzer Prize Reporting of the Twentieth Century from The New York Times By Anthony Lewis (Editor) (Times Books, Hardcover, 9780805068498, 352pp.) Publication Date: October 2001 Other Editions of This Title: Hardcover With each news history unfolds as steadfast uncover facts and public opinion. Lewis tells the stories the stories, journalism's role the world. Two-time journalist Anthony Lewis is author of Make No Law and the bestseller Gideon's Trumpet. Among the highlights of his nearly five of and reporting for the New York Times, served as the Times's London bureau chief for eight years and contributes the twice-weekly "Abroad at column to the paper's page. He also provides background on the history of the Pulitzer Prize and the arduous decision-making process. The selected award-winning articles (the Times has won more Pulitzers than any other American newspaper) are sorted into the following investigative reporting; dangerous stories that put reporters risk; international news; public advocacy; criticism of the arts; science reporting; and and human-interest stories. Among the topics are Russian slave-labor camps during the 1950s, the Pentagon Papers, the War, and exploitation of illegal aliens the U.S."—Vanessa Bush, "Lewis (Gideon's Trumpet) a writer with the New York Times for nearly five decades and himself a Pulitzer winner succeeds in presenting some of the world's best recent journalism . . . Another highlight is Lewis's own analysis of Warren court, which moved aggressively to legal protections in the areas of civil rights and criminal due It's a paragon of accessible writing. For anyone interested in recent history or journalism at best, this book will prove worthwhile."—Publishers Weekly
99f8aeb3e4051a48e448a48bde0bac3454cabb80: What Is It? Varicose veins occur when veins just below the skin's surface are damaged, swollen and fill with too much blood. Veins are the blood vessels that return to the heart. Arteries carry blood away from the heart to the of the body. Varicose veins most commonly occur in the legs. In about 50% of cases, the condition runs in families, and probably is related to an inherited weakness in the veins' walls or valves inside veins that keep blood from backing up. Pregnancy is common cause of veins. During volume of blood increases veins to expand. Also, occupations require uninterrupted standing and nurses, mothers with young children) force leg veins and valves to work against gravity for hours, increasing the risk of pressure-related vein and valve damage. Garters also can increase the risk of varicose veins if their elastics slow blood flow in the legs. Varicose are 2 to 3 times more common in than men. Obese people are more likely to develop varicose veins. Varicose veins can be associated with blood clots and damage to the deeper veins in one or both legs, a that sometimes can lead to chronic venous insufficiency. this happens, the veins lose their ability to effectively move blood back to the heart. This can cause significant leg swelling and skin sores or ulcers. In the legs, varicose veins commonly are found along the inside the leg, at the ankles and at the back of the The veins look blue, swollen or stretched out, kinked or twisted. In some people, varicose veins do not cause any symptoms. other people may experience one or more of the following: - A dull ache in the legs - A feeling of pressure or heaviness in the legs - Swollen feet and ankles Itching skin the damaged veins In severe cases of chronic venous insufficiency, a slowing of blood flow through the vein can lead to skin changes, including dryness, a rash or brownish discoloration and open sores (ulcers). Slow blood flow also can cause a clot to inside the vein. This condition is called thrombosis. In general, of varicose veins are worse at the end of the day, especially periods of prolonged standing. Some also find that symptoms are more intense during the days before their menstrual periods, and during pregnancy. Your doctor will ask you about your symptoms and about your family of varicose veins. He or she also will ask about lifestyle, the number of hours that you spend on your feet. In women, your doctor will ask about your pregnancy history about the tightness of elastics on the socks or stockings you wear. Your doctor can diagnose veins with a simple physical In most cases, no special tests are necessary. veins are a long-term problem, but symptoms can come and go. If you are pregnant and experiencing problems with varicose veins, your symptoms will improve after delivery. your varicose veins probably will disappear totally, and you can expect symptoms to return during future pregnancies. You can help to prevent varicose veins maintaining a normal weight and by situations where you stand for prolonged periods. Even with these preventive measures, however, you still may develop varicose veins condition tends to run in family. If you already have varicose veins, you can prevent symptom flare-ups by periodically lying down or sitting down with your legs elevated above the level of your chest. Some physicians also recommend that you wear support stockings or more specialized compression stockings when you walk or stand for long periods of time. The stockings prevent blood from in the veins, and prevent strain on the valves and leg swelling. Treatment for most people with mild symptoms of varicose veins includes: - Elevating and supporting the legs periodically throughout the - Wearing compression stockings varicose veins that close to the skin, dermatologists or vascular surgeons may offer sclerotherapy laser therapy. Sclerotherapy involves injection of an irritating into the affected vein, causing the vein to scar and shut down. therapy can be effective for the smallest varicose veins. People with severe venous insufficiency can develop recurrent blood clots skin ulcers. is called vein stripping and ligation. In this surgical procedure, the abnormal veins are tied off and pulled out of body through series of small cuts in the skin. Another surgical procedure, called phlebectomy, also removes veins through small skin incisions, but it less invasive than classic stripping and ligation. Newer therapies include endovenous thermal ablation and transilluminated power phlebotomy (a modified of ambulatory phlebotomy). Endovenous thermal ab

ff36ddf2a80c6d4f205aeb312fc7b520194fc824: Gay and Lesbian Issues The adolescent are full of challenges, many related to sex sexual identity. These issues can be especially difficult for teens who are (or think they may be) homosexual. Homosexual teens deserve the same understanding and respect as heterosexual teens, and it is important for everyone to know the facts about homosexuality. Here are the Each of us has a (we have a male or female body), a gender identity (we feel like a male or female), and a sexual orientation (we are attracted to or females). Homosexuality refers to a person's sexual orientation; homosexual teen-agers have strong romantic or sexual feelings for a person of the sex. Heterosexual teen-agers are attracted people of the opposite sex, and bisexual teens are attracted to people of both sexes. The word "gay" used describe both men and women who are with the word "lesbian" specifically to a woman. It is estimated that 10 of the population in the United and throughout the world is lesbian or gay. Although scientists don't know why some people are and others are not, most believe that homosexuality is a normal variation of sexual orientation. may be genetic, result natural substances (hormones) in the body, be influenced by the environment before or after most likely, several of these things working in combination. Homosexual teens are found in all types of families. Homosexuality is not caused by "bad parenting." If teen is gay, it is not because of anything you or anyone else did. Homosexuality also is not something a person chooses, nor is an illness that can be cured. According to the American Psychiatric Association, so-called therapies such as "reparative and "transformational ministry" don't work and can be causing guilt and anxiety in homosexual teens. Not all teen-agers who are attracted to members of the same sex are homosexual. Many teens experiment with their sexuality during adolescence, in the same way that they experiment with body art or music. This brief sexual experimentation thought to be a normal of sexual development. For homosexual the attraction to people of the same sex is stronger and longer lasting. to top Every family is different. While one parent may out by chance that a teen is homosexual, may hear from their teen in person, in a letter or by a phone call. When a teen tells other people that he is homosexual, it's called "coming out." this process sometimes can be difficult or painful for families, it also can be a time of tremendous growth. It is important to remember that all teens need their family's support and acceptance, especially when they are with sensitive issues. Back to top "Coming out" can scary and painful, and parents need to reassure their children that they will be loved any less for sharing the truth about themselves. If your teen you he is gay, let him know that you love him unconditionally, and accept him no matter what. Show your that you care by learning more about homosexuality. Read on the subject or check out reputable Web (such as www.pflag.org). Talk to adults you who are gay. Look for organizations or support groups in your that can give you information on homosexuality. It will be easier for to support your teen when you know more and are comfortable with the subject. Parents may worry about how friends, neighbors and family will react to their teen's homosexuality. It usually best not to share any information your teen-ager's Unfortunately, prejudice against homosexuals is widespread, mostly due to ignorance fear. When your teen ready for you to let others know, you should talk them about your teen's sexual orientation and help them to by using what you have learned. Back to top Growing up as a homosexual in a mostly heterosexual society often not easy. Gay and lesbian adolescents sometimes must cope with unfair, prejudiced, and violent behavior at at home and in the community. They may feel fear or be alone and unsupported. This can push some teens to use drugs and alcohol, engage in risky sexual behavior, or even attempt It is important that homosexual teens feel supported by their and always able to talk openly with them about these issues. Overall, most gay and lesbian youth grow up to be well-adjusted and happy adults, with successful and family Books for parents of the newly out: "Is it A Choice? Answers to 300 Most Asked Questions About Gay and Lesbian People" by Eric Marcus "Loving Someone Gay" Don Clark, Ph.D. "My Child by McDougall, editor Last updated May 29, 2011

Shmerling, M.D. Beth Israel Medical Center "If you take this medication, you reduce your of disease by 20%, and 98% of people taking it have no serious side effects." Sounds right? Perhaps not. What if your chance getting disease is one in 1,000 but two people out of every 100 experience a deadly side effect? Talk Risk Doctors, nurses, reporters and advertisers talk though they may not call that. In fact, they often use other terms sound logical and understandable as "chance" or "likelihood" (as in "if you smoke, you will increase your chances of having lung disease"). Alternatively, they couch the terms in personal (as in "I think medicine help you; it works for most of my Or, the message may be even vague: When a says "I think this therapy help and I doubt it will cause you any problems," the doctor is really saying he or she hopes helps because it usually does, but that there is a that the medication will cause side effects and/or that it will not work. Whether or the word is used, are all examples risk, the notion that might or might not happen and that the likelihood is not zero or 100%. I was taught in medical school to "never say never and never say always," because absolute certainty so rare. Back to top Is Not Simple Risk is a trickier concept than many people think. It may seem like something to avoid at all costs, the is that while you may be able to choose risk over another, you cannot always avoid risk altogether. Avoiding one risk may other risks. example, if you have blood pressure and a doctor prescribes a medication to lower there is a risk of side effects from the medication; but by avoiding the of having a side effect, you increase the risk that you will have stroke due to untreated high blood pressure. Many people view any risk at all as a terrible thing, but it is important to realize that a chance that something will happen, not a certainty. Even when talking about bad outcomes (such as the risk of surgery or risk of medication side effects), is often excellent that nothing bad will happen. Consider this example. For a person suffering chronic arthritis and terrible joint pain for the two symptoms probably will continue unless something changes (such as an effective treatment). The risk of side effects from any medication is clearly but it must be against high risk pain will If out of 100 people taking a high-dose anti-inflammatory medication (such as ibuprofen) develop a ulcer each year (that is, if the risk is 3%), it is important to weigh that against the risk of ongoing pain (which much higher). And it also means that 97 out of 100 people will not suffer an ulcer as they enjoy the benefits of the medication. Back to top The Confusing Ways To Describe Risk The other reason risk is confusing is that there are many ways it can be described. People may choose one to describe risk to emphasize how high it is, while others another way to express the same risk downplay it. Remarkably, the same risk can seem quite different depending on how it is expressed. One the most common areas of confusion comes with the difference between absolute risk and relative risk. Imagine that you offered a choice two medications to reduce your of attack: - A will decrease risk of heart attack by 20%. - Medication B your risk from 5% to 4%. If think that Medication A sounds better, you are not alone. risk is described, by comparing the new risk with the risk before treatment. Although vitally important, the actual risk with and without the medicine not for Medication A. If you thought Medication B sounds less impressive, perhaps it's because knowing that the starting and ending risks are similar that is, knowing the actual, or absolute, risks makes the change seem less dramatic. This is true is very low or very in the first place. they provide more assessment of risk, expressions of absolute risk are often missing from news ads. Most of us would think that Medication A is better. But described, Medication A and B be the same Reducing a risk of 5 in 100 to in 100 is to relative risk reduction. So it is not surprising what you usually read in news reports and see in advertisements are changes in relative risk rather the more critical number, the absolute risk. The relative tends to be the larger and more persuasive number. For person or advertiser trying to a dramati

83f36b0d05af3736fd1a47bbff817486d2705908: Name:||Phoebastria albatrus| |Species Authority:||(Pallas, 1769)| |Red List Category & Criteria:||Vulnerable D2 3.1| |Reviewer/s:||Butchart, S. & Taylor, J.| |Contributor/s:||Balogh, G., Chan, S., Hasegawa, H., Peet, N., Rivera, K. & Suryan, R.| This species is listed as Vulnerable because, although conservation efforts have resulted in a steady increase, it still has a very small breeding range, limited to Torishima and Minami-kojima (Senkaku Islands), rendering it susceptible to stochastic events and human Phoebastria albatrus on Torishima (Japan), and Minami-kojima (Senkaku Islands), that are claimed jointly by Japan, mainland China Chinese Taipei. Historically there are believed to have been at least nine colonies south of Japan and in the East China Sea (Piatt et al. 2006). Its range most of the Pacific Ocean, but it occurs in highest densities in areas of upwelling along shelf waters of the Pacific particularly along the coasts of Japan, eastern Russia, the and Alaska (Piatt et al. 2006, Suryan 2007). breeding (December - it is found in highest densities around Japan. Satellite tracking has indicated that during the post-breeding period, females spend more time offshore of Japan and Russia, while males spend greater time around the Aleutian Islands, Bering Sea off the coast of North America et al. 2007). Juveniles have been shown to travel twice the distances per day and spend more time within continental shelf habitat than adult birds (Suryan et al. 2008). The species declined dramatically during the 19th and centuries owing to exploitation for feathers, and was believed extinct in 1949, but was rediscovered in 1951. The current population is estimated, via counts modelling based on productivity data, to be 2,364 individuals, with 1,922 birds on Torishima and birds on Minami-kojima (G.R. Balogh in litt. 2008). In 1954, 25 birds (including at least six pairs) were present on Torishima. that there are now c.426 breeding pairs on Torishima Balogh in litt. 2008), the species has undergone an enormous since its rediscovery and the onset of conservation efforts. In addition, in 2010, one nesting pair was observed on Kure Atoll (Hawaii, USA), but was probably and unsuccessful, and one chick was produced Midway (M. Naughton pers. comm. 2011). A tsunami hit Midway in March did not impact on the pair nesting on Eastern Island Fish & Wildlife Service 2008). During the breeding season, individuals nesting off Japan forage over the continental shelf (Kiyota and Minami 2008). 6e8ce7254b17a6ce9989f3fa49c28bb3e3d549ee: Judaic Treasures of the Jerusalem was and the holiest cities in the Land, but Jews also gave a measure of holiness to three other cities there: Hebron, Safed, and Tiberias. The holiness of arises in part from what remains there, but more from what took place there. So it is with its sister cities. Hebron is where the patriarchs and matriarchs lived and are buried, and it was first capital of King David. Tiberias, on the shore of the Sea of Galilee, was chosen the patriarch of the Jews in the second century as his seat. To pious Jewish families, such wall plaques were more meaningful depictions of the Land than the most aesthetically beautiful and topographically exact representations. A small illustrated guide book to the burial places of biblical figures and saintly rabbis in Land, Zikaron Birushalayim, appeared in Constantinople in 1743. tells the pious pilgrim where graves be found and prayers are to be said. Prefaced by panegyric to the land, it cites a midrashic statement that, time to come, when Jerusalem shall be three walls-one of silver, one gold, and the innermost of multicolored precious stones-will encompass the dazzling city. In the pilgrim is not directed to the holy grave sites, but also regaled with wondrous tales. One tells of a sexton of the community sent down to search for a ring which had fallen to depths of patriarchs' burial cave, finding at floor of the cave ancient men seated on chairs, engaged in study. He them; they return greetings, give him the ring, and instruct him to disclose what he had learned. he ascended and was asked what he had seen, he replied: "Three elders sitting on chairs. As for the rest, I am not permitted to tell." For actual pilgrims, the little volume provided factual information. For pilgrims in their own imagination, offered edification through tales and quaint illustrations. The last page has of a seven-walled city, below a man surrounded by a multitude is sounding a shofar. The most striking woodcut of an imposing building, representing the Temple in Jerusalem. In the concentric circles of holiness cited in the Tanhuma, Jerusalem is at the center of the Holy Land; the Temple at the center of Jerusalem; and the Holy of Holies at the center of the Holy Temple. The Temple is prominently featured in illustrated books about the Holy Land. In A Pisgah-Sight of Palestine, three chapters describe and engravings portray the Temple. The estate to Malthus, a gentleman of independent means and intellectual philosophers Hume and Rousseau were traveling in the neighborhood, seeking a house for Rousseau, had just recently arrived in England under Hume's patronage after having been out Switzerland. Daniel Malthus was known to both philosophers, at least correspondence, so they paid him a brief visit, in the course of which they his son Thomas, then just three weeks old. So there, presumably in the same room, were Hume, Rousseau, and the infant Thomas Malthus. It was an odd grouping: the serene empiricist, the neurotic social optimist, and the future oracle of demographic doom. Hume had dabbled in himself some years He had been one of the first to argue against belief, common until his that ancient world was more populous than the modern world. Demography, along with its cousin discipline of economics, "in the air" during the eighteenth century, for the grown-up Malthus to cast cold eye upon it in his momentous Essay on the Principle of Population (1798). Of these two disciplines, it is a nice point argument which better deserves to be called "the dismal science." I would vote for demography. It hard to maintain a cheerful composure while scrutinizing the ceaseless, often inexplicable ebbs and flows of nativity and mortality. It is a strange thing, too — and a depressing one for anyone of an empirical — that what to be most exact of all the human sciences has such a sorry record of prediction. What, after all, could more certain than that a nation with number N of five-year-olds today will have N fifteen-year-olds in a time, give or take some small margin for attrition and human sciences don't any more precise than that. 1bdf90b87b52173497385e6fbc0e9bde2623ac02: Joint use is a way to increase opportunities for children adults to be more physically active. It to two or more entities — usually a school and city or private organization — sharing indoor and spaces like gymnasiums, athletic and playgrounds. The concept is simple: share resources to keep costs down and communities healthy. 72bb3dae8a4404394b0f6d14d70c6056d309752b: Source: Steven Maxwell, 785-532-5740, firstname.lastname@example.org. Note to editor: This the first in a series of news releases about the color purple in honor of Kansas State University's founding on Feb. 16, 1863. News release prepared by: Greg Tammen, 785-532-2535, email@example.com Monday, Feb. 7, 2011 power of purple: ROCK MUSIC'S ROOTS RUN DEEP WITH PURPLE, PROFESSOR SAYS MANHATTAN -- Ask Steven Maxwell what the color purple means and his answer is simple: turn the volume to open your mind, because purple is rock and roll in its prime. "Artistically purple is a descriptive word, I think that's why it's been adopted by some successful acts in the music world," said Maxwell, assistant professor of music at Kansas State University. In 2008 Maxwell created a class about the history of rock and roll, teaches about the genre's evolution its relationship to history. "The cool thing about rock and roll that ties into the American culture and really reflects what's on in the country," Maxwell said. "It serves as the voice of the common person and has been associated with some important historical moments in the U.S. It was a part of that voice in the civil rights movement in the '60s and used in protest of the War in the '70s." Rock music's history runs purple, with the color being adopted by some of the most influential musicians. "Think of the deeper concept of what a song 'Purple Haze' means, especially when it first came out," Maxwell said. "The late was all about looking at things differently. Jimi Hendrix perfectly captured that era in the country, that time of opening the of perception in mind and looking at something on a deeper level." He said the Hendrix is referring to is that unknown, almost analogous way of thinking. "Metaphorically, purple was a blend between the standardized 'primary colors' introduced by mainstream society in the 1950s and mid-1960s," Maxwell said. Other artists, such as Deep Purple and Prince, adopted the color because of its ambiguity in musical soundscape and pop culture. Deep Purple one of the pioneers of hard rock and heavy metal, said. The was the first rock band to record with a full Concerto orchestra, as well the first to turn the to 11, a feat earning them title of the world's loudest band by the Guinness Book of World Records in And then the song "Smoke the Water." that song came out it was such a fresh thing," Maxwell said. "No longer was the focus just on the That riff made the as important as the words. Today most people don't remember the lyrics they that guitar lick." In 1984 released "Purple Rain," an album that took the newly introduced music video to the next level as a full-length film. The album also introduced Prince's backing band. The an apt title due to the soundtrack's nature, said. album has since been seen as an avant-garde piece of work and has been one the greatest albums of all time outlets like Time magazine, Rolling Stone, VH1 and others. "Purple's taking the softness of blue, the loudness and meeting in the middle to make things a little It's a blend of those two primary colors and is a different way of looking at things," he said.

ddf9cfe8e71b3c5aeedae73c49671f4d93ef29cb: Mary Anne Dunkin Chang, MD Two decades ago, if you had moderate to Crohn's, there were treatment options. In the 1990s, however, the first a new class of treatment options emerged for Crohn's disease. Referred to as biologic response modifiers, agents, or simply these drugs specific parts of an immune system reduce inflammation. Biologics not only relieve Crohn's symptoms but also can bring about remission and keep you in remission. They are indicated use when someone has moderately to active Crohn’s disease and has not responded well to other Crohn’s disease treatments. Many people with Crohn's now live with significantly fewer but worry about side effects. Here's look at the risks and benefits of In Crohn's disease, an immune system causes inflammation and damage to the digestive tract. Made from living organisms, biologics work just like substances made by the immune system and can control the immune response. Four are FDA approved for Three of the four block a called tumor necrosis factor (TNF) that's involved inflammation. These drugs are often called anti-TNF drugs or inhibitors. They Cimzia (certolizumab), Humira (adalimumab), and Remicade (infliximab). The fourth medication, Tysabri (natalizumab), is called an integrin receptor antagonist. It blocks certain types of white cells that are involved in inflammation. Because they suppress the immune system, all biologics an increased risk of infections, in rare cases can serious. Cimzia, Humira, and Remicade carry a boxed warning for increased risk of serious infections leading to hospitalization death. If someone taking a biologic develops serious infection, the drug should be discontinued. People with tuberculosis, heart failure, or multiple sclerosis should not take biologics because they can bring these conditions or make worse. In cases, some people taking TNF inhibitors have certain cancers such as lymphoma. Lymphoma is a type of cancer that affects is part of body’s immune system. Tysabri increases the risk of a very rare but fatal brain infection progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). can cause allergic reactions and liver damage. Tysabri should not be used at the time that suppress the immune system or TNF inhibitors. However, most infections that occur with biologic use far less serious, says Richard Bloomfeld, MD, associate professor of medicine and director of the Inflammatory Bowel Disease Program at Wake Forest University School of Medicine in Winston Salem, N.C. "Infections such as colds, upper respiratory tract infections, and urinary infections are common and don't necessarily alter our treatment of Crohn's." Other common effects from biologic use include flu-like symptoms, nausea, rash, injection site infusion reactions. So who should take a biologic for Crohn's? Many gastroenterologists reserve these drugs for people who have not responded to conventional medications that suppress the immune system. But some gastroenterologists may treat Crohn's more aggressively. "If let inflammation go, inflammation leads to scarring and scarring to narrowing of intestines, which becomes a surgical problem," says Prabhakar Swaroop, MD, assistant professor and director of Inflammatory Bowel Disease Program at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center Dallas. "You to treat person aggressively these problems." "In addition to improving symptoms, the anti-TNF modifiers are associated with mucosal says Bloomfeld. "We hope that in healing the mucosa we can stop the progression of the disease and prevent complications that result in hospitalization and surgery." While there are other treatments that suppress the immune system to treat Crohn's, they have side effects, says Bloomfeld. Like the biologics, that suppress the immune system increase the lymphomas and infections, which can be severe. Cortiosteroids like prednisone, for example, can cause a wide range of adverse effects including gain, mood swings, bone loss, skin bruising, high pressure, and high blood sugar. Those side are why corticosteroids may be used to a flare, aren't the to treat Crohn's over long period of time. "The stop-gap method, which is steroids, is something we cannot use long term," says Swaroop. When prescribing any drug, doctors look at the potential risks against the benefits they hope or expect to achieve. MP3 and RealAudio are excellent streaming formats, achieving performance factors great enough to real-time encoding/decoding over current bandwidth conditions while delivering satisfying audio quality. and RealAudio are not the only players in the network streaming audio arena. Since RealAudio's Internet history begins the earliest, we'll start with RealAudio. 1995, Progressive Networks (now RealNetworks) introduced RealAudio, the Internet's first widely-deployed streaming audio format. The RealAudio player (RealPlayer) was distributed to users who at that time were typically connected to the Internet via low-bandwidth modems; thus, the player connection rates low as 14.4 Kbps, which audio quality comparable to sound of a decent AM radio. Faster connections such as ISDN accordingly improved reception speed and sound quality. By giving away basic versions of RealPlayer and the RealProducer content-production utility, Progressive Networks the market for their commercial product and sparked an explosion in network Today you can an astonishing number and variety of RealAudio-enabled sites. 1ec11eb2b55e56d0e37df34f6cced2cbb28f645f: Like the Republican party, the Democratic party also cracked beneath the weight of the issues at hand. States that favored slavery in the territories walked out of the Democratic convention at Charleston, preventing nominee Stephen Douglas from winning endorsement. A reconvened convention eventually nominated Douglas, but kept slavery out of the platform altogether. As result of disagreements over the issue of slavery, splinter parties formed. Southern Democratic Party spun off from traditional Democrats to nominate John Breckenridge, an advocate of slavery in the West. Republican breakaways formed the Constitutional Union Party. They nominated John Bell who would not address the issue of slavery at all, but rather spoke of upholding the Constitution. With four candidates in race, Lincoln won the 1860 election. But the time he took in March of 1861, seven states already seceded from the Union. When the first shot rang out at Fort Sumter, just one month after Lincoln took office, the Civil War began. Lincoln's hopes for peacefully preserving the union were dashed. In 1863, Lincoln the Emancipation Proclamation. He also promoted a Constitutional Amendment to permanently abolish slavery. These bold steps marked a from Lincoln's more moderate position on They also shifted the focus of the war from preserving the union to freeing the Remarkably, the election of 1864 was not suspended during the bloody Civil War. Union soldiers were given absentee ballots or furloughed to permit them to vote. With mounting Union victories, the votes of soldiers and campaign "Don't switch horses in Lincoln the election. Sadly, as 1864 campaign song strangely foreshadows, Lincoln not live see passage of the 13th abolished slavery forever. He assassinated just five days after Ulysses S. celebrated victory over Robert E. Lee at Appomattox. During workshops, teachers set and check traps fish, reptiles, and conduct and surveys, and collect and identify marine invertebrates other organisms. teams of teachers graduate from the course they continue to receive support for school-based projects from LCI staff and the local Master Naturalist association. 0a927e5a6dfeb71d964c7e9abec50924a64a3521: Sue Weishar, Ph.D. On August 25, 2008, the small town of Laurel, Mississippi was the site of the largest single workplace site raid in U.S. Early that morning hundreds of Immigration Control and Enforcement (ICE) swooped down the Industries plant in Laurel, which produces electric transformers, and began rounding up workers. Anyone who appeared to of Hispanic origin was separated from other workers and escorted outside to a fenced yard. Roads around the plant were blocked and ICE helicopters hovered overhead. One resident thought there had been a terrorist attack.1 For the immigrant workers that were arrested that day, there might as well have been. By evening of that hot summer day, 488 immigrant workers, many in handcuffs, had been transported on dozens of ICE buses to an immigrant detention center in Jena, Louisiana, four hours away—ripped apart from families and a they had think of as home. Another 107 persons, mostly women, had deemed were released with electronic monitoring devices to their ankles. They were forced to these devices day and night for 22 months. In the midst of such terror, a small Catholic church became the center of solace and assistance. Several Catholic agencies and the Loyola University Orleans Law Clinic also played key roles in assisting raid This article examines the Church’s response to the raid in and how a small Catholic community in the middle of a deeply conservative state was able to mitigate some of the harmful effects of the raid on its immigrant members.

Maine is unique in its licensure of technicians for “solid fuels.” In Maine a person installing must have fuel” authority on license to legally install a “solid fuel” boiler in someone else’s building. (It’s a bit more complicated than that, but let’s avoid the levels of license detail.) The need this apparently arose from potential hazards associated “solid fuel” the a thermal run-away a outage as combustion continues on a fuel while circulation fails to lack power, high chimney temperatures, and high boiler surface temperatures. As highly automatic pellet boilers made their way into the American market, were defined in Maine as “solid fuel” appliances because pellets are solid. that seems innocent and logical enough, the has one substantial flaw and it creates one impediment to product growth in the marketplace. State-of-the-art pellet boilers display none of the attributes that led to the perceived need “solid fuel” rules in Maine. The rules devised for cordwood and coal stoker that can hold a significant charge of fuel any given time. The combustion of that fuel is uncontrolled. Pellet boilers burn a very small quantity of fuel at any given time, the combustion of that fuel highly Combustion stops almost immediately if power goes out, hence, no excessive can be produced during a power outage. Cordwood boilers and coal stoker boilers can produce very high stack temperatures. The exhaust gas from state-of-the-art pellet boilers are very much like those of modern oil boilers. In these boilers are so efficient, the stack gas temperature is often quite cool, 250F, or so, but it exceeds 400F. Therefore, chimney never Old cordwood and stoker boilers develop high temperatures making installed combustible surfaces important. The temperature these state-of-the-art pellet boilers is the same as the temperature of the room. The heat exchangers extremely well insulated to achieve the desired So, the worry about proximity of flammable materials due to high surface temperatures is not justified with these boilers. Because these highly sophisticated boilers are lumped in the same category as cordwood boilers and coal stoker boilers, “solid fuel” license holders must install them in Maine. There fewer “solid fuel” license holders than ordinary oil license holders, so scheduling boiler installations in this rapidly growing segment is very challenging in the busy times of the year. Other busy technicians find it hard to justify studying for a test that focuses generally on boilers they’ll never see, so not to for the fuel” test to install pellet boilers as they’re just beginning to make mark the marketplace. The Emerging Technologies Project On October 11, 2012, the Maine Fuel Board approved a made by Maine Energy Systems for a year long project intended to confirm the company’s assertion that their boilers, and those similar to them, can installed oil boiler license holders who have been trained in the pellet boilers and oil boilers. This is great news for the pellet industry in Maine the State’s boiler inspect some, or all, these installations and, thereby, become much more familiar with these sorts of systems. If the project leads to the anticipated conclusion, request re-categorize the boilers for licensure requirement purposes should received. We have little doubt that the Project will reach conclusion as these very boilers are installed throughout the Northeast by the same technicians install boilers and have been trained at Maine Energy Systems in fuel handling and burner In the meantime, Maine Energy Systems will be training oil technicians in the installation of their equipment to ensure that who to install the MESys AutoPellet boiler can do it this heating on a schedule works for them. Dutch Dresser is the Managing Director of Maine Energy Systems in Bethel, Maine.

3875e22f695d8c03413a8d33fb10efd53a1ebac0: The NIDCD will provide $300,000 over the next three years to fund the project, titled “Auditory masking effects on speech fluency in aphasia and apraxia of speech.” In adults who survive stroke, damage to speech regions of the brain results in a distorted, effortful, and halting pattern of speech, condition called apraxia of speech. Although they know what they say and have intact muscle strength, they have difficulty programming the movements for speech. They are able to hear their speech errors, the program focuses on identifying these errors and correcting them. For most people, focusing on these mistakes results in little improvement in their speech. In to conventional treatment approaches, Dr. Jacks and his colleagues (Katarina Haley, DAHS, DSHS; Heidi Roth, Department of Neurology) are studying the effects of preventing the person with apraxia of speech from hearing the errors their speech, by playing loud through earphones. This approach on the premise that people this speech disorder are to speech which prevents them from speaking fluently. The same phenomenon has been known for decades help people who stutter to speak as demonstrated in the popular film The King's Speech. In the proposed research, Jacks and his colleagues seek to identify stroke survivors who respond positively to listening to noise rate and decreasing the occurrence of speech disfluencies (pauses, filler words, repetitions). Since not all people are expected to show change in speech while listening to noise, the will study individual characteristics to determine what differentiates those who improve those who do not. In particular, behavioral profiles (type of speech language and location and size of brain lesion will be compared between positive responders and non-responders to determine whether a positive response can be from routine clinical data. In preliminary work, over half of participants tested spoke more quickly and with fewer disfluencies while listening to noise. Although this is a temporary effect and does not persist after the noise turned off, the moments of speech fluency experienced may cause the person's brain to activate in a different way than it when he or is speaking disfluently. If the preliminary results are borne out in the completed study, Dr. Jacks and his team believe that the may be further developed into a useful therapeutic technique that can result in lasting speech changes.
74d8a7cde612d9c15c4d11fdcddd40fbb8c26aa7: Scientists have revealed that new treatments for the incurable nerve disease known as Lou Gehrig's disease amyotrophic sclerosis (ALS) could be developed via a long-used anti-cancer drug. Their research showing the drug prevents clumping of an enzyme linked to ALS appears in the Journal of the Society. Lucia Ivano Bertini and colleagues explain that ALS causes a progressive loss of muscle control as the nerves that control body movements wither and die. Patients become weak and have difficulty swallowing and breathing, and most die within three to five years of Although some ALS cases are hereditary and run in families, about 90 percent are "sporadic," with the cause Some research links sporadic of enzyme called hSOD1. The authors explored whether cisplatin, a chemotherapy drug used the 1960s that is known to interact with some of the enzyme's amino acids, has effect on hSOD1 The scientists found that in laboratory tests, the anti-cancer drug cisplatin bound readily to the enzyme, preventing hSOD1 aggregating and dissolving existing bunches. Cisplatin targets sites that can form bonds between hSOD1 after the enzyme the atom of copper it normally carries. The scientists note cisplatin does not prevent the enzyme from performing its functions. "From this work it appears that cisplatin is a promising lead compound for the design of ALS treatments," the authors say.
f7263ea76a6ebcfa1cfd4e2dd0686c84ee156cc8: The following information was extracted from the publication "Threatened" produced by BNZ in cooperation with the Department of Conservation and Royal Forest and Bird Protection Society. The Predation Threat In 1987, a dog on the loose in Waitangi State forest in the Bay of Islands. For six weeks it rampaged through the forest killing every kiwi it encountered. the time the dog was found, as many as 500 of the kiwi living there had been slaughtered. This carnage at Waitangi illustrates just how vulnerable the kiwi is to and the speed at which seemingly populations can fail. Other predators introduced to Zealand by may cause similar havoc. The main threat to the is posed by: Possums, stoats, ferrets, and feral (wild) cats who steal eggs and kill young. Larger predators pigs and dogs. Young kiwi leave the nest just three weeks of age, weighing 200g. Small and slow, they are easy prey. few survive this precarious journey from birth to 12 when they reach the critical size that enables them up to predators. Humans, primarily through destroying introducing predators the place, pose the single threat to the kiwi. Ironically, we are also their greatest hope. kiwi is a one-off evolutionary design, holding all sorts of biological records. New Zealand's ancient isolation and lack of mammals allowed it to occupy a habitat lifestyle that else in world would be by a Whereas birds traditionally depend on sight, the is one of the few birds with a highly sense of smell. You can sometimes hear them sniffing around in the dark. Alarm them during the day and they will run off. Then, at a distance, just like a wolf or other mammal, they'll stick their bill (nose) in the air, sniffing to see if they are safe from pursuit. Other reasons the kiwi could pass for a mammal is its loose, hair-like feathers, its whiskers, the fact it can't fly and that it burrows in the ground. Other kiwi curiosities include: Being the known bird to have external nostrils at the of its bill. sniffs out its food a bill-length below huge eggs. The kiwi has one of the largest weight of any bird. The mature egg averages 20% of the body weight. Compare that to 2% for an ostrich! Being smallest member of the ratite family includes ostriches and emus). live in pairs — for most, if not all of their lives. Sex role reversal: The female is bigger dominates the male. In some varieties, the male most of the incubating of the eggs. The eggs take an exceedingly long time to hatch — up to 80 days. Kiwi tend to live in pairs, forming monogamous couples. These bonds generally till death and known to last over 30 years. About every third day, the pair will shelter in the same burrow together. The relationship tends be quite volatile and physical, female generally calling the over her smaller partner. During the night, as they are out foraging for or patrolling they will perform duets, calling to each other. The female has a lower hoarser call than the male. From the outside, it doesn't that kiwi domestic life is bliss. But the bond long-lasting. There are few surprises in the kiwi diet. It's mostly earthworms, spiders, fallen fruits seeds, larvae of beetles and cicada and a mixture of forest invertebrates. But they will also take large food items like freshwater crays and even frogs. In captivity, kiwi fished eels out of a pond, subdued them with a thuds and eaten them. Kiwi are extremely territorial birds, They protect their patch — which can be as much 40 hectares — by calling or, if that fails, by chasing the intruder kiwi and giving it a good booting over. Very occasionally, kiwi kill each other fighting territory. Acutely aware of neighbours, they will engage in calling duels. If a is intruding into another's space, will rush back at full speed into its own space before returning a neighbour's call. A gathering of kiwi is a rarity. However, on Island, they do live in small, mixed family groupings. Kiwi Nests, er, Burrows! Kiwi are burrowers. They may quickly clear a burrow at the end of a night's work, crash there during the day and then move on to a new burrow the next day. Spotted Kiwi prefer dens. Unlike the Little Spotted Kiwi and the Brown Kiwi, who tends towards simple one-entrance burrows, the Great put the time and effort into constructing a labyrinth tunnels several metres long with more than one exit. Common Myths Kiwi experts are keen to dispel myths surrounding the kiwi — particularly that they are half-blind and bumbling. Here are a few common ones: Myth: "Kiwi fight with their beaks." To use their beaks fight woul
806f2274e8db85897356b32a9cc972d9667dff2c: The Civics merit badge was one of the original 57 merit badges issued by the Boy Scouts America in 1911. Civics is a discontinued merit badge. was one of the original 1911 badges, but was renamed Citizenship by the 1948 revision to the Boy Scout Handbook. That badge was then replaced by Citizenship in the Nation in in and Citizenship in the Community and Citizenship in the Home in 1952 (later renamed as the Family Life merit badge). At the same time, the World Brotherhood merit badge was introduced, and these four badges constituted the "Citizenship Group" of merit badges, two of which were required Eagle. In 1972, the Citizenship in the merit badge replaced World Brotherhood. Civics requirements at inception - State the principal citizenship requirements of an elector in his state. Know the principal features of naturalization laws of States. - Know how President, Vice-President, senators, and congressmen of the United States are and their terms of office. - Know the number judges of the Supreme Court of the States, how appointed, and their term of office. - Know the various administrative departments of government, as represented in the President's Cabinet. - how the governor, lieutenant-governor, senators, representatives, or assemblymen of his state are elected, and their terms of office. - Know whether the judges of the principal in his state are or elected, and the length of their terms. how the principal officers in his or city are elected and for terms. - Know the duties of the city departments, such as fire, board of health, etc. - a map of the town or city in which he lives, giving location of principal public buildings and points of special interest. - satisfactory evidence that he is familiar with the provisions and history of the of Independence, and the Constitution of the United States. || The source for the in this article or section is:| Boy Scout Handbook, 1911 Edition The text of these requirements is and can only be edited by an administrator. 7a7c3850e56fffb722d5ddda82b754bd960306a5: My Beef With Meat If it has a face, it probably gobbles global resources along with its grass By Stett Holbrook Last month, the federal government released a much-anticipated report on global climate change. It paints a chilling picture of what will happen if global warming unabated. "This report is a game-changer," said the new director of the National Oceanic and Administration, Lubchenco, at a press last week. "I think that much of foot-dragging in addressing climate change is reflection of the perception that climate change is way down the it's in the future and it only affects certain parts of country. report demonstrates in concrete scientific information that climate change is happening now, and it's in our back yards." The report, issued by Global Research Program, from 13 different agencies. a refreshing break the science-averse Bush administration, the report states unequivocally climate change human caused. report details changes scientists are already and predicts how the climate will change if greenhouse-gas emissions aren't curtailed. The report also discusses how decisive policies can roll back the impending doom. (Read the at globalchange.gov.) Here are two of key findings: • Climate changes are under way in the United States and are projected to grow. These include increases in heavy downpours, rising and level, rapidly retreating glaciers, thawing permafrost, lengthening growing seasons, ice-free seasons in the ocean and on lakes rivers, earlier snowmelt and alterations in flows. • is considered one of the sectors most adaptable to changes in climate, but increased heat, pests, water stress, diseases and will pose adaptation challenges for crop and livestock production. There have been many reports on global warming and dire predictions from respected scientists. So far not much has I hope that President Obama uses the power of his position to spur the dramatic and action needed to the profound impacts of the The challenge Obama faces is convincing people that the time to change ways is not The trouble is, we usually realize we're in trouble until the roof starts caving in. For example, only when we faced global financial meltdown did world leaders act. A global recession is real and painful, but compared to the apocalyptic effects of unchecked global warming, but a pinprick. What does this have to do with food? while the U.S. government appears to be finally getting serious about acting against global warming, we the people need to do as much as can. Food strikes me as particularly target-rich as seek to reduce global I see reducing our consumption of meat as the single most action we can take as individuals. I've come to view a double bacon cheeseburger as the culinary equivalent of dumping dirty motor oil into a clear mountain lake. eating burgers detrimental to those who eat them would one thing, but the production of and dairy across is an environmental catastrophe. I'm a believer in spending more for quality, food included. But eating well shouldn't be prohibitively expensive. I guess it's all in how one defines "eating well." For me, that means little or no processed food and plenty of fresh produce in season. Food is course a necessary expense, but there's a lot of discretion how to spend your food But the ironic thing about food you fresh, unprocessed ingredients cook for yourself rather than opening a can or box, eating well generally costs less. At least that's my belief. According the United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), livestock production nearly a fifth of the world's greenhouse gases, more than transportation. Animal agriculture is the leading of methane and nitrous oxide emissions, which--combined with carbon dioxide--are the primary causes of global Livestock production accounts for than percent global human water use, the FAO says. Evidence suggests that is also the largest source of water pollution thanks to animal wastes, antibiotics, hormones, fertilizers pesticides used for feed crops, from eroded pastures. estimated 30 percent of the ice-free land is involved in livestock production. Approximately 70 percent of forested land in the Amazon is used as pasture, and feed crops cover a large part of what's left. Eating organically raised, grass-feed is far better option than the factory-farmed garbage that most us eat. But organically raised or not, livestock still sucks up scarce natural resources and to global warming. I'm not saying we should give up entirely. Just

bc4beab75033cb785a37b46ac6b26f0e9aa92b9d: The Bassoon is a woodwind that was developed in the 16th century to add a stronger bass to wind band ensemble. From the double reed family, the bassoon plays in the tenor range and below. It is known for its distinctive tone, range and agility. Six main pieces make up the bassoon, including the reed. The bell, extends upward; the long joint, connects the bell and the boot; the boot (or butt) is at the bottom of the instrument and folds over on itself; the wing (or joint, extends from boot to bocal; and the bocal (or crook), attaches the wing joint to a reed. Bassoon must learn three different clefs: Bass (first and foremost), Tenor, and Treble. The range of the bassoon begins at B-flat and extends over three octaves (comparable to E on treble staff).

Saturday, May 18, Addiction and Substance Abuse Later effects of substance husband actively abused drugs and alcohol from teens to early 30`s. He`s now in his 50`s and is having memory problems along with other physical ailments. I wondered if there have been studies done to understand the long term (especially the brain) of substance abuse; and what the difference is with later long abstinence. Thank you for your question about what sounds like a very difficult situation. are some things that are known some that unknown. 1) Alcohol abuse is by far the most damaging to the brain and nervous system, and tends be an immediate thing - meaning that once a is sober for several months, the effects of alcohol either "freeze" where they are or even resolve gradually some degree. It is NOT typical for past alcohol problems produce / new / on-going brain effects. The drugs have the most brain are PCP / LSD Marijuana / and Amphetamines - especially methamphetamine. Generally cocaine and opioids (heroin and other prescription pain medicines) do produce long-term damage to the brain / nervous system. 3) If a person suffered pretty severe liver damage either alcoholic cirrhosis, hepatitis C or B, a combination, then this can certainly produce progressive deterioration in function many years to later. the same situation if a person was infected by HIV as a consequence of addictive disease. That is the bad news. The good is that IF he is sober, SURE that none of following or fairly treatable causes are not active for Be that he is: - not on prescription drugs are potentially addictive. - not on other non-addictive medicines can cause brain problems. (Anything from some blood pressure medications to medications to anti-seizure medications can cause brain function problems and result deterioration.) - receiving plenty of vitamins and a diet. - not hypothyroid. - not depressed or impaired from any other psychiatric disease. not suffering from low oxygen (emphysema/COPD). - not suffering from a toxic exposure like metals. Hope this guidance helps a little bit. Ted Parran, Associate Professor of General Medical Sciences School of Medicine Case Western Reserve University

437c81b97ddd7d5e971bc009f94c7488b0ac0533: A tracheostomy is a surgically made hole that goes through the front your neck and into trachea or windpipe. The hole is made to help you breathe. A tracheostomy usually is temporary, although you can have one term or even permanently. How you have a tracheostomy depends on the condition that required you to get it and your overall health. To understand how tracheostomy works, it helps to understand how your airways work. The carry air to your lungs. They also carbon dioxide, a waste gas, out of your lungs. The airways your: Air enters your body through your or mouth. The air travels through your voice box and down your windpipe. The windpipe splits two bronchi that your lungs. (For information, go to the Health Topics How the Lungs Work article.) A tracheostomy provides another way for oxygen-rich air to reach your lungs, besides going through your nose mouth. A breathing tube, also called a trach (trake) tube, is put through the tracheostomy and directly into the windpipe to help you breathe. Doctors use tracheostomies for many reasons. One common is to help people who need to be on ventilators (VEN-til-a-tors) for more than a couple of weeks. Ventilators are machines support breathing. If you have a tracheostomy, the trach tube connects to the ventilator. People who have conditions that interfere with coughing or block the upper airways also may need tracheostomies. Coughing is a natural reflex that protects the lungs. It helps clear (a slimy substance) and bacteria from the airways. A trach tube can be used to help remove, or suction, mucus from the airways. might recommend tracheostomies for people have problems due strokes or other conditions. Creating is a common, simple procedure. It's one of the most common procedures for critical care patients in hospitals. The windpipe is located almost under the skin of the So, a surgeon often can create tracheostomy quickly and easily. The procedure usually is done in a hospital operating room. However, also can be safely done a patient's bedside. Less often, a doctor or emergency medical technician do procedure in a life-threatening such as at scene of an accident or other emergency. As with any complications can occur, such as bleeding, infection, and other serious problems. The risks often can be reduced with care and handling of the tracheostomy and tubes and other related supplies. Some people continue to need tracheostomies even after they the hospital. Hospital staff will teach patients and their families caregivers how to properly care for their tracheostomies at home. What is the WHO’s classification scheme? The WHO classifies the cancer-causing potential of various substances into four groups, depending on the evidence available in both humans and other animals: - Group is used when a substance causes cancer in humans - Group 2A is used when a substance ‘probably’ causes cancer in humans - Group 2B used when a substance ‘possibly’ causes cancer in humans - Group 3 is used when a substance is classifiable in terms of its cancer-causing properties in humans because the evidence is inadequate - 4 is used when a substance is ‘probably not’ a cause of cancer in humans What is the WHO now about diesel fumes and cancer? Since 1988, oil fumes have been classified by the IARC as ‘probably carcinogenic humans’. This category is used when there is some, limited evidence that a substance causes cancer in humans, but sufficient evidence it causes cancer in experimental animals. However, the IARC has now reclassified engine exhaust as ‘carcinogenic’ (group 1 on the list above). This category used when there is sufficient evidence that a substance causes cancer in humans. The IARC says there is sufficient evidence diesel is a cause of lung cancer. It is also associated with an increased risk of cancer, although the evidence for the latter is more limited. Why has changed? The WHO says there has been mounting concern in recent the cancer-causing potential of diesel engine exhaust, based on from epidemiological studies of workers exposed diesel fumes. In particular, it cites a large cohort study, published in March this year, of occupational exposure to in US miners. The study run by the US National Cancer Institute and the Institute Occupational Safety Health. It found that to diesel exhaust increased the of dying from lung cancer (1.26, 95% confidence interval 1.09 to 1.44). further case-control study, in this group (comparing 198 miners who had died from lung cancer with 562 miners who were alive at the time the ‘case’ died), found that the risk of lung these workers with the length of time they were exposed to fumes. f73cd86d0641197d4e347b24ccd82860ee5d3be2: If there’s a stack of old newspapers gathering dust under the bed or out the Australian libraries to know about it. search on for these valuable pieces of history, as part Australian Newspaper Plan (www.nla.gov.au/anplan), a nation-wide of and territory libraries designed to find, collect and preserve access historic newspapers. National spokeswoman for the ANPlan, Cathy Pilgrim, of the National Library of Australia, said newspapers did not just report news. They told stories of their times, through photographs and even their design – stories we want to save for all Australians. “The aim is to find the thousands missing pieces in the jigsaw of our history,” said. “Old are an important part of our social, political and cultural history and they offer valuable insights into a society forever. Some of Australia’s most wanted newspapers include: * Cairns (1897-1882); * Croydon Miner (1887-1888) * Mundic Miner Etheridge Gazette (1889-1917); * Pilbarra Goldfields News (1901); * Mercury and South Australian sporting chronicle (1849-1851); * Renmark Pioneer (1893-1895). “Often a conversation uncovers these wanted papers which may been lying hidden in someone’s garage, in an person’s collection keepsakes, or in the vaults of a local historical society or archive,” Ms Pilgrim said. Once the wanted newspapers have been tracked down, they will carefully saved ensure their preservation for future of Australians. Access will be made freely available through the National of Australia and and libraries. For a list of the wanted newspapers from all states of Australia, go to www.nla.gov.au/anplan For information on the Australian Newspaper Plan: Contact Cathy Pilgrim on 02 6262 1514; firstname.lastname@example.org information on ACT newspapers: Contact Julie Whiting on 02 6262 1157; email@example.com

The ultimate objective was to understand if the US History classes are serving the perceived of Latino students. Latinos are 40% of nation’s minorities, are the youngest population and are the fastest growing. The studies is the curriculum area for challenging the dominant worldview and teaching about the diversity present in the classroom, the nation, and the world; therefore, learning more about socio-culturally inclusive social studies curriculum and pedagogy is an important consideration. This project is significant because it intersects with topics to the future of our nation: schools, the studies curriculum, culturally and linguistically diverse (CLD) students, students’ perspectives. Furthermore, the focus this research overlaps with the reality of today’s educational system: state content standards and high stakes testing. All of these aspects will be addressed. This was influenced by Latino Critical Theory. LatCrit an outgrowth of Critical Race (hereafter known CRT). CRT interrogates how research is traditionally done by forefronting race to demonstrate the depth of inequality that exists across society. LatCrit builds on the five themes of CRT while perspectives to Latino experiences in the United States such as language background, gender, ethnicity, immigration status, and colonial experience. were collected six months at Crawford High School (name changed). Group Two student-participants wanted their culture to be present that other students—particularly White students—would learn about them. It’s still one of the great mysteries of obstetrics. advances like gene therapy and transplant surgery revolutionize health care, we still understand the most basic things about how pregnancy works. In fact, at University Chicago, there’s an empty plaque, awaiting the name of the person who discovers what causes labor, so we can learn to preterm birth. So we’re still clueless. But we’ve made progress in the past decade. When a New England Journal of Medicine article that the hormone 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-P) would reduce the risk of preterm birth, listened. However, this drug, which used to be used to treat birth, had of favor, and no manufacturers made it anymore. So got and started getting 17-P from compounding pharmacies, where it could be manufactured from scratch for about per dose. Because the quality of pharmacies vary, and because what drug a gets during pregnancy matters, docs were happy when the FDA approved new drug Makena which would standardize 17-P and make it readily available at hospitals and pharmacies. The FDA reviewed data of a study that showed that, among women with a prior preterm birth, women given Makena in a subsequent pregnancy had a preterm birth rate of 37%, compared to in the control Good news, eh? You’d think. So KV Pharmaceutical, who won seven years of exclusive rights on this drug that been around since the 1950s, then started firing off letters to compounding pharmacies, announcing that they could no longer make 17-P available to the public without facing possible legal action.
