Yes, you heard me right. This $20 drug now costs per dose. That’s about $30,000 per at-risk pregnancy. And insurances get to decide individually whether or not they will cover it -- but even if they that’ll mean co-pays and deductibles. just say it like it is? BULLSHIT. you, Big Pharma. Are you telling me that women who at risk of preterm (lower socio-economic women are at the highest risk) will have to up 30 grand if they want to prevent a pregnancy or raising a disabled child because insurance won’t cover it? Are you telling me our health care industry is so broken that, instead of this ancient drug at price and preventing preterm births, they’d prefer to pay millions to care for that preemie in the NICU or treat that disabled child? Why? Why? Why? Why this According to the Washington Post, “FDA officials that they had no idea how much the planned to charge the drug and were by the cost but that the agency has no power over pricing.” How did our health care industry become so broken that kind of thing can happen? Where is the heart in medicine these days? When did patient care start taking a backseat to the bottom line? No wonder patients health care alike feel so frustrated, demoralized, and disempowered. Something’s gotta change. According to the same FDA official, “If requested, the agency could approve a lower-priced generic version of the drug for another use that doctors prescribe 'off label.'” The also said that the agency would not compounding pharmacies from continuing to provide 17-P unless patient safety is to be “We have our hands full pursuing our enforcement priorities,” the said to the Post. “And it’s not for a physician to write prescription for a compounded drug or for a patient to take a compounded drug. We certainly are concerned about access of patients to medication.” So if you or anyone know had a previous preterm baby, tell them to ask their doctor about prescribing 17-P. A newer version of the talk presented at YAPC::EU 2008 is available SMOP is an alternative implementation of a C to run Perl 6. It is focused in the most pragmatic approach possible, but still focusing in being able to support all Perl 6 features. Its core resembles Perl 5 in some ways, and it differs from Parrot in many ways, including the fact that SMOP is a Virtual Machine. SMOP is simply a runtime engine that happens to have a interpreter run The main difference SMOP and Parrot (besides the not-being-a-vm thing), is that SMOP is from bottom-up an implementation of the Perl 6 OO features, in a way SMOP be able to do a full bootstrap of the 6 type system. Parrot on the other hand have a much more static implementation (the PMC) The same way PGE is a project on of Parrot, SMOP will a grammar engine for itself. SMOP is the implementation that is stressing the meta protocol more than any other implementation, and so far that has a very fruitful exercise, with Larry making many clarifications on the object system thanks to SMOP. Important topics on - SMOP doesn't recurse the C stack, and it doesn't actually define a mandatory paradigm (stack-based or register-based). SMOP has a Polymorphic Eval, that allows you to switch from interpreter to another using Passing Style. See SMOP Stackless. - SMOP doesn't define a object system in its own. The only thing it defines is the concept of Responder which then encapsulates whatever object system. This feature is fundamental to implement the SMOP Native Types. - is intended to bootstrap from the low-level to the high-level. This is achieved by the fact that in SMOP is an Object. This way, even the low-level objects can be exposed to level runtime. See SMOP OO Bootstrap. - SMOP implement a in its own, it will use STD or whatever parser gets ported to its runtime - In order to enable the bootstrap, the runtime have a set of Constant Identifiers that are available the sub-language compilers use. - There are some special SMOP Values Not Subject to Collection. - A interpreter implementation SMOP Mold replaced SLIME - The "official" smop Perl 6 compiler mildew - it lives in v6/mildew - Currently there exists an Elf backend which - it lives in misc/elfish/elfX SMOP GSoC See the Old SMOP Changelog

59fbe0d9993094f762952e5a99b5e6140ca4d013: July 24, 2009 Mark S. Blumberg is Professor and Starch Faculty Fellow at the University of Iowa. His books include Oxford Handbook of Developmental Behavioral Neuroscience, Body Heat: Temperature and Life on Earth, and Basic Instinct: The Genesis of Behavior. He is Editor-in-Chief of journal Behavioral Neuroscience, and President International Society for Developmental Psychobiology. His newest book is Freaks of What Anomalies Tell Us About Development and Evolution. In conversation with D.J. Grothe, Mark Blumberg describes how he became interested in "freaks of nature" as a way to question prevailing concepts within genes, instincts, and pre-formed abilities. He talks about why he sees determinism as "action at a distance thinking," and why he it is similar to creationist views, and describes both as "magical ways of thinking nature." He explains epigenetics. He describes how non-genetic factors that shape behavior may be inherited from one generation to the next. He discusses "sexual freaks" and sexual ambiguity in nature, shows how in many ways, it is the norm in nature. He predicts the extinction of creationist thinking, and about how freaks of nature are a missed opportunity for those science advocates battling intelligent design and creationism, even he also criticizes belief in "evolution's design" and "magical genes." He contrasts his views with those of evolutionary psychology as regards brain development. And he responds to notable of his views, such as Jerry Coyne. Books Mentioned in This Episode: Basic Instinct: The Genesis Behavior Mark S. Blumberg February 27, 2009

9b5c4232e2d08959c96c2ba99fcd5e08b344a59e: A Fertility Specialist Tells About This Medication Used In The Treatment Of Infertility Mark Kan, MD What is Clomid, and how does it The expert answers (also known as Clomid or Serophene) is a medication that is commonly used in fertility treatment. Because it is relatively inexpensive and be orally, clomiphene is generally one of the first medications prescribed for patients who not ovulate regularly. In women who do ovulate regularly, clomiphene may be used for "superovulation," where or 3 eggs are increases the number of "targets" for the sperm, thereby increasing the chance pregnancy. Clomiphene is normally administered for five during the follicular part of the cycle (the portion of the cycle following menstrual bleeding). Clomiphene is similar to estrogen and acts on the estrogen receptor. First approved by the FDA in 1967, it has recently as a selective-estrogen-receptor-modulator (SERM). How does clomiphene work? The hormonal signals that cause ovarian follicles to grow are released from the pituitary gland. These hormones are named Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Leutinizing Hormone (LH) for their actions in the ovary. The receives its signals from hypothalamus in the Clomiphene the estrogen receptor and "tricks" the brain into thinking there are low levels of estrogen. The pituitary responds by releasing FSH and LH, thus stimulating follicular growth in the ovaries. Whereas clomiphene "tricks" the pituitary producing more FSH and LH, gonadotropin injections of FSH and LH increase the amount of signals directly. Treatment with these injections requires more intensive monitoring does therapy with clomiphene. In general, treatment with fertility medications is initiated to help women overcome dysfunction, or produce multiple so there is a higher chance of achieving pregnancy. In the "Clomiphene citrate challenge test" (CCCT), clomiphene is and FSH levels are before and after treatment. theory, clomiphene blocks the negative feedback of estrogen, only inhibin (a substance that inhibits FSH) to suppress FSH. In some women, inhibin alone is able to block the high levels of FSH without the help of estrogen. The CCCT will therefore be abnormal and show high FSH levels after clomiphene in women with diminished ovarian reserve. While the CCCT help to identify some patients with diminished ovarian there is no single test that can predict which patients can or cannot become pregnant.

The event a platform for constructive dialogue and cooperation for the wise use of the resource-rich Caspian Sea. The forum attended representatives of environmental and fisheries agencies and academics of the Caspian countries, with delegations Azerbaijan, Iran, Kazakhstan, Russia and Turkmenistan. Representatives of the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), United Nations Convention on Combating Desertification (UNCCD), as well as and gas companies the Caspian shelf also participated in the forum. The Caspian Sea is the world's landlocked water body; with its particular climatic salinity gradients and its isolation, it is home to about 400 endemic species, including the world's largest herd of sturgeon (90 percent of the world reserves) and endangered Caspian Seal Pusa Following the early days of the Caspian Environment Programme in 1995, The Framework Convention for the Protection of the Marine Environment of the Caspian Sea (Tehran Convention) was ratified by Caspian littoral states in 2006. It is the first legally binding regional agreement ratified by all five Caspian states, defines the general requirements and institutional mechanism for the protection the marine environment of the Caspian Sea. Four to the have currently been developed by the countries, they focus biodiversity conservation; land-based sources of pollution; preparedness, response and cooperation in combating oil pollution incidents; and environmental impact assessment a transboundary context. The Ramsar Secretariat would like to thank Turkmenistan for the invitation and and for its dedication to ecological conservation, expresses its readiness to assist support all Caspian states for wise use and protection of the Caspian Sea. Report by Nessrine Alzahlawi, Advisor Asia-Oceania

PCR for the detection of aflatoxigenic Aspergilli, patulin-producing Penicillum trichothecene- well as fumonisin-producing Fusaria strains have been described. The usefulness of the PCR methods developed so far to monitor quality and safety in the food feed industry was already demonstrated. Thus, PCR may be applied to the screening agricultural commodities for the absence of producers prior to or even processing. Negative results in this assay indicate that a sample should be virtually free mycotoxins. Only the positive samples must be for the presence of mycotoxins using physico-chemical standard methods. This review does not only summarize the so far developed qualitative and quantitative assays for the detection of mycotoxigenic fungi in agricultural commodities, and animal feeds, but describes also to develop new PCR assays for such a detection. 66c2473453acf8d3a6d0ad31c4bd75986ee9e15a: Oct. 9, 1998 COLUMBIA, Mo.--Ducks, geese and bald eagles soaring over areas the size of small towns are envisioned when talking about protected wetlands, not areas that are as big as a small swimming pool and apparently void of life. University of Missouri-Columbia Professor Ray Semlitsch is trying to change that view and explain the importance of smaller wetlands before managed out of existence. "Large wetlands are beautiful and need to be protected, but some animal species such as frogs, toads and salamanders, it is small wetlands that support greater species diversity," said Semlitsch, who along his research assistant, Russ Bodie, recently published their research in Conservation Biology. "These smaller, temporary wetlands--because they dry times during the year--are much to appreciate than vast marsh areas. But without these smaller wetlands, it is very possible that much the animal and plant life that make wetlands rich, productive habitats would not survive. We need worry about the conservation of smaller wetlands as as the larger Small wetlands currently are defined as being less than 4 hectares, or about 8 9 acres. The of the nation's are much smaller than might be imagined, closer to 1 2 acres and sometimes as small as square yards. small wetlands may comprise the majority of wetlands in the United States and help support a vast of species. However, unlike the wetlands, these smaller areas are protected to the same extent. Recently, the Army of Engineers, which manages wetlands of all throughout the United States, drafted regulations that will the way wetlands managed in the future. They have put off any change in management until April, but the researchers argue that in the regulations could manage these smaller wetlands out of existence. "Right now we can't detect losses of small wetlands by satellite imagery, a technique used to assess environmental change," said. "We lose thousands of acres each in and these smaller ones are not even taken into account. Yet, they play a vital role in the ecosystem and support a great variety of organisms." Research by Semlitsch and Bodie has indicated that when some individuals of a species move between wetlands, this increases their chances of survival. By populating many different wetlands, various species thrive, even during years when some wetlands are dry. When smaller wetlands are destroyed, the chances of survival for many species' may decrease dramatically because between individual wetlands longer, making movement between wetlands more difficult. These small breeding sites for amphibians especially critical in light of purported world-wide declines, Semlitsch said. Wetlands in general also have direct benefits to humans as they filter out chemicals and silt, buffer from flooding, are favorite of hunters and fishers. They also are very costly and difficult to develop for construction or other purposes. 43b23a17efd3f9255862ed00be7df26094641cc5: The word vivisection was first coined in the 1800s to denote the experimental dissection of live animals - or humans. It was created by activists who opposed the practice of experimenting on animals. The Roman Celsus claimed that in Alexandria in the 3rd century BCE physicians had performed on sentenced criminals, but vivisection on humans was generally outlawed. Experimenters frequently used living animals. Most early modern researchers considered this practice acceptable, believing that animals felt no pain. Even those who opposed vivisection in the early modern period did not usually do so out of consideration for the animals, but they thought that this practice would coarsen the experimenter, or because they concerned that animals stressed under experimental conditions did represent the normal state body. Prompted by the rise of experimental physiology and the use of animals, an anti-vivisection movement started in the 1860s. Its driving the British journalist Frances Power Cobbe (1822-1904), founded the Victoria Street Society in 1875, which gave rise to the British government's Cruelty to Animals Act of 1876. This law regulated the use of live animals for experimental purposes. R A Kopaladze, 'Ivan P. Pavlov's view on vivisection', Integr. Physiol. Behav. Vivisection Historical Perspective (London: Crooms Helm, 1987) of the of living organisms and their parts.

83071ac03f0ed8bcd7b66c3b6c31ea171e934fa8: Posted by admin on August Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) the size (in bytes) of the largest packet or frame that a given layer of a communications protocol can pass onwards. The may be fixed by standards (as is the with Ethernet) or decided at connect time. A higher MTU brings higher bandwidth efficiency. However, large packets block up a slow interface for some increasing the lag for further The MTU for ethernet is 1500 bytes, 1492 for PPPoE and 576 for Dialup. rare occasions, you may change the MTU size due connectivity issues with your ISPs or in a VPN environment on your openSUSE. The following procedure should help to change Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) openSUSE. In Network Manager If are using Network-Manager to control the network settings your openSUSE then 1. From the menu, click Computer – 2. Click Network Devices in the leftpane and click Network Settings 3. Select the Network Adapter and click Edit. 4. Under General tab, select from the values or own required value. Please be aware of what you are doing as an incorrect MTU setting can cause and performance issues. Click Next and Finish to complete the settings wizard. This will set the MTU value and restart the Network Service. Network configuration you are not using the Network Manager and the traditional method of settings using ifcfg scripts then 1. Using a terminal window, change directory to /etc/sysconfig/network/ opensuse:~ cd /etc/sysconfig/network 2. In /etc/sysconfig/network directory, you a config for each of your network interface card. For on my laptop, have ifcfg-eth0 and (wireless). These hold configurations for the respective network Edit the interface file and enter the line as following opensuse:/etc/sysconfig/network # vi ifcfg-eth0 and add a line like So it looks something like this opensuse11:/etc/sysconfig/network cat 3. Restart network service or reboot your computer for changes to take effect. opensuse11:/etc/sysconfig/network /etc/init.d/network restart Dynamically change To dynamically change the MTU, you can use the ifconfig command. To MTU of interface eth0, opensuse11:~ # ifconfig eth0 mtu However, be lost upon reboot.

58265706c0f6e17ff1ed899ab18e7afe5b712941: The lushly forested nation of Guyana on Thursday joined a regional pact to protect jaguars, the elusive spotted that is the biggest predator in Americas, but is vulnerable expanded agriculture and mining that have carved away at their fragmented habitat. of the government’s environment ministry were signing an with the York-based conservation group Panthera, which is to establish a “jaguar a network pathways that would link core jaguar from northern to Mexico. Guyana is pledging to ensure the protection of jaguars, the national animal that is a near-threatened species. The South American nation some of the region’s least spoiled wilderness joins Colombia and nations Central America recognizing corridor and agreeing to work toward the long-term conservation of jaguars, said Esteban Payan, regional director for Panthera’s South America program. A network of equipped with motion sensors and fixed to tree has revealed tantalizing glimpses of sleek, solitary jaguars through Guyana’s forests vast grasslands stretching to the country’s border with Brazil. Scientists reported finding a relatively healthy jaguar density of three four animals per Guyana’s southern Rupununi Savannah. means that preserving grasslands are as important to conservation of jaguars as protecting the rain say. Evi Paemelaere, a Belgian jaguar scientist with Panthera, said Amerindian villagers in remote spots in Guyana have helped her up cameras along the roads and hunting trails that the big cats like to on. “Amerindians are keen on being part of the project,” she said from Georgetown, Guyana’s capital. Jaguars once widely from the southwestern US to Argentina, but have lost nearly half their territory and have altogether from some countries. Heavy hunting for their spotted coats decimated their numbers in the 1960s and early 1970s until the pelt trade was largely halted. No one has any reliable of how many jaguars are left in the wild, where prey on peccaries, tapirs and, they are powerful swimmers, river turtles.

4977e0f7cce5fb75ed5a8ae20fadfb3f031f933b: They are not expecting any angry birds, but bird-watchers already seeing evidence of what is expected to be a major invasion of hungry winging through the region. Normally content to hang out in the deep forests of Canada, grosbeaks, pine siskins, finches, redpolls and other are winging their way south, hoping to find something eat. The tree seed crop, normally plentiful in the forests of Ontario and Quebec, has some cases failed completely, causing what is known a bird irruption. “The invasion is under way,” said David Small, president of the Athol Bird and Nature Club and one of the Central Massachusetts bird count leaders. “I had redpolls at the feeder, which don't up every and often not January or February.” Mr. Small, who is a supervisor at the Quabbin Reservoir, has been seeing pine grosbeaks at the reservoir headquarters and several locations. Central Massachusetts birders also report seeing white-winged and red crossbills. “I was at Plum Island and Salisbury in early November and saw 250-plus white-winged crossbills,” he said. “So a year is upon us. I recall year it started this early with such diversity and large numbers.” Based on data from ornithologists in the National Audubon Society issued a winter bird warning — not really warning of disaster — that because there is so little to eat up a bird invasion is under The was issued more for the interest of those who will take part in Audubon's Christmas Bird Count, which takes place all over the country from Dec. 14 Jan. 5. The bird count offers up to support what ornithologists are predicting based on climate conditions. The seed crop failure may have been connected to lack of rainfall. Central and Eastern Canada experienced long-term drought conditions this year. Over the years, some species of seed-eating birds have been seen in small numbers; some not seen for several years a time, but the region saw a of pine siskins pass through in October and November. The birds what could get from the limited number of feeders out in Central Massachusetts at time and headed possibly making their way as far south as North and South Carolina. This year's small bird irruption followed banner year for the eye of wild birds — snowy owls. The large white raptors were seen throughout the country as they, too, went off in search of food. Irruptions occur regularly when food various types are disrupted. In the case of the owls, it was a lack of small mammals them to eat. Local birders have been keeping close watch on the ebb of Recently there have been reports WPI's Central Massachusetts Bird Update list of pine at Pond in Brookfield and Worcester Airport. There have also been large numbers pine grosbeaks in downtown Westminster, Royalston and areas of Gardner and Lunenburg. Bill Cormier, co-owner of The Bird and More Sturbridge, said bird activity has been very active this early winter. “There was big of pine that came through earlier in the season,” he said. Mr. Cormier said he is interested to see what collected during the Sturbridge Christmas Bird Count, set for Dec. 18. The count will be led by local bird observer Mark Lynch; after 24 hours of recording birds, volunteers will report data to compilers at The Store. Along with bird counts in Athol and Sturbridge, there will be counts in Uxbridge and Westminster. Feeders are an important part of the bird-count effort, and said he recommends black sunflower seeds with some nuts mixed “Nuts are a major ingredient,” he said. The birds expected or already seen irruption are mostly regular sights in Central Massachusetts, although in smaller numbers, but a few are fairly rare. “We rarely get a hoary redpoll,” Mr. Small said. The hoary redpoll's range is mostly no south than the Canadian border, but Mr. Small said even it is a possibility this year. The Athol and Worcester Christmas will be held Dec. Westminster will be Dec. 23 and Quabbin and Uxbridge will be Dec. 29.

(June 2012)| |Arnold Henry Guyot| Henry Guyot |Born||September 28, 1807 Boudevilliers, Canton of Neuchâtel, Switzerland |Died||February 8, 1884 Princeton, New Jersey, United States Guyot was born at Boudevilliers, near Neuchâtel, Switzerland. He was educated at Chaux-de-Fonds, then at the college of Neuchâtel. 1825, he went Germany, resided in Karlsruhe where met Louis Agassiz, the of a friendship. From Karlsruhe he moved to he studied at the gymnasium. He returned to Neuchâtel in 1827. He to enter the ministry and started at the University Berlin to lectures. While pursuing studies, he also attended lectures on philosophy and natural science. leisure was spent in collecting shells and plants, and he received an entrée to the Berlin Botanical Garden from Humboldt. In 1835, he received the degree of Ph.D. from In 1838, Agassiz's suggestion, he visited the Swiss glaciers and communicated the results of his six weeks' investigation to the Geological Society of France. He was the first to point out certain important observations relating to glacial motion structure. Among other things he noted the more rapid flow of the center than of the sides, and the more rapid flow of the top than of the bottom of glaciers; described the laminated or ribboned structure of the ice; and ascribed the movement of glaciers to a gradual molecular displacement rather than to a sliding of the ice mass as held by de Saussure. He subsequently collected data concerning erratic boulders. In 1839, he became the colleague of Agassiz as professor of history and physical geography at the of Neuchâtel (a.k.a. Neuchâtel Academy?). suspension of that in caused to emigrate, at Agassiz's instance, to the United States, where he settled in Cambridge, Massachusetts. He delivered a of lectures Lowell Institute which afterward published as Earth and Man (Boston For several years the Massachusetts Board of Education retained his services as a lecturer on geography and methods of instruction to the normal schools and institutes. He was occupied with work until his appointment, in 1854, as professor of and geology at Princeton University, which office he retained his death. He was also for several years lecturer on physical geography in the State Normal in Trenton, New Jersey, and from 1861 to 1866 lecturer the Princeton Theological Seminary. also gave courses in the Union Theological Seminary, New York, and at Columbia College. He founded the museum at Princeton, many of specimens of which are from his own collections. His scientific work in the United States the perfection of plans for a national system of meteorological Most of these were conducted under the auspices of the Smithsonian Institution. His extensive to the establishment of the United States Weather Bureau, his Meteorological Physical Tables (1852, revised ed. 1884) were long standard. His graded series of text-books and wall-maps were important in popularization of geological study in America. In addition to text-books, his principal publications - Earth and Man, Lectures on Physical Geography in Relation to the History Mankind (translated by Cornelius Conway Felton, - Memoir of Louis Agassiz (1883) - Creation, or Biblical Cosmogony in the Light Modern Science (1884). - Universal Cyclopaedia (1876) - with Frederick Augustus Porter Barnard He is the namesake of several geographical features, including Guyot Glacier in Alaska, Mount Guyot on the North Carolina and Tennessee border, and a different Mount Guyot in New Hampshire, as well Mount Guyot the Rocky Mountain Continental Divide in Colorado. The building housing the Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology the Department of Geosciences at is named Hall in his honor. - James Dana's Memoir in the Biographical Memoirs the National Academy of Science, vol. ii. (Washington, 1886). - This article text from a publication now in the public domain: Chisholm, Hugh, ed. (1911). "Guyot, Arnold Encyclopædia Britannica (11th Cambridge University Press. 22d8008b713250f42b3be8f56f1dab770fdd773a: WAKING GIANT Bill McGuire we transmit more than million tweets a day nearly one hundred trillion emails each year, we're also emitting record amounts of carbon dioxide (CO2). Bill McGuire, professor of geophysical and climate hazards at University College London, expects our continued rise in greenhouse gas emissions to awaken a slumbering giant: the Earth's crust. In Waking the Giant: a Changing Climate Triggers Earthquakes, Tsunamis Volcanoes (Oxford University Press), he explains that when the Earth's crust (or geosphere) becomes disrupted from rising temperatures and a C[O.sub.2]-rich atmosphere, natural disasters frequently and with catastrophic force. Applying a presentation of what we know about how climate the geosphere interact," the book links warming periods 20,000 to 5,000 years a greater abundance of tsunamis, landslides, seismic activity and volcanic eruptions. McGuire urgently warns of the "tempestuous future of our own making" as we progressively inch toward a similar climate. Despite his scientific testimony to Congress stating "what is going on in Arctic now is the biggest and fastest that Nature has done" and the that the Earth's climate draws response from brutal weather events are still not widely seen as being connected to human influence. Is our global population sleepwalking toward imminent destruction, he asks, until "it is obvious, even to the most denier, that our climate is being transformed?"
9b403143fb0a36ba3a0176ebc2a525a31459a005: From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Preventive medicine or preventive care refers to measures taken to prevent diseases, injuries) rather than curing them or treating their symptoms. term contrasts in method with curative and palliative medicine, and in scope with public health methods (which work at the of population health rather than individual health). takes place at primary, secondary prevention levels. - Primary prevention avoids the development of a disease. Most population-based promotion activities are primary measures. - Secondary prevention activities are aimed at early disease detection, thereby increasing opportunities for interventions to prevent progression of the disease and emergence symptoms. - Tertiary prevention reduces the negative impact of an already established disease by restoring function and reducing disease-related complications. - Quaternary prevention is the set of health activities that mitigate or avoid the consequences of unnecessary or excessive interventions in the health system. Simple examples preventive medicine include hand and immunizations. Preventive care may include examinations and screening tests tailored an age, health, family For example, a person with a family history of certain cancers or diseases would begin at an earlier age and/or more frequently than those with no family history. On the other side of preventive medicine, some non-profit organizations, such as the Northern California Cancer Center, apply epidemiological research towards finding ways prevent diseases. Universal, and indicated Gordon (1987) in area of disease and later and Baxley in the area of substance use proposed a three-tiered preventive intervention classification system: universal, selective, and indicated prevention. Amongst others, this typology has gained favour and is used by the U.S. Institute of Medicine, the NIDA and European for Drugs and Drug Addiction. addresses the entire population (national, local community, school, and aim to prevent or delay the abuse of tobacco, and other drugs. All individuals, without screening, provided with information and skills necessary the problem. Selective prevention focuses on groups whose risk of of abuse or dependence is above average. The subgroups may distinguished characteristics such as age, gender, family history, or economic status. For example, drug campaigns in recreational settings. Indicated prevention involves a screening process, and to identify individuals who exhibit signs substance abuse and other problem behaviours. Identifiers include falling grades among students, known problem consumption or conduct disorders, alienation from parents, school, and positive peer groups etc. Outside the scope of this model is environmental prevention. prevention approaches are typically managed the regulatory or community level, and focus on interventions to deter drug consumption. Prohibition and bans (e.g. smoking workplace bans, alcohol advertising bans) may be the ultimate environmental restriction. However, in practice environmental preventions programmes embrace various initiatives at the and micro level, from government monopolies for sales, through roadside sobriety or drug tests, worker/pupil/student drug testing, in sensitive settings (near schools, at rock festivals), and legislative guidelines aimed at precipitating (warnings, penalties, fines). Professionals involved in public health aspect of this practice may be involved in entomology, pest control, and public health inspections. Public inspections can include waters, pools, beaches, food preparation and serving, and industrial inspections and surveys. In the United States, preventive medicine is a medical specialty, one of the 24 recognized by the American Board of Medical Specialties (ABMS). It encompasses three areas of specialization: - General preventive and public health - Aerospace medicine - Occupational medicine In order to become board-certified in one of the preventive areas of specialization, a licensed U.S. physician (M.D. or D.O.) must successfully complete a preventive medicine medical residency program a one-year internship. Following that, the must complete a year of in area and pass the preventive medicine board examination. The residency program is at least two in length and includes completion of a degree in public health (MPH) or equivalent. The board takes an entire day: the general preventive medicine questions, while the afternoon session concentrates

da3ede0d9d9f68bc0eec3a043a9cc501fe90ccd2: SEA level rises and climate change are linked, say top scientists as they prepare the next major global climate change update. More than 250 from 39 countries are in Hobart this week to the latest draft of the Panel on Climate Change's report including a new chapter on sea level. The co-ordinating lead author on the new chapter, CSIRO's Dr John Church, said sea level is clearly to change. sea is rising, the rate of the rise has increased and will continue to increase," he said. the rate had increased from a few tenths of a millimetre a year before the 20th century to more 3mm a year in the past 20 years. "It's clear the rate of sea level rise has already increased," he "Whether that 3mm a further acceleration not is yet unclear but we do expect a acceleration during the 21st century and it's clearly linked to greater levels of greenhouse gases." He said thermal expansion because of ocean warming and the melting of glaciers were two causes of sea rise. CSIRO's Dr Steve Rintoul, is involved with the observations chapter, said oceans were very for climate amount of heat they absorbed and stored. He said the temperature of the ocean surface had increased by 0.3-0.5C over the past 50 years. "There's no disputing the oceans are warming," he said. "It's clear from the published literature that greenhouse gases as natural variability have contributed to this observed warming of ocean." said oceans around Tasmania were changing, with recordings showing temperatures around Maria Island increased by 1.5C over the past 60 years. "It's a very large compared with other parts of the ocean," said. The Hobart conference the last meeting before scientists prepare the draft the IPCC report's physical science section. The final report be submitted in September.

aa29ae3b216b167d1f27add2bf9696e0f0e8f2aa: What Are The Main Of Water Filter? There are several different types of water filters available for use in home and for other purposes. type water filter that you require depends on what you need to use it for. ordinary tap in the home for the purpose improving the taste is a common practice. Chlorination and excess minerals can drastically change the taste and smell of tap water, but running the water through filter can eliminate these substances and make the water much better. If you are spending time in doing some camping available water sources as lakes can dangerous or even deadly to drink. In this case a more powerful type of would be needed. Other instances in which you might need to have a much more method of water filtration when traveling in foreign countries or in the event of a major disaster such as a flood. The charcoal based water filter is one the most of all of water This is the type of filter that you find in a typical water filtration pitcher such as the Brita pitcher, and also in most types of on-the-faucet water filters. types of filter usually have a cartridge that contains a combination of charcoal and sand. When water is poured through filter, the charcoal removes chlorine, chemicals and some other contaminants the filters out any larger particles. The result is clear looking and clean tasting water. filtration of outdoor water when camping and backpacking, a portable reverse system is one option. Reverse osmosis purifies water by passing it through a semi-permeable membrane, which traps nearly of all contaminants, both chemical and biological. Since biological contaminants as bacteria and are a major threat in rivers and lakes, is important to have a filter that is able to safely remove them. disadvantage of reverse osmosis is that the is extremely slow and wastes a lot of water. A reverse osmosis filter can also a valuable part of any emergency supply because contaminated water is a common encountered in emergency situations. Because reverse osmosis is capable of even removing viruses from this type of filter save lives countries where there is an extreme shortage of safe drinking water. Another one of the more popular types of water filter is the ceramic microfilter. Like a reverse osmosis system, ceramic filtration system also uses an ultra-fine to the water. In this case, porous ceramic is used as a filter. The ceramic is fine enough to trap even most bacteria and some types of virus, so they successfully purify water in most parts of the world. Many ceramic-based water also incorporate charcoal the filters improve taste while offering maximum filtration at the same time. Logic and Loss It’s logical: If inflammation causes certain diseases, then eating foods that combat inflammation should prevent those diseases. Heat-labile nutrients are also lost in dried fruits, but soluble fiber (especially good for cholesterol levels) and many nutrients like magnesium and iron are maintained. One caveat: Dried fruit tastes good, so likely eat more. “It’s a substantial calorie load,” she warns. As for cooking, “there’s certain wisdom to things raw; you don’t destroy the nutrients that are heat-labile,” explains. “But by the same token, are substances in food that, when them, actually have a benefit for you.” She recommends vegetables in the microwave, which introduces the least amount of vitamin-leeching water and requires a shorter cooking time. 4c5a9ba1019f37b8c774f6334cc43265c6aa68f6: 1 October 2009 A picnic basket linked to Agatha Christie, soil samples collected before Channel Tunnel was built and a radioactive rock used in a Nobel Prize-winning experiment feature in a new exhibition at UCL. Disposal?, which opens on Monday 19 October 2009, invites you to comment on the most challenging question by museums today: What should we collect and hold on to and what should we get rid of? includes objects which would normally be on display, such as a crusher which can apply the weight of 150 hippos, a collection of plastic dinosaurs slides containing microscopic fossils. these are five objects earmarked for disposal the public can vote on. This is one of several ways which people can contribute their views on the collections: on what think is important, what should collected what they feel would be better off elsewhere. Featured pieces will include: - A picnic basket to Agatha Christie’s second wife Barbara Parker. The husband, Max Mallowan, was a famous archaeologist. Parker donated the hamper and its contents to UCL. The contents included Minoan pottery, a key, a doorknob, beads and a copy of The Times. - Soil collected before the building of the Channel Tunnel. Archaeologists take to see if site contains archaeological material. These samples were stored at soon after they were taken, have been analysed. - A radioactive mineral sample which emits alpha particles, but is historically important. William Ramsay (1852–1916), a former head of UCL Chemistry, used it to discover helium in one a series Prize-winning experiments. The will also host two events: - ‘Fight at the Museum: My Object!’ on Tuesday 20 October, 6.30pm – 9pm, will see battle to convince an audience to save their favourite object housed in different collections at UCL. - ‘Treasured? Hunt’ on Wednesday 28 – 9pm, will invite people to seek out intriguing and specimens in store and decide for themselves just how treasured objects should Disposing of objects by museums is controversial, conjuring up emotive images of collections thrown into skips or valuable artworks lost to nation through private sales. With ever-decreasing resources and collections, are under serious pressure. are fast becoming unsustainable – ethical but tough decision-making is essential to museums’ survival. In a research-led university such as UCL, collections have to keep with cutting-edge innovations and new discoveries. While active collecting always on, responsible and regular disposal is essential for collections to stay manageable. Subhadra Das, UCL Collections Reviewer, says: Museums & Collections of fascinating and historically important objects which are for teaching and research. Like all museums, they also contain objects whose roles unclear or problematic. Some objects may no longer be useful, some are too big or have become damaged and should never have been collected. In the such things have sometimes been of thoughtlessly – by putting them in the skip. This exhibition is about disposal.” The exhibition runs from Monday 19 October to Saturday 31 October 2009, is open to the public and is free of Opening hours are Monday-Friday 10am-7pm, Saturday 10am-6pm. The exhibition is in the Chadwick Building, UCL, Gower Street, London WC1E 6BT. Media contact: Jenny Gimpel Image: A hippopotamus skull
a9989b082eb91ac71a18a7689f6f67dfd8908b58: A simple, inexpensive method for preventing type 2 diabetes that relies on calling people and educating them on the sort of lifestyle changes they could make to avoid developing the disease has effective in a study conducted researchers at the University of Francisco (UCSF) the City Berkeley Department of Public Health. The study involved 230 people in poor, urban neighborhoods in the San Francisco Bay Area cities of Richmond, Oakland and Berkeley. Contacted by phone about once a month, half of them received specific dietary guidance and lifestyle counseling. After six months, those who had received the counseling had on average lost more were consuming less fat, were eating more fruits and vegetables and showed more improvements in lowering in their a key risk measure for type diabetes. Described this week in the American Journal of Public Health, the intervention is specifically designed for urban, poor, predominantly minority communities. It addresses need for diabetes prevention interventions in these communities and highlights a simple fact that doctors and elsewhere have repeating for years — that type 2 diabetes is preventable in first place. “Diabetes is not something you are necessarily going to get just because it runs in your family,” said Alka Kanaya, MD, associate professor of UCSF and one of two senior authors on study. very preventable, and lifestyle changes can really impact the onset of diabetes.” “You can do something about said Anita PhD, a professor at the UCSF Institute Health & Aging and Center for Aging in Diverse Communities who is the other senior author on the paper. How Lifestyle Changes Can Prevent Diabetes Diabetes is a chronic and complex disease marked by high levels of sugar in the blood that arise due to problems with hormone insulin, which regulates blood sugar levels. It is usually caused by an inability insulin (type 1) or an inability to respond correctly to insulin (type 2). A major health concern in the United States, diabetes of types affect an estimated 8.3 percent of the population — some 25.8 million Americans — and cost U.S. more $200 billion annually. In California an estimated 4 million people (one of every seven adults) type 2 diabetes and millions more are at risk of developing it. These numbers are poised to explode in the next half if more is done to prevent diabetes. Previous studies have shown that counseling and other lifestyle interventions are effective at preventing type 2 diabetes, but those interventions have designed for clinical settings and include separate sessions with numerous health professionals. This makes them expensive difficult scale to large urban populations where are needed the most. Many this country’s urban poor face thin health insurance coverage, low literacy, and low income, and a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes. These disparities were apparent in the UCSF study. About half study population was of immigrants, nearly a quarter had no health insurance. Almost a said they faced financial hardship, and 22 percent had less than education. By focusing on a phone-based solution delivered by Public Health department staff, the UCSF researchers designed their new intervention specifically as a low-cost community-based approach that would be relevant to poor, minority and low-literacy populations. Similar telephone interventions have used to reach out broadly to populations San and in cities to spread messages related hypertension, smoking, high cholesterol and other issues. “This adds to our public health toolkit of ways to do outreach and prevent diabetes,” said Kanaya. The article, “The Live Well, Be Well Study: A Community-Based, Translational Lifestyle Program to Lower Diabetes Risk Factors in Ethnic Minority Status Adults” by Alka M. Kanaya, Jasmine Santoyo-Olsson, Steven Gregorich, Melanie Grossman, Tanya Moore and Anita Stewart appears 14, 2012 issue of American Journal of Public Health. This work was funded by National Institutes of Health a translational research grant from National Institute of Diabetes Digestive and Kidney Diseases (DK067896-01A2) and by the Resource Centers for Minority Research of the Institute on Aging (P30-AG15272). UCSF is a leading university dedicated promoting health worldwide through advanced biomedical research, graduate-level education in the life health professions, and excellence in care.

06f07033d9aa86b11081305c96272308e26f8ed5: Conference underscores young leadership in prevention 27 August 2010 The role of people in improving the state of the world took centre stage this week’s World Youth Conference in Leon, Mexico. Over days, delegates from 112 countries—including 25 000 youth and representatives from government, civil society and the United Nations—shared ideas on young people’s involvement in achieving Millennium Goals (MDGs). With an estimated 40% of new HIV infections occurring among people aged 15-24, a youth-centered approach the AIDS response will be critical to meet MDG 6—halting and reversing the spread of HIV—and to ensure efforts are sustained in the long term. In a video message to young delegates, UNAIDS Executive Director Michel Sidibé said young people had the power to shape a future with zero new infections, zero discrimination and zero AIDS-related deaths. “Each you is driving force for change and development in your own countries,” he said. “Together you are an incredible movement that is shaping future of the world.” the 33.4 million people living with HIV worldwide, some 5 million are young people. An estimated 2500 young become newly infected with HIV each day. The epidemic has taken a particularly devastating toll on the lives of young women, who account for 66% of youth worldwide. Empowering young to protect themselves from HIV represents one of UNAIDS’ ten priority areas, with the overall goal of a 30% reduction in new HIV infections by 2015. At joint workshop on HIV and young people, UNAIDS and UNFPA introduced a new “business case” successes to date in the HIV response among youth and areas for improvement. Through the workshop, young were invited to offer their perspectives on the relevance and application of the business case at the national level. Evidence-based information and HIV including sexual and reproductive health, were highlighted as critical to reducing infection among young people. Many participants voiced concern reaching young people HIV prevention messages. we are still and exploring, we may get into risky behaviors,” said Gastelum, a youth participant from Mexico who attended the workshop. information on is the first step—that will protect us.” Less than 40% of young men and women have access to accurate about HIV transmission—far short of the 95% target set in the UNGASS of Commitment for the year 2010. In developing China, only 30% of young men and 19% young women benefit from information on HIV. Despite challenges, there are signs of progress. A new study from UNAIDS has reported more than 25% in HIV prevalence among young people in 15 countries heavily affected by the AIDS epidemic. “Simply young people are leading a prevention revolution over the globe,” said Dr. César Nunez, of the UNAIDS Regional Support Team for Latin America, in a session at the conference. “The empowerment of young people has led to changes in sexual behavior. Young people are choosing to sex later, with fewer partners, and they are using condoms.” Earlier this month, UN launched International of Youth, an initiative designed to increase youth participation in global development issues and enhance inter-cultural dialogue and understanding across generations. a launch event in York City, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon urged young people across the world to look beyond the borders of own countries: “Engage with the world. Become a global citizen,” he said. “We are the leaders of today. You are the of tomorrow.”

f5e7fe7fa0137e14c7c1746ecc1f7dc1b6e900d9: What is Harvesting? Rainwater harvesting is an ancient practice of catching and holding rain for later use. In a rainwater harvesting system, rain is from a building rooftop other source and is held in containers for future use, such as watering gardens or washing cars. This practice reduces the demand water resources and excellent during times of drought. is it Important? In addition to reducing the demand on our water (especially important during drought), harvesting also helps prevent water pollution. Surprised? Here’s why: the of the Clean Water has meant that the greatest threat to New York’s waterbodies comes not from industrial sources, but rather through the small actions all make in daily For example, a rain storm, oil, pesticides, animal waste, and litter from our lawns, sidewalks, driveways, and streets are washed down into our sewers. This is called non-point (NPS) pollution because the pollutants come from too many sources to be identified. Rainwater harvesting water from becoming polluted stormwater; instead, this captured rainwater may be used to irrigate gardens near where it falls. In New York City, keeping rainwater out of the sewer system is very important. That’s because the city has an old sewer system that uses the same pipes to transport household waste stormwater to treatment plants. During heavy rains, the overloads; then untreated sewage and contaminated stormwater overflow into rivers and estuary, serious consequences: is Harvesting Rainwater in New York City? Back in 2002, a emergency pushed many community to the brink of extinction. For the first in years, community gardeners were denied permission to use fire hydrants, the source of water for community This crisis led to the formation of the Water Resources Group (WRG), an open collaboration of community gardening and environmental organizations. With help from the WRG, rainwater harvesting systems have now been built as demonstration sites in twenty NYC community gardens. At community harvest rainwater, rain diverted the gutters of adjacent buildings and is stored in tanks in the gardens. A 1-inch rainfall on a 1,000-square-foot roof produces 600 gallons of water. The tanks are mosquito proof, so standing water does not encourage West Nile virus. Because rainwater is chlorine free, it is than water for plant growth, meaning healthier plants. And it’s free! What are Other Cities Doing? Many cities have creative, low-cost ways to stop wasting rainwater by diverting from their sewage systems and putting to use where it falls. Here are some examples: What Can I Do? Spread the word! Educate those around you on the importance of lifestyle Tell people to litter, dump oil down storm drains, or overfertilize their lawns. Install rainwater harvesting system at your home, school, business, local community center. Contact your local elected officials, and let them know you support rainwater harvesting! 151e12b268124681c8b2b9a4edda22340c12194a: What is Morbid Obesity? Obesity becomes "morbid" when it reaches the point of significantly increasing the risk of or more obesity-related health conditions or serious diseases (also known as co-morbidities) result either in physical disability or even death. As you read about morbid obesity you may also see the term "clinically severe obesity" used. Both are of same condition and can used interchangeably. Morbid obesity is typically defined as being 100 lbs. more over ideal body weight or having a Body Mass Index of 40 higher. According to the National Institutes Health Consensus Report, morbid obesity is a serious disease and must be treated as such. It is a chronic disease, meaning that its symptoms build slowly over an period of

By keeping tires properly inflated, you can reduce your vehicle's "carbon footprint" by an average of 327 pounds per year. 328b4b5b42cc8ef72b9a547de57505d08d4d6166: Streptococcus, Group B It is possible that the main title of the report Streptococcus, Group B is not the name you check the synonyms listing to find the alternate name(s) and disorder subdivision(s) covered by this - B Streptococcal Septicemia of the Newborn - Lancefield Group B Streptococcus - Sepsis of the Newborn - Streptococcus Agalactiae - Infant Early-Onset Streptococcus, Group B - Infant Late-Onset Streptococcus, Group B - Adult Onset Streptococcus, B Group B streptococcus (group B strep) is a type of bacteria that causes infection among newborns, pregnant women or women after childbirth, after gynecologic surgery, and older and female patients with serious diseases. Group B strep remains common cause among newborns (neonates) of infection of the blood (septicemia) and of the brain (meningitis). The bacterium, usually S. agalactiae, may be found most often in and rectum of females be transmitted sexually, as well as a fetus as the infant passes through the birth canal. Group B strep infection of newborns may be prevented by giving pregnant women who are carriers antibiotics through vein (intravenously) during labor. U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommend that any pregnant woman who has had a baby with group B strep disease the past, who has a bladder (urinary tract) infection caused group B strep, or tests positive for group B strep during pregnancy antibiotics during labor. Prevention and prompt treatment important because group B strep infections may become life-threatening among newborns. GBS disease is said to be early if it is obvious within first week life. It is said to be onset if the disease is after the first week of life and before the end of the months. Those at greatest risk of GBS disease are children of infected mothers, women after childbirth, females after surgery and male and female patients with other serious diseases. 3adb4ead2bfaa515d168790bdf0c69eeb4cadbfb: Divers have found bottles of champagne thought to pre-date the French Revolution on the Baltic seabed. When they opened one, they found wine - to have been made Clicquot (now Veuve Clicquot) between 1782 and 1788 - was still in condition. The bottle - whose shape indicates it was produced in the 18th Century - has been sent to France for analysis. If confirmed, it would be the oldest drinkable champagne in the world. Diver Christian Ekstrom was exploring a shipwreck on Baltic when he found the bottles. He took one to the surface, where he opened it and tasted it with his colleagues. "It was fantastic," he told the Reuters news agency. "It had a very sweet taste, you could taste oak and it had a very strong tobacco smell. And there were small bubbles." According records, Clicquot was first produced in 1772 but was laid down for 10 years. was disrupted after French Revolution in 1789. The wine found on the seabed was perfectly preserved because of the conditions dark and cold on the seabed. If the bottles do come from the 1780s, that would make them 40 years older than the current a bottle of 1825. Wine experts estimate each bottle would fetch around 500,000 Swedish kronor (£45,000; $69,000) at auction. The bottles were found off the coast of Aaland, autonomous part of Finland. The authorities will decide what is done with the - and the champagne.

Haroche is a professor at the College de France and Ecole Superieure in Wineland is leader and Fellow at the National Institute Standards and Technology and the University of Colorado Boulder. dedb25d23707f037a443e32902143a646c149b05: Here's way the NWS defines it: Forecasts issued by the National Weather Service include a "PoP" (probability of precipitation) statement, which is often expressed as the "chance of rain" or "chance of precipitation".http://www.srh.noaa.gov/ffc/?n=pop ZONE FOR NORTH AND CENTRAL GEORGIA NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE PEACHTREE CITY GA 119 PM EDT THU MAY 8 2008 INCLUDING THE CITIES OF...ATLANTA...CONYERS...DECATUR... 119 PM EDT THU MAY x 2008 AFTERNOON...MOSTLY CLOUDY WITH A 40 OF AND THUNDERSTORMS. WINDY. HIGHS IN THE LOWER NEAR STEADY TEMPERATURE IN THE LOWER 80S. SOUTH WINDS TO MPH. .TONIGHT...MOSTLY WITH A CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS IN EVENING...THEN A SLIGHT CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS AFTER MIDNIGHT. LOWS IN THE MID 60S. SOUTHWEST WINDS 5 TO 15 MPH. CHANCE OF RAIN 40 PERCENT. What does this "40 percent" ...will it rain 40 percent of of the time? ...will it rain over 40 percent of area? The "Probability of Precipitation" (PoP) describes the chance of precipitation occurring at any point you select in the area. How do forecasters arrive value? Mathematically, PoP is defined as follows: PoP = C x A where "C" = confidence precipitation will occur somewhere in the forecast area, and where "A" the of the area that will receive measureable precipitation, it occurs at all. So... in the case of the forecast above, if forecaster knows precipitation is sure to occur ( confidence is 100% ), he/she is expressing much of the area will rain. ( PoP = "C" x "A" or "1" times ".4" which equals .4 or 40%.) most of the time, the forecaster expressing a combination of degree of confidence and areal If the forecaster only sure that occur, and expects that, if does occur, it will produce measurable rain over about 80 percent of the area, the PoP of rain) is 40%. ( PoP = .5 x which equals .4 40%. ) In either event, the correct way to interpret the forecast is: is a percent chance that rain will occur at any given point in the area.

765e59a748065aeafaf2ddc06c8f3b15ea6f8d78: Why is my paper pink? The color of today’s paper is probably quite a shock to many of our readers, and that is just the effect are hoping for. Today marks the beginning of Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and this edition The Herald is dedicated to raising awareness about the importance of early detection and for efforts to help find a cure. Most of us know someone who has been affected by breast cancer. Besides some forms of skin it the most common cancer in women. It doesn’t discriminate. Breast cancer rates are equally high among women of all races. The Center of Disease Control reports that it is the highest of death by cancer among Hispanic women and the cause death among white and black women. One eight women in the United States will suffer from invasive breast cancer at some point in their lives. Fortunately, breast deaths have been decreasing since 1990 as detection and treatment improve, reducing the mortality rate to 3 in 100. If you’re reading this and you haven’t had an it’s time to make an appointment. Last Updated (Friday, 30 September 2011 18:19)

d8ee230c3b580d88965ace27efd8ef2278be2e2e: |Yoon Jae Kim, yj1dreamer AT gmail.com (A project report written under the guidance of Prof. Raj Jain)||Download| Service Architecture (SOA) is a design pattern which is composed of loosely coupled, discoverable, reusable, inter-operable platform agnostic services in which each of services follow a well defined standard. Each of these services can be bound or unbound at any time and as needed. [Jamil08]However, as defined, SOA has a loosely-coupled feature, which makes open the challenges of security. It means that SOA must meet several requirements. The main requirements are as follows[Candolin07]: service discovery, service authentication, access confidentiality, integrity, availability, and privacy. To security in a loosely-coupled SOA the open standards communities that created Web services developed number of security for Web services which one of the most active and widely adopted implementation of SOA. Figure 1 depicts a notional reference model for Web services security standards. This reference model maps the different standards to the different functional layers of a typical Web service implementation. As described above, in the Web Services Security Stack the Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) and the eXtensible Access Control Markup Language (XACML) are the standard for access control which means that when service is requested by a user the service must enforce the specified policy to access control. focus on access in Web Services and represent what SAML XACML are, how work and where they able to be applied together. SAML, created by the Security Services Committee of the Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards (OASIS), a an XML-based framework for communicating user authentication, entitlement, and attribute information. As its name suggests, SAML allows business entities to make assertions regarding the identity, attributes, entitlements of a subject (an entity that is often a human user) to other entities, such partner company or another enterprise [Madsen05] SAML is a flexible and extensible protocol designed to be used - and customized if necessary - by other standards. Web Single Sign-On In web SSO, a authenticates to one web site and then, without additional authentication, is able to access some personalized or customized resources at another site. SAML enables web the communication of an authentication assertion from the first site to the second which, if confident of the of the assertion, choose to log in user as they had authenticated directly. A principal authenticates at the identity provider and is subsequently recognized (and given corresponding access/service) at the service provider.[Google] For example, Google made SAML Single Sign-On (SSO) Service for Google Apps. And Google provides a SAML-based Single Sign-On (SSO) service that offers partner companies with full over the authorization and authentication of hosted user accounts that can web-based applications like or Google Calendar. As the service provider Google services Gmail Start Pages and partner companies control account information as identity provider. Similar to the Web SSO scenario, the authorization has one web site communicating identity information about a subject to another web in support of some identity information may be characteristic of the subject (such as a person's role in a B2B scenario) rather than, addition to, information about when how the person was authenticated. The attribute-based authorization model is important when the individual's particular identity is either not important, should not be shared for privacy or is insufficient on its own. Securing Web Services SAML assertions can be messages in order convey security and identity between actors in web service The SAML Token Profile produced by the OASIS Web Security (WSS) TC specifies how SAML assertions should be for purpose WS-Security Liberty Alliance's Identity Web Service Framework (ID-WSF) builds these specifications to use SAML assertions for enabling and privacy-respecting access to web services. WS-Trust, one component of the framework initiative, proposes protocols for exchange and validation of security tokens used as described within WS-Security. SAML assertions one such supported token format. Figure 3 illustrates these actors and information As can be seen in the figure, the PAP writes Polices and PolicySets and makes them available to the PDP. She that she does not want anyone to shoot the antlered deer just the does. She gives you four special non-antlered damage tags, and you have your own state antlered tags. 253d062127e32d02b6e6a13e1e6409abfe2129fa: Eighteen years ago, the eminent conservation Gary Meffe warned he considered to be the greatest problem in human – humanity’s inexorable and exponential increase in Meffe’s paper, entitled ‘Human Population The Missing Agenda’ published in the journal Conservation Biology, outlined the threats posed by an ever-increasing human to biodiversity in terms species extinctions, and to the ecosystem services necessary for our survival. These include water and air hydrologic cycling and food production. only is humanity’s deluge drowning the creatures we share the Earth with, but it the risk of submerging itself too. But was this ‘missing agenda’ acknowledged? Was a dam constructed to our exponential flow? Nearly two decades later and we see the publication of the UN’s State Population report 2011. It announced that on October 31st we the population milestone of seven billion people inhabiting Instead of warning future population and the associated negative impact, it had a more positive that encouraged us to ask “What can I do to make our world better?” rather than “Are too many?” This is the Nations after and understandably it has to take a progressive and reassuring stance rather than one doom gloom. But the angle taken is perhaps revealing of prevailing of the global consciousness – population growth is inevitable and cannot be stopped. Of course there’s no such thing as a global collective consciousness, explaining in why Meffe’s view has been largely ignored, because humanity a collective impetus and so anything that requires mass cohesion, for instance only having one child or reducing carbon emissions, is doomed to fail. Seven billion people – it’s enough to make you feel insignificant. Except it’s not, it’s just a number. very big number too large to visualise, grasp or comprehend. you’re ever having trouble feeling insignificant, then listen to what the ‘Woody Allen’ of science, Krauss has to say. In his recent on cosmic connections for The School of Life he stated that “you are much more than you thought” before going on to with Brian Cox title of ‘King of making outlandish profound points’, by explaining how we are all literally “made stars”. Every atom in our bodies comes from the remnants of an exploded star. It turns Moby was right (see video below). This digression aside, the ineffably large human population will continue to increase and even if we wanted to implement population control, doing so would be unethical and practically speaking impossible. Very few people, not even many devout conservationists, would be to sacrifice the have children. I for one wouldn’t, in our evolutionary spirit. Instead of tackling the so called ‘root cause’ of the population problem by implementing unrealistic, unfavourable, and unwanted control, efforts have been directed addressing offshoot as those relating to overconsumption and overexploitation natural resources. If we adopt cleaner technologies and practices to ensure our impact the environment is neutral or at least negligible, it will a step the right direction. Just this week the production of a ‘microbial fuel cell’ has been announced which can purportedly produce electricity from urine! Researchers at the University of the West of England (UWE) found that by utilising anaerobic bacteria as they metabolise organic waste waters, electrons can be harnessed and useful electricity generated. By ‘useful’ is meant that enough electricity would be generated to charge a battery say, but presumably not to heat home for instance, For now, no one is suggesting this is the answer to the world’s problems, but switching to technologies that rely less on finite Earth and more on recycling waste products will help ameliorate the effects our species on the Unfortunately though, those who sing the praises of such advances are often branded with the stigma of being too ‘preachy’. Increasing public apathy to important issues such as clean technology, climate change and biodiversity decline should be at least as to everyone as financial crises or terrorism.
0d33a3bb918787a9b46adc61b4d12be51806d6b2: Idaho State researchers study newly discovered earthquake fault in Idaho’s Mountains September 28, While looking at a highly detailed topographic image of Idaho’s Sawtooth Range, State University geosciences professor Glenn Thackray had an "eureka moment" when he discovered a previously unknown active earthquake fault about 65 miles, as the crow flies, from Boise. The researchers examined a Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) image. LIDAR is a remote sensing system used to topographic data with aircraft-mounted lasers capable of recording elevation measurements at a rate of 25,000 pulses per second and can have a vertical precision of about six inches. The images can be displayed they don't show an area's vegetation. Four years ago while doing some research on glaciers in the Sawtooth Range, Thackray was examining a "bare-earth" LIDAR image of the mountains: this is when he noticed a line running through the image in vicinity Redfish Lake. "The black line stood and I thought that it had to be an earthquake Thackray said. "It was long suspected that there was an active fault in the Sawtooths, but without the LIDAR it would have been exceptionally hard find." Since that time, ISU researchers have on the ground documenting the fault that is least 25 miles long and could be as long as 40 is located the eastern edge of the range and comes within about five miles from the town of Stanley. A portion of it runs through the upper end of Redfish Lake. It runs along range approximately from near Stanley Lake to at least far south as Lake. reason this discovery so important that is within the heavily visited areas the Sawtooth Recreation area, very close to the town of Stanley, and 65 miles of Idaho’s largest city, Boise, the most populated area in the state,” Thackray said. “We would like know how big the earthquakes are along this and how active it is.” Thackray emphasized that the fault is for concern, but not alarm, for visitors to and residents of the Stanley-Sawtooth area, and the residents of Wood River or Boise valleys. The discovery may have implications for and emergency planning, and perhaps building codes. Depending on magnitude of a earthquake, it could do to surrounding areas. There are few active faults in Idaho. Idaho’s three other major faults run along the base of the Lost (where the famous Borah Peak magnitude 7.3 earthquake, the largest ever recorded in Idaho, occurred in 1983), the Lemhi Range and Beaverhead Range. Faults are break in the earth’s crust, along which rocks and earth move. Typically, the earth up on one side of the fault, and moving down on the other. "It's the of the rocks that important. is what creates earthquake Thackray said. After discovering the fault on the image and then confirming its existence on the ground, researchers to determine whether it was an active fault, defined as fault that has featured an earthquake within the last 10,000 years. Determining whether the fault was active was a challenge for the researchers because most of the is located within Sawtooth Wilderness and Recreation Area. "Normally, to test a fault you could take in a Cat or backhoe and dig up sediment and rock and use carbon dating to date the of previous activity," Thackray said. "But we couldn’t do that because the fault is in a wilderness area." This is where a little luck and scientific serendipity came into play. Other researchers, sciences professor Bruce Finney, postdoctoral researcher Mark and ISU geosciences graduate student Eric Johnson, were doing lake sediment core sampling of lakes in the including Redfish to study the historical record of sockeye returning area. While the in the upper portion of Redfish Lake the researchers levels where deposits interrupted the regular accumulation of sediment deposits. "We were able to date the occurrence of the most recent fault by those samples the large in Redfish Lake," Thackray said. "There is a lot that we still don’t know about this fault, but our studies have revealed the outline of its history," he added.

c4bbee77bc587c877215506e5ac643c4c9ebea36: Genetic model organisms have revolutionized science, and today, with the advances in technology, there is significant potential to many more plant species towards model However, these new model organisms have to be carefully selected. Hemerocallis (the daylily) satisfies multiple criteria for selection and deserves serious consideration as a subject of intensive biological investigation. Several attributes of the genus are of great biological interest. These include the strict control of flower opening within a short period, the precisely regulated floral death by programmed cell system. self-incompatibility system in Hemerocallis is also noteworthy and deserves more attention. Importantly, the genus cultivated for food, medicinal value and ornamental has considerable potential as a ‘nutraceutical’ food plant and the source of compounds with biomedical activity. The genus has been embraced by ornamental plant breeders and the extraordinary morphological diversity hybrid cultivars, produced a relatively short time by enthusiasts, is an exceptional for botanical and studies. This in PLANTS explores these points in detail, explaining the reasons why this genus has considerable value – both academic socio-economic and deserves new resources devoted to its exploration as a model. Its impact as a future model be enhanced by its amenability to cultivation in laboratory and field conditions. In addition, established methods for various tissue and cell culture systems as well as transformation will permit maximum exploitation of this genus by science. Rodriguez-Enriquez, M.J., and Grant-Downton, R.T. (2012) A new day dawning: Hemerocallis (daylily) as a future model organism. AoB Plants 5: pls055 doi: 10.1093/aobpla/pls055
03ef2ad73ed6475e823ca3a95a0274a1f882fe41: Discover the cosmos! The above picture captures a of the Orion Nebula that reflects light from bright Orion stars. This reflection nebula because the blue light from the neighboring stars scatters more efficiently from nebula gas than red light. e0efae42fa1544f1a3a369cd8edeba83479a4699: Discover the Each day a different image or photograph of our fascinating universe is along with a brief explanation written by a professional astronomer. 2001 December 20 Explanation: Viewed from Earth, the solar system's planets do a cosmic dance that is hard to appreciate on any single night. But consider this planned animated sequence combining pictures taken at approximately 2 week intervals June 2000 through May 2001. It reveals the graceful looping or retrograde motion of bright Jupiter (leftmost) and Saturn. Loitering among the background stars are the familiar Pleiades right) and V-shaped Hyades (below left) clusters. The planets didn't actually loop by reversing the direction of their orbits, though. Their apparent retrograde motion is a reflection of the motion of the Earth itself. Retrograde motion can be seen each Earth overtakes and laps planets orbiting from the Sun, Earth moving more rapidly through own relatively close-in orbit. Astronomer Tunc Tezel captured Jupiter and Saturn's "paired" retrograde loop in this remarkable made after the close alignment of these gas giants in May 2000. The next opportunity to see these two planets dance such a pas de deux will be in the year 2020. Authors & editors: Jerry Bonnell (USRA) NASA Rep.: Jay Specific rights apply. On first day of the war, the German Reichsbank, like the other central banks of the belligerent powers, suspended redeemability of notes in prevent a run on its gold reserves. Like all the other banks, it assistance to the central government in financing the war effort. Since taxes are always unpopular, German government preferred to needed amounts money rather than raise its taxes substantially. To this end it was readily assisted by the Reichsbank, which discounted most treasury obligations. A percentage of government debt found its way into the vaults of the central bank and an equivalent amount of printing press money into people’s cash holdings. In short, the central bank was monetizing the government debt. the end of the war the amount of money circulation had risen fourfold and prices some 140 percent. Yet the German mark had suffered no more than the British pound, was somewhat weaker than the American but stronger than the French franc.
