Yet until its discovery in the 1911, Machu Picchu, "the city the Incas," forgotten for years. Actually, Machu Picchu was not a city at all. was probably built by Pachacuti Inca as a royal estate and religious retreat in 1460-70. Its location—on a remote secondary road in nearly impassable terrain high above the River canyon cloud forest—almost ensured that it would have no administrative, commercial or military use. Any movement in that direction to or from Cusco and the valley upriver would have by other roads, either the high road Salcantay or the Lucumayo valley road. Travel was restricted on these roads except by Inca decree. After Pachacuti Inca's death, Machu Picchu remained the property of his or kinship group, who were responsible for maintenance, administration and continued building. an extraordinary sacred site (location as well as it surely was visited Topa Inca and the last great ruler, Huayna Capac, although each in turn built own estates and palaces. But few outside the Inca's retainers would have known of its existence. Inca: "Information's Gotta Be Of course the compound would have required steady supply of outside goods. Machu Picchu, like most Inca sites undergoing constant construction and must of had a crew of builders as well as planters, and others. So in order to really how Machu Picchu remained a secret, it's necessary to understand how Inca culture constricted travel and information. The Inca were a completely ordered an regimented society. Although great numbers of people moved around corporate state projects and resettlement, once at a location, they didn't move. The royal roads were reserved for official travel. The Incas to control their remarkable state system through a pyramidal hierarchy with information direction flowing down through 10 overseers to 100, 1000 and so on. We know from historical writing and the archaeological record that the Incas did not possess a written language, although, must have used some symbols and perhaps diagrams. We also know that the Quipu (collection of colored strings and knots) was extensively used for accounting and record keeping. But Quipus need highly trained interpreters to read and the Spanish were unable to locate or even one of these specialists. The also maintained a class or guild of verbal historians. But with the catastrophic collapse of Inca state structure following the Spanish, these historians were scattered and forgotten. But Machu Picchu was mostly forgotten even before the Spanish came. Small pox was the conquistadores' advance guard. Huayna Capac and an estimated 50 percent of population died of small pox sometime around 1527. Inca government suffered, and after a period of turmoil, the empire fell into civil war over Inca secession. Machu Picchu was probably abandoned at this time—both because was expensive to maintain with most of the population dead from war or epidemic, it was hard find labor to keep it up. Conquistadores: If It Ain't Gold, We Care The Pizarros arrived in Cusco 1532. The wave of were illiterate, uneducated adventurers who had little interest in anything besides wealth and power. By the time scholars and administrators arrived, of Machu Picchu had been lost. But by that point it hardly mattered. The Machu Picchu and the site itself would have been long overgrown and approach by seasonal landslides that so hinder backcountry in Peru. Beyond personal observations and many trips to Machu Picchu, I have borrowed heavily from the excellent of John Hemming, John Rowe and Johan Reinhart. fd9bc96532dd79f3abc64cf98a38e244f2ebcf24: Report Highlights Declining Health of Caribbean Corals 7 September 2012: A new International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) report highlights average coral cover on Caribbean reefs declined to just 8% of the reef today, compared with more than 50% in 1970s. The report stems from a workshop held by Global Reef Monitoring Network at the Smithsonian Research Institute in the Republic of Panama, 29 April-5 May 2012. According to the report, of decline on most show no signs slowing. However, many reefs the Antilles and Cayman Islands have 30% or more live coral cover. The causes of these regional differences in reef conditions are not well understood, the of human exploitation disturbance. Carl Gustaf Lundin, Director, IUCN Global Marine and Polar Programme, notes that the major causes of coral include overfishing, pollution, disease, and bleaching caused by rising resulting from burning of fossil fuels. IUCN has recommended local action to improve the health of including limits fishing through catch quotas, an extension of protected areas a halt to runoff from land, and a reduction on the global reliance on fossil fuels. [IUCN Press Release] [Publication: Tropical Americas Coral Reef Resilience Workshop: Summary]

076d3e11d8ace725ba8c833636621fa8179e8b43: Something astonishing happening China. An unfolding story that Chinese me, be a turning point conservation and wild protection in China.” On Sunday 11 November people discovered many sick and ORIENTAL (Ciconia boyciana) at Beidagang Reservoir, Tianjin (just 30 mins from Beijing by train). These globally endangered birds - with a restricted range East Asia – had been poisoned illegally by poachers using a chemical called carbofuran that, although banned in the EU, Canada and other countries, is commonly available and used, legitimately, as a pesticide all over China. The storks were possibly unintended victims of well-organised and, sadly, all-too poaching activity intended to catch ducks and geese for restaurant trade. Carbofuran is mixed with cereal, or given to fish in small man-made pools. Birds lose consciousness after eating the bait, are caught by hand and injected with an antidote. The victims are then shipped – usually alive – to restaurants, primarily in southern China. The demand for wild birds is high and they are sold a delicacy, with many consumers, particularly in southern cities like Guangzhou and Shenzhen, believing that wild birds taste better than produce, and they are prepared to pay premium. A wild goose or swan can fetch several hundred Yuan (100 Yuan = 10 GBP). The business is highly profitable. The scale of activity in China, and the range of used by poachers to wild birds, are covered in an excellent, but sobering, article in most recent of Goose Bulletin. authors estimate that between and swans and geese are caught illegally in China for the restaurant trade every year. So what makes the recent case involving Oriental Storks at Beidagang such a big deal? The answer is the incredible public reaction, led by local people and driven by social media. The unfolding at Beidagang, although desperately could have been much worse were it not for some dedicated and brave individuals. Local birders, with volunteers, officials from the Forestry Administration, police and even firemen have working together help catch, treat care for these birds. They have set up 24/7 patrols to deter the poachers. All of this been transmitted on social media and the coverage gone viral. The Chinese service, Weibo, has over 500 million users (on a par with global membership on Twitter) and activists have been regular updates that have been ‘re-tweeted’ by growing band followers. As I write this post, the latest update been over 900 times to more than a million users in less than one hour. This leading the traditional print and visual media. we are seeing articles relating to this poisoning incident in Chinese and English language media, both local national. All of a outcry against the illegal trapping and hunting of wild birds China, also led by social media. Three weeks ago a brave undercover journalist released a shocking video about using spotlights to confuse migrants in before gunning them out of the sky. The Chinese outraged and Weibo was alive with condemnation of the hunters criticism of the authorities being to act. Shortly after this major local birders discovered over 2km of illegal mist nets at Beidagang, site of the current Oriental Stork tragedy. Local activists, of whom are now on site trying to save storks, led a ‘day of action’ over 60 volunteers, even the Chinese army, to take down illegal mist nets in the reedbed. This was by local and national TV as well as print media. Due to these two the number of articles relating to illegal trapping and nationwide has exploded. The campaign to eradicate the illegal hunting of birds is gaining momentum. And the scale the reaction by ordinary Chinese people all over the country overwhelming, demonstrating clearly that the vast majority of Chinese care deeply about their wild birds. It will be hard for authorities to ignore. 9f1825546dbc66b6643e91bb6f0891620c77453a: Guest post by Henry B. Perry Perry, M.D., Ph.D., MPH, is a senior in the Department of International Health at Johns University’s Bloomberg of Public Health in Baltimore, Md. During past half-century, there has been a recognition that community-based workers can an important contribution to the health of communities, especially in resource-constrained settings. These workers are known by many names, but most Community Workers (CHWs). initial training of usually weeks or less, they can effectively provide different types of services from community mobilization to health education to preventive screening to family planning education to identifying persons symptoms of leprosy or tuberculosis to diagnosis and treatment of life-threatening childhood illness, and many more. These persons may work as volunteers or for modest or salaries. Based on early projects that CHWs effectively in a number of developing countries, seminal International Conference on Primary Health Care — sponsored by the World Health Organization and UNICEF in 1978 and attended by high-level representatives of almost every country in the world — recognized that in many where facilities highly trained workers are CHWs can an important part of a primary health care system. The Declaration of Alma Ata, adopted at the conference, called for basic health services — promotive, preventive, curative and rehabilitative to be “health workers, including physicians, nurses, midwives, auxiliaries and community [italics added] as applicable, as well as traditional as needed, suitably trained socially and technically to as a health team and to to the expressed needs of the community.” The Declaration also recognized the importance of health services “as as possible where live and work.” A rapidly growing number of studies demonstrate that make it to access and improve coverage of essential services, particularly in remote poorly served populations, thereby improving equity. have been shown to play critical roles in interventions to - reduce child mortality, including distribution vitamin A capsules and other critical micronutrients - promote and sanitation education (hand point-of-use water treatment and safe water storage, latrine construction and promotion of latrine use) - distribute mosquito and assist communities in draining stagnant to breeding grounds for mosquitoes - diagnose and treat childhood pneumonia, diarrhea, newborn sepsis and severe malnutrition - promote healthy behaviors such as appropriate breastfeeding (exclusive breastfeeding the first six months of life and continued breastfeeding until at least one year of age) - provide hygiene and cleanliness education - ensure appropriate care of newborns - promote and facilitate immunizations for mothers and Many countries can benefit by scaling up integrated management pneumonia, diarrhea, and newborn sepsis and promotion of healthy behaviors that can save the lives of millions of children who are dying from preventable causes. CHWs are one of the essential ingredients for making this possible — along with commitment, leadership, long-term training, and supervision the health system logistical support of basic medicines and supplies. A commitment by the world community to these activities, which are some of most cost-effective approaches to promoting global in health, is moral imperative for today tomorrow. James the renowned director of from 1980 1995 and champion what is often referred to as the First Child Survival Revolution, repeatedly reminded us “morality must march with capacity.” We know that CHWs can have the capacity to make a difference between life death for millions of children. The moral imperative for the world is to ensure that health systems and underserved communities support CHWs in attaining capacity. Berman, P. A., D. R. d742f8fdaa710eed085b73ee7af87211e3b33d07: The Garo community is one of the major tribes in Bangladesh. According to the books, the Garo tribe entered Bangladesh in the first century. They were from Mongolia and came to this region through Tibet. The Garo have stayed in for thousands of years. Initially, they followed a religion Sonatoni; during the British rule in this subcontinent came to Christ. nearly 100 percent of the Garo tribe Christianity, though a few in Sonatoni. Garos have their own language, which is completely from the language, Bengali. Achik has several accents/branches such Habeng, Attong, etc. The Garo tribe also has own culture. Their food habits and celebration styles can easily distinguished from the Bengalis and other tribes. The people from the Garo tribe have different features than the original inhabitants of (Bengali people). They are a little shorter and have fair skin. Their eyes and nose are to their ancestors from Mongolia. Compared to other tribal groups, the Garo tribe is little advanced education and social activities. The first Garo church (Garo Baptist Convention) was established in 1910. Many missionaries and evangelists from Europe and North worked among the Garo people over the decades. Being of a developing country, the community suffers from Many Garo families are deprived of education. Garos in villages and in remote places suffer from lack of clean water and sanitation. There are many villages like Gobindopur and Nalchapra, which greatly need hospitals medical facilities. The people Garo community have go to the local pharmacy for minor diseases or injuries. major problems, they have to take the patient to the town, is about 35 kilometers away. The Garo have only high school (sixth 10th grade) with a of only children. This government school only nine teachers. two primary schools in those villages with limited capacity and facilities. The houses of the Garo people are of bamboo walls and straw or tin roofs. houses have mud walls a roof of straw and plastic sheets. House are typically 7 feet wide and 14 feet long. The Garo build their own houses. they have free spaces in front their houses. cows, chicken and ducks as pets. Garo usually have an average of two to three children. Thirty of the Garo people have completed high school. However, the remaining 70 percent have not; poor families can’t afford to send their children to school. The government Bangladesh has ensured all children can attend primary school. But many children from Garo community drop out after the primary level. The educated people from the Garo community work in nongovernmental and other corporate organizations. The poorer people earn their keep by working as day laborers, usually in the crop fields for nine or 10 hours daily. Available transportation in Garo villages is cycle or for long distances. But since most peope can’t afford the fare, they walk. Cycle-vans are used carry goods. In the both male and have to work for the family. The interesting part is that the Garo ladies get ownership of the properties the family, a tradition completely opposite of the Bengali people. The festivals are very colorful and full of music and dancing. and Easter are two major religious festivals. Their biggest cultural festival is called Wangala the festival when Garo thank God for new crops. It takes place just after the harvesting period. The Garo prepare pitha (homemade sweets and other food to celebrate this occasion. At the celebration, Garo girls their dress sprinkle puffed rice and dry rice with their The traditional dress of the Garo ladies is called a combination of a long skirt blouse. The wear regular shirts, trousers and lungi (Bangladeshi skirt for men). The favorite of the Garo are pork, snails, eel and little They use a substance called Khari to make the food more tasteful. prepare the at home. 7a06421979d386d7e6339a8068988ffd938ec00f: Using the Congressional Set for Genealogical Research By Jeffery (This article appeared in the Spring 2009 issue of Prologue. It has been excerpted and reprinted with the permission of the author. The Historical Documents section in GenealogyBank includes over 243,000 reports from the US Set and the American State Papers). Click here to search the American State Papers and US Congressional Serial Set in GenealogyBank.com Genealogists use whatever sources are available to them in pursuit of their family history: diaries, Bibles, census records, passenger arrival records, and federal records. set materials that is often overlooked, however, is Congressional Serial Set. This large multivolume resource various congressional reports and documents from the beginning of the federal government, and its coverage is wide and varied. Women, African Americans, Native Americans, soldiers and sailors, pensioners, landowners, and inventors are represented in some fashion. While a beginning genealogist would not use the Serial Set to begin a family history, it nevertheless can serve as valuable tool and resource for someone helping to flesh out an ancestors life, especially where coincided with the interests of the U.S. federal government. In 1817, the Serial Set was begun with the intent of being the official, collective, definitive documenting the activities of the federal Following the destruction of the Capitol in 1814 by the British, Congress became interested in publishing their records to make them more accessible and less vulnerable to loss. In the early Federal period, printing of congressional had been haphazard, and the Serial Set was an effort designed to rectify that situation. Although initially there were no regulations concerning what should be included, several laws and regulations were promulgated over the years. The contents, therefore, vary depending on the year in question. Because it was retrospective effort, these 38 volumes were chronologically within 10 subject areas: Foreign Relations, Indian Affairs, Finance, Commerce & Navigation, Military Affairs, Naval Affairs, Post Office, Public Lands, Claims, and Miscellaneous. ff217e7b242c58902265f5f7e4b7dc5a2a1a84b2: Mississippians know the strength longleaf pines. These native trees braved Hurricane Katrina percent better than their cousins. Even so, the ancient longleaf pine forests of the South are a threatened These forests once dominated region, spanning million acres. Now, they cover just 3 million acres. As longleaf habitat disappears, so do many important and endangered species, the tortoise, which rely on it. The gopher tortoise is considered a keystone species in longleaf pine habitat, with than 300 different vertebrate and invertebrate species relying on burrows by the reptiles for their homes. Longleaf pine forests are home to 122 endangered or threatened plant and animal species. In addition, they can contain many as 300 different species of groundcover plants per acre, and about 60 percent of and reptile species found in the Southeast. USDA’s Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) wants to restore longleaf forests to their former glory with the help of landowners Orby Purvis, Miss. The Healthy Forests Reserve Program (HFRP) offered by NRCS allows Wright to manage tall stands of longleaf and the blanket legumes and forbs across the of his Quail Hollow Ranch. HFRP is one of several programs in the tool chest of the Longleaf Pine Initiative, a nine-state to bolster longleaf pine forests. Forbs clovers, sunflowers, milkweed and other common wildflowers typical of the Mississippi forest floor. Both forbs and legumes provide sustenance and cover for a range of wildlife. Wright purchased about 2,000 acres four years ago from a pecan company. The land boasts pines of different ages—some are decades old, while others are just saplings. With the help of NRCS, Wright has planted longleaf pines while taking of his older, A healthy longleaf ecosystem requires occasional fires. Many years ago, wildfires frequented the longleaf landscape, creating food for wildlife and providing other benefits. To help maintain rugged habitat, Wright has lanes and out prescribed burns, all NRCS’ assistance. So far, NRCS programs have helped restore 1,641 acres of longleaf pines in Mississippi and assisted in prescribed burns on 1,812 acres. In Lamar County, lives, 669 acres of longleaf pines were restored in 2010. Approved participants receive financial assistance for implementing conservation practices including planting longleaf pine, installing firebreaks, conducting prescribed burning and invasive plants. 8705c0e8ab071cab0f35898f79dcc32ad336c812: Millennial themes: age, services December 01, 1999 The Bureau of Labor Statistics recently released its force projections for the period 1998-2008. Some of the themes that may be important to watch over the next several years include: - The continuing aging of the labor The median age of workers is projected to rise to nearly 41 years. At the median age of labor force will just exceed the previous high of 40.5 years reached in 1962. - The growing importance of education. Occupations that least an associate degree will account for 40 percent of all job growth out to 2008, compared to a one-quarter share of all jobs that existed in 1998. - The dominance of the service-producing sector a source of employment growth. In the projection period—1998 to 2008—the service sector will account for more 90 of job growth. Projections of the labor force and the industrial and occupational composition of employment are a product of the Employment Projections program. To find out more, see articles from the November 1999 issue of Monthly Labor Review. 57383057cc6e71f34ff84017555617d582a6c9c0: Disease outbreaks, such as cholera, are commonly thought happen after earthquakes and other disasters, but studies have found no evidence to support this. And the persistence of this belief may be hurting relief efforts. The devastating earthquake in Haiti in January 2010 was followed by a deadly cholera Many saw this as inevitable outcome of disaster, as sanitary conditions combined numerous bodies and survivors housed in cramped quarters to produce an incubator for deadly diseases. “It’s what all of us worried about when we arrived in Haiti just hours after the quake,” said NBC's Brian Williams, according to Popular Science. “Beyond the toll, the inevitable spread of disease.” However, a forensic analysis of the outbreak has shown that it had very little to do with either earthquake or conditions in Haiti afterwards. The spread of the disease was traced back to a small military that built years before, its faulty sanitation system that allowed fecal matter to pollute nearby river. Analysis of the strain of cholerae that swept the Haitian population showed that it was identical to the one that was infecting people in Nepal, where some of the soldiers at the base stationed before they joined the Haiti relief efforts. [ More Geekquinox: Man out stunning Mars ] The problem with the belief in the 'inevitability' the according journalist and author Jonathan M. Katz wrote in his PopSci article, "most journalists and responders shrugged off cholera as a natural product of the disaster. The attitude made epidemiologists and aid workers less likely to seek out the source of what was in fact a particular infection not only new to Haiti, the entire hemisphere." "And it since to provide cover for the United Nations as advocates for reparations, and public health try to reform the peacekeeping system to prevent such a catastrophic error from happening again." he "Conditioned to look for a problem that wasn’t there, responders ignored the greatest public health threat of all: themselves."

d2413b2a225da1440d15756adddf0e5ab19a683a: Epilepsy Phenome/Genome (EPGP) The purpose of this study to collect detailed the characteristics and genetics of a number of individuals with epilepsy. |Study Design:||Observational Model: Case Control Time Perspective: Prospective |Official Title:||Epilepsy Phenome/Genome Project: A Phenotype/Genotype Analysis Epilepsy| - EPGP will recruit persons with specific forms of epilepsy. DNA will be isolated from participants' blood and variants associated with common forms of epilepsy will be identified. [ Time Frame: over 4.5 years ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ] Biospecimen Retention: Samples With |Study Start Date:||November 2007| |Estimated Study 2013| |Estimated Primary Completion Date:||December 2012 (Final data collection date for primary outcome measure)| individuals with epilepsy Epilepsy is one of the most common neurological disorders and is a major public health concern. Approximately 30 percent of people with epilepsy have medically epilepsy, and the medical and social consequences of the disorder are enormous. Treatments developed for epilepsy have largely been experimental rather than based on of mechanisms because the mechanisms are poorly understood. Epilepsy Phenome/Genome Project (EPGP) is a large-scale, international, multi-institutional, collaborative research project aimed at advancing the understanding of the genetic basis of the most common forms epilepsy. The overall goal of EPGP is to collect detailed, high quality phenotypic (i.e., characteristics of from the molecular level to the whole person) information on persons with epilepsy and to compare the phenotypic information with genomic information. EPGP will provide a resource that may lead to many discoveries related the diagnosis and treatment of including the eventual development of new therapies on a better understanding of causes of the disorder. This can also be broken down to 50,000 victims per hour, 820 per or 14 victims every second. In just the last 12 months 44% people have been victim of cybercrime while only 15% have been a victim of physical crime in the same period. I regularly meet with law enforcement who are fighting cybercrime. The above clearly illustrate the biggest challenge by enforcement—the enormous scope of the problem. so many victims in many different countries, police can one cybercriminal but still be left with thousands of more cases. The police do a great job trying to stop cybercrime but problem requires significantly more resources than currently being devoted to stop it. of people in the Norton study reported the cybercrime to law enforcement. This also creates a significant problem for police and prosecutors. Some prosecutors will accept cases that exceed a certain amount of victims or high level of damages. US law allows federal to combine multiple into a common case if crime is linked. This is critical in many cybercrime where there be a small number of victims who have lost a relatively small amount individually. However, failure report enforcement from addressing the problem. Finally, the key message of this report is one of hope. Despite the really frightening statistics on scale of cybercrime, cybercrime is still largely a preventable the three most common reported of cybercrime viruses, scams, phishing attacks. All crimes are largely preventable by following good security practices and using updated security software. I have worked with crime victims some capacity for over a decade now. Nobody wants to be a victim. The police are to help but is an extremely rare cybercrime case in which a victim actually recovers lost money . Time dealing with cybercrime also lost forever. It is far better to use good software and follow careful safety online that can greatly reduce likelihood of one of the 7 in 10 global cybercrime last year.
b00466a7ee0a9989384328587b0e9acff8ba638b: Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) Passed in 1996, The Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) denies federal recognition marriages and gives each state the right to refuse recognition of same-sex marriage licenses issued by other states. The act does not prohibit from allowing gay marriages, but neither does it obligate states to recognize the gay marriages from other states. For the time in history, the federal government defines marriage in the Act as a "legal union between one man and one as husband and wife," and spouse is as "a person of the opposite sex who is a husband or a wife." Marriages that do not this description are not eligible for any benefits offered by the federal government. For Information DOMA, see Senate Subcommittee Hearing on the Proposed Federal Defense of Marriage Act.

6dc91569ece2111c79161eed132763032355c853: Last Updated: Feb 17, 2012 Fair trade is a sales model that honors each participant in the production and purchase process. It focuses on sustainability and of the environment, and is rooted in fair economic practices and When you purchase an item labeled as trade, you are helping support fair prices, environmental protections, direct trade, fair labor conditions, and local communities. Why Buy Fair Trade Our modern world economy puts a heavy focus on the bottom line: in decision between two similar products, price is usually the deciding However, this practice often discriminates against small craftsmen, and labor cooperatives, since their per-unit production and materials costs are higher than those of mass producers. Additionally, major manufacturers may employ unjust business practices, such as low wages or poor worker rights, to maintain low prices for their finished products. Fair trade, on the other hand, honors the developing world's small businesses and promotes rights for workers and producers around the Additionally, this business model social development, helping fund schools and community growth, and directly some of the world's poorest communities. & Fair Labor The international Fair Trade Labeling Organization sets the price for all Fair Trade products, ensuring that item is priced justly. By these standards, a fair price adequately covers the cost the production and living wages workers. A wage is defined as sufficient to cover medical care, education, shelter cost of living. Fair trade companies, farmers and artisans respect their environment and engage sustainable production. For example, fair trade farmers avoid the use of most agrochemicals by employing natural methods like crop rotation and biological pest control. 85% of Fair Trade Certified™ coffee is organically. The conventional supply employs many intermediaries – buyers, exporters, and importers, among others. Fair supports a more route, connecting a producer or cooperative to a fair trade distributor, then to the store. This process allows for profit dilution, fosters long-term relationships between producers importers. Support Local Communities Without fair trade, artisans, and cooperatives from small, developing would not have access to the By purchasing fair trade items produced by you contribute directly to their local economy. In fact, many fair trade producers invest profits back into their businesses and communities. Additionally, all fair trade sales include a "social premium," which is a set fee the cooperative that must be invested in community development. Each cooperative a collective as how to invest social premium.

45213f47b09c690b76ba529f881599846973463d: Date: December 2004 Creator: Habel, Agnieszka Description: This problem in lieu is a discussion of two topics: Brownian movement and quantum computers. Brownian movement is a physical phenomenon in which the particle is constantly undergoing random fluctuations. Chapters 2, 3 and 4, describe Brownian motion from three different perspectives. The next four chapters are devoted to the subject of quantum computers, which are the signal of new era of technology and science combined together. In the first chapter I present to a the topics of my problem in lieu of thesis. In the chapter I explain the idea of Brownian motion, its interpretation as stochastic process and I find its distribution function. The next chapter illustrates the probabilistic picture of Brownian motion, where the statistical averages over trajectories are related to the probability distribution function. Chapter 4 shows how to derive the Langevin equation, introduced in 1, using a Hamiltonian of a with infinite number of harmonic oscillators. The chapter 5 explains how the idea quantum was developed and step-by-step all the puzzles for field of quantum computers created. next chapter 6, discus the basic quantum unit of information ... 9d74d5270fe863ceaaa9592e822e13a6fd979bfa: Labrador Retriever originated in Newfoundland, Canada. Small dogs were used retrieve birds fish; they even pulled small boats through the water. Their desire to versatility, and waterproof coats impressed fishermen, of whom brought a dog back to England with him. Lord Malmsbury saw this dog, then called a John’s Dog, and imported from Newfoundland. Lord Malmsbury is credited with having started to call the dogs Labradors, although the reason is lost to history. Eventually, the English quarantine stopped additional imports from coming into the country, and the Labradors already in England were cross-bred to other retrievers. However, breed fanciers soon put a that, and the breed we know it today born. Labrador Retriever is probably the most popular dog breed in the Labrador Retriever is a medium-sized, strongly built dog breed that retains hunting and working Standing between 21.5 and 24.5 inches tall and weighing between 55 and 80 pounds, with females than males, the is compact and well-balanced. Labrador Retrievers have short, coats that can be yellow, black, or chocolate. The head is broad, the eyes are friendly, and the tail is otterlike. Grooming a Labrador Retriever is not difficult, although it is how much the coat can times. Shedding is worst in spring and fall the short, dense undercoat and coarser outer coat lose all dead hair. Brushing daily during these times will lessen the amount of hair in the house. Photo: Labrador Retriever – Brown, Black and Yellow. Labrador Retrievers everything with vigor. When it’s time to they play hard. When it’s time to take a nap, they that with enthusiasm, too. But this desire to and instinct to work means Labs need vigorous exercise every day and a job to do. They need bring in the newspaper every morning, learn to up their toys, and train in obedience. Labrador Retrievers do very well in many canine activities, including agility, flyball, field tests and tracking, search-and-rescue and therapy dog work. Labrador Retrievers still enjoy swimming, and if water a swim is a great way to burn off excess energy. Early and training can teach a Labrador Retriever puppy household rules and social manners. Training continue throughout puppyhood and into adulthood so that the Labrador Retriever’s mind is kept busy. The Retriever can advanced obedience, tricks, or anything else her owner wishes to teach her. Labrador Retrievers are great family dogs. They will bark when people the house but are not watchdogs or protective. Labrador Retriever puppies are boisterous and rambunctious and need to be taught to be gentle with young children. Older kids will enjoy the Lab’s willingness to play. Most Labrador Retrievers also good with other dogs and can to live with small pets, although interactions should be supervised. Health concerns include hip and elbow dysplasia, knee problems, eye problems, and allergies. The Labrador Retriever loves to swim. b6bb65e52ebd9fd528c9ec943a67d20827f42aaf: Fixing Math Education AKA "Drill-n-Kill" vs "Inquiry Based" AKA "Traditional" vs "Progressive" Notice how some terms naturally sound better than others? Does that have anything to do with the substance of the ideas? So there's really no general agreement on what constructivism is. Some people argue it's not curriculum or pedagogy, it's brain science. I use it to refer to those approaches of mathematics that require students to develop their mathematics scratch. It might include "Problem Solving," Learning," and "Inquiry-based Learning (IBL)." My apologies to those who claim that I do violence to their pet definitions here. But there do seem be two general camps. On the one we have those who think students should learn efficient, time-tested methods solving problems, and learn them mastery (automation). These I call "traditionalists." On the other hand, we have who emphasize that should learn to think creatively, develop strategies novel problems, and develop deep insights into mathematics. These I call "constructivists." The answer is actually simple. We need both. However, sacrifices must made, there one approach that is essential, and one that is merely desirable. Unfortunately, reasonable people disagree about which is This, however, is my blog, so opinion is right. The much-maligned traditional is essential. We must first realize that there is a great deal of disinformation floating around about the traditional method. Its opponents claim the traditional method teaches rote memorization without understanding or thinking. Except perhaps in some isolated enclaves where stereotypically poor teaching took place, this has never the All the widely used math textbooks of 19th century, for example, emphasized "mental arithmetic," that is, the ability to think through multiple-step problems "in your head" and give the solution, not only without a calculator but even without a pencil. The kinds of thinking and understanding that were required differed from what expected today, because the skill set an educated person has changed. So in those days, being able to sums in your head was far more important than, say, sketching the graph an exponential function. In honest we must realize that "Back-to-the-Basics" or "traditional education" does not imply restricting ourselves to the content or of a bygone era. The primary features of the traditional method include: 1) Understanding a mathematical concept, e.g. "What does it mean to add two numbers?" 2) Memorization of basic facts/definitions/results, e.g. "the Times Tables." 3)Application of knowledge to novel problems and more advanced concepts. 4) Review and maintenance knowledge. The traditional method results in efficient learning and provides the foundation necessary for creative thinking, even if it fails sufficiently address that objective, according its critics. yes, even from Singapore, whose students smoke the Americans in international tests, are looking with envy at the creativity of some of our This demonstrates that a commitment to the essential objectives may not produce the results that are desirable. is well documented in cognitive science that the brain has a limited capacity to manipulate objects in "working memory." It is said that process more than seven memory objects at once, which supposedly explains why phone numbers have seven (only now they have 10, but that's OK, because the phone remembers all the numbers The memory is where problem and creative activities take place. The memory can access permanent memory for information it needs. However, new information that be taken in to solve a problem must occupy space in the working memory, thus taking away from the space available for creative activity. That is why we quickly become frustrated when trying to follow instructions that include many terms with which we are not familiar. Even the actual steps in the process are simple, if they involve several terms that are not in our permanent memory, those terms require space in our working memory which is then not available for the This explains why the pedagogic fad of "learning to learn" is a failure. do indeed need for learning--but such skills are utterly on a bank of information which can accessed instantly and does not require the use of working memory. The first step in problem solving or creativity must be putting as much relevant information as we can permanent memory.

Type Design Guidelines in .NET From the CLR perspective, there are two categories of types—reference types and value types—but for the purpose of framework design discussion we divide types into more logical groups, each with its own specific design 4-1 these logical groups. Classes are the general case of reference types. They make up the bulk types in the majority of frameworks. Classes owe popularity to the rich set object-oriented features they support and to their applicability. classes and abstract classes are special logical groups related to extensibility. Extensibility and base classes are covered in Chapter 6. Interfaces are types that can be implemented both by reference types and types. This allows them to serve as roots of polymorphic hierarchies of reference types and value types. In addition, interfaces can be to simulate multiple inheritance, which is not natively supported by the CLR. Structs are the general of value types and should be reserved for small, simple types, similar to language Enums are a special case of value used to define short sets of values, such as days of the week, console colors, and so on. Static classes are types intended as containers for static members. They are commonly used to shortcuts to other operations. Delegates, exceptions, attributes, arrays, and collections are all special cases of reference types intended for specific uses, guidelines for their design and usage are discussed elsewhere in this book. - DO ensure that each type is a well-defined set of related members, not just a random collection of unrelated functionality. - It is that a type can be described in one simple A good definition should also rule out functionality that is only tangentially you have ever managed a team of people you know that they don't do well without a crisp set of responsibilities. Well, types work the same way. I have noticed that types without a firm and focused scope tend to be magnets for more random functionality, which, over time, make a small problem a worse. It becomes more difficult to justify why the next member with even more random functionality does not belong in the type. As the focus the members in a type blurs, the developer's ability to predict where to find a given functionality is impaired, and therefore so productivity.| |Good types are like good diagrams: What has been omitted is as important to clarity and usability as what has been included. Every additional member you add to a type starts at a net negative value and only by proven usefulness does it go from there to positive. If you add too much in attempt to make the type more useful to some, you are just as likely to type useless to everyone.| | When I was learning OOP in the early 1980s, I was taught a mantra that I honor today: If things too complicated, make more types. Sometimes, I find that I am thinking really hard trying to define good set of methods for a type. When I start to feel that I'm spending too much on this or when just don't seem to fit together well, I remember my mantra I define more, smaller types where each type has well-defined functionality. This has worked extremely well for me over the years. On the flip side, sometimes types do end up being dumping grounds for various loosely related functions. The .NET Framework offers several types like this, such as |

f98cdcf9bcf3a232aaec6f7ada8e77a2e3abe29d: Benefits of XQuery principal benefits of are: - - XQuery can query many different data structures and nature makes it ideal for querying tree graph structures - - XQuery statements are than similar SQL or XSLT programs - Flexibility - can query hierarchical and tabular data - Consistency - XQuery has a syntax and can be used with other XML such as XML Schema datatypes XQuery is frequently compared with two other languages, SQL and XSLT, but has a number of advantages over these. Advantages over SQL Unlike SQL, XQuery just tables but arbitrary tree structures. This allows XQuery to directly create XHTML structures that can used in web pages. XQuery is for XML-based object databases, and object databases are much more and powerful than databases which store in tabular format. XSLT, XQuery can be learned by anyone familiar with SQL. of the constructs are very similar such as: - Ordering Results: Both XQuery and SQL add an order byclause to the query. - Selecting Distinct Values: XQuery and SQL have easy ways to select distinct values from a result set - Restricting Rows: Both XQuery and SQL have a X=Y clause can be added an XQuery Another big is that XQuery is essentially the native query of the World Wide Web. One actual web pages with XQuery, but not if one uses SQL-based databases to store pages or fragments of such pages, one will many of the advantages of XQuery's simple tag/attribute search (which is akin to searching for names Advantages over XSLT Unlike XSLT, XQuery can be quickly learned by anyone familiar with SQL. XSLT has many patterns that unfamiliar to many procedural software developers. Also, whereas XSLT is good for using as a static to convert one type of document to another, for example RSS to HTML, XQuery is more dynamic querying tool, useful for pulling out sections of from large and/or large number of documents. Debate about XQuery vs. for Transformation There been a sorts about the merits of the two languages for transforming XML: XSLT and XQuery. A common misconception is that "XQuery is best for querying XML, and XSLT best for it." In reality, both methods are capable of transforming XML. Despite XSLT's longer history and larger install base, the "XQuery typeswitch" of transforming XML provides numerous advantages. Most people need to transform XML hear that they need to learn a called XSLT. XSLT, whose first version was published by the W3C in 1999, was a huge innovation for its indeed, remains dominant. It was one of the very first languages dedicated to transforming XML documents, and it was the first language (DSL) to use theories from the world of functional to create reliable, side-effect transformations. Many XML developers still feel strong indebted to this groundbreaking language, since it helped them see a new model development: one focused around the transformation of models and empowering them to fuse both the and documentation of a transformation routing into a single, modular On the hand, learning XSLT requires overcoming a very substantial learning curve. XSLT's difficulty due, in part, to one of the key design decisions by its architects: to express the transformation using XML itself, than a brand new syntax grammar for the transformation rules. XSLT's unique approach to transformation rules also contributes the steepness of the learning curve. The learning curve can be overcome, but it is fair to say learning curve has created a opening for an approach. XQuery has filled this demand for an alternative among a growing community of users: they find XQuery a lower learning curve, meets their needs for transforming XML, together with XQuery's other advantages, it has become a compelling "all-in-one" language. Like XSLT, XQuery was created by the W3C to handle XML. But instead of expressing the language in XML syntax, the architects of XQuery chose a new that would be more familiar users of server-side scripting languages such as PHP, Perl, or Python. XQuery was designed to be similar to users of relational database query languages such as SQL, while remaining true to functional programming practices. Despite its relative youth (XQuery 1.0 was only released 2007 when XSLT had already reached its version 2.0), XQuery was born remarkably mature. XML servers like eXist-db and MarkLogic were already using XQuery as their language for querying XML and performing operations (obviating the need for learning PHP, Perl, or Python). So,

Ban Chao a general and cavalry commander in charge of the administration of the "Western Regions" (Central during the Eastern Han dynasty. He repelled the Xiongnu and secured Chinese control over the Tarim Basin region, and was awarded the title of 'Protector of the Western Regions'. He fought for 31 years. Control of the Tarim Basin Ban Chao, like his predecessors Huo Qubing Wei Qing from the Former Han Dynasty before him, was effective at expelling the Xiongnu from the Tarim Basin, and brought the various people of the Western Regions under Chinese rule during the half of the 1st century CE, helping to open and secure the trade routes to west. He was generally outnumbered, skillfully played on the divisions among his The kingdoms of Loulan, Khotan and Kashgar came under Chinese rule. Ban Chao recalled to Luoyang, but then sent again to the Western area four years later, during the reign the emperor Han Zhangdi. He obtained the military help of the Kushan Empire in 84 in repelling the who trying to support the rebellion of king of Kashgar, and the next in his on Turpan, in the eastern Tarim Basin. Ban Chao ultimately brought the whole of the Tarim Basin under Chinese control. In recognition for their support to the the Kushans (referred to as Da Yuezhi in Chinese sources) but were denied, a Han princess, even they had sent presents to the Chinese court. In retaliation, they marched on Ban in 90 CE a force of 70,000, but, exhausted the expedition, were finally turned by smaller Chinese force. The Yuezhi retreated and paid tribute to the Chinese Empire. (Later, during the Yuanchu period, 114-120 CE, the Kushans sent a military force install Chenpan, had been a hostage among them, as king of Kashgar). In 91 CE, Ban Chao finally succeeded in pacifying the Western Regions and was awarded the title of Protector General and stationed at Qiuci (Kucha). A Wuji Colonel was and, commanding five hundred soldiers, stationed in the Kingdom of Nearer Jushi, within the walls Gaochang, 29 kilometres southeast of Turfan. In 94 CE, Chao proceeded to again attack and defeat Yanqi [Karashahr]. Subsequently, more than fifty presented hostages, submitted to the Interior. In 97 CE Ban Chao an envoy, Gan Ying, who reached the Persian Gulf and left the first Chinese account of Europe. Some modern authors have even claimed that Chao advanced the Caspian Sea, however, this interpretation has been criticized as a misreading. 102 CE Ban Chao was retired as General the Western Regions due to age and ill health, and returned to the capital Luoyang at the age of but the following month there in 9th month of the 14th Yongyuan year Sept. to 28th Oct., 102). 58c085dd6285481adf2d7576367a5e48dbf83a0b: |Time period||c. 400–?| [a] The Semitic origin of the Brahmic scripts is not universally agreed upon.Note: This page may IPA phonetic The Gupta script (sometimes to as Gupta Brahmi Script or Late Brahmi Script ) was used for writing Sanskrit and is associated with the Gupta Empire India which was a period of material prosperity and great religious and scientific developments. The Gupta script was from Brahmi and gave rise to the Nagari, Sharada and Siddham scripts. These scripts in turn gave to many of the most important scripts of India, Devanagari (the most common script used for writing Sanskrit since the 19th century), the Gurmukhi script for Punjabi Language and the Tibetan script. Origins and Classification The Script was descended from the Ashokan Brahmi script, and is a crucial link between Brahmi and most other scripts in the Brahmic family of Scripts, a family of alphasyllabaries or abugidas. This that while only phonemes have distinct symbols, marked by diacritics, with being the pronunciation when the diacritic is not present. In fact, the Gupta script works in exactly the same manner as predecessor and successors, and only the forms of the graphemes and diacritics are different. Through the 4th century, letters began to take more cursive and symmetric forms, a result of the desire to write more quickly and aesthetically. This meant the script became more differentiated throughout the Empire, with regional variations which have been broadly classified into three, four or five categories; however, a classification is not clear, even on a single inscription, there may be variation in how a particular symbol is written. In this sense, the term Gupta script should be taken to mean form of writing derived from the Gupta period, even though may be a lack of uniformity in the scripts. The surviving inscriptions of the Gupta script are mostly found on or stone pillars, and on gold from the Gupta One of the most the Prasasti. Composed by Harishena, the court poet and minister of Samudragupta, it describes Samudragupta’s reign, beginning from his ascension to throne as the second king of the Gupta Dynasty and including his other kings. Gupta Numismatics study of Gupta coins began with the discovery of a hoard of gold in 1783. Many other hoards have been discovered, most important being the Bayana hoard, discovered in 1946, which contained more than coins issued by the Gupta Kings. Many of the Gupta Empire’s coins bear inscriptions of legends mark historic events. In fact, it was one the first Indian Empires to do so, probably as a result unprecedented prosperity. Almost every Gupta king issued coins, beginning with its first king, Chandragupta I. The scripts on the coin are also of a different nature compared to scripts on pillars, due to conservatism regarding the coins that to be accepted as currency, which would have prevented regional variations in the script from on the coinage. Moreover, space more especially their silver coins, thus of the symbols are truncated or stunted. 799fcfc40f4ffb03d57d486a6b483864fd93e31b: Hundred Years' War (1369–89) ||This article a list of references, but its sources remain unclear because it has insufficient inline citations. (May 2012)| |Hundred Years' (1369-1389)| |Part of Hundred Years' War| The Battle of Najera | Kingdom of France Crown of Castile |Kingdom of England| |Commanders and leaders| | Charles V of France Charles VI of France | Edward III England Richard II of England losses| The Caroline War was the second phase of the Hundred Years' War France and England, following the Edwardian War. It was so-named after V of France, who resumed the war after the Treaty of Brétigny (signed 1360). In May the Black Prince, son of Edward III of England, refused an illegal summons from the French king he come to Paris and responded declaring war. He immediately set out reverse territorial losses imposed Brétigny and he was largely successful in his lifetime. His Charles VI, made with of the Black Prince, II, in 1389. This truce was extended many times until the war was resumed in 1415. The reign of Charles V saw the English steadily pushed back. Although the English-backed claimant to the Duchy of Brittany, John of Montfort, defeated and killed the French Charles of Blois, at the Battle of Auray in 1364, John and heirs eventually with kings. The War of the Breton Succession ended in of English, but gave them no great advantage. In the French received the benefit of improved generalship in the of the Breton commander Bertrand du Guesclin, who, leaving Brittany, entered the service of Charles and became one of his most successful generals. At about the time, a war in Spain occupied the Black Prince's efforts from 1366. The Castilian Civil War pitted Pedro the Cruel, whose daughters Constance and Isabella were married the Black Prince's brothers John Gaunt and Edmund of Langley, against Henry of Trastámara. In with the support of Du Guesclin, Henry deposed Pedro to Henry II of Castile. He then went to war with England, which was with Portugal. years Just before New Year's Day 1370, the English seneschal of Poitou, John Chandos, was killed at the bridge at Lussac-les-Châteaux. The loss of this commander was significant blow to the English. Jean III de Grailly, the captal de Buch, was also captured and locked up by Charles, did not bound by "outdated" chivalry. Du Guesclin a series of careful campaigns, avoiding major English field forces, but capturing town after town, including Poitiers in 1372 and Bergerac in 1377. Du Guesclin, who according to Jean Froissart, had advised French king to the English in the field, was successful in these Fabian tactics, though in the only two major battles in which fought, Auray (1364) and Nájera (1367), he was on the losing side and was captured but released for ransom. The English response to Du Guesclin was launch series of destructive military called chevauchées, in an effort at total war to destroy the countryside and the productivity of the land. But Du Guesclin refused to be drawn open battle. He continued his command of the French armies until his death in In 1372, English dominance at which had been upheld since the Battle of Sluys, was reversed, at least in the Bay Biscay, by the disastrous defeat by a joint Franco-Castilian fleet at the Battle of La Rochelle. This defeat undermined English seaborne trade supplies and threatened their Gascon possessions. In 1376, the Black Prince died, and in 1377, III England sent his Adam Houghton, to negotiate for peace with Charles, but in June Edward himself died, Houghton was called home. The underaged Richard of Bordeaux succeeded to the throne of England. It was not Richard had been deposed by his cousin Henry that the English, under of Lancaster, could forcefully revive their claim to the French The war nonetheless until the first of a series truces was signed in 1389. Charles V died in September 1380 and was succeeded by underage son, Charles VI, was placed under the joint of his three uncles. On his deathbed Charles repealed the royal taxation necessary to fund war effort. As the regents to reimpose the taxation a popular revolt known as the Harelle out in Rouen. As tax collectors arrived at other French cities revolt spread and violence out in Paris and most of France's other northern cities. fe1227561a4e8e4a324fce98fb5c5cb40b52be8c: Real form (Lie In mathematics, the notion of real form relates objects defined over the field of real and complex numbers. A real Lie algebra g0 is called a real form of a complex Lie algebra g if g is complexification g0: Real forms for Lie groups and algebraic groups Using Lie correspondence between Lie groups and Lie algebras, the notion a real form can be defined for Lie groups. In the case of linear algebraic groups, the notions of complexification and real form have a natural description in the language of algebraic geometry. Just as complex semisimple Lie algebras are by Dynkin diagrams, the real forms of a semisimple Lie are classified Satake diagrams, are obtained the Dynkin diagram of the complex form by labeling vertices (filled), and some vertices in pairs by arrows, to certain rules. It is a fact in the structure theory of complex semisimple Lie algebras that every such algebra has two special real forms: one is the compact real form corresponds a compact Lie group under the Lie correspondence (its Satake diagram has all vertices blackened), other is the real form corresponds to a Lie group that is as far as possible from being compact (its Satake diagram has no vertices and no arrows). In case of the complex special linear group SL(n,C), the compact is the special unitary group SU(n) and the split real form the real special linear group SL(n,R). The classification of real forms of semisimple Lie algebras was accomplished by Cartan in the of Riemannian spaces. In general, there be more than real forms. Suppose that g0 a semisimple Lie over the field of real numbers. By Cartan's criterion, the Killing form is nondegenerate, and can be diagonalized in suitable basis with entries +1 or -1. By Sylvester's law of inertia, the number entries, or the positive index of intertia, is invariant of the bilinear form, it does not on the of the basis. This a number between 0 and dimension of g which is important invariant of the Lie algebra, called its index. Split real form A real form a complex Lie algebra g is said to be split, or normal, if in each Cartan decomposition g0 = k0 ⊕ p0, the space p0 contains a maximal Abelian subalgebra of i.e. its Cartan subalgebra. Élie Cartan proved that every complex semisimple Lie algebra g has a split real form, is unique to isomorphism. It maximal index among all real forms. The split form corresponds to the diagram with no vertices blackened and no arrows. real form A real Lie algebra g0 is compact if the Killing form negative definite, i.e. the index of g0 is zero. In this case g0 = k0 is a compact Lie algebra. is known that under the Lie correspondence, compact Lie algebras correspond to compact Lie groups. The compact form to the Satake diagram with all vertices blackened. Construction the compact real form In general, the construction of the compact real form uses structure theory of semisimple Lie For classical Lie algebras there is a more explicit construction. Let g0 be a real Lie algebra of matrices over R that is under the transpose map, The complexification g of decomposes into the direct sum of g0 and ig0. The real vector space of is a subspace of the complex Lie algebra g that is closed under commutators and of skew-hermitian matrices. It follows that u0 is a real Lie subalgebra of g, that its Killing is negative definite (making it a compact Lie algebra), and that the complexification of u0 is g. Therefore, is a compact form of g. See also - Helgason 1978, p. 426

8356c58673f95bbf3b3d607cd7a097e77130db8e: A token to the future : a digital ‘archive’ of early Australian children’s literature Mallan, Kerry M., Cross, Amy, & Allan, Cherie (2012) A token to the future : a digital ‘archive’ of early Australian children’s literature. Papers: Explorations into Children's Literature, 22(1), pp. This essay considers a digital ‘archive’ of early Australian children’s literature, known as the Children’s Digital Resources (CLDR), which is in AustLit: The Literature ( http://www.austlit.edu.au ). We examine what the collection can tell us about Australia’s To narrow the scope, on how Australia was itself as a with its own character, or national identity, in texts written for children from the latter part of the nineteenth century up the end of World War II. Our is to consider how early children’s literature included in the CLDR rhetorically constructs nation and place, and in doing constructs an Australian identity for its implied readers. ea07ee8d6c7d847e9b87e1ba6d784f4c6ef69758: Snow leopard population discovered in Afghanistan The Wildlife Conservation Society discovered a surprisingly healthy population of rare snow leopards living in the mountainous reaches of northeastern Afghanistan's Wakhan Corridor, according to a new study. The discovery gives hope to the most big cat, calls to some of the world's tallest mountains. Between 4,500 and 7,500 snow leopards remain the wild scattered across a dozen countries in Central Asia. study, which appears in the June 29th issue of the of Environmental Studies, is by WCS conservationists Anthony Simms, Zalmai Moheb, Salahudin, Hussain Ali, Inayat Ali and Timothy Wood. WCS-trained community rangers used camera traps to document the presence of snow at 16 different locations across a wide landscape. The images represent the first camera trap records of snow leopards in Afghanistan. has been conserving wildlife and improving local livelihoods in the since 2006 with support from the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID). "This is a discovery – it that there is real snow leopards in Afghanistan," Peter WCS Deputy Director for Asia "Now our goal is to ensure that animals have a future as a key part of natural heritage." According the study, snow leopards remain threatened in the region. Poaching for their pelts, persecution by shepherds, the of live animals the illegal pet trade have all been documented in the Corridor. In response, WCS has developed a set of conservation initiatives to snow leopards. These include partnering with local communities, training of rangers, and outreach efforts. Anthony Simms, lead author and the project's Technical Advisor, said, "By developing a community-led management approach, we believe leopards will be conserved in Afghanistan over the long term." WCS-led initiatives are already paying off. Conservation education is now occurring in every school the Wakhan region. Fifty-nine rangers have been trained to date. They monitor not only snow leopards but species including Marco Polo sheep ibex while also enforcing laws against WCS has also initiated the construction of predator-proof livestock corrals and a livestock insurance program that compensates shepherds, though initial research shows that surprisingly few livestock fall to predators in the region. In Afghanistan, USAID has provided support to WCS to work in more 55 communities across the and is training local people to monitor and sustainably wildlife and other One of the many outputs of this project was the creation first national park – Band-e-Amir – is now co-managed by the government and a committee consisting of all 14 communities living around the park. Snow leopards have by as much 20 percent over the past 16 years and are considered endangered the International for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). is a world leader in the care and conservation of snow leopards. WCS's Bronx Zoo became the first zoo in the Western Hemisphere to exhibit these rare spotted cats in 1903. In three decades, nearly 80 cubs have been born in the Bronx and have been sent to live at 30 zoos in the U.S. and eight countries in Europe, Asia, Australia, and North America. 42b6a21fd0ffbd47e5c492011cc52c55dd1fac26: Estonia Has Least Polluted Urban Air in World27 September Levels of particles in Estonia's areas are the lowest in the world, a table published by the World Health Organization (WHO) on 26 September reveals. The Indian Ocean nation Mauritius ranked second while Canada landed in third place, according to the data. The report looked at different particle sizes: those with a diameter less than 2.5 micrometers (PM2.5) and those smaller 10 micrometers (PM10). In Estonia, PM2.5 was at 5.4 micrograms per cubic meter of air, while PM10 was at 11 micrograms per meter of air. The highest concentration of particles was registered in Mongolia, where PM2.5 at 63 and PM10 at 279 micrograms per of air. According to WHO, each year over two million people around the world die due to the inhalation of fine particulate matter. The WHO ranking list results of urban outdoor air pollution monitoring from almost 1 100 cities with a of at least 100 000. Air pollution in Estonia measured only in Tallinn and the data dates back to 2008. Estonian Public Broadcasting

8e53880b81a9c49159de8a367d0720700a124767: Children are willing to ask one parent and then the to get the desired answer. Parental communication is key to combating this divisive strategy. Children determine from early age which parent they should ask for permission in which circumstance. I can illustrate this with the example my family. If the request involved degree of risk, or danger, they always approached Dad, the one more likely to allow a ride on the horse run down a black diamond ski slope. When it came to social events, they made the intelligent choice to come to I am — always been — more of a social butterfly than dear old division of labor in regard to granting permission is logical and harmless. The problems a child asks one is denied and then the other parent, looking for an override of the first ruling — Divide and If is allowed in your family, it will be disruptive. When Divide and Conquer is successful, Mom and Dad find themselves distracted and in conflict with each other. That leaves the child free to disregard the first parent’s decision. To combat the Divide and Conquer strategy, you need communicate. Find out if there has been an initial answer given your child’s request. If the other parent has responded, it is best to let the first answer hold. If you find that two of you continually disagreeing, it would be best to simply address your child’s request by saying, Dad and I will have to talk about it.” It is always good to have a united front or, as I like to say, to be singing off the same songsheet. While the what it for late-April being an ideal planting time in the central Midwest, add this caveat. What soil conditions are right now, and temperatures are right now, but it's too wet or too cool to plant the week of April? What if the last week of April becomes first week of May? During the two seasons in much of Indiana, for example, the last week of April became the last week May or the two weeks of June. One could argue that the proper comparison ought to not the first of April planting vs. last of April, but the first of April planting vs. planting the last week of May? Which corn likely to yield more? Most university data and data form several seed companies, Beck's Hybrids their Practical Farm Research plots, would say that anything planted in April higher percentage of yielding more the last week of May. Given that logic, who can blame someone who has watched their planter sit for four straight in May for the past two years if they want to get some crop the ground now? Of course if fair weather continues or if the last week April is ideal, and you could it make a difference. Farming doesn't come with guarantees. Ken Scheeringa, an assistant at Purdue University, says warmer than normal weather is likely through April, it be extreme warm side as in March, as compared to normal. Rainfall is more of fuzzy call. The real that May and June aren't on the radar screen yet. Some who have ventured out into May still for a cool, wet spring. So is it wise or foolish have corn planted now? It's your decision, your money. For money, it's a gamble either way. Perhaps experts should talk in terms calculated and what-if scenarios when they out planting date options.
7e6ff2daaed3e4f881172fcaadbb20f385eaa107: & Wolf to join forces? BirdLife International and FACE (the Federation of Associations Hunting and Conservation of the EU) have signed a historic agreement recognising that the conservation of bird and their habitats is a common objective. Both organisations agree that the Birds Directive is the instrument for conservation in the European Union, and undertake not to attempt to change Both recognise the importance of the Natura 2000 which includes all the Special Protection Areas for required under the Birds Directive. They also agree to cooperate in promoting strategic conservation priorities, such as halting biodiversity decline 2010, protecting sites, and reforming the Common Agricultural Policy. The Agreement, signed on 12 October by Mike Rands, Director and Chief Executive BirdLife International and Gilbert de Turckheim, President of was welcomed countersigned Mrs Margot Wallstr?m, Commissioner the Environment. Progress towards agreement began 2001, when the European Commission launched the Sustainable Hunting Initiative (SHI) to create a constructive between conservationists and hunters, represented by BirdLife and FACE. The SHI was started at a time when the two organisations could be considered arch-enemies, and constant confrontations on hunting issues seemed to be leading nowhere, said Dr Clairie Papazoglou, BirdLife`s Head of EU Policy. This Agreement proves that reasonable and reasonable conservationists can together for the benefit of birds and people. It represents step forward in the relations of the two organisations, which on the basis of this text can chart a list of common actions, to be carried out in the years to come. It can also be the basis on which BirdLife`s Partners can promote similar initiatives at the national level. Created: 5th Nov 2004
39f5eb654f4e829cee929c22a6f446a66ae9f335: COGNITIVE MORAL DEVELOPMENT AND LOEVINGER'S CONCEPT OF EGO DEVELOPMENT (KOHLBERG) This study explored the nature of the relationship between cognitive moral development as defined Lawrence Kohlberg ego development as defined by Jane Loevinger. The effects of general cognitive were controlled the selection of subjects who were capable of formal operational thinking. Subjects were 120 Jewish volunteers comprised of equal numbers junior high-school, senior high-school, and college students of both sexes. All received three tests: A Measure for Formal Operations, The Sentence Completion Test (SCT) which measures ego development, and The Moral Judgment Interview (MJI). Results indicated the existence of significant positive correlations between the SCT and MJI in the overall sample, in the total male and female samples, in the college group, and in the female college group. No significant correlations were found the junior and senior high-school possibly due to restricted ranges of scores. In addition, most subjects at development stages 3/4 and above had attained at least conscientious-conformist level. Results also indicated the presence of differences between male and female scores. correlations for females were consistently higher than for males, scored significantly higher on the SCT, males scored significantly higher on the MJI, and the relationship between specific and ego development stages seemed to stronger for females than for males. The differences found in this between the sexes in performance on are consistent with Gilligan's theory about the distinctions between male and approaches to moral dilemmas. However, that theory was found to be inadequate in explaining the stronger relationship between MJI and SCT the females in this study. The SCT was criticized for not specifying clearly ego development features that it measured. It was suggested that exact nature of the interplay between moral and ego development could be more fully by research on specific well-defined of ego development. ^ "COGNITIVE MORAL DEVELOPMENT AND LOEVINGER'S CONCEPT OF EGO DEVELOPMENT (KOHLBERG)" (January 1, 1984). This page lists the most notable ones that necessary to know when converting to PCRE. - The PCRE functions that the pattern is by delimiters. - Unlike POSIX, the PCRE extension does have dedicated functions for case-insensitive matching. Instead, this is supported using the i (PCRE_CASELESS) modifier. Other pattern modifiers are also available changing matching strategy. - The POSIX functions find the longest of the leftmost match, but PCRE stops on first valid match. If the string doesn't match at all it makes no difference, but if matches it may have dramatic effects on both the resulting match and the matching speed. To illustrate this difference, consider the following from "Mastering Expressions" by Jeffrey Friedl. Using the pattern one(self)?(selfsufficient)? on the string oneselfsufficient with PCRE will result in oneself, but using POSIX the result be the full string oneselfsufficient. 977619c7e0abe9944712d9a2cd117ff4b38c4d78: |Page of 1 - 03/02/13||email page| The Power is in the Pixels: Power Game Added to Thinking Skills Club(March 02, 2013) Toronto, ON (PRWEB) March 02, 2013 A steam kettle whistles. The steam activates an electric current causing a beaker of water to heat up and drip onto a turbine, which activates a new current and completes the circuit. Not usual way to get energy from Point A to Point B, but a creative and compelling way to get to the next level in an online game called Electric Box. The game, by Candystand.com, was recently added to the Thinking Skills Club, an after school club where in grades through 8 play computer games that help kids develop a variety of cognitive skills. Thinking Skills Club Mitch Moldofsky says the game was chosen it logic, the concept of cause and effect, planning and making mistakes in order to win. "Making mistakes is very important in learning," says an educator and Cognitive graduate from the University of Toronto, "I do it all the time." Moldofsky believes game encourages the development of executive function the lobes of the brain, based on another executive function training method, Tools the Mind. "What they've found with Tools of the Mind is that simply modifying activities during the school day to include things like self-reflection, evaluation, planning and trial and error can shape a approach to outside the classroom as as behavior," says Moldofsky. "Games like these encompass all of these skills." Unlike other brain training games on the web, which Moldofsky claims are often repetitive and boring, the games on the Thinking Skills Club are "fun-tested," since they are culled from gaming sites. "These games are already being played by the kids in this age group, without the coercion of parents or teachers. intrinsically he says. There are five types of on the Thinking Club aside from executive function, including attention and memory, social skills. "There's some good new out there about the of prosocial says Moldofsky, "and they're not too hard to find know where to look." 7adb07a2ef0675ec829eed79090d7255f29bf7c1: It’s a fact. Men are better than … at sweating. Yep, we do it more frequently and more effectively. Congrats guys. Researchers Osaka International University in Japan measured the perspiration rates of men and women while they biked for hour under conditions. The researchers 37 subjects cycle for an hour increasing subjects had participated in endurance sports for more than six years, while inactive subjects had, for the most not performed regular physical activity in the previous three years. The scientists measured the subjects’ temperature, rate and activated sweat glands for a number of sites on the body, including the forehead and thigh. The information was used to calculate sweat gland output and measure performance. The study revealed that physically fit men sweat more than anyone else. In general, men sweat more than women, and that has its advantages. Sweating is how our body cools off. by sweating more than women, men are able to exercise for a time. ‘”It appears women are at disadvantage when they need sweat a lot during exercise,” said Yoshimitsu Inoue, the study’s “Especially in hot conditions.” Previous physical training increased sweating in men and women, but the increase was with men. As the workouts more intense, the difference in sweating between the sexes increased. Interestingly enough, fit women sweat more than unfit men, but by an insignificant margin. The researchers believe that testosterone could explain men sweat better than women. Prior has shown a link between the male sex-hormone testosterone, physical training and an increase rate. Although they did not measure the among their subjects, the researchers suggest the hormone may play a role in their results. So guys, the next time enter into a women’s marathon, just make sure it’s hot out. You’ll sweat more, and you’ll be a lock to win.
