A giant battery bank installed by the side of Southeast Pennsylvania Transit subway tracks little over a month ago is saving about nine megawatt-hours power a week, its manufacturer says, which is electricity than the apartment-dweller uses a year. The battery system, which I wrote about year, the trains to run a bit like Prius hybrids. they slow down at a station, their motors turn into generators, converting torque into current. Before the battery was installed, some of that current was returned to the third rail; the voltage got too high, it was shunted instead into a giant electric heater under the train, which simply dissipated the energy as heat. Now the battery captures excess current, about 3.5 to kilowatt-hours that stops, and puts it on the line when a train is accelerating. Sometimes does this for several trains at once. 5f3d2e55362f547bb2798208d1f52e9f18b56e61: Vedic Art: Indian Miniature Painting, Part BY: SUN STAFF Ahmadnagar, c. 1595 Dec 26, 2011 CANADA (SUN) A presentation India's artistic in paintings, sculpture and temple THE DECCANI SCHOOLS to 18th Centuries Like the group of Bikaner paintings featured in yesterday's segment, of Govinda fluting with His cows, are many beautiful themes to be found among Deccan Miniatures. Today we take a brief look at paintings from the School, a sub-category of the Deccan School. In the Ahmednagar Miniatures, Vaisnava are overshadowed by the Persian influence, no because earliest examples of this are no longer in existence. Ahmednagar, Maharashtra, situated about 250 km. due of was an Islamic kingdom during the Sixteenth Century. During the late Iron Age it was part the territory of the Sattavahanas and during the 1st Millennium A.D. it was ruled by the Yadavas, until it fell to the Muslim intruders. Ragamala, Ahmednagar, 17th c. Nearly all the early examples of Ahmednagar painting are in the style, an seen not only in themes, but also in the richly brilliant colors, horizons, golden and landscapes, gilt scripts framing the wide borders of manuscript illustrations. This style is equally evident in Ahmednagar School Ragamala illustrations of the In the Ragamala illustration of Raga above, the painting is bordered along with top with the Raga verse in Devanagari script vas (anta). Not shown is an additional caption above that, in Arabic characters, which mislabels painting as Hindola Raga and Vasant Ragini. The raga depicted actually the Vasanta, and it was no doubt introduction of the swing (hindola) that led to the confusion titles. The Sanskrit verses for this describe how (the male personification of Spring, or Kamadeva) is sprayed with holi colors by maids in a mango on a Kashmiri mountain. Praised by strings of bees, he disports himself on a swing. Like a blue lotus (dark complexioned) and dressed in a tawny he holds in his fingers shoots the fresh In the the young male Spring wears a four-pointed coat, a fashionable worn during the reign Akbar. This aspect of the figure may have been adopted by the artist from a Malwa influence. The distinctive feature of the women's costumes are the projecting transparent veils, a style also found in the Nimat Namah Malwa. This may tie it to the Chaurapanchasika Group of Miniatures, perhaps developed in its classical form in Malwa or Rajasthan during the half of the Century. This detail of costume does point to the northern Deccan origin Vasanta Raga illustration. of Culture, Government India Submit an Article Copyright 2005, 2011, HareKrsna.com. All rights reserved.

Testosterone, which plays an important role in sexual development, is produced mainly by the testes in boys and in much amounts by the ovaries in girls. Testosterone is by the adrenal glands in both girls and boys. young boys, testosterone are normally low. As puberty approaches — usually between the ages 10 and 14 — the pituitary gland (a pea-sized gland near base of the brain) secretes two hormones hormone, or LH; and follicle-stimulating hormone, or FSH) that together to stimulate the testes to make testosterone. Increased testosterone production is what causes to develop deeper voices, muscles, and body and facial hair. It also the testes produce sperm, and it plays role in speeding a boy's growth in height during puberty. Two assessments may be performed as part of a testosterone test: total testosterone, which measures amount of testosterone in the body, including both the bound to proteins that help transport the hormone through the bloodstream and free testosterone free testosterone, which measures only the testosterone that's not attached to proteins The doctor may order one or both tests. However, because sexual development involves many other hormones, a more complete picture can often be obtained by performing other tests at the time, including an LH or FSH test. 2d76593b332cb4997eba2d4da99191c944b480db: Types of literature PRIMARY SOURCES are publications that the results of original research. They may be the form of conference papers, monographic series, technical theses and dissertations, or journal articles. Because they present information in its original form (that is, not been interpreted or condensed or otherwise “repackaged” by other writers), these are considered primary sources. The works new thinking/discoveries/results unite with the knowledge base. Journal articles that report original research are of more common and important steps the information sharing cycle. often go through a process in which they are “peer reviewed” by other experts who evaluate the work and findings before publication. SECONDARY SOURCES those which are published about the primary literature, that generalize, analyze, interpret, evaluate or otherwise “add value” to the original information, OR which simplify the finding and evaluating the primary literature. Some examples of secondary sources are “review” articles and indexes or bibliographies, such as PubMed or ScienceDirect. TERTIARY SOURCES compile or information from or secondary sources that has become accepted. They aim to provide a broad overview of a topic, or already proven facts, and definitions, often presented in a convenient form. They provide no new information. These include “reference” types works such as textbooks, encyclopedias, fact books, guides and handbooks, and computer databases such as The Handbook the Microbiological and SciFinder. LITERATURE are source materials not through the systems of publication books or periodicals) and distribution. Gray conference proceedings, dissertations, technical reports, working papers. Locating type of literature is a little more difficult, but there are finding tools such as Dissertations Abstracts and PapersFirst. What is a literature review? A literature review discusses published information in a particular subject area, and sometimes information in a particular subject area within a certain time period. A literature review can be just a simple summary of the sources, but it usually has an organizational pattern and combines both summary and synthesis. A summary is a recap of the important information of the source, but a synthesis is a re-organization, or a that information. It might a interpretation of old material or combine new with old Or it the intellectual progression of the field, including major debates. And depending on the situation, the literature review may evaluate the sources the reader on the most pertinent or relevant. But how is a literature review different from an academic research paper? While the main of academic research paper is to support your own argument, the focus a literature review is to summarize and synthesize the arguments and ideas others. The academic paper also covers a range of sources, but it is usually a select number of sources, because the emphasis is the argument. Likewise, a review can also have an but it is not as important as covering a number of sources. short, an academic research paper and a literature contain some the same elements. In fact, academic research papers will a literature review section. But it is aspect of the study (the argument or the sources) that is emphasized that what of document it is. Why do write literature reviews? reviews provide you with a handy guide to a particular topic. If you have limited time conduct research, literature reviews give an overview or act as a stepping stone. For professionals, they are useful reports keep them to date with what current the field. For scholars, the depth and breadth of the review emphasizes the credibility of the writer in his or her reviews also provide solid background for a research paper's investigation. Comprehensive knowledge of the literature the is essential to most research papers. Who writes these things, anyway? Literature reviews are written occasionally in the humanities, but mostly in sciences and social in experiment and lab reports, they constitute a section of the paper. 40a6065430ba0e5f79e4f733c9f783c2d79e150a: News tagged with renewable energy Related topics: , wind turbines , electricity , solar panels fossil Renewable energy is energy generated from natural resources—such as sunlight, wind, rain, tides, and geothermal heat—which are renewable (naturally replenished). In about 18% of global final energy consumption came from renewables, with 13% coming from traditional biomass, as wood-burning. Hydroelectricity the next largest renewable source, providing 3% of global energy consumption and of global electricity generation. power is growing at the rate of 30 percent annually, with a worldwide of 121,000 (MW) in 2008, and is widely used European countries and the United States. The annual manufacturing output of photovoltaics industry reached 6,900 MW in 2008, and photovoltaic (PV) power stations are popular in Germany and Spain. Solar thermal power stations operate in the USA and Spain, and the largest of these is the 354 MW SEGS power plant in the Mojave The world's largest geothermal power installation is The Geysers in California, with a rated capacity of 750 MW. has one of the renewable energy programs in the world, involving production of ethanol fuel from sugar cane, and ethanol now provides 18 percent of the country's automotive fuel. Ethanol fuel is also widely available in the USA. While most renewable energy projects and production is large-scale, renewable technologies are also to small off-grid applications, sometimes in rural and remote areas, where energy is crucial human development. Kenya has the world's highest household solar ownership rate with roughly 30,000 small (20–100 watt) solar systems sold per year. Some renewable energy technologies are criticised for intermittent or unsightly, yet the renewable energy continues to grow. Climate change concerns coupled with high oil prices, peak oil and increasing government support driving increasing energy legislation, incentives commercialization. New government spending, regulation, and policies should help the industry weather the 2009 economic crisis better than many other sectors. a47aeeaeef46ce7b849ffecbf12d6f3f852c4d8f: cancer represents one of the most common cancers among women in the United States. Data that more than 180,000 American women received a diagnosis of breast cancer in 2009. The various risk factors include: the female gender, heredity, genetic factors, aging and idiopathic causes. What You Should About Breast Cancer The short answer to what should about breast cancer is that a tumor in the breast tissue. With non-invasive breast cancer, the tumor stays localized and does not spread (metastasize) from its origin growth. Experts refer to this as “Carcinoma in Situ”. The tumor occurs in and remains confined to the ducts (ductal carcinoma situ) or confined to the lobules (lobular carcinoma in situ). “Duct” and “Lobules” refer to the milk duct the milk glands, respectively, in the mammary glands. Most breast cancers start in the ducts to other tissues. carcinoma doesn’t meet the criteria of a true cancer by itself, but is a for other types of cancer – both and non-invasive. An invasive spreads beyond its area of origin and can have three different stages of – regional distant As the suggest localized types those which remain localized to the breast tissues, the regional stage refers to the of the tumor to tissues the breast (e.g. – lymph nodes) and the distant tumors are those spread away from the breast to tissues organs. to patients with distant tumors are not easily managed. About Breast Cancer Stages Doctors breast cancer stages on the tumor size, nodal status (involvement lymph nodes) and degree of spread (metastasis) tumors are grouped into 5 stages 0 IV. Stage zero means the cells confined to the duct or lobule and not spread This is the foremost stage of breast cancer. In stage I the tumor is very – less than or equal to 2 cm in and is confined to an area in the not spread to the lymph nodes or surrounding tissues. In stage II, the tumor grows to 1-2 inches in diameter and cancer cells appear at the lymph nodes. Sometimes the tumor is even bigger than 5cms, but the lymph nodes remain unaffected. In the tumor grows more than 5 cm and spreads to the lymph nodes sometimes to multiple lymph nodes, skin chest wall. Stage IV is the last one and in this case the spreads to somewhere else in the body. Tests for Breast Cancer A biopsy of the tumor determines the type of cancer. This enables the doctors to freeze on the treatment methods and also to figure out how quickly the cancer might grow. The hormone receptor status HER2 status of the patient is also of importance to the doctors, female hormones estrogen and progesterone play a vital role in the development of cancer types. “ER+” and “PR+” are, respectively, estrogen receptor positive and progesterone receptor positive tumors. Hormonal therapy has been found to be beneficial in patients with tumors. HER2 status also influences the mode of treatment. Therapy and of Breast The most used breast treatment methods include mastectomy and lumpectomy The former refers to the removal of entire breast surgery and the latter refers to the of only the tumor and some surrounding tissues believed to contain the roots of tumor. As is the case with cancer types, the cancer cells in breast cancer are too tiny for detection and doctors cannot rule out the chances that some cells will remain in body, even after successful surgery. The leftover cells can cause recurrence. To rule out recurrence adjuvant therapies are Such therapies include: - Hormonal therapy - Targeted biological therapy In chemotherapy, the oncology health care team will administer a chemical to the patient (usually intravenously, sometimes orally) to disrupt communication and growth of the cancerous cells. Hormonal involves dosing patient with a drug that works to bring down the estrogen levels or reduce its action. Experts believe estrogen promotes growth in some In biological therapy, doctors inject the body with monoclonal trained to recognize and destroy certain proteins and cells (the cancerous cells) through (mechanism of through immune system). How to Cope with Breast Cancer It’s important that cancer patients get rid of fear traumas associated with the diagnosis and actually try to understand the disease. This will help them manage it effectively: Share your with the near and ones. - Joining a support group helps get rid of the so called “blues”. - Indulge in activities of interest like books, music, movies etc. - Eat healthy, think healthy. - Take rest. a51a30d963124737a64907e3053c3a2d8a40f868: The Oregon Trail opened the way west for intrepid settlers and enterprising miners. Once it was well established and the roads were cleared and expanded, once towns had grown along the route and locations the Rockies and west were settled, it was only natural that a new method of transportation would take over: stagecoaches. The behind stagecoaches wasn’t new. Carriages were the primary form of mass transportation in the pre-locomotive age. made stagecoaches different from regular carriages were size and the way they were supported on the wheel frame. Rather than relying on springs, which jostled a rider up and down, stagecoaches use of thoroughbraces, leather straps that supported the body of the and gave more of a rocking motion.Stagecoaches could generally fit passengers inside six outside. Inside, as you can probably guess, meant that passengers traveled inside the body of would ride on three benches, and the foremost one facing backwards, three riders to a bench. As you can imagine, it was a tight squeeze. Passengers in the two benches would often have to knees between another to make room. They would carry their baggage and have mail under their feet. But if that wasn’t bad enough, six passengers riding outside of the carriage would be just as cramped and exposed to the But passengers lost in comfort, they made up for in speed. The most common type of stagecoach was the Concord stagecoach, manufactured in Concord, New Hampshire. These stagecoaches rarely broke down. They were drawn by a team horses and could cut through the new roadways of the west much faster than any wagon ever could. is part of the reason that almost all carried mail as well as passengers. More than mail, in fact. It was common for stagecoaches to carry gold and cash being transported on behalf of one bank or another. This, of course, meant there was a real danger of robberies along the road. The first major stagecoach robbery in California took place in 1852 when Reelfoot Williams and gang robbed a Nevada City coach. The gang had up a network of to when stages were coming and what money and passengers they were carrying. They carried off the setting a precedent that many would follow. For that reason, and because of the very real threat of attacks by Native Americans, passengers were advised to carry guns and knives with them and drivers were well armed. So, you might ask yourself. Who was in charge of all these stagecoaches? You probably already know the answer without knowing it. There were several stagecoach in the east that been in operation even before 19th century. But one of the and most successful companies developed in the 1830s as a service to deliver packages between Boston, New York, and Philadelphia. Adams & Company gradually moved west as steamships replaced routes for fast transportation between the major eastern cities. Adams & Company did well in after the gold rush, until mismanagement and the emergence of a serious competitor changed everything. That competitor was a little company started by men, Henry Wells and G. Fargo. The company that Wells Fargo started offered more than just service. It offered banking and mail services as well. In fact, by the the 1850s rolled around, Wells Fargo was known to be and more reliable about delivering the than the U.S. Postal service. Then came the of 1855. The banking system, puffed up on speculation of continued profits from the Gold Rush, collapsed. Many businesses, Adams & Company, folded. But Wells Fargo managed to hold on. Not only did it hold on, it emerged as one of only viable options in stagecoach transportation. Since Fargo much had a monopoly on stagecoach transportation in the west after 1855, they could make the rules. 3a448014aaae6c4e9b8002a5081d0a424124332b: Halloween blackout of '57 spurs creation of portable pacemakerby Lorna Benson, Minnesota Public Radio years ago massive Halloween blackout disrupted power across a highly populated of and western Wisconsin. People from Cloud to Faribault, the Twin Cities Eau Claire had no electricity for up to three hours. For most, was simply inconvenient. But for a few young heart patients connected to pacemakers it was life-threatening. The blackout did spur the creation the portable, battery-powered pacemaker. Minn. — At the University of Minnesota hospital 50 years ago, had recently started using pacemakers to help children recover from heart surgery. The devices plugged into a wall socket, so when the power went out in patients' rooms, their pacemakers stopped working too. It's hard to piece together exactly what was like at the hospital during the blackout. But what can be from old newspaper accounts paints a frenzied picture, according to historian Jack Norton. "They police officers pull up to side of the surgery suites and simply turn their headlights to provide light for the surgeons," says Norton. "They scrambled try and keep blood cold grabbing ice from various coolers stick in the blood refrigerator." Norton dug up dozens of newspaper stories about the blackout while doing research for Medtronic. He says the articles show that the university hospital no reason to suspect it was vulnerable to a power because it was connected to two different power "They thought if of them went down, the other would provide them with electricity," But this was a rolling blackout that took down plants all across power grid. No anticipated that happening, Norton says. "It's a nightmare scenario and there's a certain amount of irony that it happens Halloween, that this nightmare critical care happens day when we all know it's famed for scary happenings." Probably the scariest place to be that morning was the children's cardiac recovery unit. A number of young kids were connected to pacemakers undergoing heart surgery. When the power went off, doctors scrambled drugs to their patients hearts pumping. Still, one child didn't survive the three hour ordeal. The trauma of that event pioneering University of Minnesota heart surgeon C. Lillehei. day in hospital hallway Lillehei flagged down Earl Bakken, an electrical engineer who spent a lot of his time collaborating with university surgeons on medical devices. Bakken had just started Medtronic a few and was still running the company out of his garage. Bakken says Lillehei clearly troubled about the blackout. "We got and talked about it and said we have to have some way to back these pacemakers up when there's a power failure," Bakken said in a recent interview. Lillehei asked Bakken if could create a portable pacemaker that ran on a "So we talked about how we do that? How do we get the battery backup?," Bakken. "And I said, 'Well, we'll take a six volt automobile battery and then an to convert the six volts to 115 volts to run the pacemaker.'" Bakken and a his employees built the device. Bakken says it would have but the car battery produced more power than he needed pacemaker. So he started looking for alternatives. Then he an article he read in his Popular Electronics It was about new circuit for a metronome. "A metronome has the same rates as heart rates," says The metronome circuit also had the being much smaller. Bakken's invention fit in box about size of a small paperback book, which meant the pacemaker could be placed in the bed with the patient, rather on medical cart next bed. Bakken took his new invention to the University Minnesota and tested it out on laboratory dog that had given an artificial heart block. 'Okay now. This seems to work, I'll go back to my garage and a pacemaker can use on humans,'" Bakken. But he never got the When Bakken returned to the hospital the next day, he saw his invention being used in the recovery "There was a child in there with this pacemaker connected to him...What a great feeling that is to see here's something hands keeping this child alive." Still Bakken wasn't convinced his portable pacemaker was really ready for human use. sought out Lillehei and asked him why he didn't for the human version of the machine. "And he said well as long as this battery operated pacemaker was available he wasn't going risk losing another child to a power failure." Bakken says it was probably inevitable that a portable would have the 1950's even if hadn't created the Surgeons at the

bc820eebacb7db843fd612932ac3939a976df714: The Jersey breed originated over 600 ago on the Island of Jersey, located in the Channel between France and England. Today, outstanding herds of Jerseys can be found from Denmark to New Zealand, from Canada South America, and from South Africa Japan. first Jerseys to be registered by the American Jersey Cattle Association were imported to United States in 1850, but cattle from Jersey Island had been to this country earlier. Today, there are almost 400,000 Jersey cows the United States and they are an part of the dairy industry all 50 states. California has the most Jersey cows, by Wisconsin, Oregon, Pennsylvania, and Ohio. Jersey calves weigh 55 pounds at birth. Mature Jersey usually weigh about 950 pounds males about 1,500 pounds. Jerseys reach maturity the earliest of all dairy breeds and are efficient reproducers. They also have the longest productive life, or longevity in the milking herd, of any dairy breed. Jerseys are more tolerant of heat than the larger breeds, and adapted to a wide range of climatic and geographical conditions. Jersey milk has a rich, smooth flavor because it naturally contains higher percentages of protein, calcium, and important nutrients than milk from other dairy breeds (for the latest milk test results, click here). The extra protein is the Jersey milk yields the greatest amount of cheddar cheese: 12.35 pounds of cheese from 100 pounds of This compares to the yield of milk the United States of 10.04 pounds of cheese. The Jersey is the most efficient dairy producer in the world, producing pounds of milk per pound of body weight than any other breed. An average Jersey in the United States produces 16 times her bodyweight in milk each year, or about twice her body weight in cheese. The Jersey production champion produced 40 times her body weight in one year: 49,250 lbs. of milk containing 1,645 lbs. protein. That is equal to 70,752 half-pint servings milk, enough milk for an entire year's lunches in a school of 400 students. The American Jersey Cattle Association was organized in 1868 to improve and the breed of Jersey cattle in the United States. It is located at 6486 East Main Street Reynoldsburg, Ohio 43068. For more subscribe to the Jersey Journal or log onto website at www.USJersey.com. breeders in your area may be by visiting Jersey Directory Online and All-Jersey® distributors are listed on Distributors page.

The recent death Lonesome George, famed Galapagos tortoise believed to the last representative of his subspecies, has many experts wondering how we should try to save other endangered and at-risk Cloning is one option. While cloning methods for reptiles are not as advanced as those for mammals, also they face other incredible obstacles. "At the most, I could envision one turtle of this cloned in future or maybe two males, but where going to get female?" Martha Gomez, a senior scientist with the Audubon Nature Institute, which one world's few "frozen zoos." Frozen Zoos stockpile materials from a wide variety of rare and critically endangered The biological material is usually composed of gametes (sperm and egg cells), embryos, tissue samples, serum and other items. Together, they represent bank vault of irreplaceable genetic information that can be preserved for possibly hundreds of years or more. In most the materials are stored in holding tanks filled with liquid nitrogen. Oliver Ryder, of genetics at the San Diego Zoo, spoke to Discovery News as his team was racing to the Galapagos to help preserve the tissues Lonesome George. The San Diego Zoo operates of the other few frozen zoos. "This is an extremely urgent matter," Ryder said. "We planned to meet in the Galapagos in two weeks to discuss preservation of the tortoises there. It is a bitter irony that Lonesome George died before we could even finish setting up the plans. It underscores the importance of preserving such animals." "We are facing some logistical problems now, but we don't want to look back if's,'" he added. "This may be the chance we'll have to preserve, document and study this tortoise subspecies." Ryder discussions of cloning George are premature at this point. Before that takes he thinks more must be learned about this particular tortoise's physiology and reproduction. George's remains may also to reveal how tortoises often live to advanced ages, information that could one lead to breakthroughs in extending human lifespans. For cloning, researchers are focusing more on "species where we have knowledge of their reproductive Ryder said. That is one reason why cats, dogs and mice were among the first animals to be cloned. Scientists are now working clone endangered relatives of such animals, in hopes of releasing those individuals into the wild to strengthen natural populations. Earlier this year, Gomez and her successfully cloned endangered black-footed cats. An endangered ox, called a and a banteng (wild cattle) have also been successfully Work is underway to clone and otherwise increase the population of Sumatran rhinos, which presently number only about 200-300 in the wild. While one clone is an interesting novelty, clones must also be able to in order to be fully successful. Gomez said that kittens of cloned wild cat parents have died "due to with nuclear programing," but some normal kittens resulted and continue to thrive. Both she Ryder say that there is no international policy calling for cloning and preservation of highly endangered species. Instead, isolated facilities and work of dedicated individuals are responsible for the successes. "The effort needs to be more widespread and organized," Gomez said. Through published papers and talks, Ryder and his have repeatedly called for organized global effort. It would need an "overarching international body" par with UNESCO, he believes. "The first step is saving tissue samples, in the process of doing for Lonesome George," he said. "But we who are among the would like to train others to establish frozen zoo biobanks in other countries." "I am confident that day such an international structure will come together, bringing in other conservation work, such as preserving habitat," Ryder concluded. ad8bca791a164e12f367b34da9f05eebba0071f3: for National Geographic News Explosive population growth is driving human evolution to speed around the world, according to a new study. The pace of change accelerated about 40,000 years ago and then picked up even more with the advent of agriculture about 10,000 years ago, the study And while humans are quickly around the world, local cultural and factors shaping evolution differently on different continents. "We're evolving away from each other. We're getting more and more different," said Henry Harpending, an anthropologist at the University of Utah in Salt Lake City who co-authored the study. For example, in Europe natural selection has favored for pigmentation light skin, blue eyes, and blond hair. Asians also have genes selected for skin, but they are different from the European ones. "Europeans and Asians are both Africans, but the way they got bleached is different in two areas," Harpending said. He and colleagues report the finding this week in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Snips of DNA The researchers analyzed the DNA 270 people International HapMap Project, an effort to identify variation in human genes that disease and as targets for new study specifically looked for genetic variations called single nucleotide polymorphisms, or SNPs (pronounced "snips"), which are mutations at a single point on a chromosome. (See an overview human genetics.) "We look for parts of chromosomes that common in the population but new, and they are common but recent, must have to high frequency by selection," Harpending explained. SOURCES AND RELATED WEB SITES

Bawa didn’t set out to study Himalayan perceptions of climate change. after hearing the same repeated again and again during household he decided to investigate. With UMB graduate student he some 500 homes across villages in Darjeeling Hills, West Bengal, India and Nepal’s Ilam district. I think when you come to people don’t any ideas—or they may have some very different ideas.” Bawa pointed to a study of this topic in Tibet, where many respondents believed that humans are causing climate change—but not by producing greenhouse gasses as most climate scientists believe. “They seem to think that the climate is changing because Gods are not happy and perhaps the people in the generations are not praying enough.” This was supported in part by a Committee for Research and Exploration grant the National Society.
d15a8879ac2cd5aab2d9c9fec388d60a4ff58b3c: Use the back button to select a different record. Librarians' Conference of the Kentucky Negro Educational Association Year : 1935 Year 1956 The Librarians' Conference was established April 11, 1935, during the 59th Annual Session of the Kentucky Negro Educational Association (KNEA) in Louisville, KY. It was the first for African American librarians and teacher librarians in Kentucky. The group continued to meet annually during the KNEA Conference until desegregation in 1956, when it was subsumed into the Kentucky Education Association. For more see Librarians' Conference reports in the Kentucky Negro Educational Association publications 1935-1956 at Kentucky State University and also available online in the Kentucky Digital Library - Journals. Subjects: Librarians, Library Collections, Libraries Geographic Kentucky

Normally, cells in a regulated manner. cells keep dividing uncontrollably when new cells are not needed, a mass of tissue forms, called a growth or tumor. The cancer refers to malignant tumors, which can invade nearby tissues and spread to other of the body. A benign tumor usually does invade or spread. Radiation may be: - External radiation therapy—radiation at tumor from a source outside the body - Internal radiation therapy—radioactive materials placed into the in or near the cancer cells This is the use of drugs kill cancer cells. Chemotherapy may be given in many including pill, injection, and/or via a catheter. Combined Modality Therapy Often times, chemotherapy and radiation therapy are used to kill of the throat. This combined may be better than surgery or radiation alone. To reduce your chance of getting throat cancer, take the following steps: - Don't smoke or use tobacco products. If you or use tobacco products, get help to quit. - Drink alcohol only moderation. A new cultural centre devoted to Kikuyu, Kenya’s offers a unique experience of this tradition rich culture in a modern world.| Riuki Cultural Centre is located not far outside Nairobi, in the Kikuyu Heartland of Kiambu. The centre is run by Kinuthia Njoroge, who wanted to a traditional Kikuyu village to show local children the history and customs of their community. The Kikuyu are the largest community in Kenya, and have always played a central role in the development of the independent Nation. For this reason, many may believe that modern influence has eroded the way of life for this who mainly live around the capital city and the highlands. But as Riuki demonstrates, this is not case. While traditional and ceremonies may be displays of proud history, many of the same beliefs and customs persist in modern life. In cuisine, music, marriage and family life, most Kenyan still hold true to their identity. this that Riuki strives to encourage and strengthen, with its own blend the modern and traditional. Now visitors to Kenya can come to Riuki and spend a day learning more about this known culture. Welcomed the centre by a group of elders, all of whom live in the local area, guests are welcomed in true Kikuyu style, with an invitation to drink from a horn filled with Muratina, a locally brewed drink. There is of a traditionally an explanation of how the traditional society operated. Communities always remained bound by strict and ties of clan loyalty and an even stronger sense of tribal - There was an set system among young men, known Mariika, all clans and villages (itura) paid deference to the wisdom and of the tribe. At Riuki, traditional proverbs and dances bring the myths and legends of the Kikuyu life. According to mythology, of creation began at the summit of Mount Kenya. icy peak was the realm Ngai, the Supreme Creator, who descended from the heavens to his mountainous throne to survey his newly created lands. The became Kirinyaga, his resting place, and it was from here that called Gikuyu, the father of Kikuyu people. Ngai told him that all of the lands around Kirinyaga would home of Gikuyu his forever. He sent Gikuyu to grove of Fig trees, where he found a called Mumbi. This would become known as Mukuru wa Nyagathanga, the birthplace of all still revered as a sacred place. Among the fig trees, Gikuyu and Mumbi produced nine daughters- Wanjiku, Wanjiru, Wanjeri, Wambui, Wangari, Wacera, Waithera, Wairimu, and Nyambura. (Traditionally all Kikuyu should given one of these names) The girls grew into beautiful women, who each wandered the lands around Kirinyaga in search of men that they could bear children. their to appeal to Ngai for help. Finally he bowed the Mountain, and him make sacrifice among the and light a fire. The sacrifice of a goat beneath a fig tree still considered a way to call rain in times of drought, but in this first case it was a different form of life sustaining rain Gikuyu sought. After the sacrifice he plunged nine sticks into fire, and prayed. The fire erupted into an inferno, from which nine strong young men emerged. Giving thanks, Gikuyu took them back to his daughters, the nine marriages were blessed by Each of the daughters made her own homestead, and nine separate clans of the were born. the unity these clans was known as the ya Mumbi, in honour of their The peak of Kirinyaga has since remained the sacred home of Ngai. at Riuki, all Kikuyu homesteads were traditionally to this Holy Mountain. A local women come the centre to perform for visitors, with a series of dances traditionally performed at weddings and initiations and to sing songs. These are simple love and courting songs, traditional hunting songs and chants used when going to work the fields. The highlands of Kenya are rich fertile land, and this great farming culture- with a great cuisine that has grown from freshly grown vegetables. The highlight of the day is a chance to sample a typical Kikuyu meal- delicious food including sweet potatoes, Githeri (a maize and bean stew), Mukimo (a mashed combination of green and potato) with roasted goat and Irio, a great Kikuyu favourite. Just as usual on every sunny day, his telescope was projecting an 11-inch-wide image of the sun on a screen, and skillfully drew the sunspots he saw. On that he capturing the likeness of enormous group of sunspots. Suddenly, before his eyes, two of white appeared the sunspots, intensified rapidly, and became kidney-shaped. Realizing that he was witnessing something unprecedented and "being somewhat by the surprise," Carrington later wrote, "I hastily ran call someone to witness the exhibition with me. returning within 60 seconds, I was to find that it was already much changed enfeebled." He and his witness watched the white spots contract to and disappear. Friday, 2nd, 1859: Just before dawn next day, skies all over planet Earth erupted in red, green, and purple auroras so brilliant that newspapers could be read easily as daylight. Indeed, stunning auroras pulsated even at near latitudes over Cuba, the Bahamas, Jamaica, Salvador, and Hawaii. Even more disconcerting, telegraph systems worldwide went haywire. discharges shocked telegraph operators and telegraph paper fire. when telegraphers disconnected the batteries powering the lines, aurora-induced electric currents the wires still allowed messages to be transmitted. 80d12f4dc19a7ae7390b0916aae9d8d43fb55f41: By Baxter A few years ago, Emory’s Michael C. Carlos Museum a fascinating exhibit based on the papyrus legal of family which lived in Egypt in the 5th Century BC. As a testament to the lasting lessons such archaeological treasures can transmit, it came mind last week when Barack Obama became the first sitting U.S. president to same-sex marriage. The papyri were the legal documents of a couple, a temple official, and his Tamut, an Egyptian woman who’d been sold into slavery a child. They lived on the island of Elephantine in the Nile, in a time when Egypt was part of the Persian Empire and Jewish mercenaries guarded its southern border. As it is today, relationships could be complicated back then. When she married on July 3, 449 BC, Tamut was owned by another man, Meshullam, didn’t free her or her daughter for another 22 years. Things worked though. Later papyri record Ananiah giving Tamut part ownership of their house, selling a to his son-in-law and making payments on a wedding gift for their daughter. The records are a striking of the bizarre with the familiar. The conventions of legalese have changed so little over the millenia that a modern-day lawyer would feel completely at home with these contracts. But the concept marriage around which these legal proceedings revolve appears to have been radically different from ours today. The contract between Ananiah and Tamut is so detailed that it specifies on which side the stairs each is to walk up and But as far as the state was concerned, marriage like theirs – the notarized enumeration what one party the other to for, if things didn’t work out – was all the marriage was. Since Ananiah was a religious leader, there may have been a to sanctify the marriage within the Jewish community on the island, but over the whole of Egyptian society, state’s involvement in defining, protecting preserving marriage was quite limited to each If government has developed better way deal this complex aspect of human society, it was not in evidence when North Carolina voters overwhelmingly declared their support for an amendment defining solely as the union between a man and a woman, and Obama declared the next day that he’d decided his views on the subject and supports the right people of the sex to marry. By comparison with historic stands taken by presidents, carried remarkably little weight. The states decide this issue, and one just had. Obama’s statement morning news show the following day was couched more something which had been forced by Vice President Joe Biden’s unguarded comments on the subject than the embarrassment of a big vote in the state where the Democrats will hold their convention this summer. This sounds progressively more fishy longer you think about it, particularly when you hear how angry the Obama staffers sounded about Biden’s goofiness, according to the reporters who repeated on-the-record what the staffers them off-the-record. Yet symbolically, Obama’s statement was rightly looked on as an historic event. The North Carolina vote, which into the state constitution what was already on the books as state law, was also largely symbolic. And lemme tell you – as Gov. Roy might said after his bitter experience with changing state flag symbolism is the rat poison of good government. Should government get more involved in as those on both sides of the current controversy would or less? At present the states and the government find themselves in a cycle of ineffectiveness. Washington has no power over what states define marriage to be, but because of the Defense of signed by President Clinton, which prohibits same-sex couples from the rights and protections of marriage in more than a thousand federal laws, really doesn’t matter what the do either. Because our modern concept of marriage unlike the Egyptians — involves a certain fusion, long since blurred, between provinces of religion and the state, we appear bound to state by state an issue which in some respects can only settled congregation by congregation. Nor does government the federal or the state level have the ability to stop the steady decline in heterosexual marriage, as attested by a voluminous array of statistics on divorce, unwed mothers and single-parent households. In terms of the work hours it has to invest, government’s biggest with marriage today is administration of breakups and the management of the carnage that often comes with them. Administratively, were much easier for Ananiah and Tamut, which makes it impossible to replicate the arrangements their day. But their preserved family records challenge us to thin

Choose from the listed below to see examples: • Citing author in the • Using direct quotes • Citing by more • Citing works three or more authors • Citing a chapter of section • Citing an organization • Citing works by the author in the same year • secondary sources Citing the Author in the Text Dogs were first animals to domesticated (Sheldrake, 1999). If the author’s name occurs naturally in sentence the year is given in brackets. Sheldrake (1999) asserted that dogs were the first animals to be domesticated. Using Direct Quotes If you quote directly from a source, you must insert the author’s name, date of publication and page of the quotation. The of dogs, long predated the domestication of other animals (Sheldrake, Citing works by more than one If your source has two you should include both names in the text. Anderson Poole (1998) note that a “narrow line often separates plagiarism from good scholarship.” Citing works by three or more Authors If there are or more authors, you should include the first author and then add ‘et al.’ in italics followed by a full stop. This is an abbreviation of ‘et alia’ which ‘and others’ In United States, revenue from computer games now exceeds of movies (Kline et al., 2003). Citing Chapter or Section When referring to a chapter or section which is part of a larger work, you should cite the author of the chapter not the editor of the whole The sea level has risen by approximately 10cm in the last 100 years (Mason, Citing Organization If an organization or company (e.g., Department of Health, Arcadia Group Limited) is named as of work rather than a person, you should cite their names. Make sure that you use the same version of the name in both the Text and List of references (e.g., always ‘Department of Health’, don’t abbreviate to ‘DoH’). Spain became a member of the Nations in 1955 (United Nations, 2000). Citing Secondary Sources When citing secondary sources (i.e., an refers a work which you have not read) cite the secondary source, but include the name of the author and date of publication of the original source in the text. Only the secondary should be listed in your List of references. You only cite if you are unable to read original Sheff (1993) that Nintendo invested heavily in advertising (cited in et al., 2003, p. 118).

In "The Wizard of Oz," Dorothy Gale steps out of her black-and-white Kansas and into the color-saturated Land of Oz. She from a humdrum existence of chores and to an intense fantasyland peopled with curious creatures, trading in a clapboard house for yellow brick roads, red ruby slippers and a green city of emeralds. would her transformation have been without this rainbow of colors? Color isn't just a component of vision. We associate color with beauty, like a gorgeous Some colors have meaning in and of themselves -- purple is for royals, red signifies passion. Colors seep our expressions -- If depressed, we say we're feeling blue. also "green with envy," we "see red" and we might go with fear." Colors even have practical meaning -- red means stop, green means go. Certain colors are said help you sleep, while others make you hungry. And never the effect of a red dress. Color is important. this article, we're going to learn what the world looks like for someone who's colorblind.

And this led to our intuition: on our Ark of Taste – a catalogue of products to save – we have included transformed foods: breads, cheese, cured meats, Because this is biodiversity. We linked diverse worlds that normally didn’t interact: farmers, cooks, veterinarians, In to achieve objectives: – Help small-scale farmers: To save a breed, we didn’t start from genetic selection; to save an apple we didn’t start from a collection of varieties. we began by seeking out the shepherds that bred certain breed, the farmers that still cultivated that apple, we went and to them. With this crucial step, the Presidia project was launched, that today is supporting in corner the world. 2 – awareness about biodiversity: need to work with producers and experts, but also with schools, journalists, restaurant and so on. We need to write and tell of producers with every tool at our disposal, because these themes transcend university halls and scientific institutions, become the heritage of us all. Biodiversity can’t saved by scientists alone, by the powerful of world, because it is no interest the market. And it’s probable that Noah won’t be arriving with his Ark. This battle, therefore, is one that needs be taken up by us, together with all people we manage to involve, our lands, every day - with our Ark of Taste, Presidia, Earth Markets, community school gardens, and the thousands of other ideas still to come. Because the battle save biodiversity isn’t like any other battle. 0ff37dbfdbd3713a7c208d140507984c62cc4fad: decay prevalent among Alaska native children 23, 2011, 7:36 a.m. By Yereth Rosen ANCHORAGE, Alaska (Reuters) - Native Alaskan children living in remote villages have rates of decay about four times the national average, a government study showed. Lack of fluoridated water and an of sugary, carbonated soda pop were the major reasons cited in the research that tracked dental health of children in the mostly Yupik Eskimo region of southwestern Alaska. Dr. Brad Whistler, Alaska state oral health director and a co-author of the study, said children need dental work. "When they smile, you see a lot of silver teeth," he said. Such severe decay sets up children to have serious dental problems as adults, Whistler said. One reason for high level tooth decay is poor water-system infrastructure many Alaska villages, which prevents the of drinking water that has helped lower rates of tooth decay. In some villages were part the study, residents must haul water home from central pumps, he said. those places with sophisticated systems are likely to lack fluoride in drinking water, because few qualified are available to work in such far-flung and install the necessary equipment. The other problem is the of the traditional Native diet the introduction food laden with sugar, Whistler said. study, by the federal Centers for Disease Control and the Department of and Social Services, analyzed 2008 dental records and habits of 348 children between the ages of four and 15. (Editing by Alex Dobuzinskis and Johnston)

Conversely, six of 10 states with the lowest percentage of LGBT-identified adults are among the top 10 conservative in the country. The states proportionally larger LGBT populations generally have supportive LGBT legal climates. With the exception of South Dakota, all of the states that have LGBT populations of at least 4% have laws that prohibit based sexual orientation gender identity and allow same-sex couples to marry, enter into a civil union, or register as domestic partners. Of the 10 states with lowest percentage of LGBT adults, only Iowa has such laws. With demographics, it’s always important to keep in mind that the number represents something very specific: the number of who willing to disclose identity an anonymous pollster. It doesn’t represent the number of people who are actually gay but don’t want to tell a pollster, who don’t yet know that they’re gay, who deny that they’re gay, or who as gay but do engage in same-sex behavior. Still, these numbers are telling. The benefits of coming out are well so in an indirect way, these results show that having laws that protect LGBT people not only protect them from discrimination, but support their mental and well-being. Indeed, the value of such positive climates is arguably a more compelling conclusion from this study than the demographics themselves. e8b901bc7ef3bd5f99a86e428048ebf832994d8c: An economist who put a premium on truth: Obituary of Leonid Hurwicz comment, July Hurwicz, the economist who last year became the oldest person ever to win a Nobel prize, helped transform economic thinking in second half the 20th century. years economists had been passionately debating the rival merits of state planning versus markets. In both systems, people had to lie to bureaucratic or to about their interests, their skills or circumstances. who has died at the of 90, founded the field of design”, a new way of which focused on giving people incentives to tell the truth to so in a way that would benefit society as a whole. His mechanism design idea has applications in a range of practical areas, from the design of computer networks and voting systems to arbitration rules. The debate between state planning and free markets must have seemed far from academic to Hurwicz. His parents were Polish Jews who fled the Kaiser’s army, going to Moscow, where Hurwicz was born in 1917. returned to Poland in a horse-drawn wagon escape the Bolsheviks when he was went to the University of Warsaw and took a degree in law, though he also studied piano at the conservatory. Throughout his Hurwicz was a renaissance man interests included music, linguistics, maths, and meteorology. Yet as a student his interest was kindled in economics. He went to London to study and then, via Geneva, to the where he arrived in 1940. His parents and his brother joined him but only after fleeing another invading German army – time the Nazis – then spending time in Soviet labour camps. On his had under both Ludwig von Mises and Friedrich Hayek, who was at the London School as Hurwicz began his PhD studies there in 1938. Von Mises and Hayek argued that a centrally planned economy was doomed to collapse: because every individual knew his own needs and capabilities best, government planners could never hope to piece it all together make sensible decisions. Other economists, such as Oskar Lange, disagreed. A burgeoning of markets, and bitter experience of the failings of socialist economies, led many conclude that von Mises and Hayek right. Hurwicz was more interested in advancing the debate declaring “Panaceas are to be found at either end the spectrum,” he wrote in 1984. with Hayek and von Mises that a bureaucrat who simply demanded results would be met with budgetpadding and lies. But rather than giving up, Hurwicz the problem directly. He asked what “mechanisms” an intelligent but ill-informed planner might use to information from others and then allocate resources efficiently or profitably. Such mechanisms are as old as trade itself, most the auction, in even ignorant seller can expect a good price. But Hurwicz laid the foundations for thinking systematically designing mechanisms, defining all the terms rigorously showing what might be possible. Hurwicz described a a kind of “message centre”, market participants would submit information, or false, a pre-specified set of rules would adjudicate the result. That abstract description is a perfect account of Ebay auction: a seller sets a minimum bid, a time limit and perhaps a reserve price, while bidders submit bids that may bear no resemblance the true value they place on the prize. EBay is just one example of a message centre; Hurwicz showed that was useful to think about many economic institutions in this way. Participants in a mechanism can always lie. A keen buyer can pretend to be an indifferent one; a brilliant worker can conceal his laziness. Hurwicz realised that in order to get better bid from the keenest buyer, for example, the seller must give that buyer a reason to tell the truth. Similarly, an employer cannot persuade the ablest worker to work just as hard as the rest unless the extra effort brings extra general problem of persuading the “best” agents to act from the rest is called the “incentive compatibility constraint”. One example would be auction where highest bidder wins but only has to pay the second highest bid. This strange-sounding rule is all it takes to persuade the keenest bidder to the about the real value he places on the prize. EBay uses a rule. Although studied with the of the field – including Kaldor at the LSE, and Paul Samuelson – he never had an economics degree. “Whatever economics learned, I learned by and learning,” he said, after winning Nobel prize. A warm and charming man, he had an impish wit. Once, a speaker wrote an equation on the board, declared proof was “obvious”

8eb96852450b64af0f44e2305f5e8f537ef07105: It's easy at first glance to envision Caribbean as all being the same sunny, sandy vacation but they are in as ways as they are similar. Just as political and economic factors determine the personality of the islands, so do various landforms that may, or may not, be shared from island to island. The islands of the Caribbean, like all islands, have water surrounds them on every side. Individual islands and of islands belong to various nations. Puerto and American Virgin Islands belong to the United States. Among the territories of Britain are and the British Virgin Islands. The islands range in size, Cuba being the largest, followed by Hispaniola Many of smaller islands are uninhabited. Some of the uninhabited islands, as the Isla de Ratones just off the shore of Rico, are available for day trips and reached by ferries, boats or kayaks. The islands of the Caribbean have enough land space to support rivers. Hispaniola has four primary rivers: del Norte, Yuna River, Yaque del Sur the Artibonite River. Cuba's important rivers are the Rio Cauto, which is the longest, Almendares and Rio Yurimi. Smaller rivers contribute these three main rivers. The Grande de Arecibo Puerto Rico's longest river. This river, along several others as the Cibuco, Loiza and La Plata, run north. One river runs westward: the Grande de Añasco. The Bahamas no rivers. Many of the Caribbean islands have mountainous areas. Most of Puerto Rico's mountains are located on island's interior. Jamaica has mountains that cover almost all of its surface. The Dry Harbour Mountains run along the northern part of the island, with the Blue Mountains on the east. Cuba is not a very mountainous country, but it has a few mountain ranges. The Maestra in are on the easternmost coastline, and the Cordillera de Guaniguanico on the west coast. The Grupo Guamuhaya are the center and south-center the island. Because the Caribbean consists of one of the prevalent landforms is the beach. Temperate weather access to sand and have helped the Caribbean thrive as destinations. The sand on the beaches of the Caribbean come in many different colors. Beaches in Bermuda and Bahamas are known for their pink sands, by the shells certain tiny sea creatures. Some Caribbean beaches are the result of volcanic matter breaking Black is not smooth as typical white, tan or pink sand, and many black sand beaches are pebble beaches. These beaches are found on Montserrat, St. and among others. Salt flats form when salt water evaporates, leaving the salt behind on large, flat areas of land. The salt flats of Rico, located Cabo Rojo region in southwest part of island, are as a part of U.S. and Wildlife Service's Cabo Rojo National Wildlife Refuge. Another in the Caribbean that has salt is the small island of Bonaire. The salt is harvested from the flats that lie on the southern tip of the island, but a portion of the salt flats of Bonaire is set aside as sanctuary for flamingos. The central coastline is the tourist area of Bonaire which is a frequent port of call for cruise ships. - World Atlas: Caribbean - Cabo Puerto Rico: Isla de Ratones Hispaniola.com: Geography of the Dominican Republic - Havana-Guide.com: Major Rivers in Cuba - Welcome to Puerto Geography of Puerto Rico - The Bahamas Guide: Bahamas Geography and Geology - Sol Boricua: Geography of Puerto Rico - Geography and History Jamaica: Physical Features - Hicuba.com: Geography of Cuba - Caribbean Magazine: Types of Caribbean Beaches--White, and Black DC Productions/Photodisc/Getty Images

ac9ce518023ddfa7c3b6d40cd75d64758cc51c69: February 11, 2011 > Low Have to Mean Low Flavor Low Fat Doesn't Have to Mean Low Flavor Lunch and Learn Cooking Demonstration Focuses on Healthy Options In an ideal world, steamed broccoli and slice cheesecake in the refrigerator have the same of and fat. Sadly, the real world, that's just not the case. To stay healthy, we have to watch what we eat, and every day decisions we make regarding our diet can have an enormous impact-on a lot of things... The pounds on the scale, our waistline, how much energy we have, and heart health. According to data published on the Centers for Control (CDC)'s Web the most common heart disease in the United States is coronary heart disease, which often appears as a heart attack. In 2010, an estimated 785,000 had a coronary attack, and about 470,000 had a recurrent attack. That means 25 seconds, an American will have a coronary event, and about one every minute will die from one. Not surprisingly, heart disease represents the No. 1 cause of death in the United States. For both and And although heart disease is of as a "man's disease," women account for nearly 50 percent of heart disease deaths, states. When it comes risk factors for heart disease, there are some we can't change, such as gender, age and genetics. Other things we can. Making sustainable lifestyle changes, like eating low fat diet, has been shown to help lower the risk of heart disease. But changing old habits isn't as easy as snapping our fingers, is it? Nutrition labels on our favorite foods can be hard to what about those recipes that call for things like butter, cream cheese and sour cream? Are they banished On Wednesday, Feb. 16, Anna Mazzei, a registered dietitian and certified diabetes educator at Washington Hospital, will be whipping up a Low Fat Cooking Demonstration at the Washington Women's to help participants get an idea of how to modify cooking and eating "National Heart Month is recognized February, and one of the things that love are foods that are typically high in fat," Mazzei says. "The question is: how do the same satisfaction without as much fat?" During her demonstration, says she won't be going for an all or nothing approach because, to be successful, it's more about being creative cutting out anything and everything. "Now the marketplace there lighter products available," she says. "You have to go nonfat, but probably to lighter products to cut down some fat and calories." Items that are high in fat-like a slice of cheesecake-also pack in the calories with little nutritional reward in the form of essential vitamins and Whereas a serving of broccoli runs you about 25 calories, the same quantity cheesecake is more like 250 calories. "I'm going to look at some of the highest fat items and how to scale them down," Mazzei explains. "We're going to do some taste testing and focus on how to take these things and make a satisfying, yet lighter version." Examples of items Mazzei is to sample during the demonstration include: * Fried chicken * Chicken nuggets Recipes with butter and cream cheese Another great way to improve heart health-and something hand in with a low fat diet-is exercise. If missed the evening Exercise for Your Health class at the Women's earlier this month, call to find out about the center's range of fitness classes, gentle yoga to the official Arthritis official exercise program. If you're learning more about how to a tasty, low-fat diet, for her Lunch Learn cooking demonstration at the Washington Center Conference Room on Wednesday, Feb. 16, from noon to 1 p.m.* The Washington Women's Center located at 2500 Mowry Ave., Suite 150. *Space is limited 20 participants. To (800) 963-7070 or go online at www.whhs.com/womenscenter For more information about exercise programs and other services at the Women's Center, call (510) or toll-free at (866) 608-1301. Learn More About Heart Health Washington Hospital physicians Dr. Jon-Cecil Walkes, cardiothoracic surgeon and Dr. Michael Parmley, internal medicine, will discuss prevention and treatment of coronary heart disease at a free seminar on Tuesday, February 15. The be held 1 3 p.m. at the Conrad E. Anderson, M.D. Auditorium 2500 Mowry Avenue (Washington West) in Fremont. can register at www.whhs.com

4db61d7dfc2444b1d24eb8ed5fec99cda88d30b4: Dr.Gerstenfeld held this lecture on the 8th of November in Helsinki Finland. The summary the lecture republished here with the author’s consent. THE ABUSE OF HOLOCAUST MEMORY Summary Lecture in Helsinki November 2012 By Manfred Gerstenfeld The Holocaust has become a symbol of absolute evil in Western society. This happened gradually over the It not the case in say, 1960. Yet one might have expected that with the Second World War more than years behind us, mention memory of it would fade away. Indeed, there is in many circles what is termed “Holocaust fatigue.” people do not want to hear anything anymore about the Holocaust. At the same time, many others increasingly mention and discuss the It took 60 years until in 2005 Nations General named 27 January as International Holocaust Remembrance Day. On this day, every member state of the UN has an official obligation to honor the victims of the Nazi era and develop material about Holocaust. This year the remembrance of the Holocaust is devoted to children.1 Why this Interest in the Holocaust? What are the main reasons for this increasing interest the Holocaust? We can identify some but do not know their relative weight. Memorial celebrations take place every year in many places. There are also new monuments still going up and new memorial being inaugurated. One was at Drancy the major transit camp in France. 63,000 of the 76,000 deported Jews transited before almost all of them to deaths. Yet both memorial days pass and monuments disappear from the public eye most of the time. New historical research is being published about the Holocaust. Additional documents are also discovered. One example among many was that in October 2012, pictures taken by Hitler’s photographer Hugo Jaeger, of Polish Jews in the ghetto of Kutno between 1939 were released. This was done to mark the official establishment the Warsaw Ghetto in October 1940.2 Such research and discoveries are mentioned in media. Thus they also a role in the increased interest. The increasing central place the Holocaust European societies is also due a number of other developments. One is that European have increasingly secular, which means that their common norms values have to a large extent broken In such ideological and moral vacuum, one out standards many people more less agree upon. The partly fills that function. plays a role as a defining moment in European history. The Holocaust touches upon very basic questions which many Europeans do not like to ask themselves explicitly. What was it in European culture and in European societies that the Holocaust possible? This leads to a taboo question. Have the elements which made the possible disappeared, or are to some extent still with us? The first nations which should ask these questions are Germany Austria. Yet present they do not seem inclined to do so. The generation is not responsible for what ancestors did. However, the Holocaust and Nazism can not eliminated from German history. I would like to phrase question somewhat differently. of the ancestors of contemporary Germans Austrians were Nazi enthusiasts. Many other Germans and Austrians went along with Nazis without hesitation. Is it at all that nothing of these has remained in these countries today? Another element of importance for the interest in the Holocaust the growing uncertainty in the world. That requires more and more of reference for events take place daily. One example which has to be analyzed is the emergence of parties in European countries with many neo-fascist and neo-Nazi characteristics. This becomes problematic in particular if these enter Parliament. While the interest in the Holocaust growing there is simultaneously also a massive increase in the distortion of the and the memory of the Holocaust. To understand the abuse of the Holocaust in our days, have start at it by category. In my book, “The Abuse of Holocaust Memory, Distortions and Responses” I have developed eight categories of distortion. These are: Holocaust Justification and Promotion, Holocaust Denial, Holocaust Deflection and Whitewashing, Holocaust Equivalence,Holocaust Inversion, i.e the Portraying Israel and Jews as Holocaust Trivialization and Obliterating Holocaust Memory The massive ongoing of Holocaust brings us the question, what can be done about it? There is no single fight against the abuse the Holocaust. Education is very important. So are memorials, monuments etc. The crucial point however remains not to let abuse of the Holocaust enter further in the public debate. It is
9d6f345cf1499b1dc8c04f610762f81cbcddf150: Gluten Free Facts What is gluten? Gluten the protein found wheat, barley, rye and related wheat species such spelt and kamut. It helps baked goods keep their form and chewy texture and is also added to other food items more and more, both for consistency and taste purposes. Helpful Hint: Buckwheat, contrary to its name, is not actually wheat and does not contain gluten. What foods contain gluten? The obvious foods that contain gluten include foods made from a flour base. Wheat, barley, and rye based breads, cookies, pastries, and bagels all contain gluten. However, hidden sources of gluten are abundant many packaged from soy sauce to spice mixes, mints. More and more companies are labeling their products as gluten free and some even go through a gluten free certification process. Here is a short of foods that can have hidden gluten: - Luncheon meat - cheese - Gravy and gravy powder - beans - Self basting turkeys - Seasoning Mixes - Instant coffee - Brown rice syrup - Potato chips - Soy sauce - Hot Chocolate - - Curry powder - White pepper - Malt vinegar - Breath mints Oats (while naturally gluten free, there is a risk of contamination through harvesting, milling, and processing; Udi’s only uses certified gluten free oats) (1) (2) For a full list unsafe ingredients, click Who should eat a gluten free diet? Some people must eat a gluten free because they’ve been diagnosed with Celiac Disease or Gluten Sensitivity, in which the only cure a gluten free diet. Others eat gluten because they suspect gluten them undesirable symptoms that they wish avoid. Still have learned that gluten can cause they seek eliminate it from diet. No matter what a gluten free lifestyle may be of benefit to you. Who can get Celiac Disease or have a Gluten Sensitivity? The short answer is: anyone. Some are more predisposed to this disease or intolerance than others, family has been diagnosed. It has noted that northern European countries, specifically Nordic countries, as well as Italy and Ireland have a rate of Celiac Disease, and approximately 1 out of every 133 Americans have Celiac Disease. (7) What is Celiac Disease? Celiac Disease is an autoimmune disorder where gluten triggers the immune system to attack the lining of small intestine. Over time, Disease can cause malabsorption, leading a range of health problems as iron and mineral deficiencies, osteoporosis, disease, infertility, neurological disorders, and even some forms cancer. (3, 4) For more information, click here: Celiac Disease and Diabetes About 1% of the total has celiac disease. It is more common in people with type 1 diabetes. estimated 10% of people with type 1 also celiac disease. For more information, here: What is Gluten Anyway Where Is It? By Danna Korn, Gluten Free for Dummies, edition Gluten has a couple of definitions; one is technically correct not and the other is commonly used but not technically correct. Here’s the common definition: Gluten is a mixture of proteins in rye, barley. Oats don’t have gluten, but may be contaminated, so they’re forbidden on a strict gluten-free diet, too. You can find lots of information about what can and can’t eat on a gluten-free diet at www.celiac.com or other websites. But you need to have a general idea of what kinds of food have gluten in you know what to avoid. with flour in (white or wheat) are the most common culprits when you’re gluten. The following are obvious gluten-glomming Cookies, cakes, and other goods But along with these culprits come not-so-obvious suspects too, like licorice, many ‘most’) cereals, and natural flavorings. When you’re gluten-free, you get used to reading labels, calling manufacturers, and digging a little deeper to know for sure what you can eat. You have to do without these foods, but you really don’t have to do without. There’s but encouraging difference. Food manufacturers make delicious versions of just about food imaginable these days.
520c62b5697bdce5bdbf1378929d2b7dba0b4c9b: Breaking the of poverty More than of the 242 counties in the Southeastern persistent poverty region are located in Georgia. from Athens-Clarke county to Miller to Troup, these counties are defined by statistics that boggle the mind, especially against the backdrop of Georgia's economic strength over the past decade: - 20.9 percent of the total population and percent of children live below poverty level as an income of $17,650 for a family of four); - 29.5 percent of residents age 25 and above do not have high school diploma; - the unemployment rate is percent, 40 higher than other Georgia counties; - the rate of low birth-weight is 25 higher the national "The data confirmed what already knew about the region, but it was still startling to see the unevenness of growth development," said Art Dunning, vice president for public service and outreach at UGA. is an economic issue, pure and "What was a complete surprise to me was the disparity between rural Georgia and metropolitan Georgia," said Jim Ledbetter, of the Carl Vinson Institute of Government at UGA, which the study. "These problems have persisted for decades. We need both a body knowledge and a set of programs built the years to address these issues." U.S. Senator Zell Miller secured $250,000 in federal funding to help start the data collection on poverty in Georgia and other Southern states. Macon businessman Griffith matched that a $250,000 gift to the UGA in support of the study. The year-long completed in December 2002, paints a stark picture of a region not only separated from the economic boom that Atlanta has enjoyed, but of a region which also threatens to draw the rest of Georgia into cycle of "I've seen this problem up close," said Griffith, whose timberland and real estate business stretches from to Texas. "I believe UGA research help develop plan to address poverty in this state. Somebody has to do something." "We need a population which can fully participate in the 21st century a community infrastructure which supports that population," said Ledbetter, looking ahead to the next phase of the study. we can craft a set of policies programs to address these "This is not an issue of historical or social justice," Dunning said. "Those discussions don't get us anywhere. We need to take a detailed look at where we are, and then together to improve Georgia."

f277eab314399ae24e1bd02cebdc5ca34b83ea35: How Do Blind People Describe Different Having been blind since birth, Tommy Edison is used fielding questions about how he perceives the concept color. He finally sets the record straight in his recent YouTube video, “Describing Colors To Blind People,” that’s been making the rounds the Internet. “I’ve never seen color. I have any concept of what is,” Tommy says. “There’s this whole part vocabulary – of language – that just doesn’t mean anything to faults sighted people trying and not succeeding to explain color to him, finding that they often attempt to explain one sense with another sense. “That doesn’t make any bloody sense at all!” In his own words, Tommy what the words “red,” “blue,” “orange,” “black,” and “white” mean him, based solely on what he’s heard about them and how they’re used in everyday speech.
9a0edc2e5954675270b543e89b0a575f1dd1950f: Gospel of Mark The Gospel According to Mark, also known as The Gospel of Mark, is one of the four canonical It was most the earliest of the four to be written. Scholars typically estimate it was written between 70CE and 90CE, by an unknown author. In Mark 9:1 , Jesus says to his followers: - "Verily I unto you, That there be some them that stand here, which shall not of death, till they have seen the kingdom of come power." 17 And was gone into the way, there came one running, and kneeled to him, and asked him, Good Master, what shall I do that may inherit eternal life? And Jesus said unto him, Why callest thou me good? there is none good but one, that is, Significance of Mark is significant in understanding the other gospels in the biblical corpus because it is said that Mark "strung the pearls" i.e. was the first to bring together sayings, teachings and stories of to create Gospel. The significance of this is that Mark is thus significant with understanding Matthew, Luke and John. For example, Mark was written in 70 AD whereas Matthew written in 80-85 AD. There are thus 2 prevalent theories for as to where the gospel story from First is the 2 source theory which states that the gospel of Matthew derived from Mark another source, Second is the source theory which states that the gospel of Matthew is derived from things unique to Matthew, things from gospel of Luke, Mark, and this other source Q. In both of these suggestions the gospel Mark is a predominant figure with regards to understanding Matthew. This holds true with the other two gospels, although is a little more intricate (cf. the Perrin Suggestion). - R.H. Gundry, A Commentary on His Apology for the Cross (Grand Rapids: Wm. Eerdmans, 1993) - V. Taylor, The Formation of the Gospel Tradition (London: Macmillan & Co., 1953) - D.M. Smith, John among the Gospels (Minneapolis: Augsburg/Fortress, 1992)

This positive news reveals that the number of tigers in the wild is feasible. “In the midst of crisis, it’s tempting to the wagons and only protect limited number of core protected areas, but we and should do better,” said Dr. Eric Dinerstein, Chief Scientist at WWF and co-author of the study. absolutely stop the bleeding, the poaching of tigers and their prey in core areas, but we need to go much further and secure larger tiger landscapes before is too late.” Wild tiger numbers have declined to as few as 3,200 today compared to 100,000 a century ago, due to of tigers and their prey, habitat destruction human-tiger conflict. “A Landscape-Based Conservation Strategy to Double the Wild Population” in the current issue Conservation Letters provides the first assessment of the political commitment made by all 13 tiger range countries at November’s historic tiger summit to double the tiger population across Asia by The study found that the priority tiger conservation landscapes with highest probability long-term tiger survival could support more than 10,500 tigers, about 3,400 breeding females. “Tiger conservation is the face of biodiversity conservation and competent sustainable land-use management at the landscape level,” said study co-author Dr. John of the Conservation Biology Institute. “By saving the tiger we save all the plants animals that live the tiger’s umbrella.” study also revealed major infrastructure projects such dams, roads and mines will threaten tiger landscapes in the next decade.
