c9e456181e7b4e03a7d16e4c6f663e8cdd4858f3: To use kickstart you must first create a kickstart file, and make it available to Red Hat Linux installation program. Normally this done by the kickstart file to the boot diskette, or making it available on the network. The network-based approach is most commonly used, as most kickstart installations to be performed on networked computers. This also makes it easier to install Red on computers, as the kickstart files can be on single server system, and read by the individual computers during the Let's take a more in-depth look at the locations where kickstart file may be placed. To perform a diskette-based kickstart the kickstart file must be named ks.cfg, and reside in diskette's top-level directory. that the Hat Linux diskettes are in MS-DOS format, making it easy to copy the kickstart file under Linux using the mcopy command (or, you insist, you can also use Windows). Although there's no technological for it, most diskette-based installations install Red Linux from CD-ROM. Network installations using kickstart are quite common, because system administrators can easily automate the many networked computers and painlessly. In general, the approach most commonly used is for the to have both a BOOTP/DHCP server and an NFS server on the local The server is used to the client system its networking information, while the NFS server serves actual files used the installation. Often these two servers run on the same physical machine, but there is requirement for this. To do a network-based kickstart installation, you must have a BOOTP/DHCP server on your and it must include configuration information the machine you are attempting to install. The BOOTP/DHCP server will used to give the client its networking information as well as the location of the kickstart file. If a kickstart file is specified by the BOOTP/DHCP server, the client system will attempt an NFS mount of the file's and will copy the specified file to the client, using it as the kickstart file. The settings required vary depending on the BOOTP/DHCP server you use. Here's an example for the DHCP server shipped with Red Hat Linux: filename "/usr/new-machine/kickstart/"; next-server blarg.redhat.com; Note that you should use filename the kickstart file's name (or directory in which the kicstart file resides), and next-server to set the NFS server the filename returned by the BOOTP/DHCP server ends with a slash (``/''), then it is interpreted as a path only. In this case, the client system that path using NFS, searches for a specially-named file. The filename the client searches for is: <ip-addr> section of the filename be replaced with the client's address in dotted decimal For example, the filename for a computer with an IP address of 10.10.0.1 would be 10.10.0.1-kickstart. Note that if you don't specify a server name, then the client system will attempt to use the that answered the BOOTP/DHCP request as its NFS server. If you don't specify a path or filename, the client system will to mount /kickstart from the server, and try to find the the same <ip-addr>-kickstart filename as described above.
5d4a17276fc393973a48a3fd33ab2dba0a46cab3: Water creatures stealing DNA Tiny freshwater organisms that have a sex-free lifestyle, may have survived so well because they steal genes from other creatures, US scientists report. Researchers from the Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts, have found genes from bacteria, fungi and even plants incorporated into the DNA of bdelloid rotifers - minuscule animals that appear to have given up sex 40 million years ago. Their report in this week's edition of Science. Sex is used by most life forms a way of coping with changing circumstances, by allowing organisms develop useful new genes and harmful, mutated ones. The resilience of bdelloid and their sex-free lifestyle has scientists. The team, headed by Professor Matthew Meselson, looked at the DNA of bdelloid rotifers see how they manage to survive and evolve. It appears they overcome this hurdle by stealing DNA from our organisms. "Our result shows that genes can enter the of bdelloids in a manner fundamentally different from that which, in other animals, results from the mating of males and females," says "We found many genes that appear to have originated in bacteria, fungi, and plants." The waterborne creatures, which range in size from 0.1 to 1 millimetres lay but all their offspring are female. believe that when bdelloids dry out, fracture their genetic material rupture cellular membranes. When they they rebuild their genomes and membranes, incorporating of genetic material from other bdelloids and unrelated species in their vicinity. "These fascinating animals not only relaxed the barriers to incorporation of material, but, more surprisingly, they managed to keep some of these alien genes functional," report co-author Dr Irina Arkhipova says. According to the researchers, the next step is to determine whether bdelloid genomes also contain homologous genes imported from other bdelloids. Meselson and his colleagues also hope to examine whether the animals actually use any of the hundreds of snippets of foreign DNA they appear to vacuum up. Understanding the animals acquire and make use of these new genes could have implications for medicine. Genetic mutations, which occur constantly in any living underlie cancer, heart and various other diseases.

ab93dc67efe69afa9a8e4ec7ea66aa6e03ff9700: Italian Food & Cuisine History the American misconception, there is no typical approach when it comes to Italian Instead, styles have developed over the centuries on the levels in a multitude customs and techniques. If there were to be a unifying theme in Italian cooking, it would have be the utilization of fresh, seasonal However, to the diversity of climate and geography in Italy, even the available ingredients themselves are different from area to area. A good example the regionalism of styles and ingredients can be found in the differences between northern and southern Italian cooking. Much of southern diet is influenced by its proximity to the Mediterranean Sea, resulting in reliance on fresh fish such as swordfish. In addition, its abundance seafood has caused the cooking style to be lighter and simpler, highlighting ingredients such as tomatoes and olive oil. This style has even been deemed by the Italian government as the “Mediterranean Cuisine”. The northern style however, the southern reliance on fish with beef, pork, and dried beans which are more in the region. In the north uses butter cream rather olive oil as it’s dominating cooking fat. The is a tradition that is heavier and heartier than the provinces. It is worth mentioning that many of the new trends in Italian cuisine seen in America are of this approach. Risotto, a savory rice dish which relies on the breakdown of produce characteristic creaminess, and polenta, a side dish made from corn meal, have long been mainstays of the northern Italian diet. Despite the popularity of these broader dishes to this country’s restaurant scene, most Americans still associate Italian with pasta and pizza. And while pasta does play an important role in cuisine, it is much more versatile than spaghetti and meatballs. Orzo, for example, is rice-shaped pasta that is seen often prepared as a side dish to beef or veal while gnocchi are potato dumplings often seen tossed in simple sauces highlight their delicateness. Even heartier pastas are often paired with more than just marinara sauce. Examples of this are the northern-used Bolognese sauce, a meaty blend of tomatoes and cream, and the dramatically different pesto, a light chopped basil, garlic, olive oil, and pine nuts. Finally, desserts play an important part of the Italian diet. Cannolis and tiramisu, both of which contain sweetened fillings, are the widely known in America though others have recently gained attention. For gelatos are similar to ice but differ in that they are served in a semi-frozen state which results in a creamier, smoother texture. For health-conscious, a granita might be preferred. Because of absence of milk or cream, the final texture coarser and more crystalline. On the other end of the dessert spectrum are those made wine or alcohol. Zabaglione is egg custard often times flavored with marsala champagne which often served with strawberries and zaletti, light cornmeal cookies. We hope this overview has helped you to better understand the diversity of Italian cuisine. course, the best learning is accomplished through experience so we encourage you to use our site and find Italian restaurant that has been waiting you. The resulting reorganization restructured the Army into three major commands: the Army Ground Forces (AGF), the Army Air Forces (AAF), a command initially called the Services of Supply (SOS)—the Army’s sustainment command. Everything that did not fit clearly into the AGF or the went to the SOS. General Brehon B. Somervell was command SOS Army Service Forces In March 1943, the War Department staff renamed the SOS the “Army Service Forces” (ASF) because they thought the word “supply” did not reflect the broad range of had been assigned to the command. At War Department level, ASF was a consolidation logistics, personnel, and administrative functions. ordinary circumstances, functions were the responsibility of the War Department G–4 and G–1, relied on the technical and operational support of the Finance, Judge Advocate General’s, and Adjutant General’s Departments; the Chaplain Corps; Inspector General; Provost Marshal General; and Chief, Special Services. Matters social etiquette—how the President should interact with the public, where he should be accessible and where insulated—prompted multiple memorandums on the what Alexander Hamilton called “a pretty high tone” that stopped short of secluding the President entirely. The solution was a weekly open called the levee, part imperial court ceremony with choreographed bows and part drop-in parlor social. The levee struck the proper middle between courtly formality and republican simplicity, though at expense of becoming a notoriously boring and wholly scripted occasion. The very awkwardness of the levee fitted Washington’s temperament nicely since he a preternatural ability to remain silent while everyone around him was squirming under pressure to fill that silence with conversation. (Adams later claimed “gift of silence” was Washington’s greatest political asset, which Adams deeply envied because lacked it The formal of the levee and Washington’s natural dignity (or was it aloofness?) combined to create a political atmosphere unimaginable in any modern-day national capital. In a year when the French broke in violent spasms destined to reshape the entire political landscape of Europe, the new Congress ratified a Bill of Rights that codified the sweeping guarantee of freedoms ever enacted, no one at the levees to comment on those events. 789299118ed744699766ce2667ac05a81ab0ac73: Smoke drum telegraphs, the marathon runner are all examples man’s effort to conquer the tyranny However, the first successful solution to the of rapidly transmitting language across space was the Frenchman Claude Chappe’s optical telegraph. Chappe's chain of stone towers, topped by 10-ft. and 14-ft. pivoting members, spaced as apart as the eye could see, was demonstrated to the public in March of 1791 on the Champs Elysees. Chappe created a language of 9,999 words, each represented by a different position of the swinging arms. When operated by well-trained optical the system was extraordinarily quick. Messages be transmitted up to 150 miles in two minutes. Eventually the French military saw value of Chappe’s lines of his towers were built out from Paris to Dunkirk and Strasbourg. Within a decade, a network of optical telegraph crisscrossed the nation. When seized power in 1799, he used the optical telegraph to dispatch the message, “Paris is quiet and the good citizens are content.” Renovated in 1998, the optical telegraph next to the Rohan Castle in Saverne as part of the line from 1798 until 1852. It one of several remaining relay points in the system that can still be visited today.

The centerpiece of autumn sky is starry square called the Great Square of Pegasus. In mid-October it lies almost overhead mid-northern latitudes around 10 pm. Pegasus was the winged horse of Greek mythology, and the Great Square represents the front of the body of Pegasus. stars mark the corners the Square, boxing in an area of sky so large that you need to hold both out at armís length to cover it. Sports fans in North America might think of it as a baseball diamond square. You should be able to find the Square without much difficulty, but your star chart can help if you need to orient yourself. (For help, see "Absolute Beginners Ė Start Observing." There is a link at the of this article.) Looking at the Square, a line from the right-hand side of the square down the southern horizon and youíll come to a bright star called Fomalhaut. Fomalhaut is the constellation Piscis Austrinus, the southern fish. In released photographs taken by the Hubble Telescope showing a in Fomalhaut. Returning to the Square, imagine a line upwards the side. This will lead you to the W-shaped constellation of Cassiopeia, one of the easiest star patterns to recognize. Continue the line northwards for the same distance see the north pole star, Polaris. Although astronomers of the Great Square of Pegasus, these days only three of its stars officially belong to that constellation. In ancient times, one star was with neighboring Andromeda, head. When, in 1930, astronomers came to define official boundaries the constellations, they ended the of sharing stars. Andromeda kept her head but Pegasus lost corner of its square. Andromeda represents the unfortunate daughter of Queen Cassiopeia. She was chained to a rock in sacrifice to a sea monster to atone for of her boastful youíll need a good imagination to see as more than a couple of crooked lines of stars leading away from upper left of the Great Square. There is, though, one great treasure to found in the constellation. Two lines extend from the Square. Look at the more prominent of the two lines. you count two stars along and then go two up, youíll come to it: the spiral 2.5 million light years away. On clear dark nights you can glimpse the Andromeda Galaxy with the unaided eye as a wisp of light. The Andromeda Galaxy is the most distant object can see without optical aid, itís more prominent through binoculars and small telescopes. Beyond the shackled of Andromeda lies her heroic rescuer, Perseus. This constellation is shaped rather like a distorted capital In the sky he is depicted holding the severed head of Medusa the Gorgon, by the star Algol. Click diagram of the Perseus. Perseus lies in a rich part of the Milky Way, so if you sweep over this area with binoculars, sparkling fields spring into view. Beyond Perseus the stars of winter lie in wait, but weíll leave these for another time and return to our starting the Square of Pegasus. Near it lie well-known, but relatively inconspicuous constellations, of the zodiac. They are Aquarius the water and Pisces the fishes. stars of Pisces are arranged in a large, faint V-shape below to the left of the Great Square. The most distinctive of is the Circlet, a ring of directly beneath the Square of Pegasus, the body one of the visualized here by ancient astronomers. Below and to the right of the Circlet of Pisces lies Aquarius. This constellationís most distinctive feature a group of four that the water carrierís jar. The common subjects tested for placement are English, mathematics and chemistry. Foreign language is also tests at some Do all colleges require them? Not all colleges require placement tests. Some colleges, typically smaller, for-profit colleges, will only offer one level of their courses. In those cases, there is no for placement testing. Some colleges that not give placement testing use other information for placement evaluation such admissions testing (SAT or ACT) or high school coursework. When do I take them? Many colleges give placement testing during orientation. Community colleges often offer a daily basis in order to more conveniently fit into the schedules of newly students. with your admission counselor to find out when your testing will be given or if you need to register for your testing. Some colleges will information about the placement testing on their websites. This information may include the of information to review. You can ask admissions counselor what you should review placement test. What is the format of test? The testing format varies colleges. Your admissions counselor should able give you information the test will be like. Will I need to bring anything the test? You should ask this question of your admissions counselor or the you speak with to register for the colleges do not require students to bring anything to their placement Some items you may want to bring your placement testing: - Photo - Sweater (in case the room is chilly) - Money for vending machines Do transfer have to take placement tests? most cases, students do have to take tests. However, it often depends on the courses the has completed. For example, transfer students who have taken a course at their previous college, may be required to take only the mathematics section of placement testing. If I took placement testing at another college, do I have to re-take it? is a your admissions counselor. Some colleges do students who can demonstrate a previous placement from another college forgo placement testing. Colleges that do not require admissions testing (SAT or ACT) may waive testing for individuals who achieved certain scores on their admissions tests. However, in most cases colleges require students to take their test.

At the U.S. Space and Rocket Center® and Space Camp, we are constantly looking for fun and innovative ways to teach our museum guests and trainees about space history and the science and math concepts that surround it. Naturally, we were excited to participate the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics series of instructional webinars in order to get some fresh ideas and content. The creativity started to flow as we reviewed the background material, but the amount and quality of the lesson plans and information presented to us by Mary Dussault and Erin Braswell was impressive. the end of first hour of the had solid ideas and lesson plans that could be implemented in every program from summer Day Camp for 5-year-olds to Advanced Space Academy® for high-school seniors. they meet both state and national curriculum guidelines! In this case, our subject was For our younger we adapted the activities that dealt with colors and filters into a hands-on for our astronomy briefing “Tenacious Telescopes.” We use PVC colored felt and theater lighting gel in the primary colors to teach the about how real telescopes like Hubble Telescope use filters to look for specific information, and how scientists can put these single-color images together to make a full-color picture. In addition to making it look like real telescope, mounting the color filter inside a PVC pipe the added bonus of keeping our filters fingerprint and wrinkle free. For our Advanced Academy (junior high to high school) trainees, we added image processing component into our astronomy curriculum which is made up of four components. At the beginning of the week, trainees participate in lecture called the Sky” where they learn the basics of astronomy and focus on finding naming the and deep space objects. Our second astronomy block is the “Micro Observatory Lab,” where our trainees use the Mobs software to compile full-color images of deep space objects. Our third astronomy block is a “Night Telescope” where the trainees real telescopes to find the same objects in the sky of which they compiled images the day before. And our final astronomy block, our Advanced Academy trainees learn the stories selected constellations in our inflatable Star Lab. We have been running the “Micro Observatory block since December, 2011, and have had more than 1,500 trainees from all the world participate. We have so many students participating that we aren’t able display their artwork at once, so we have set up two small rotating exhibits of 12 featured photos each here at the U.S. and Rocket Center, one located in the Main Museum and the other located in the Science Lab for our summer Space Academy for Educators® camp, we to add a third, larger display to our computer lab this summer. The first step in understanding is that most songs are played a single key and that the chords in the come from that key. The formula (i.e. order) you use for the chords is what make up the song. For example, blues often uses the 1, 4, and 5 chords. If you’re playing in E, the chords are E, A, B (or B7). The blues in the key of C, uses C, F, and G. Francis Bacon, who provided some of the ideas Johnson put to use, famously gave the advice: "Read contradict and confute, nor to believe and take for granted, nor to find talk and discourse, but to and consider." I add to and Johnson a third sage of reading, Emerson, fierce enemy of and of all historicisms, who remarked that the best books "impress us the conviction, that one nature wrote and the same reads." Let me fuse Bacon, and Emerson a formula of how to read: find what comes near to that can be put to the weighing and considering, and that addresses you though you share the one nature, of time's tyranny. Pragmatically that means, Shakespeare, and let find you. If King fully to find you, then weigh and consider the nature shares with you; to I do not intend as an idealism, but as a pragmatism. Putting tragedy use as a complaint against patriarchy is to forsake your own prime interests, particularly as a young woman, which sounds more ironical than it is. Shakespeare, more than Sophocles, inescapable authority upon intergenerational and more anyone else, upon the differences women and men. Be to a full reading King Lear, you will understand the origins of what you judge to be patriarchy. we read -- Johnson, and agree -- in order to strengthen the self, and to learn its authentic interests. We experience such augmentations as pleasure, which may be why aesthetic values have always been deprecated by social moralists, from Plato our current campus Puritans. I remain skeptical the traditional social hope that care for others may be stimulated by the growth of individual imagination, and I am wary of any whatsoever that connect the pleasures of solitary reading to the public good. The sorrow of professional reading is that you recapture the pleasure of reading you knew in when books were a Hazlittian gusto. The way we read now partly depends upon our distance, or outer, from the universities, where reading is scarcely taught as pleasure, in any of the deeper senses of the aesthetics of pleasure. Opening yourself to a direct confrontation with Shakespeare his strongest, as in King Lear, is never an pleasure, whether in youth or age, and yet not to read King Lear fully (which means without expectations) is to be cognitively as well as aesthetically defrauded. A childhood largely spent watching yields to an adolescence a computer, and the university receives a student unlikely to welcome the suggestion that we must endure our hence even as our going hither: ripeness is all. Reading apart, much of the self scatters it. All this is past lamenting, and will not be remedied by any vows or programs. What to be done can only be performed by some version of elitism, that is unacceptable, for both good and bad. There are still solitary readers, young and old, everywhere, even in the If there is a function of criticism at the time, it must to address to the solitary reader, who reads for herself, and not for the interests that supposedly transcend the self. d582df8fe474121878bc3b90e98988ef8312bca0: Emmanuel, count de las CasesArticle Free Pass Emmanuel, count de las Cases, in Emmanuel-augustin-dieudonné-joseph, Count De Las Cases (born June 21, 1766, Languedoc, France—died May 1842, Passy), French historian best known as the recorder of Napoleon’s on St. Helena, the publication of which greatly to the Napoleonic legend in Europe. An officer the royal navy, Las Cases in 1790 emigrated from France to England, where wrote and published his Atlas Historique . . that attracted Napoleon’s attention. Consequently, on his return to France with other Royalists rallying to Napoleon, Las Cases given a minor position on the council of state and created count in 1810. After defeat (1814), he returned to England joined Napoleon the Hundred Days (1815), following him into exile at St. Helena. For 18 months he recorded his conversations with Napoleon on his principles of warfare, his identification the French Revolution with the Empire, his political philosophy, and his sentiments on religion and philosophy. A letter of complaint about Napoleon’s treatment led Las Cases’ deportation and to the seizure of his manuscript by the British government. Forbidden to enter England, he traveled in Germany Belgium he was allowed to return to after the death of Napoleon in 1822. Recovering his manuscript, published his Mémorial Sainte-Hélène (1823), which at once became extremely popular. deputy for Saint-Denis (1831–34; 1835–39), he sat with the extreme left, opposing the rule of Louis-Philippe. Cases’ de Sainte-Hélène was the first defense after his defeat. prejudiced in Napoleon’s favour, the identification of the idea of the Revolution with Napoleon furthered a union of liberals with Bonapartists, thus contributing to the rise of III. 63b947313c8149119cf6b064f5a382e3a1b265af: Not one, two, but three female addax calves have been born at Brookfield Zoo within the last two months, and one more is expected by end of the summer. The most recent born this past Saturday, July 9. The other two were born on May 30 and 1. All are well and can be seen with their mothers—Martha, Sara, and exhibit in their outdoor habitat on the north of zoo. The three births are a welcomed addition to the zoo because the species is critically endangered in its Africa. Zoo has exhibited addax since 1935 and in was the first zoo in North America to addax birth. Since the of the first breeding pair, there have been 140 addax at Brookfield Zoo. “We are about the addax births at Brookfield Zoo and being able to share the significance and importance of these new additions with our guests,” said Amy Roberts, curator of mammals for the Chicago Zoological Society. “What is really exciting is that there is the possibility that one of calves or their descendants may one day be introduced the wild as of a collaborative program.” The of the three new moms with Winston, who is the sire of all calves, was based on recommendation by the Association of and Aquariums’ Species Survival Plan (SSP). The Chicago Zoological which manages the zoo, has been an participant in the Addax SSP since its inception in 1989. An SSP a cooperative population conservation program for the species in North American The program manages the breeding of addax in zoos to maintain a healthy, self-sustaining population that is both genetically diverse and demographically stable. Currently, there are 159 addax in 18 accredited North American Once widespread across North Africa, the addax has been largely driven to extinction in the wild by over-hunting since the mid-1800s as well as unrest. Additionally, although highly adapted to hyper-arid conditions, are nonetheless impacted by long periods severe drought. The current population is restricted a narrow band of desert between eastern Niger and Chad. Researchers estimate there to be less than 300 individuals remaining in the wild, with the last major population of around 200 the Tin Toumma desert of eastern Niger. However, there is hope for the species to an international effort involving zoos in North America and Europe, the Tunisian government, and the Convention on Migratory Species. Brookfield Zoo is one of more than 40 zoos worldwide that has provided support for the reintroduction of zoo-born addax into fenced reserves in Tunisia. Current efforts are focusing on securing the remaining wild populations in Niger and Chad, increasing scientific management of captive populations in Africa and elsewhere, and reintroducing individual to secure, and protected areas in former range states. Addax have some of the most impressive horns all antelope, which is one of the reasons they have been over-hunted. In older individuals, they can spiral three turns and extend three They are one of a group of species called “horse-like antelope,” which are unusual in the females have horns as as those of the males. The lives in one of the most inhospitable habitats in the world, and they are the most antelope. Their feet are extra-large spread out, perfect for staying on top of sand. Their legs shorter most antelope, giving them a low center and keeping them the sand shifts foot. They get nearly all the moisture they need from the sap of vegetation from dew, going almost their entire lives without drinking water at all. When vegetation is not they can live the water stored in their body fat. They are with no fixed territory, following the that produce the plants on which they depend. They have a relatively heavy body with sandy-white coat in the summer that turns grayish-brown in the winter. White markings can be found on their legs and belly, with a black tuft of their forehead, under the horns.

3cfabc94285643855841da66a105a447c13ac11b: The Immune System Because the human body provides an ideal environment for many microbes, they try to pass your skin barrier and enter. Your immune system is bodywide of cells, tissues, organs that has to defend you against such "foreign" invasions.The proper targets of your immune system are infectious organisms--bacteria such as these streptococci; fungi (this one happens to be Candida, the cause of yeast infections); parasites, including these worm-like microbes that cause malaria; viruses such as this SARS virus. Markers of Self At the heart of the immune response the ability to distinguish between "self" and "non-self." cell in your body carries the same set of distinctive surface proteins that distinguish "self." Normally your immune cells do not your own tissues, which all carry the same pattern of self-markers; rather, your immune coexists with your other body cells in a state known as This set of on human cells is called the major histocompatibility complex (MHC). There are two classes: MHC Class I proteins, which are on all cells, and MHC Class II proteins, are only on certain specialized cells. Markers of Non-Self non-self substance capable of triggering an immune response is known as an antigen. An antigen can be a whole non-self cell, a bacterium, a virus, an MHC marker protein or even a portion of a protein from a foreign organism. distinctive markers on antigens that trigger an immune response are called epitopes. When tissues or cells from another individual enter your body such antigenic non-self epitopes, your immune cells react. This why transplanted tissues may be rejected as foreign and antibodies will bind to Markers of Self: Major Histocompatibility Complex Your cells recognize major histocompatibility complex proteins(MHC) when they distinguish and non-self. An MHC protein serves as a recognizable scaffold that presents pieces (peptides) of a foreign protein (antigenic) to immune cells. An empty "foreign" MHC scaffold itself can as an antigen when donor organs or cells are introduced into a patient's body. These MHC self-marker scaffolds are also as a patient's "tissue type" or as human leukocyte (HLA) when a patient's white blood cells are being characterized. For example, when the immune system of a patient receiving a kidney transplant detects a non-self "tissue type," the body may its own immune cells to attack. Every cell in your body is covered with these MHC self-marker proteins, and--except for identical twins--individuals carry different sets. MHC proteins are as distinct as types and come in categories--MHC Class humans bear 6 markers out 200 possible variations; and MHC Class II: humans 8 out of about 230 possibilities. Organs of the Immune System The organs of your immune system are positioned throughout your body. They are called lymphoid organs because they are home to lymphocytes--the white blood cells that are key operatives of the immune system. these organs, the lymphocytes grow, develop, are deployed. Bone marrow, the soft tissue in the hollow center of is the ultimate source all blood cells, including the immune cells. The thymus is an organ that behind breastbone; lymphocytes known as T lymphocytes, or just T cells, mature there. The spleen is a flattened organ at the upper left the Like lymph nodes, the spleen contains where immune cells gather and confront In addition to these organs, clumps of lymphoid tissue are found in many parts of the body, especially in linings of the digestive tract and the airways and lungs--gateways to the body. These tissues include the tonsils, adenoids, and appendix. The organs of your immune system are connected with one another and with organs of the body by a network of lymphatic vessels. Lymphocytes can travel throughout body the blood vessels. The cells can travel through system lymphatic vessels that closely parallels the body's veins arteries. Cells and fluids are exchanged between blood and lymphatic vessels, enabling the lymphatic system to monitor the body for invading microbes. The lymphatic vessels carry lymph, a clear fluid that bathes the body's tissues. Small, bean-shaped lymph nodes sit along the lymphatic vessels, with clusters in the neck, armpits, abdomen, and groin. Each node contains specialized compartments where immune cells congregate and encounter antigens. be09758a32dc7d0978a3413cf96d84ede4231433: Locust Care Sheet Locust are the largest type of insect that you will use as livefood. Adults measure up to 8cm and are a yellow colour with darker brown/purple patches. They are popular for their large gut content which means they are highly nutritious feeders but are expensive compared to foptions. The Locust is a fascinating insect. They are quite pleasant to have around and will not try to bite like a cricket would. Locust are often portrayed as a swarm insect that crops and eats everything in their In they are down the pecking order than crickets so the two should never be mixed, unless the aim is to feed the crickets. However, they do eat a lot and grow fairly quickly. Only adult locust have wings are able to give them flight. locust have wings but only at the 5th and final moult a locust develops flying wings and are capable of flight over short distances. Locust amazing claws they can onto and climb just about anything including glass. They tend to hang upside down while shedding so their good grip comes is readily Housing and Heating Housing locust is just like housing crickets, you will want to put them biggest tub can find (of glass is fine), as long as it sufficiently deep to any would-be escapees. Ventilation is important to locust so make sure the lid is perforated with holes, you can do this a drill or soldering iron. As locust prefer to perch a substrate really is not necessary, so stack of egg crates does the trick and also provides hiding places. water, provide a dish of damp kitchen this prevents drowning and is easily changed when it gets dirty. When comes to cleaning time after a week or two, there are several options. You are best lifting the hides slowly transferring them to tub while around the the locust while cleaning the tub. Shake the locust off the egg crates throw them away, swap them with clean ones and you have a nice clean tub of locust. you can use all the locust throw the whole away before purchasing a fresh batch. As temperature, locusts like a temperature of 25-33Â°C (77-91.4Â°F) and a dry atmosphere which will prevent fungal infections. Feeding Locust Feeding is very similar to crickets. They need to be provided with a good supply of dry foods, "bug grub" is an insect feeder that a mixture of designed be fed to insects that they a good gut content and provide ample nutrients to your pets. Alternative foods can be used such as bran, weetabix, digestives and bread. such as grapes, apples vegetables such as potatoes, tomatoes and cabbage provide extra vitamins and If moist foods are available on a regular basis then a dish is not really needed. Breeding Locust Temperature and humidity are important in breeding. Eggs are laid in a 4 inch deep filled with silver or sharp sand so prepare a tub as such. The sand should be kept moist but too so it looks soggy. The female locust will position herself over the sand and push her down and deposit to 200 eggs. will emerge after 10 - 12 days. The hoppers go through 5 instar molting before becoming adult locust.

286c8d9288f407f5f3534eafd4681787729cc896: Fill out the form below to find out if have case. A new making physical and occupational therapy more convenient for adults with cerebral palsy. Using the Internet, the program connects adult cerebral palsy to “virtual trainers” who help them complete movement-based training from the comfort of their own homes. The Upper Limb Training and Assessment Program, known as ULTrA, is of joint research and movement aimed at helping adults who have upper limb and hand impairment. “Physical therapy are the most important treatments for cerebral palsy. The ULTrA program works with the idea of bringing therapy into the home to allow adults to do their therapy at time that’s convenient for them,” said Dr. Edward Hurvitz of University of Michigan. Patients participating in the program have their homes equipped with the computer-based training unit, a training CD, and a high-speed Internet connection. They then complete five 40-minute training a week over the course of an eight-week period. “The computer interface in the individual’s home includes computer-generated images of people and we also have people in our lab who are able to coach and provide encouragement to participants via web cameras. Being to the patients allows us to modify their program as needed, without them coming into the research lab or said Susan Brown, Ph.D. Brown, who directs the Motor Control Lab at the U-M School of Kinesiology, said that the technology has potential to up the for people who have mobility issues.” One cerebral palsy patient, 41-year-old Laura Grable, praised the project. “The ULTrA project is a step toward moving cerebral treatment the 21 st century. There’s the potential to figure out how to improve range of motion and quality of life people with CP,” she said.

db04a5a764e48de2e7cff7f5925fbc06b224abb8: A common virus that affects 50-70% of adults. If a woman acquires cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection during pregnancy, there is about a 15% chance that her infant have infection and serious complications. Women who have had CMV and who are considering their prematurely born infant should check first with child's doctor since there is risk of transmitting the virus to the infant through breast milk. Prematurely born infants may not be able to fight off the CMV infection as do infants born at term. CMV infection is a mild infection in adults. Infants born women who have had CMV long before they became pregnant are at low risk of having an infant with serious CMV infection.

69163ad0a2b19ebd4f9ccda4062bf337304a8f36: Interviewing Children About Evaluating the NICHD Interview Protocol This study, the NICHD in collaboration with Lancaster University in Lancaster, England, will evaluate the accuracy of information obtained from using AN OF NICHD's interview protocol. The NICHD protocol was developed to help forensic interviewers OBTAIN INFORMATION FROM children who may be victims of or witnesses to crime ABOUT THEIR EXPERIENCES. This study does not involve forensic interviews, DESIGNED TO OBTAIN INFORMATION FROM children ABOUT an event that takes place at their school. The study will examine how children a interaction with adult, how the of the event changes over time, and how the use of interview techniques can give a and more accurate accounts of past experiences. Children 5 and 6 years of age who attend local schools in the Lancaster, England, area may eligible for this study. Participants will be told that they are going to have pictures taken and will be escorted by a researcher to a room at the school with another researcher who is posing as a photographer. The "photographer" and the child will put on a such as a pirate's outfit, their street clothes, helping each other put on pieces of costume. The photographer will take pictures the child the costume. They will each take off the and the child will be told that he or she will receive the photographs at a later time. Another researcher posing as a photographer will into the the event, begin to argue with the first photographer about who had booked the equipment. They will resolve the and apologize to the for the interruption. ba1b22aca662e6e8004b5db12cb7473c8c3acaa0: An electron is a subatomic particles of spin 1/2. It couples with photons and, thus, is electrically charged. It is lepton with a rest mass of * 10 − 31kg and an electric charge of − 1.602 * 10 − 19 C, which is the smallest known charge for an isolated particle (confined quarks have fractional charge). The charge of the electron e is used as a unit of charge in much of physics. Electron pairs within an orbital system have opposite spins due to the Pauli exclusion principle; this characteristic pairing allows electrons to exist in quantum orbital, as the opposing magnetic dipole moments induced by each of the electrons ensures that they are attracted together. Current theories the electron as a point particle, as no evidence for internal structure has been observed. As a theoretical construct, electrons have been able to explain other observed phenomena, as the shell-like structure of an energy distribution around an atom, and energy beams (electron and positron beams). - ↑ Massimi, (2005). a168b589dcc3a00436e997de5b84b4dff8ca93fd: Use it or lose it? Researchers investigate dispensability of our DNA| October 2, 2008 Our genome contains many genes encoding proteins that are similar to those of other organisms, suggesting evolutionary relationships; however, protein-coding genes for only a small fraction genome, and there many other that are conserved across species. What these sequences doing, and do we really need at all? a study published online today in Genome Research (www.genome.org), have delved into this mystery and found that evolution has actively kept them in our genome. Before human genome was sequenced, estimated the contain upwards of 140,000 protein-coding genes, but surprisingly, sequencing revealed only about 20,000, accounting for less than 2% the entire genome. Previously, Dr. Bejerano of Stanford University found that lurking within other 98% of the genome are stretches of sequences, known as ultraconserved elements, which are identical humans and animals such as rodents and chickens, though hundreds of millions of years of independent evolution separates them. Other evidence has suggested that sequences can harbor critical functions, such as of the activity of genes. Yet research in this has laboratory results that are seemingly disagreement: some ultraconserved elements can be deleted the genome and produce no observable effect on mice. Bejerano cautions that experiments such as these not be to detect evolutionary forces at work. "With this in mind, we set out to examine genomic data, much as someone would examine archaeological data, in search of similar deletion events that have happened naturally, and more importantly, were retained in the wild." "An analogy I like to entertain that of tectonics: fraction of the phenomena may be enough be directly measured by our instruments, to appreciate its full magnitude we must dig into the geological record," said Bejerano. "This digging into record is what our current work was all about. Bejerano and graduate student Cory McLean studied the genomes of six mammals, investigating ultraconserved elements that are shared between primates and closely mammals, were present in the ancestor of modern rodents, but have lost in the rodent lineage more recently. The researchers found that the genomic evidence supports an important biological role for ultraconserved as well as thousands of other non-coding elements that are resistant to deletion. "The importance of elements is reinforced the observation that the elements rarely lost in any species," said McLean. "In fact, they are over 300-fold less to be lost than genomic loci which evolve neutrally in our genome." Bejerano explained that while of some elements may have a significant impact on the fitness of a species and the loss of other elements might be harder to detect the laboratory, all changes these are up by evolution swept out of the population. "Perhaps our most striking observation is one of sheer magnitude," Bejerano said. "Our work how essential these dozens of thousands of regions are to the natural evolution of species even as their actual functions remain, at large, a mystery." Scientists from Stanford University (Stanford, CA) contributed this study. This work was supported by a Stanford Bio-X Graduate Fellowship and Edward Mallinckrodt, Jr. Foundation. Gill Bejerano, Ph.D. (email@example.com; +1-650-723-7666) has to be contacted for more information. Interested reporters may obtain copies of the manuscript from Peggy Calicchia, Editorial Secretary, Research (firstname.lastname@example.org; +1-516-422-4012). About the article: The manuscript will be published ahead of print on October 2, Its full citation is as follows: McLean, C., and Bejerano, G. Dispensability of mammalian Genome Res. doi:10.1101/gr.080184.108. About Research: Genome Research (www.genome.org) is an international, continuously published, peer-reviewed journal published by Cold Spring Harbor Press. Launched in 1995, one of the five most highly cited primary research journals in genetics and genomics. About Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press is an internationally renowned publisher of journals, electronic media, located on Long New York. It a of Cold Harbor Laboratory, an innovator in life science research and education scientists, students, and the public. For more information, visit www.cshlpress.com. becc1c5dd1f9c90038535a8bf575597b9aee639c: Micro vs Macro Micro and macro are prefixes that are used before words to make them small or respectively. This is true with micro and macroeconomics, micro and macro evolution, microorganism, micro lens and macro lens, micro finance and macro and so on. The list words that makes use of these is long and exhaustive. Many people confuse between micro and macro despite knowing that these prefixes signify small and large respectively. article takes a closer look at the two to find out their differences. To understand the difference between micro and macro, let us take up the example and macro evolution. To signify that takes place within a single species, the word microevolution is used whereas evolution that transcends the boundaries of species and takes place on a very large scale is termed as macroevolution. Though the principles of evolution such as genetics, natural selection, and migration remain the same across microevolution as well as macro evolution, this distinction between microevolution and macroevolution is a great way to explain this natural phenomenon. Another field of study that makes use of micro and macro is economics. While the study of overall economy and how works is called macroeconomics, microeconomics focuses on the individual person, company, or industry. Thus, the study of employment, inflation etc. in an economy classified under macroeconomics. Microeconomics is the study of forces demand and supply inside a particular industry effecting the goods and it macroeconomics when economists choose to concentrate upon the state the economy in a nation whereas the study of single market or industry remains within the realms of microeconomics. There is also the study of finance where these two are used. Thus, we have microfinance where the focus is upon the monetary needs and requirements of a single individual where there is also macro financing by the banks or other financial institutions is of very large nature. Micro and macro are derived from Greek language where micro means small and macro refers to large. These prefixes are used in many fields of study such as finance, economics, evolution etc. where we have words like micro and macro finance, micro evolution and macro evolution etc. Studying something at small level is micro while studying it on a large scale is macro analysis. Financing the needs of an individual may be micro financing whereas the financial needs of builder requiring money for a very large infrastructural project be referred to as macro finance.

61d0357e9ab1c0763dd2614a1308ec01da4189a3: Can Affect Hair Growth? Tocotrienols—a natural compound related vitamin E—may increase hair growth by as much as 34% Hair loss low self-esteem a lack confidence in both men and women. Now a study Tropical Research holds promise hair-loss sufferers and reports that tocotrienols—a natural compound related to vitamin E—may increase hair growth by as much as 34%. Counting the hairs on head Vitamin E is up of four tocotrienols and tocopherols, respectively called alpha, beta, gamma, and delta. In this study, 38 (mostly men) with hair loss, were randomly assigned to receive 100 mg of mixed tocotrienols plus 46 IU of vitamin E (alpha-tocopherol) or placebo daily for eight months. The of scalp hairs in a specific area of each participant’s head was monitored at four and eight months. The tocotrienol experienced an average of 34% more scalp hairs compared with the placebo group who experienced a decrease. 59e99195374d5deed2d49add9082a38dda98095f: Contrary popular cranberries do not grow in water. They grow in beds called 'bogs' made of impermeable layers of sand, peat, gravel, decaying matter from the cranberry vines. The vines can grow and survive when conditions exist such as an acid peat soil, an adequate supply of fresh water for irrigation and periodic flooding, supply sand and a growing season that extends from April to November. There are two main of harvesting cranberries - dry and wet harvesting. EDEN Organic Dried Cranberries are a native American Vaccinium organically grown on family owned cranberry bogs in Québec, Canada. Ours are wet harvested, considered by some to be the best way to harvest First our grower floods bog with about 12 to 18 inches of water. Next, simple machine called a reel' stirs up the water and loosens the cranberries from their vines. The water reel is nicknamed the 'egg and resembles a paddle Cranberries small air bubbles in the center, and once loosened from vines they float to the surface of the flooded bog. Harvesters wade out into the bog when all the cranberries are on the surface. Using a specially designed gathering device they hand berries into a large circle forming a thick red carpet berries which are then loaded into trucks and taken to the processing station. Here the cranberries are cleaned, sorted, and quick When ready for drying, the cranberries thawed and infused immersing them apple juice concentrate that is circulated over them until they reach just the right sweetness or 'Brix'. The infused cranberries are then rinsed, low heat and coated very lightly with a mist of organic sunflower oil to prevent clumping. The low heat drying is warm air circulated until they are dry to become shelf requiring no refrigeration. commercial dried fruit, EDEN Organic Dried Cranberries contain no added refined sugar or high fructose corn syrup. We NO sulfites, preservatives, or additives any kind. Cranberries native to North and were first used centuries ago by native Americans. versatile fruit, they discovered that it could be used not only as a food source, but also a dye for rugs, blankets and clothing, and as a healing plant to treat arrow wounds. American had many names for the cranberry such as 'sasamanesh, ibimi, and atogua'. To the Delaware Indians it was a of peace. Many Americans believed that berries had a special power that could calm the nerves. It's current name comes early Dutch and German settlers who named fruit, 'crane berry', because its small, pink blossoms resembled the and bill of a Sandhill crane. Although folklore and anecdotal accounts of cranberries healthful properties (especially the benefits to urinary tract health) have been touted centuries, it is that scientific research began how healthful cranberries can be. Packed with nutrients like antioxidants and other natural compounds, cranberries are great choice for the health conscious. The USDA found that the high phenolic content in cranberries delivers a potent antioxidant punch, rating it one of the highest out of 20 common fruits rated. To determine the antioxidant activity of various foods, the USDA uses a system referred to as Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC). By testing the ability of foods and compounds to subdue oxygen free USDA was able to determine each antioxidant capability. After World War II Australia shared in an economic boom created by the rejuvenation of the world economy. Work was plentiful and to ease labour shortages introduced an immigration program, which added to the economic momentum. These were good times, coming after years of depression and war which had restricted consumer spending and household formation, but the building industry was unable to meet the demand for housing. For around 15 years after the war, shortages of labour and building materials meant that income earners had to downscale of housing space, style and amenity. Many built their own houses, or provided unskilled to cut construction costs and delays. houses were smaller and expensive than before the war. As Robin Boyd put it, 'the traditional plan and structure remained unaltered, but one by one the decorations and embellishments went'. This simple weatherboard house, built in outer suburban Melbourne in 1955, was typical. Modest and unadorned, enabled the owners to live and raise a family in a suburban setting, during a period of escalating building costs. In 1948 John 'Jack' a toolmaker from Coventry, migrated to Australia. in 1919, he was still single and by making new start in a new land he hoped to put sadness of the war in his mother and brother had been killed the Blitz, behind him. After stints as a mechanical fitter at Yallourn, as a gold miner in Kalgoorlie, Jack worked as a toolmaker around Melbourne. He was never out of work until the day he retired. But land was cheap, and only £300; similar lots in nearby Chelsea, served by made roads, around double the price. 0ef0411101ff81efee4a9077bb7871192dffe436: Air pollution is a broad term applied to all chemical and biological that modify the natural characteristics of the atmosphere. Some definitions also consider physical perturbations such as noise pollution, heat, radiation or light pollution as air pollution. Some definitions include the term harmful as a requisite to consider a change to the atmosphere as pollution. The sources of air pollution are divided in two groups: anthropogenic (caused by human and natural. Natural sources include: Anthropogenic are mostly related to burning different kinds of fuel. They include: - Volcanic activity Dust from natural sources, usually large areas of with little or no vegetation Gases, such as methane, by the digestion animals, cattle. - Smoke from wildfires. - Dust chemicals from farming, especially of erodible land, Dust Bowl - Industrial in general. Vehicles with internal-combustion engines. - Stoves incinerators, specially coal ones. - Paint fumes, or other toxical vapors. Contaminants of air can divided in particles gases. Particles are classified by their sizes. A usual division is in PM10 and PM10 are particles whose size is less 10 microns (0.01 mm); are dangerous to humans because they can be and reach the lungs. PM2.5 are particles whose size is less than 2.5 microns (0.0025 mm), they are even more dangerous because they can pass the alveoli and reach the blood. pollutant gases include: worst single incident of air pollution to occur in the United occurred in Donora, Pennsylvania in late October, 1948 - Davis, Devra, When Smoke Ran Like Water: Tales of Environmental Deception the Battle Against Pollution, Books, 2002, hardcover, 316 pages, ISBN 0-465-01521-2

b2b8d62b7131b254fac017814896717e515de5f0: What reaction can I expect my small children when tell them we’re separating and in months following? Posted January 10, 2012 While no child wants to hear that their parents are breaking up, children often have predictable responses you tell that you are separating that relate to their stage. what these might be will hopefully make you more prepared for the emotional, behavioral and physical changes that will Young children do not fully understand the concept of marriage and separation. will only understand that mommy daddy will no longer be living together. Be prepared for them to find it difficult to grasp what is happening. Try to make them otherwise they will be frustrated and confused. Children under the age of 5 years old will have various reactions depending on their personality. They will either cry, pretend you never mentioned the separation, they may change the subject because they want to stop their feelings or they go back to focus on what they were doing before you started talking to them they may show no emotion all at the time but then leave the room to process their they have been able to process some the information you tell them they will lots of feelings and fears about the future. The fear of abandonment is very common and is in variety ways. Children may cling, whine and have tantrums when left at childcare. They want the of being with their main carer and don’t want to be left. When you pick them up they may also be upset because you left them but also relieved pleased to see you. Children may get upset when moved between parents access visits and will feel unsettled if their main changes e.g. they may have a new person looking after them if mum to go to back to work. Being around unfamiliar people can make them tearful and anxious. Often they will struggle with a new routine and to be moved between both parents. Some children often regress in their behaviour. They may return the of blanket or a toy they had outgrown or they may have a lapse in toilet training. It is not unusual for children to disturbed sleep either. Bear with as it won’t be forever. These types of behaviour rarely last for more than a few weeks. Some children become irritable and engage more in physical activity and fighting. This is because of the hurt they feel and the anger towards the situation. Other children may become more fearful of and being hurt. Children five may become less imaginative and co-¬‐operative in their play. They may prefer to play by themselves rather than with friends and they may show a preference for adult company as being near adults makes them feel secure. They can show anger and apathy in their play in their interactions with and adults as they act out how they feel and the they are in e.g. when dad to the house to pick them up for the day. Many children grow up emotionally together and psychologically strong even though they have had the adverse childhood experience of their parents separating. Young children do necessarily their through into their adult life. If a young child’s life improves and changes, especially during the ages two and six, the negative effects of early childhood can be reversed. Young children are likely to do just as well in school as they did before the separation. The Coach
f23aebe1e03beb28e3b93e69f8e378642f82c6f1: Math is basis music, but for those of who aren’t virtuosic at either, the connection isn’t always easy to grasp. Which is what makes the videos of Vi Hart, a “mathemusician” with a dedicated YouTube following, so wonderful. Hart explains complex phenomena--from cardioids to Carl Gauss--using simple (and often very) funny means. Maria Popova pointed out yesterday, Hart’s latest is a doozy. In it, she uses a music and a Möbius strip explain space-time, how the two axes of musical notation and tempo) correspond to space and time. Using the tape notation as a model for space-time, she cuts and it show the finite ways you slice and the axes. Then, she shows us how you can loop the tape into a strip of twinkling notes: If you fold space-time into a Mobius strip, you get your melody, and then the inversion, the melody played upside down. And then right side up And so on. So rather than and cutting up space-time, just cut tape a little loop of space-time, to be played over, and over. It’s a pretty magical observation, and it even me--the prototypical math dunce--wish I’d tried Yet there’s still time: Hart works the Khan Academy, a that offers free educational videos about biology, and more. Check it out. [H/t Brain Pickings]

f1e555a8933780127dc4b29d2fdde3d8e3dfb5e9: Foreign Minister Bob Carr has welcomed a new to support the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT). Senator Carr said the framework involves scientific and technical cooperation between Australia and New Zealand to promote a effective ban on nuclear weapon tests. "International enhances the ability of scientific experts to advice to governments on whether a nuclear test has occurred," Carr said. "Cooperation between Australia and New Zealand can serve as a model for around the world and strengthen the CTBT. "Australia strongly advocates the earliest possible entry into force of the CTBT, so we are taking technical steps to prepare for that time." In the 16 years since CTBT opened for signature, the CTBT Organization largely completed work on a global network of over 300 facilities to monitor the for acoustic waves radionuclide particulates and gases from a possible nuclear explosion. Data collected by these facilities is made available to CTBT who have the final responsibility determining which events – about 30,000 per year - could be a explosion. Although the CTBT has not yet entered into force, its monitoring has already shown potential by readily detecting nuclear tests conducted by Korea in 2006 and 2009. Technical agencies in Australia monitoring for nuclear explosions are Geoscience Australia and the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency. The for bilateral is set in a memorandum of understanding between the Australian Safeguards and Non-Proliferation Office and the New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs. - Minister's office: (02) 6277 7500 - DFAT Media Liaison: (02) 1555
e13531081630427bebfb3ddf56317f5de40becc6: A stinky little problem: True its name, malodorous bug invades many homes DOVER — small insect notorious for big headaches around the Seacoast is once again giving homeowners to gripe. As Eaton explained, most of these stink bugs are known as the western conifer seed an insect which has expanded eastward since first being detected in Pennsylvania in 1992. The western conifer seed bug is a of the brown marmorated stink bug — another insect that has contributed to this sudden influx. brown marmorated stink bug, however, is currently present in eight municipalities statewide. Eaton credited the western conifer seed bug as primary source these recent headaches. “Sealing holes, cracks, and other is the best approach,” Eaton said. “There are a lot of places people might not think about that are actually great for these insects.” Although neither bites, is poisonous, spreads disease, these dime-sized bugs emit terrible odors when triggered and are classified as agricultural pests. Stink bugs can cause widespread to fruit and vegetable crops, including peaches, apples, green soybeans, cherries, raspberries, and pears, among others.
